Chapter 3 - OFFICIAL MAP[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note At the direction of the city, chapter 26 of the 2009 Compiled Ordinances has been renumbered as a new chapter 3. 
 
Sec. 3-1. - Intent. 
It is the intent of the common council to establish an official map for the purpose of conserving and promoting the public health, safety, convenience, economy, orderliness and general welfare of the community; to further the orderly layout in the use of land; to stabilize the location of real property boundary lines; to insure proper legal description and proper monumenting of land; to facilitate adequate provision for transportation, parks, playgrounds and storm water drainage; and to facilitate the further subdivision of larger tracts into smaller parcels of land.  
Sec. 3-2. - Authority. 
This chapter is enacted under the authority granted by § 62.23(6), Wis. Stats.  
Sec. 3-3. - Description of official map. 
(a)  Official map adopted. The official map of the former Town of Fitchburg established and maintained by the City of Madison in effect on the date of incorporation of the City of Fitchburg, specifically sections 1 through 12, together with all existing conditions for the remaining sections of the map and all amendments heretofore or hereafter duly adopted by the common council is hereby adopted as the City of Fitchburg's Official Map. The official map, together with all information shown thereon, shall be as much as part of this chapter as if fully set forth and described herein. 
(b)  Streets, highways, parkways, parks and playgrounds to be shown. The official map shall show the location and width of all platted and existing streets, highways, parkways, historic districts, parks and playgrounds heretofore laid out, adopted and established by law and shall also show the exterior lines, widening or extending of any existing, proposed or planned streets, highways, parkways, historic districts, railroad rights-of-way, public transit facilities, waterways or parks and playgrounds. The official map is deemed to be final and conclusive with respect to the location and width of streets, highways, historic districts, waterways and parkways and the location and extent of railroad rights-of-way, public transit facilities, parks and playgrounds.  
Sec. 3-4. - Extraterritorial areas may be mapped. 
As set forth in § 62.23(6)(d), Wis. Stats., the street, highway, waterway, railroad right-of-way, public transit facility or parkway systems shown on the official map may be shown as extending beyond the boundaries of the city in extraterritorial approval areas as provided by Wis. Stat. § 236.10(1)(b)2.  
Sec. 3-5. - Amendments. 
(a)  Common council to initiate. The common council whenever and as often as it deems necessary for the public interest, may amend the official map of the city so as to establish the exterior lines of planned new streets, highways, waterways, historic districts, parkways, railroad rights-of-way, public transit facilities, waterways, parks or playgrounds; or to widen, narrow, extend or close existing streets, highways parkways, railroad rights-of-way, public transit facilities, parks or playgrounds. When adopted amendments become a part of the official map and are conclusive with respect to location and width of the streets, highways, parkways and the location and extent of parks, railroad rights-of-way, public transit facilities and playgrounds shown thereon. 
(b)  Referral to plan commission. The common council shall refer any proposed amendment to the official map to the city plan commission for review and report thereon prior to adoption. The city plan commission must report its recommendation to the common council within 60 days. In the event the city plan commission does not make its report within 60 days of such reference, it forfeits the right to further suspend action. 
(c)  Public hearing on amendment. A public hearing before the common council of parties in interest and citizens shall be required before any amendments to the official map, as defined by Wis. Stat. § 62.23(6), are effective. Notice of the time, place and purpose of such hearing shall be given by publication as a Class 2 under Wis. Stat. ch. 985 in the official city newspaper. Notice of the time, place and purpose of such public hearing shall also be sent to the owners of record who are owners of property in whole or in part situated within 200 feet of the boundaries of the properties affected, and whose post office address is known or can be ascertained with reasonable diligence. If the properties affected are outside the city limits, notice shall also be sent to the clerk of the township involved. All said notices shall be set at least ten days prior to the date of such public hearing. 
(d)  Amendments by subdivision plat. The locating, widening or closing or the approval of the locating, widening or closing of streets, highways, waterways, parkways, railroad rights-of-way, public transit facilities, parks or playgrounds by the city under provision of law other than this section, shall be deemed to amend the official map and are subject to this section, except that changes and additions made by a subdivision plat, approved by the common council under Wis. Stat. ch. 236 do not require the public hearing specified in subsection (c) if the changes or additions do not affect any land outside the platted area.  
Sec. 3-6. - Effect of placement upon official map. 
(a)  Not construed as opening or dedication. The placing of any street, highway, historic district, parkway, railroad right-of-way, public transit facility, waterway, park or playground line or lines upon the official map does not constitute the opening or establishment of any street, highway, parkway, railroad right-of-way, public transit facility, waterway, park or playground or the taking or acceptance of any land for these purposes. 
(b)  No building permit issued without street access. No building permit shall be issued for erection of a building unless a street, highway or parkway giving access thereto has been duly placed on the official map. 
(c)  Restriction on building in streets, etc. No permit may be issued for any building in the bed of any street, highway, waterway, railroad right-of-way, public transit facility or parkway shown or laid out on the official map except as provided in this chapter. 
(d)  Building permit prerequisite to compensation. Any person desiring to construct a building within the limits of a street, highway, waterway, railroad right-of-way, public transit facility or parkway shown as extended beyond the boundaries of the city within its extraterritorial plat approval jurisdiction or within the limits of the city may apply to the building inspector and zoning administrator of the city for a building permit. Unless an application is made and the building permit granted or not denied within 30 days, the person is not entitled to compensation for damage to the building in the course of construction of the street, highway, waterway, railroad right-of-way, public transit facility or parkway shown on the official map. Applicant for such a building permit shall submit with the application, an accurate plot plan certified by a qualified surveyor showing the location of the proposed building with reference to any street, highway, waterway, railroad right-of-way, public transit facility, historic district, parkway or park or playground shown on the official map. 
(e)  Buildings to access mapped streets, etc. No permit for the erection of any building may be issued unless the street, highway or parkway giving access to such proposed building has been duly placed on the official map. For purposes of this section a street, highway, or parkway shall be considered duly placed on the official map at the time that the governing body accepts such street, highway or parkway.  
Sec. 3-7. - Municipal improvements. 
No public sewer or other municipal street utility or improvement shall be constructed in any street, highway or parkway until such street, highway or parkway is duly placed on the official map. For purposes of this section, a street, highway or parkway shall be considered duly placed on the official map at the time that the governing body accepts such street, highway or parkway.  
Sec. 3-8. - Appeals. 
(a)  Zoning board of appeals authority. The zoning board of appeals, created under chapter 22 shall have the following powers: 
(1)  Upon finding that the land within a mapped street, highway, waterway, railroad right-of-way, public transit facility or parkway is not yielding a fair return, the zoning board of appeals may review any administrative decision of the city building inspector or zoning administrator denying a permit for the erection of a building or addition under this chapter and may, by the vote of a majority of its members, grant, conditionally grant or refuse a permit for the building or addition which will as little as practicable increase the cost of opening the street, highway, waterway, railroad right-of-way, public transit facility or parkway or tend to cause a change of the official map. 
(2)  The board shall also have authority to hear appeals under 3-6(e) from denial of building/zoning permits for buildings not having access to a mapped street, highway or parkway and to grant permits for such construction upon finding that enforcement of 3-6(e) would cause practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship and that the circumstances of the case do not require the structure to be so related. 
(b)  Appeal procedure. Before taking any action authorized in this section, the board of appeals shall hold a hearing in accordance with the procedures set forth in Wis. Stat. § 62.23(6)(g). The board may impose reasonable requirements to promote the health, safety, convenience or general welfare as a condition of granting a permit and may refuse a permit where the applicant will not be substantially affected and will not incur practical difficulty or unnecessary hardship by not constructing the addition or building outside the mapped street, highway, waterway, railroad right-of-way, public transit facility or parkway.  
Sec. 3-9. - Certified copy of official map to be maintained. 
A certified copy of the official map shall be kept in the offices of the assessor, building inspector and zoning administrator and shall be available for inspection by an interested person during regular office hours. The certified copy shall bear on its face a certification that it is a true copy of the official map described in the ordinance and shall show the date of adoption of this chapter and shall be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city clerk. Thereafter every amendment of a proposed street, proposed highway, proposed waterway, proposed historic district, proposed parkway, proposed railroad right-of-way, proposed public transit facility, proposed park or proposed playground on the official map shall be indicated by the appropriate convention on the aforesaid certified copy of the official map and a certificate placed thereon or attached thereto bearing the number or date of adoption of the amendment. The certificate shall be signed by the mayor and countersigned by the city clerk. For purposes of this section, plats, certified survey maps and property transactions complying with applicable laws or ordinances do not require certification when being placed on the official map.  
Sec. 3-10. - Filing with register of deeds. 
Upon adoption of the official map, the city clerk shall immediately file with the Dane County register of deeds a certificate showing that the city has established an official map.  
Sec. 3-11. - Enforcement. 
It shall be the duty of the city departments of assessing, building inspection and zoning to enforce the provisions of this chapter.  
Sec. 3-12. - Penalties. 
See forfeiture/bond/deposit schedule for penalties for any person, firm or corporation who fails to comply with the provisions of this chapter.  
Chapter 4 - MAYOR AND COMMON COUNCIL[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Cities generally, Wis. Stats. § 62.01 et seq.; municipal budget systems, Wis. Stats. § 65.01 et seq.; general municipality law, Wis. Stats. § 62.11; municipal borrowing and municipal bonds, Wis. Stats. § 67.01 et seq.; municipal disposal of abandoned property, Wis. Stats. § 66.0139; local government purchasing, Wis. Stats. § 66.0131; municipal finance, Wis. Stats. § 62.12; manner of exercise of home rule, Wis. Stats. § 66.0101; municipal police and fire departments, Wis. Stats. § 62.13; municipal administrative procedures, Wis. Stats. § 68.001 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 4-1. - Form of government. 
The city is a state political corporation, has the powers and privileges afforded cities under the constitution and laws of the state and of the United States of America. Its corporate authority is vested in a mayor and common council comprised of the mayor and eight alderpersons, two from each of four aldermanic districts. Commencing with the spring election in April of 2020, the mayor is to be elected for a three-year term, and the alderpersons are to be elected for two-year terms on a staggered basis with alderpersons for district 1 seat 2, district 2 seat 4, district 3 seat 6, and district 4 seat 8 elected in even years and alderpersons for district 1 seat 1 district 2 seat 3, district 3 seat 5, and district 4 seat 7 elected in odd years. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.01; Ch. Ord. No. 4, § 1, 1-9-2018) 
State Law reference Incorporation of cities, Wis. Stats. § 66.0201 et seq.; classes of cities, Wis. Stats. § 62.05; common council, Wis. Stats. § 62.11; powers of constitutionally incorporated city, Wis. Stats. § 66.0213.  
Sec. 4-2. - Official newspaper. 
(a)  Eligibility. To be eligible to submit a proposal for contracting with the city for publication of the city's legal notices or common council proceedings under the terms of this section a newspaper must: 
(1)  Be published at a minimum once a week; 
(2)  Meet the eligibility requirements set forth in Wis. Stats. § 985.03(1); 
(3)  Be a newspaper published in the city, if any, otherwise be published in the county and have general circulation in the city. 
(b)  Certification of qualification. A newspaper may not be designated as the official city newspaper for publication of city legal notices unless and until it files proof that a certificate stating that it qualifies under Wis. Stats. § 985.03 and stating its place of publication has been filed with the county clerk. 
(c)  Designation. The common council, at its last regular meeting in April or as soon as possible thereafter, shall designate one or more newspapers eligible under Wis. Stats. § 985.03 and published in the city, if any, otherwise published in the county and having a general circulation in the city, for publication of the common council proceedings and as the official city newspaper for the publication of the city's legal notices for the ensuing year. 
(d)  Absence of official newspaper. If for any reason the city is at any time without an official newspaper, legal notices and other matters required to be published not otherwise provided for in accordance with this section shall be published in a newspaper designated by the common council, at not more than the legal rate for like work in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 985.03. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.80) 
State Law reference Official municipal newspapers, Wis. Stats. § 985.05.  
Secs. 4-34-22. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - COMMON COUNCIL[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference Common council, Wis. Stats. § 62.11. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 4-23. - Composition. 
(a)  Two classes of alders. The common council shall consist of the mayor and eight alderpersons elected for seats numbered as follows: district 1, seats 1 and 2; district 2, seats 3 and 4; district 3, seats 5 and 6; and district 4, seats 7 and 8. Alderpersons shall be divided into two classes, one class of alderpersons to be elected in odd years and one class to be elected in even years as follows: 
Alderpersons for district 1 seat 2, district 2 seat 4, district 3 seat 6, and district 4 seat 8 to be elected in even years. 
Alderpersons for district 1 seat 1 district 2 seat 3, district 3 seat 5, and district 4 seat 7 to be elected in odd years. 
For purposes of nominations, primaries, ballots, election procedures and filling of vacancies, each numbered seat shall be considered a separate office. The mayor and all alderpersons shall be elected in the spring election held on the first Tuesday in April. 
(b)  Transition to staggered terms. During the spring election in April of 2019, the alderpersons of the city shall be elected as follows: 
(1)  Alderpersons for district 1 seat 2, district 2 seat 4, district 3 seat 6, and district 4 seat 8 shall be elected for a one-year term. 
(2)  Alderpersons for district 1 seat 1, district 2 seat 3, district 3 seat 5, and district 4 seat 7 shall be elected for a two-year term. 
Commencing with the spring election in April of 2020, the alderpersons are to be elected for two-year terms on a staggered basis as described in subsection (a) above. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(1); Ch. Ord. No. 4, § 2, 1-9-2018) 
State Law reference Vacancies in city office, Wis. Stats. § 17.23; authority for city to provide for election of one alderman from each district, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(b); manner of choosing mayor and aldermen, Wis. Stats. § 62.09; council composition under city manager plan of government, Wis. Stats. § 64.07.  
Sec. 4-24. - Rules. 
(a)  The common council shall preserve order at its meetings, compel attendance of members, punish nonattendance and shall be judge of the election and qualification of its members. 
(b)  Meetings of the common council shall be conducted in accordance with Robert's Rules of Orders, Newly Revised, 10th Edition, Perseus Publishing, 2000, (Robert's Rules of Order), as amended, except to the extent that it contradicts any provision herein. Additionally, debate rules shall be modified so that, during common council debates on motions, alderpersons shall be able to speak to an issue each time they are recognized by the chairperson, but shall be limited to five minutes each time they are recognized, except for the annual budget approval meeting, which shall be governed by rules set forth in this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(2)) 
State Law reference Common council procedure, Wis. Stats. § 62.11(3).  
Sec. 4-25. - Compensation. 
(a)  The salaries of all elected and appointed officials, including members of boards and commissions, shall be as determined by the common council from time to time; provided, however, that neither the mayor nor any alderperson shall during the term of such office be paid a salary in excess of that provided at the time the person took office since the person's most recent election or appointment. 
(b)  The salaries of the mayor, the municipal judge, and the alderpersons shall only be changed upon the favorable vote of three-fourths of all the members of the common council. Whenever such salaries are to be changed or established the common council shall, not later than the first regular meeting in February, fix the amount of salary of any such officer entitled to a salary that may be elected or appointed for a definite term during the ensuing year. 
(c)  Common council members serving on any board, commission, or committee shall not be entitled to receive any remuneration or per diem if such member receives any compensation for serving as a common council member. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(3)) 
State Law reference Compensation of mayor and aldermen, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(6); compensation of councilmembers, Wis. Stats. § 64.08.  
Sec. 4-26. - Quorum. 
Two-thirds of the members shall be a quorum but fewer may compel the attendance of absent members and adjourn. The mayor shall not be counted in determining whether a quorum is present at a meeting, but may vote in case of a tie, as provided in this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(4)) 
State Law reference Common council quorum, Wis. Stats. § 62.11(1).  
Sec. 4-27. - Confirmations. 
The favorable vote of a majority of all members of the common council shall be required to confirm any nomination that requires confirmation by the common council. In case of a tie, the mayor shall have a casting vote as provided in this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(5))  
Sec. 4-28. - Member voting. 
The ayes and noes may be required by any member. The vote shall be by ayes and noes on confirmation and on the adoption of any measure assessing or levying taxes, appropriating or disbursing money, or creating any liability or charge against the city or any fund thereof. All aye and no votes shall be recorded by the clerk. A measure shall carry upon obtaining the favorable vote of the requisite number of common council members. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(6)(a)) 
State Law reference Common council voting, Wis. Stats. § 62.11(1).  
Sec. 4-29. - Mayor's vote. 
The mayor may vote in case of a tie as set forth herein. When the mayor does vote in case of a tie, the mayor's vote shall be counted in determining whether a sufficient number of the common council have voted favorably or unfavorably on any measure. The mayor's vote shall be limited only to breaking a tie vote. The mayor shall not be permitted to vote to create or break a supermajority in cases where a supermajority is required. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(6)(b)) 
State Law reference Voting by mayor, Wis. Stats. § 62.11(1).  
Sec. 4-30. - Chairperson. 
The chairperson of all common council meetings shall be the mayor. In the event that the mayor is unavailable, the chairperson shall be determined in the order as follows: council president; chairperson of the finance committee; chairperson of the public safety and human services committee; chairperson of the personnel committee. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(8))  
Sec. 4-31. - Election of council president. 
(a)  The common council shall appoint a council president at the organizational meeting. The mayor shall accept nominations from the floor. Once nominations are complete, each nominee shall be afforded not more than five minutes to present reasons he/she should be appointed. A vote shall be taken by secret ballot. 
(b)  If there are more than two nominations, and no one receives enough votes to constitute a majority of the entire council, the top two nominations shall be voted upon. If more than two nominations tie for the largest number of votes, the common council shall vote again. If no one receives a majority and there are still more than two who tie for the largest number of votes, those names shall be written by the clerk on individual pieces of paper, and the mayor shall draw two names to be voted upon. 
(c)  In the event that there is a tie between the two nominees or no one receives enough votes to constitute a majority of the entire common council after five successive votes, the mayor shall select the council president by choosing between the two final nominees. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(9)(A)) 
State Law reference Appointment of council president, Wis. Stats. § 64.07(2).  
Sec. 4-32. - Duties of president. 
The council president shall nominate common council members to the standing committees (finance, personnel, and public safety and human services) who shall be confirmed by a majority of the common council members present and voting, and shall preside at committee of the whole meetings. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(9)(B)) 
State Law reference President as presiding officer who may vote but has no veto power, Wis. Stats. § 64.07(2).  
Sec. 4-33. - Powers of the common council. 
(a)  General powers. The common council shall have the management and control of city property, finances, highways, streets, navigable waters, and the public service, and shall have the power to act for the government and good order of the city, for its commercial benefit and for the health, safety, welfare and convenience of the public. The common council may carry out its powers by license, regulation, suppression, borrowing of money, tax levy, appropriation, forfeiture, and other necessary or convenient means. The powers herein referred to shall be in addition to any other statutory and constitutional powers the common council may have and shall be limited only by express language. 
(b)  Powers regarding property. The common council may acquire property, real or personal, within or without the city, for parks, libraries, historic places, recreation, beautification, streets, waterworks, sewage or waste disposal, harbors, improvements of watercourses, public grounds, vehicle parking areas, and for any other public purpose; may acquire real property within or contiguous to the city, by means other than condemnation, for industrial sites; may improve and beautify the same; may construct, own, lease and maintain buildings on such property for instruction, recreation, amusement and other public purposes; and may sell and convey such property. 
(c)  Powers to finance city government. The common council may levy and provide for the collection of taxes and special assessments; may refund any tax or special assessment paid, or any part thereof, when satisfied that the same was unjust or illegal; and generally manage city finances in accordance with this chapter. 
(d)  Emergency powers. All powers enumerated in Wis. Stats. § 323.14(2) shall be reserved and exercised by the common council, or the mayor, as provided in said statute. The mayor may designate temporary and permanent emergency routes, and may designate or suspend traffic control restrictions along such routes. 
(e)  Construction of powers. All powers given herein shall be liberally construed in favor of the rights, powers, and privileges of the city to promote the general welfare, peace, good order and prosperity of the city inhabitants thereof. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.03(1)(5)) 
State Law reference Powers of common council, Wis. Stats. § 62.11(5).  
Sec. 4-34. - Style of ordinances. 
The style of all ordinances shall be: "The common council of the City of Fitchburg do ordain as follows:." 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.02(7)) 
State Law reference Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 62.11(3)(f).  
Sec. 4-35. - Ordinance and resolution review. 
(a)  No ordinance or resolution may be acted upon by the common council until it has been reviewed by all the committees, commissions, and boards to which it is referred and returned to the common council with a recommendation for adoption, disapproval, amendment, or with no recommendation. 
(b)  If a committee fails to return an ordinance or resolution to the common council within 30 days of the date the ordinance or resolution was referred to the committee, the ordinance or resolution may be deemed to have been returned without recommendation and may be acted upon by the common council and shall be placed on the agenda by the request of two or more alderpersons or the mayor as provided in this article. 
(c)  No ordinance, resolution or other matter referred to a committee, commission, or board for action shall be reported out until it has first been considered at a properly noticed meeting of each body to which it was referred. 
(d)  The recommendation to approve, to approve with amendments or to disapprove any measure shall be determined upon motion by a majority vote. 
(e)  All action taken by committees, commissions, and boards shall be recorded in the minutes of the meeting. 
(f)  The recommendation of the committee shall be reported to the common council when the item is scheduled for voting on the common council agenda. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.03(6))  
Sec. 4-36. - Items referred by mayor to common council. 
The mayor may, after informing the council president, refer items of an immediate nature, to the common council that are not to be reviewed by any other body. These items shall be properly noticed and placed on the common council agenda, in accordance with the provisions of this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.03(7))  
Secs. 4-374-60. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - MEETINGS 
 
Sec. 4-61. - Regular meetings. 
(a)  Regular meetings of the common council shall be held on the second and fourth Tuesday evening of each calendar month at 7:30 p.m. Regular meetings shall adjourn no later than 11:00 p.m. unless extended by a majority vote of the common council members present and voting. 
(b)  If the date of any regular meeting falls on a legal holiday, such meeting will be canceled or rescheduled to another date or time by order of the common council. Following a regular city election, the new common council shall hold its first meeting on the third Tuesday of April. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.04(1)) 
State Law reference Council meetings to be held not less than once monthly on first Tuesday or as otherwise fixed by council, Wis. Stats. § 62.11(2).  
Sec. 4-62. - Orientation meeting. 
Every year, immediately after the adjournment of the first monthly meeting in April (held on the second Tuesday of the month and which shall be held by the outgoing common council members), there shall be held a common council orientation meeting for the new common council members who will assume their positions the third Tuesday in April. The orientation meeting shall include, but not be limited to a discussion of Robert's Rules of Order, open meetings law, open records law, ethics code, and other topics of interest. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.04(1)(A); Ch. Ord. No. 4, § 3, 1-9-2018)  
Sec. 4-63. - Organizational meeting. 
(a)  The organizational meeting is to be held on the third Tuesday in April every year. At this meeting the council president will be elected. The council president may present nominations for standing committees for immediate action by the common council. A majority of those present and voting shall be required to confirm nominations. 
(b)  The mayor may also present nominations for other committees and commissions for immediate action by the common council as provided in this article. Referrals to committees and commissions may be made at the organizational meeting, as well as approval of bills, and any item deemed necessary for immediate action. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.04(1)(B); Ch. Ord. No. 4, § 4, 1-9-2018) 
State Law reference New council to meet on third Tuesday in April after regular city election, Wis. Stats. § 62.11(2).  
Sec. 4-64. - Special meeting for approval of nominations. 
Provided the council president or mayor did not make all nominations at the organizational meeting, or, if the common council did not act or did not approve any or all of the nominations, a special meeting of the common council shall be held at 6:00 p.m. on the fourth Tuesday in April for the sole purpose of approving nominations to committees, commissions, and boards. The nominations not yet approved shall be provided to the clerk by 8:00 a.m. on the Friday before the fourth Tuesday in April for distribution to the common council. The common council shall then take action on the nominations at the special meeting on the fourth Tuesday in April. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.04(1)(C))  
Sec. 4-65. - Other special meetings. 
(a)  Who may call. The mayor or any three alderpersons may call a special meeting of the common council by filing a signed written notice thereof with the clerk at least 24 hours before the meeting is to be called stating the purpose, time and place of the meeting. 
(b)  Notice. Immediately upon the filing of a notice of a special meeting, the clerk shall notify the members of the council in a manner likely to give each member notice of the meeting and provide the notice at least six hours before the meeting. 
(c)  Held without common council notice. A special meeting can be held without notice being given when all of the members of the common council are present, or consent in writing. If all of the members consent in writing each member shall file a written consent with the clerk prior to the beginning of the meeting. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.04(2); Ch. Ord. No. 2018-O-09, § 1, 2-27-2018) 
State Law reference Call by mayor and notice of special meetings, Wis. Stats. § 62.11(2).  
Sec. 4-66. - Compliance with open meeting law. 
Neither any regular nor special meeting of the common council shall be held unless and until the public notice requirements of the state open meeting law have been complied with. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.04(3)) 
State Law reference Open meeting of public bodies, Wis. Stats. § 19.81 et seq.  
Sec. 4-67. - Review of agendas. 
(a)  Common council meeting. The common council meeting agenda shall be developed and reviewed by the mayor and the city administrator before the agendas are distributed. 
(b)  Items initiated by common council members. Any two common council members may agree to have an item placed on the common council agenda. These agenda items may be items for referral to other committees, items for immediate action under unfinished business or new business, or may be items for discussion only. Items placed on the agenda this way must be received in the clerk's office, with all background materials, no later than 24 hours prior to the distribution deadline, as provided in this article. Items not in format ready for immediate distribution must be submitted to the clerk's office at least 48 hours prior to the distribution deadline. 
(c)  Item format. The clerk shall distribute to all common council members, upon their induction into office, the format to be used for agenda items. All items submitted by common council members shall be presented to the clerk with all required information. 
(d)  Committee of the whole agenda. The committee of the whole agenda shall be developed and may be reviewed by the mayor and the council president before the agendas are distributed. 
(e)  Standing committee. Agendas for the standing committees (finance, public safety and human services, and personnel) shall be developed by appropriate staff and may be reviewed by the chairperson and the staff representative before the agendas are distributed. 
(f)  Board, committee, and commission. Agendas for all other boards, committees, and commissions shall be developed by staff and may be reviewed by the chairperson and the staff representatives before the agendas are distributed. 
(g)  Distribution. Agendas for meetings listed in this section shall be distributed to members of boards, committees, and commissions by noon of the Friday before the scheduled meeting. Changes to agendas must be submitted to the appropriate staff contact at least four hours before distribution. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.04(4))  
Sec. 4-68. - Meeting start times. 
No meeting of any committee, commission, or board may commence to take any official action unless a quorum is present within 30 minutes of the designated time for the meeting. In the event that a meeting is posted to occur after the conclusion of another meeting or event, the meeting may still commence after the 30-minute period provided the posting also states, "or as soon as possible thereafter" or "as soon as possible after the conclusion of (specified) meeting" or similar language. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.04(5))  
Sec. 4-69. - Publication of proceedings. 
Proceedings of the common council shall be published in the official city newspaper as a Class 1 notice, under Wis. Stats. § 985.07. For the purpose of publication, the term "proceedings" means the substance of every official action taken by the common council at any meeting, regular or special. All ordinances shall be published as a Class 1 notice within 15 days of passage and shall take effect on the day after publication or at a later date if expressly prescribed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.05) 
State Law reference Publication of council proceedings, Wis. Stats. § 62.11(4).  
Secs. 4-704-96. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - STANDING COMMITTEES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 4-97. - Designated. 
There shall be standing committees of the common council as established by the council from time to time, including the committee of the whole, the finance committee, the public safety and human services committee, and the personnel committee. Nominations to the standing committees shall be as set forth in this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.06(1))  
Sec. 4-98. - Composition. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this article, each standing committee shall consist of at least three alderpersons one of whom shall act as chairperson. The council president shall designate the chairperson at the time of nominations, or the first person named for each committee shall be the chairperson according to Robert's Rules of Order. The second person named shall be vice-chairperson. 
(b)  The council president shall act as presiding officer at meetings of the committee of the whole. 
(c)  Each common council member may serve on two standing committees but may only act as the chairperson of one. 
(d)  The council president may alter membership on the committees at the time of the election or appointment of any new common council members. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.06(2))  
Sec. 4-99. - Additional duties of chairpersons. 
The chairperson of the finance committee or the chairperson's designee and the chairperson of the personnel committee or the chairperson's designee shall serve on the bargaining team for all labor negotiations. A designee selected by either chairperson shall be selected from among the membership of their committee. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.06(3))  
Secs. 4-1004-126. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FUNCTIONS 
 
Sec. 4-127. - Finance committee. 
The finance committee shall: 
(1)  Oversee appropriations for and expenditures from the city budget and fund accounts. 
(2)  Oversee the actions and affairs of the city treasurer, the assessor, the board of review, the TIF district advisory committee, and the community development authority. 
(3)  Review all bills and claims submitted to the city and upon completing such review, recommend payment, disallowance or tabling of any such bills or claims to the common council. Except for the routine payment of recurring expenses, such as wages, utilities, insurance and retirement fund contributions, no expenditure of city funds in excess of $10,000.00 shall be made unless it has been first approved by the committee. 
(4)  Review the annual budget, and hold a meeting at which the mayor, the city administrator and all department heads appear to explain and respond to questions concerning their respective budget requests. 
(5)  Review and make recommendations to the common council concerning the borrowing of funds in any manner for any municipal purpose, the issuance of revenue bonds of any sort for any municipal purpose, the purchase or lease of real property, personal property or air space for public use, the sale of city property, insurance coverage and policies, labor contracts, the levy or imposition of any tax or forfeiture, the levy of and manner of levying any special assessment by the city, the need for a treasurer's bond under Wis. Stats. § 70.67 and the authorization of installment payments for any tax or special assessment under Wis. Stats. § 70.12. In addition to any public hearings required by law, the committee may conduct such public hearings as it deems appropriate with respect to any such review performed by it. 
(6)  Oversee the disposition of any personal property which has been abandoned or remained unclaimed for a period of 30 days after the taking of possession thereof by any city officer, in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 66.0139. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.07(1))  
Sec. 4-128. - Personnel committee. 
The personnel committee shall: 
(1)  Oversee all boards, commissions, officers, officials and employees in any matter concerning labor contracts, salaries, benefits, compliance with affirmative action, equal employment opportunity, or other employment-related programs. 
(2)  Approve all application forms, hiring guidelines, employee training programs, employee guidelines and handbooks, disciplinary procedures and discharge and termination procedures. 
(3)  Oversee all personnel matters. 
(4)  Consider and make recommendations to the common council the reassignment of duties of any office which is eliminated, recreation of any office previously eliminated, or the elimination of any office which may be eliminated under state law and the method by which city officers, other than the mayor, the municipal judge, the alderpersons, the police chief and the fire chief, should be selected. 
(5)  Have charge of all matters arising under Wis. Stats. ch. 111 and shall oversee all personnel matters involving employees of the city including any matters involving the state employment relations commission relative to collective bargaining including the following: 
a.  Certification and decertification of collective bargaining units, including proceedings for the determination of the number of employees, type of bargaining unit and eligibility of employees in the classified service. 
b.  Participation in such elections and fact-finding proceedings, mediation, and arbitration. 
c.  Judicial or administrative proceedings arising out of or in any way related to personnel matters. 
(6)  Be responsible for conducting disciplinary hearings involving employees covered by the city's civil service provisions and shall have the duties and powers prescribed in section 16-10 and Wis. Stats. § 66.0509. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.07(2))  
Sec. 4-129. - Public safety and human services committee. 
The public safety and human services committee shall: 
(1)  Oversee fire and police service, public health, and services for the elderly. 
(2)  Review and make recommendations to the common council concerning the issuance of any license, permit or franchise required by the city in connection with the sale of alcoholic beverages. 
(3)  Consider, ascertain the need for and make recommendations to the common council concerning the enactment, implementation and enforcement of any criminal codes, fire, building or residence codes, traffic codes, and such other codes, ordinances, and resolutions as may be appropriate to ensure the good order of the city, its commercial benefit and the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(4)  Review and approve or deny all applications for outdoor sound permits, permits for the installation of basketball hoops within the city's right of way, and permits for the sale of tobacco products. 
(5)  Oversee the use of any public buildings, lands, easements, streets, or property for special events and other purposes as the common council may deem necessary. 
(6)  Review and provide recommendations on contracts for senior services, garbage collection, library services, emergency medical services, and other goods and services that the committee oversees. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.07(3))  
Sec. 4-130. - Committee of the whole. 
(a)  Composition and rules. The committee of the whole shall consist of all common council members and the mayor, all of whom shall be voting members, unless otherwise provided herein. The committee of the whole shall operate using the same rules as the common council. A majority of the committee of the whole shall be a quorum. 
(b)  Meetings and function. The committee of the whole meet as needed, generally monthly, as called by the council president, for the purpose of examining various issues before the common council in greater depth. The common council may refer issues to the committee of the whole for recommendation, or the committee of the whole may address other issues. 
(c)  Chairperson. The council president shall be the chairperson of the committee of the whole. In the event that the council president is unavailable, the chairperson shall be determined in order as follows: chairperson of the finance committee; chairperson of the public safety and human services committee; chairperson of the personnel committee. 
(d)  Annual review meeting. A meeting of the committee of the whole shall be held in July, and at that meeting the committee of the whole, with the advice of the city administrator, shall recommend issues for future committee of the whole meetings. In addition, the committee may discuss items of interest to the city to be forwarded to legislators at the county, state, and federal levels. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.08)  
Chapter 6 - BOARDS, COMMISSIONS, AUTHORITIES AND COMMITTEES  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 6-1. - Appointment, term and removal of members; chair; staff contact; scope and exceptions. 
(a)  Scope; exceptions. The terms and provisions of this section apply to all committees, commissions and boards other than special and ad hoc committees included in article VI. 
(b)  Appointments. Members of citizen committees, commissions, and boards shall be nominated by the mayor, subject to the approval of the common council. 
(c)  Terms. 
(1)  Common council members appointed to citizen committees, commissions, and boards shall have terms that end every year on the third Tuesday in April. 
(2)  Citizen members shall have three-year staggered terms that expire on the third Tuesday in April of the year scheduled except as otherwise provided in this article. If no successor has been named, an occupant of an expired term may continue to serve until July 31 of the year in which the term is scheduled to end. If no successor is named by then, the seat shall be deemed vacant until a successor is named. 
(3)  For any newly created committee, commission, or board, the first members shall be appointed to staggered terms of one, two, or three years, and the term of office thereafter shall be three years, except as otherwise provided in this chapter. 
(d)  Cross committee appointments. 
(1)  Members of citizen committees, commissions, or boards may be appointed as representatives to other committees, commissions, or boards, as provided in this article. Such appointments shall be known as "cross-committee appointments", and the committee that a member is initially appointed to shall be known as the "committee of origin." 
(2)  Council members or citizen members may be appointed, and their term shall be concurrent with the term of their committee of origin. In addition, a cross committee appointment will terminate if, for any reason, an appointee is no longer a member the committee of origin. 
(3)  Cross committee appointments shall be made by a duly noticed, majority vote of the committee of origin, and should occur at the first regularly scheduled committee meeting following a vacancy in a cross committee appointment. 
(e)  Chair. Citizen committees, commissions, and boards shall appoint by majority vote of those present and voting a chair at the May meeting of each odd-numbered year, or whenever a vacancy occurs in that position, unless otherwise stated in this chapter. Except as otherwise provided in this article, common council members appointed to citizen committees, commissions, and boards shall not be the chair. No person may be appointed chair of a citizen committee, commission, or board for a third or greater consecutive term. 
(f)  Staff contact. The mayor shall assign a staff representative to each citizen committee, commission, and board. The staff representative or their designee shall be the secretary of the committee, commission, or board, and shall take and keep the minutes of all meetings. 
(g)  Removal. Removal of appointees shall be as stated in section 8-6. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.30(1)(6); Ord. No. 2012-O-17, 11-13-2012; Ord. No. 2019-O-27 , § 1, 10-22-2019)  
Secs. 6-26-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BOARDS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 6-196-39. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BOARD OF REVIEW 
 
Sec. 6-40. - Composition. 
(a)  The board of review shall consist of five city residents nominated by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the common council. The mayor shall also nominate, subject to confirmation by the common council, three alternate members of such board. 
(b)  The mayor shall designate one of the alternate members as first alternate, one as second alternate and one as third alternate. The first alternate shall act, with full power, only when a member of the board refuses to vote because of interest or when a member is absent. The second alternate shall so act only when the first alternate so refuses or is absent or when more than one member of the board so refuses or is absent. The third alternate shall so act only when the second alternate so refuses or is absent or when more than two members of the board so refuse or are absent. The provisions with regard to removal and the filling of vacancies shall apply to such alternates but upon any vacancy or removal, the mayor shall redesignate all of the alternates as first, second or third alternate. 
(c)  At least one member of the board of review in attendance at the board of review shall be certified to conduct board of review. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.34(1))  
Sec. 6-41. - Chairperson. 
(a)  The mayor shall biennially appoint one member of the board to act as its chairperson. Such person shall be the mayor's designee for purposes of Wis. Stats. § 70.46 and shall attend the certification training for board of review. 
(b)  The chairperson shall hold that position for the duration of his/her term of appointment or until the next biennial appointment, whichever first occurs. Service as chairperson shall commence, except when appointed to fill a vacancy on May 1 of the year of appointment. 
(c)  The chairperson shall preside over proceedings and meetings of the board of review but in all other respects shall have the same powers and duties as any other member of the board. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.34(2); Ch. Ord. No. 2018-O-27, § 1, 7-10-2018) 
State Law reference Local boards of review, members and organization, Wis. Stats. § 70.46.  
Sec. 6-42. - Meetings. 
(a)  The board of review shall meet annually at any time during the 45-day period beginning on the 4 th Monday of April, but no sooner than seven days after the last day on which the assessment roll is open for examination as required by Wis. Stats. § 70.45. 
(b)  A majority shall constitute a quorum and a majority vote of a quorum shall be required to raise or lower the assessor's valuation of any property. 
(c)  Two members may hold an evidentiary hearing, but no member may vote or constitute part of a quorum for purposes of determining an assessment unless the member attended the hearing of the evidence, or received a transcript or a mechanical recording of the hearing not less than five days prior to the meeting and read such transcript or listened to such recording; or received a copy of a summary of the hearing and all exceptions thereto not less than five days prior to the meeting at which the determination is made. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.34(3); Ch. Ord. No. 2018-O-27, § 2, 7-10-2018) 
State Law reference Proceedings of local boards of review, Wis. Stats. § 70.47.  
Sec. 6-43. - Duties and powers. 
The board shall have all of the powers and duties delegated to it by state law including, but not limited to, the following duties: 
(1)  To examine the assessment rolls, to correct all apparent errors in description or computation and to add omitted property thereto. 
(2)  To conduct public hearings, in the manner prescribed by statute, concerning any objection to the amount or valuation of property. 
(3)  To correct any assessment which it determines, from evidence before it, to be too high or too low. 
(4)  To review the assessment of any property which it has reason to believe may have been over-assessed, under-assessed or omitted from the roll. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.34(4))  
Sec. 6-44. - Rules of procedure. 
The board may adopt rules governing its own proceedings; provided, however, that any such rules are in accordance with the statutes governing the board and have been reviewed and approved by the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.34(5)) 
State Law reference Proceedings of local boards of review, Wis. Stats. § 70.47.  
Sec. 6-45. - Clerk. 
The clerk or designee shall serve as clerk of the board. The clerk may not vote. The clerk shall keep an accurate record of all board proceedings. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.34(5))  
Secs. 6-466-63. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - BOARD OF PUBLIC WORKS 
 
Sec. 6-64. - Created. 
A board of public works is hereby created. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.42(1))  
Sec. 6-65. - Composition. 
The board of public works shall be comprised of an alderperson, three residents of the utility district, and the mayor unless the mayor names a designee to serve in the stead and at the pleasure of the mayor. The mayor may change a designee or choose to assume membership on the board at any time. The mayor or the designee of the mayor shall serve as chairperson of the board and the alderperson shall serve as vice-chairperson. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.42(2))  
Sec. 6-66. - Organization. 
The director of public works shall serve as the executive secretary of the board of public works, but shall not vote. All matters to be considered by the board of public works shall be submitted to the director of public works who shall summarize these proposals, provide additional information as he/she may deem to be appropriate, append his/her recommendations, and submit them to the board of public works for consideration. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.42(3))  
Sec. 6-67. - Quorum; records; report. 
A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum for doing business. The board of public works shall keep a record of all of its proceedings which shall be open at all reasonable times to inspection of any elector of the city and shall make a report to the common council on or before March 1 in each year and oftener, if requested. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.42(4))  
Sec. 6-68. - Powers and duties. 
The board of public works shall, subject to review and advice by the common council, have the following duties and powers: 
(1)  To superintend all public works and keep the streets, alleys and public works in repair in accordance with law, division 5 of article IV of chapter 10 and the direction of the common council. 
(2)  To determine the time and manner of using streets for laying or changing water or gas pipes, placing or maintaining electric light, telegraph and telephone poles therein. 
(3)  To superintend the city's refuse collection and recycling programs, including the collection of yard waste. 
(4)  To cause, in accordance with the law and division 5 of article IV of chapter 10, the restoration of streets, alleys and sidewalks. 
(5)  To oversee all municipal building, maintenance and engineering activities within the city. 
(6)  To conduct public hearings on special assessments under Wis. Stats. § 66.0703(7)(a) and report thereon to the common council. 
(7)  To take charge and manage Fitchburg Utility District 1, as now or hereafter constituted, and to undertake the responsibilities prescribed in Wis. Stats. §§ 66.0805(1) and 66.0805(6). In this regard, the board shall: 
a.  Supervise and control the buildings and grounds and the waterworks and sewerage systems of the district to ensure the collection, transmission and treatment of potable water and wastewater. 
b.  Make adequate provision for enforcement of district rules and regulations. 
c.  See that all contracts relating to the district are faithfully complied with and that all utility taxes, charges and special assessments for use of the district water and sewage disposal system are duly made, collected and paid into the appropriate city accounts. 
d.  Make provision for management and control of the affairs of the district, including the hiring and termination of district employees, and take charge of the installation of new machinery and of the projection, planning, construction and maintenance of district improvements, including a system or systems of waterworks and sewerage, including sanitary sewers, provide for sewage collection and perform such related activities as may be necessary for the promotion of public health, comfort, convenience or public welfare of the district. 
e.  Place the director of public works in direct control of district operations and place under his/her supervision all work let by contract, or where work shall not have been let by contract, the general supervision of such work, and may, by rule or regulation grant authority to the director to purchase the material therefore and to employ the necessary help and labor for such work. 
f.  Undertake such related activities and responsibilities as set forth in chapter 40. 
(8)  To take charge and manage the city stormwater utility, as now or hereafter constituted, and to undertake the responsibilities prescribed in Wis. Stats. §§ 62.04, 62.11, 62.16, 62.175, 62.18, 66.0621, 66.0809, 66.0811, and 66.0821. In this regard the board shall: 
a.  Supervise and control the structures and grounds of the utility to ensure the collection and transmission of stormwater. 
b.  Make adequate provision for enforcement of utility rules and regulations. 
c.  See that all contracts relating to the utility are faithfully complied with and that all utility taxes, charges and special assessments for use of the stormwater utility are duly made, collected and paid into the appropriate city accounts. 
d.  Make provision for management and control of the affairs of the utility, including the hiring and termination of utility employees, and take charge of the installation of new machinery and of the projection, planning, construction and maintenance of utility improvements, including a system or systems of stormwater collection and dispersal as may be necessary for the promotion of public health, comfort, convenience or public welfare of the residents of the utility. 
e.  Place the director of public works in direct control of utility operations and place under his/her supervision all work let by contract, or where work shall not have been let by contract, the general supervision of such work, and may, by rule or regulation grant authority to the director to purchase the material therefore and to employ the necessary help and labor for such work. 
f.  Undertake such related activities and responsibilities as set forth in chapter 40. 
g.  Appoint one person from among its membership to be a member of the transportation and transit commission. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.42(5))  
Secs. 6-696-94. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - BOARD OF POLICE AND FIRE COMMISSIONERS 
 
Sec. 6-95. - Composition. 
The board of police and fire commissioners shall consist of five city residents nominated by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the common council. One member shall be appointed annually between the last Monday in April and the first Monday of May for a term of five years. No more than three members may be of the same political party. Before May 31 of each year, the board shall appoint by majority vote of those present and voting one member to be president/chair. Three members shall constitute a quorum. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.41(1)) 
State Law reference City police and fire commissioners board, Wis. Stats. § 62.13.  
Sec. 6-96. - Duties and powers. 
The board shall, within the limits of the funds available for such purpose, have the following powers and duties prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 62.13: 
(1)  To appoint the police chief and the fire chief. 
(2)  To approve or disapprove the written hiring protocol the police chief and fire chief will follow in making all personnel decisions, including hiring, promotion, suspension, demotion, and termination, prior to the implementation of any such procedure. 
(3)  To prepare a list of persons eligible to appointment as police officers or firefighters. For choosing of such list, the board shall adopt, repeal or modify rules calculated to secure the best service in the department, provide for examination of physical and educational qualifications and experience and may provide for competitive examinations and for classification of positions with special examination for each class. 
(4)  To approve or disapprove the appointment of any subordinate by the police chief or fire chief. This power shall include any promotion or reclassification that results in any change in title, position, or pay. Any change in pay shall be subject to review by the personnel committee and must remain within budget constraints as established by the common council. 
(5)  To print and distribute all rules relating to examination and qualification of police officers and firefighters and all changes therein at city expense. 
(6)  To conduct or provide for conducting, at city expense, examinations for appointments to the police or fire department. Such examinations shall be free for all United States citizens over 18 and under 55 years of age with proper limitations as to residence and health and, subject to Wis. Stats. §§ 111.321, 111.322 and 111.335, proper limitations as to arrest and conviction records. 
(7)  To suspend, reduce in rank, or remove the police chief, fire chief, or any firefighter or sworn law enforcement personnel for cause after hearing on charges filed with the president/chair of the board in accordance with the procedures of Wis. Stats. § 62.13(5). The board may also suspend the police chief, fire chief, or any firefighter or sworn law enforcement personnel pending disposition of charges filed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.41(2))  
Sec. 6-97. - Optional powers not granted. 
The option powers set forth in Wis. Stats. § 62.13(6) are not delegated to the board and the board may not exercise them. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.41(3))  
Sec. 6-98. - Judicial review. 
Any person suspended, reduced, suspended and reduced, or removed by the board may appeal from the order of the board to the county circuit court in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 62.13(5)(i). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.41(4))  
Secs. 6-996-124. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - ZONING BOARD OF APPEALS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Local zoning boards of appeal, Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7). 
 
Sec. 6-125. - Created. 
The zoning board of appeals is hereby created. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.45(1)) 
State Law reference Authority for creation of board of appeals, Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7)(e)(1).  
Sec. 6-126. - Composition. 
The zoning board of appeals shall be comprised of five citizen members and two alternates. The mayor shall annually, between April 30 and May 31, designate one of the members as chairperson, and shall designate one of the alternate members as first alternate and the other as second alternate. The first alternate shall act, with full power, only when a member of the board refuses to vote because of interest or when a member is absent. The second alternate shall so act only when the first alternate so refuses or is absent or when more than one member of the board so refuses or is absent. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.45(2)) 
State Law reference Composition of local board of appeals, Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7)(e)(2).  
Sec. 6-127. - Powers and responsibilities. 
The zoning board of appeals shall have the powers and duties prescribed by Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7) and by chapters 22, 24, 25 and 35 and such other and further powers and duties as may be prescribed by statute or ordinance. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.45(3)) 
State Law reference Powers of local board of appeals, Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7)(e)(7).  
Secs. 6-1286-152. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - PUBLIC LIBRARY BOARD 
 
Sec. 6-153. - Board committed. 
The city has created a board known as the "Fitchburg Public Library Board" (hereafter called the board), pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 43.54. The purpose of this committee is to govern and administer the city public library. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.46(1)) 
State Law reference Authority for municipal public library boards, Wis. Stats. § 43.52.  
Sec. 6-154. - Membership. 
(a)  Number of members. The board shall initially consist of seven members. Up to five additional members may be appointed by the county pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 43.60(3). 
(b)  Selection. Seven members of the board shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the common council. 
(c)  Term of office. Upon first appointment, the members shall be divided into three groups, one group of three members and two groups of two members, to serve for two-, three- and four-year terms, respectively. Thereafter each regular appointment shall be for a term of three years. Vacancies shall be filled for unexpired terms in the same manner as regular appointments are made. 
(d)  Composition. The mayor shall appoint as one of the members a school district administrator, or the administrator's representative, to represent the public school districts in which the library is located. Not more than one member of the common council shall be at any one time a member of the board. Members shall be residents of the city, except that not more than two members may be residents of other municipalities. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.46(2)) 
State Law reference Composition of municipal public library boards, Wis. Stats. § 43.54.  
Sec. 6-155. - Powers and duties. 
The board shall have all the powers and duties set forth in Wis. Stats. ch. 43, including, but not limited to, Wis. Stats. § 43.58. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.46(3))  
Secs. 6-1566-178. - Reserved.

DIVISION 6. - LANDMARKS PRESERVATION COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 6-272. - Membership. 
A landmarks preservation commission is hereby created, consisting of seven members. Of the membership, one shall be a registered architect; one shall be a member of the city's historical society; one shall be a licensed real estate broker or appraiser; one shall be a common council member; and three shall be city residents at large. Each member shall have, to the highest extent practicable, a known interest in historic preservation. If a vacancy occurs for any reason, and a person fitting the distinct categories of this section cannot be found within three months, a resident with a known interest in historic preservation may be considered for the vacancy. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.38(1); Ord. No. 2016-O-04, § 1, 1-26-2016)  
Sec. 6-273. - Powers, duties and responsibilities. 
The landmarks preservation commission shall perform the duties prescribed in section 29-4 and such other duties as may be prescribed, from time to time, by ordinance, by the mayor or by the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.38(2))
