DIVISION 7. - PARK COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 6-295. - Composition. 
The park commission shall consist of one alderperson and six citizen members. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.39(1))  
Sec. 6-296. - Powers and duties. 
The park commission shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To review proposed plats and subdivisions and determine the size and location of any required park land dedications or reservations or in lieu of fees which will be acceptable to the city under section 24-2(d)(2). 
(2)  To prepare and recommend to the common council master plans for the city's park system as well as for individual parks or sites. 
(3)  To review and monitor city parks and recreational programs and recommend changes or additions thereto. 
(4)  To review and report to the common council on ordinances or proposals involving use of city parks and the city community center. 
(5)  To adopt, subject to common council direction, policies and procedures for rental and operation of the city park system and community center. 
(6)  To oversee the operation of all city-owned cemeteries in accordance with this Code. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.39(2))  
Secs. 6-2976-325. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 8. - PLAN COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 6-326. - Created. 
The plan commission is hereby established. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.40(1)) 
State Law reference Authority for creation of city plan commission, Wis. Stats. § 62.23.  
Sec. 6-327. - Composition. 
The plan commission shall consist of the mayor or mayor's designee, an alderperson, and five citizens. The citizen members shall include at least one person from each aldermanic district and at least one citizen member shall reside outside the urban service area. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.40(2)) 
State Law reference Composition of city plan commission, Wis. Stats. § 62.23.  
Sec. 6-328. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The plan commission shall have the powers and duties prescribed by Wis. Stats. § 62.23 and this Code and such other and further powers and duties as may be prescribed by statute, by ordinance, or by the common council. 
(b)  The plan commission shall appoint one person from among its membership to serve on the transportation and transit commission and one person from District 4 from among its membership to serve on the agriculture and rural affairs committee. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.40(3)) 
State Law reference Powers, duties and functions of city plan commission, Wis. Stats. § 62.23.  
Sec. 6-329. - Organization. 
The mayor or mayor's designee shall be the presiding officer and chairperson of the plan commission. The zoning administrator/planner shall keep a written record of commission proceedings, including all actions taken by it, and a copy thereof filed with the clerk. Four members shall constitute a quorum, but all actions shall require the affirmative approval of a majority of the seven voting members. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.40(4))  
Sec. 6-330. - Staff and budget. 
The plan commission may employ experts and such staff as may be necessary, and pay for their services and such other expenses as may be necessary and proper, within the limits of the budget established by the common council, or placed at its disposal through gift, and subject to any ordinance or resolution enacted by the common council. As far as possible the commission shall utilize the services of existing city officials and employees. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.40(5))  
Sec. 6-331. - Procedures. 
The plan commission may adopt such policies, rules, and procedures governing its meetings and activities as it deems necessary and appropriate to fulfill its duties and responsibilities. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.40(6))  
Secs. 6-3326-350. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 9. - RESOURCE CONSERVATION COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 6-351. - Membership. 
A resource conservation commission is hereby created, consisting of seven members. One member shall be an alderperson, and six shall be city residents at large, who shall serve staggered three-year terms. Each member shall have, to the highest extent practicable, a demonstrated interest in conservation of natural resources and preservation of the environment. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.43(1))  
Sec. 6-352. - Powers, duties and responsibilities. 
The resource conservation commission shall recommend policy, enforcement, and information programs that will implement and carry out the findings and provisions of chapter 41, solid waste and recycling, chapter 30, article II, erosion control and stormwater management, and chapter 40, article V, stormwater utility. The resource conservation commission shall also recommend policy, enforcement, and information programs that serve to promote the general preservation and improvement of the environment, including but not limited to groundwater, stormwater, waste material, energy efficiency, and climate protection. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.43(2))  
Secs. 6-3536-377. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 10. - TRANSPORTATION AND TRANSIT COMMISSION[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference City, village and town transit commissions, Wis. Stats. § 66.1021. 
 
Sec. 6-378. - Created. 
The transportation and transit commission is hereby created. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.44(1))  
Sec. 6-379. - Composition. 
(a)  The transportation and transit commission shall be comprised of seven members: four citizen members, nominated by the mayor, subject to confirmation by the common council shall serve staggered three-year terms; one alderperson, subject to confirmation by the common council, whose term shall be concurrent with his/her common council term; one citizen member appointed by the plan commission from its membership; and one citizen member appointed by the board of public works from its membership. 
(b)  No person holding stocks or bonds in any corporation subject to the jurisdiction of the transportation and transit commission, or who is in any other manner pecuniarily interested in any such corporation may be a member of nor be employed by the transportation and transit commission. 
(c)  Each nominee shall certify, before confirmation by the common council, that they are not in violation of this section and agree that they shall not acquire any investments in any corporation or organization that violates that section during the term of their appointment. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.44(2))  
Sec. 6-380. - Powers and responsibilities. 
In addition to the duties set forth in Wis. Stats. § 66.1021, the transportation and transit commission shall: 
(1)  Assist in developing the transportation component of the comprehensive plan. 
(2)  Develop and maintain a mass transit plan. 
(3)  Integrate city mass transit plans with county, state, federal, and other local transit plans. 
(4)  Address any other transportation concerns as the common council may deem necessary. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.44(3))  
Sec. 6-381. - Other responsibilities. 
The transportation and transit commission shall review all new development plans and shall recommend, to the plan commission and to the common council, changes to be incorporated which conform to the comprehensive plan. The transportation and transit commission shall also be responsible for any other duties assigned to it by the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.44(4))  
Sec. 6-382. - Organization. 
A written record of commission proceedings, including all actions taken by it, shall be kept by the city engineer, or his/her designee, and a copy thereof filed with the city clerk. A majority of members shall constitute a quorum, and all actions shall require the affirmative approval of a majority of those present and voting. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.44(5); Ord. No. 2010-O-03, § 1(1.44(5)), 2-23-2010)  
Sec. 6-383. - Staff and budget. 
The transportation and transit commission may employ experts and such staff as may be necessary pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.1021 and pay for their services and such other expenses as may be necessary and proper, within the limits of the budget established by the common council, or placed at its disposal through gift, and subject to any ordinance or resolution enacted by the common council. As far as possible the commission shall utilize the services of existing city officials and employees. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.44(6))  
Sec. 6-384. - Procedures. 
The transportation and transit commission may adopt such policies, rules, and procedures governing its meetings and activities as it deems necessary and appropriate to fulfill its duties and responsibilities. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.44(7))  
Secs. 6-3856-411. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - AUTHORITIES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 6-4126-435. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AUTHORITY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference Housing authorities for elderly persons, Wis. Stats. § 66.1213; housing and community development authorities, Wis. Stats. § 66.1335. 
 
Sec. 6-436. - Created. 
Pursuant to Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1213 and 66.1335, the community development authority (the authority) is created. The authority shall be deemed a separate body politic exercising necessary public powers and having the powers, duties and functions conferred on housing authorities for the elderly under Wis. Stats. § 66.1213 and on housing and community development authorities under Wis. Stats. § 66.1335, except as otherwise herein provided. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(1))  
Sec. 6-437. - Composition. 
The governing body of the community development authority shall consist of seven commissioners. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(2))  
Sec. 6-438. - Appointment of commissioners. 
The mayor shall, subject to confirmation of the common council, nominate seven residents of the city having sufficient ability and experience in the fields of urban renewal, community development, and housing, as community development authority commissioners. Two of the commissioners shall be members of the common council and five shall be citizen members. Terms of citizen members shall be four years pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.1335(2)(b). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(2)(A))  
Sec. 6-439. - Officers. 
(a)  The commissioners shall annually appoint by a majority vote of those present and voting a chairperson and vice-chairperson of the authority from among the commissioners, at the first authority meeting in May. Vacancies occurring in the office of chairperson or vice-chairperson shall be filled from among the commissioners for the unexpired portion of the term. 
(b)  The economic development coordinator shall be the executive director of the authority and shall be the chief administrative officer of the authority and shall direct, manage and supervise the authority's administrative operations and technical activities in accordance with the directives of the authority. The executive director shall also act as secretary of the authority and shall perform such other duties and have such other powers and responsibilities as may, from time to time, be delegated to him/her by the authority. 
(c)  In carrying out its duties, the authority may form committees of commissioners or others, hold public meetings and utilize the services of the city or other public or private services as it deems necessary, subject to the policy and budgetary approval of the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(2)(B))  
Sec. 6-440. - Meetings; quorum; bylaws. 
(a)  All meetings of the authority shall be held in compliance with the provisions of the state open meeting law, Wis. Stats. § 19.81 et seq. 
(b)  Four commissioners shall constitute a quorum of the authority for the purpose of conducting its business and exercising its powers and for all other purposes. Action may be taken by the authority upon the affirmative vote of a majority of the commissioners present at any meeting of the authority at which a quorum is present. No vacancy in the membership of the authority shall impair the right of a quorum to exercise the powers and perform the functions of the authority. 
(c)  The authority may adopt and from time to time amend or repeal such bylaws and other rules and regulations not inconsistent with applicable law as it deems necessary in the performance of its functions. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(2)(C))  
Sec. 6-441. - Evidence of authority. 
The filing of a certified copy of the ordinance from which this section is derived with the clerk shall be prima facie evidence of the authority's right to transact business. In any suit, action or proceedings commenced against the authority, a certified copy of the ordinance from which this section is derived or of this division shall be conclusive evidence that the authority is established and authorized to transact business and exercise its powers. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(3))  
Sec. 6-442. - Statutory powers. 
The authority shall have all powers necessary to carry out and effectuate the purposes and provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.1213, and all powers, duties and functions set out in Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1201, 66.1333, and 66.1335 for housing and community development authorities. In this regard, it is authorized to: 
(1)  Exercise all powers, duties and functions of a housing authority under Wis. Stats. § 66.1201. 
(2)  Exercise all powers, duties and functions of a housing authority for the elderly under Wis. Stats. § 66.1213. 
(3)  Exercise all powers, duties and functions of redevelopment authority under Wis. Stats. § 66.1333. 
(4)  Act as agent of the city in planning and carrying out community development programs and activities approved by the mayor and common council funded under the Federal Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, 42 USC 5301 et seq., and other federal and state laws relating to housing and community development, and, following review and recommendation by the plan commission, to perform all acts, except development of the general plan of the city and other duties performed by the plan commission, under Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1301 to 66.1337, and 66.1105. 
(5)  Act as agent of the city in performing all functions required to be performed by a sponsor of a housing rehabilitation program, as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 66.1325, both within and outside of neighborhoods or areas designated by the common council as reinvestment neighborhoods or areas pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.1107 and in performing all other functions related to the operation and administration of the city's housing rehabilitation program and any other programs of rehabilitation financing involving financial assistance from either the federal or state government, or both, in which the city participates. 
(6)  Issue bonds in aid of its powers and duties and functions as permitted under Wis. Stats. § 66.1201 or Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1301 to 66.1329, Wis. Stats. § 66.1331, 66.1333, or 66.1337. Such bonds are declared to be issued for essential governmental and public purposes and to be public instrumentalities and, together with interest thereon and income therefrom, are exempt from taxes. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(4))  
Sec. 6-443. - Additional powers. 
In addition to its statutory powers, the authority is further authorized, within the limits of the funds available for such purposes, to: 
(1)  Employ such technical experts and such other agents and employees, permanent and temporary, as may be required from time to time in the performance of its duties and functions. 
(2)  Contract with the city or any other agency or entity, public, or private, for the provision by the city, or such agency or entity, of any necessary staff services associated with or required by the authority in the staff of the authority. Any staff services provided to the authority by the city pursuant to such contract shall be coordinated through the executive director of the authority or his/her designee. 
(3)  Call upon any department, board, commission or agency of the city for assistance and cooperation in the performance of the authority's duties and functions, and all city departments, boards, commissions and agencies are hereby authorized and directed to cooperate with, and furnish assistance to the authority in the performance of the authority's duties and functions. 
(4)  Work with business, education, government, labor and citizens to: 
a.  Retain and expand existing business and commercial enterprises within the city. 
b.  Recruit new businesses and encourage the expansion and diversification of business and commercial enterprises within the city to expand local employment opportunities and the tax base. 
c.  Foster and facilitate economic development activities through cooperative efforts with area business organizations, adjoining municipalities, the county, and the state. 
d.  Assist new and existing businesses through programs and resources which facilitate quality growth and development within the city. 
e.  Publicize and promote the business, employment, residential, educational, and recreational opportunities available in the city. 
f.  Foster, develop, and enhance a sense of community, a positive community image, and civic pride. 
(5)  To identify itself as the community and economic development authority in anything other than contracts, resolutions, and financial reports. 
(6)  Administer the hotel room tax as provided in chapter 10, article III, division 3. 
(7)  Encourage the development and preservation of affordable housing in the city by: 
a.  Serving as a focal point for housing issues, including landlord tenant issues. 
b.  Overseeing the creation and coordination of city housing policies. 
c.  Making recommendations to the mayor and common council on all aspects of housing policy. 
d.  Holding public hearings on and recommending to the common council specific policies and programs to encourage and assess the city's housing efforts. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(5))  
Sec. 6-444. - Manner of proceeding. 
(a)  As to all housing projects initiated by the authority it shall proceed under Wis. Stats. § 66.1201, and as to all projects relating to blight elimination, slum clearance, urban renewal and redevelopment programs it shall proceed under Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1105 and 66.1301 to 66.1337, as determined appropriate by the common council on a project by project basis. As to all community development programs and activities undertaken by the city under the Federal Housing and Community Development Act of 1974, 42 USC 5301 et seq., the authority shall proceed under all applicable laws and ordinances not inconsistent with state law. 
(b)  The authority and its commissioners shall comply or cause compliance strictly with all provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 66.1201 to 66.1211 and state law and in addition thereto, with each and every term, provision and covenant in any contract of the authority on its part to be kept or performed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(6))  
Sec. 6-445. - Plans; recommendation; reports. 
The authority in consultation with the city plan commission, the TIF district advisory committee, and other appropriate bodies and staff shall: 
(1)  Prepare and periodically update an economic development plan and development strategy for use by the mayor and common council. In formulating said plan, the authority shall monitor and evaluate economic conditions in the city, identify economic problem areas, and prioritize any economic problems identified. 
(2)  Consider alternative approaches to improving economic deficiencies in the city in problem areas identified. 
(3)  Recommend specific programs and projects to allocate available city resources among the elements of the city's economic development effort. 
(4)  Recommend items for inclusion in the annual city budget to implement the development strategy adopted by the common council. 
(5)  Prepare an annual report on the city's economy. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(7))  
Sec. 6-446. - Budget. 
The authority together with the economic development coordinator shall prepare an annual budget which shall be submitted to the mayor as part of the general budget process. The budget shall include estimated fees for consultants, travel expense for staff, publication costs and other ordinary and necessary expenses. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(8))  
Sec. 6-447. - Staff. 
The authority shall receive primary staffing through the offices of the economic development coordinator and the city planner/zoning administrator. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(9))  
Sec. 6-448. - Construction. 
All powers, duties and functions of a community development authority, as set forth in Wis. Stats. § 66.1335 are deemed to have been granted to the authority as though set forth in this section. This section and the powers granted hereunder shall be construed liberally to effectuate its purposes. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.37(11)) 
State Law reference Local housing and community development authorities, Wis. Stats. § 66.1335.  
Secs. 6-4496-479. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CITIZEN COMMITTEES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 6-480. - Created. 
A housing advisory committee is hereby created. 
(Ord. No. 2019-O-23 , § 1, 8-27-2019)  
Sec. 6-481. - Composition. 
The housing advisory committee will be made up of nine members as follows: one alderperson, one community economic development authority (CEDA) member, and seven citizen members. The citizen members shall have a background in one of the following areas: housing finance, housing development, non-profit with an emphasis on housing, attorney, real estate broker or appraiser, housing expert, property management or economist. At least three of the seven citizen members shall be residents of the city. A majority of members shall constitute a quorum. 
(Ord. No. 2019-O-23 , § 1, 8-27-2019)  
Sec. 6-482. - Powers, duties and responsibilities. 
The committee shall act as an advisory to the community and economic development authority, plan commission and common council. The committee may study, research and recommend policies and actions to the common council and other committees as appropriate to promote affordable homeownership and rental housing, and implement the goals, strategies and action items of the Fitchburg Housing Plan. 
(Ord. No. 2019-O-23 , § 1, 8-27-2019)  
Sec. 6-483. - Staff. 
The housing advisory committee shall receive primary staffing and support from the economic development specialist. 
(Ord. No. 2019-O-23 , § 1, 8-27-2019)  
Secs. 6-4846-510. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - COMMISSION ON AGING WELL[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note The title of division 2 was amended by Ord. No. 2017-O-24, § 1, adopted September 26, 2017. 
 
Sec. 6-511. - Created. 
The city commission on aging well is hereby created. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.31(1); Ord. No. 2017-O-24, § 2, 9-26-2017)  
Sec. 6-512. - Purpose. 
The purpose of the commission shall be to enhance the well-being of older residents of the city, to promote their independence, and to promote their involvement in community affairs and activities. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.31(2))  
Sec. 6-513. - Composition. 
The commission shall be comprised of one alderperson and six residents of the city. No less than five of the resident members shall be 55 years old or older. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.31(2))  
Sec. 6-514. - Duties and responsibilities. 
The commission shall: 
(1)  Investigate the changing needs of older persons in the city and the programs available to meet and serve such needs. 
(2)  Develop a network of volunteer and private sector resources, community-based programs and services with the direct involvement of older people in planning, implementing and evaluating such programs and services. 
(3)  Plan programs and services of interest to senior citizens that shall be implemented by the senior services director. 
(4)  Assist the senior services director in preparing an annual budget for submittal to the mayor each year covering the activities, services, programs and the needs of the commission during the next fiscal year. The budget shall include recommendations for action that may be taken by the city to improve the quality of life of senior citizens. 
(5)  Consider and make recommendations to the senior services director and common council concerning any proposals for services, programs, activities or facilities for older people in the community. 
(6)  Adopt such policies, rules, and procedures governing its meetings and activities as it deems necessary and appropriate to fulfill its duties and responsibilities and to accomplish its purpose. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.31(4))  
Secs. 6-5156-536. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - AGRICULTURE AND RURAL AFFAIRS COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 6-537. - Created. 
An agriculture and rural affairs committee is hereby created. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.32(1))  
Sec. 6-538. - Membership. 
(a)  The committee shall have seven members: one alderperson from district 4 or whichever district contains the most rural residents, one plan commission member from district 4 or whichever district contains the most rural residents, two city farmers, one resident who resides outside the urban service area and two city residents at large. 
(b)  The committee may seek advice, as needed, from various experts who could include individuals from the UW College of Agriculture and Life Sciences, the UW Extension, or other individuals as meet the committees' needs, within the limits of the funds available for such purpose. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.32(2); Ord. No. 2010-O-18, § 1, 12-14-2010)  
Sec. 6-539. - Powers; duties; responsibilities. 
The agriculture and rural affairs committee shall act as an advisory committee to the plan commission. The agriculture and rural affairs committee shall: 
(1)  Study the potential future of agriculture in the city. 
(2)  Develop and recommend policies to promote sustainable and economically viable agriculture in the city. 
(3)  Recommend areas to be preserved for agriculture, if any. 
(4)  Study and recommend any potential compensation to landowners in areas designated for agricultural preservation. 
(5)  Take action on any items referred to it by the plan commission or the common council. 
(6)  Make recommendations on all rezoning requests in which any property zoned A-T or A-X outside the urban service area is being considered. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.32(3))  
Sec. 6-540. - Staff. 
The agriculture and rural affairs committee shall receive primary staffing and support from the office of the city planner/zoning administrator. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.32(4))  
Secs. 6-5416-549. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - TREE ADVISORY COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 6-550. - Created. 
A tree advisory committee is hereby created. 
(Ord. No. 2017-O-11, § 1, 5-9-2017)  
Sec. 6-551. - Membership. 
The committee shall have seven members: one alderperson and six residents of the city. Each member shall have, to the highest extent practicable, a working knowledge of arboriculture, a love for trees, and a demonstrated interest in the enhancement, maintenance, and protection of Fitchburg's urban forest. 
(Ord. No. 2017-O-11, § 1, 5-9-2017)  
Sec. 6-552. - Powers; duties; responsibilities. 
The tree advisory committee shall act as an advisory committee to the park commission. The tree advisory committee shall provide oversight of the city's forestry program and urban forest, including but not limited to, advising the park commission and common council on policies for maintenance, planting programs, tree preservation, vegetation management, public outreach, and such other matters on which the city forester/naturalist desires input. 
(Ord. No. 2017-O-11, § 1, 5-9-2017)  
Sec. 6-553. - Staff. 
The tree advisory committee shall receive primary staffing and support from the city forester. 
(Ord. No. 2017-O-11, § 1, 5-9-2017)  
DIVISION 5. - BICYCLE COMMITTEE[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 2019-O-28 , § 2, adopted August 27, 2019, renumbered div. 6, §§ 6-6916-693 as div. 5, §§ 6-5546-556. 
 
Sec. 6-554. - Created. 
A bicycle committee is hereby created. 
(Ch. Ord. No. 2018-O-13, § 1, 3-27-2018; Ord. No. 2019-O-28 , § 2, 8-27-2019)  
Sec. 6-555. - Membership. 
The committee will be comprised of one alderperson, one Fitchburg Chamber of Commerce representative and five Fitchburg residents. Members shall have a strong interest and varied levels of experience with cycling, be it recreational or for transportation; or a strong interest and background in developing and promoting events. 
(Ch. Ord. No. 2018-O-13, § 1, 3-27-2018; Ord. No. 2019-O-28 , § 2, 8-27-2019)  
Sec. 6-556. - Powers; duties; responsibilities. 
The purpose of this committee is to encourage and promote bicycling at all levels in Fitchburg. This shall be done by engaging the community through public information programs, by organizing citywide events, and by promoting the city as a venue for all types of cycling events. This committee shall identify bicycle tour routes and promote the safe use of roads, trails and road crossings. They shall also work to identify social and economic barriers to cycling and identify opportunities to make cycling more accessible for everyone. This committee shall use the Bicycle and Pedestrian Plan as a map to accomplish these goals and will be the lead committee for the periodic review of this document. 
(Ch. Ord. No. 2018-O-13, § 1, 3-27-2018; Ord. No. 2019-O-28 , § 2, 8-27-2019)  
Secs. 6-557, 6-558. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - SPECIAL, AD HOC, AND OTHER COMMITTEES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 6-559. - Appointment. 
Ad-hoc, select or special committees may be appointed by the mayor and are not subject to confirmation by the common council, to consider any special matter. Each such committee shall consider only those matters specifically referred to it and shall exist only so long as may be required to complete its work, but may not exist for longer than one year without annual approval by the common council. All ad-hoc, special, and select committees that exist for more than one year shall provide a written annual report of their activities and findings to the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.60(1))  
Sec. 6-560. - Common council to be apprised. 
The mayor shall inform the common council of the specific assignment given to each special or select committee together with the name, address, occupation, education, and community involvement of each person appointed to the committee and the reason for recommending the appointment of each committee member. This information shall be provided to the common council at least three days prior to the common council meeting at which the appointments will be considered. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.60(2))  
Sec. 6-561. - Size and membership. 
The mayor shall determine the size and composition of select and special committees at the time the committee is created. All ad-hoc, select and special committees shall contain at least one common council member. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.60(3))  
Sec. 6-562. - Common council representation. 
The common council may be represented on city boards and commissions. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.61)  
Secs. 6-5636-587. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BARGAINING TEAM 
 
Sec. 6-588. - Collective bargaining. 
Collective bargaining with certified bargaining units shall be carried on by a bargaining team which may adopt, and thereafter amend, rules and procedures governing the conduct of such bargaining (not in conflict with any other existing ordinances of the city). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.50(1))  
Sec. 6-589. - Composition. 
The bargaining team shall consist of the chairperson of the finance committee or the chairperson's designee, the chairperson of the personnel committee or the chairperson's designee, the city administrator, and labor counsel for the city. The department heads shall provide such assistance and advice as may be requested by the bargaining team and may attend bargaining sessions. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.50(2))  
Sec. 6-590. - Agreements. 
Any agreement reached at the conclusion of collective bargaining shall be reduced to writing by the bargaining team, and may be submitted as a proposed resolution to the personnel committee which shall review the agreement and recommend its approval or rejection to the common council, or the agreement may be direct referred to the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.50(3))  
Sec. 6-591. - Public hearing. 
Recognized city employee organizations shall submit their proposals to the common council which shall refer these matters to the bargaining team. The bargaining team may then conduct a public hearing on the requests, and all interested persons may appear and state their view thereon. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.50(4))  
Sec. 6-592. - Employees excluded from recognized bargaining. 
The mayor and city administrator shall annually review the wages, hours and conditions of employment of all employees not represented by recognized city employee organizations and submit their recommendations to the finance committee each year for the budget review. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.50(5))  
Sec. 6-593. - Distribution of negotiating materials restricted. 
No department heads, supervisory personnel or member of the bargaining team shall distribute any information or written communication bearing upon the subject matter of any collective bargaining or other employment relations matters to any employee unless such distribution or communication has been expressly authorized by the bargaining team, the city labor attorney, the principal labor negotiator designated by the bargaining team, or the mayor. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.50(6))  
Secs. 6-5946-619. - Reserved.

The TIF district advisory committee shall study, analyze, and recommend TIF district policies to the community development authority, finance committee and common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.51(3))

Chapter 8 - CITY OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Municipal officers, Wis. Stats. § 62.09; eligibility for office, Wis. Stats. § 66.0501; elections, Wis. Stats. § 5.01 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 8-1. - Qualifications for elected officials. 
No person shall be eligible for election or appointment as an official of the city unless he/she is a citizen of the United States and of the city and satisfies the statutory qualifications for the office. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.70) 
State Law reference Qualifications of city officers, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(2).  
Sec. 8-2. - VacanciesCause. 
A municipal office shall be vacant whenever: 
(1)  The incumbent dies, resigns, or is removed. 
(2)  In the office of mayor, the incumbent ceases to be a resident of the city. 
(3)  In the office of alderperson, the incumbent ceases to be a resident of the district from which elected. 
(4)  The incumbent is convicted and sentenced by a state or federal court for treason, felony or any crime punishable by imprisonment in any prison or jail for one year or more or any offense involving a violation of the incumbent's official oath. A vacancy so created shall not be affected by a stay of execution of judgment. Reversal of the judgment, but not a pardon, immediately restores the incumbent to office if the term has not expired and entitles the incumbent to the emoluments of the office for the time the incumbent would have served in the office but for the judgment. 
(5)  A competent tribunal voids the election or appointment; or adjudges the officeholder to be incapable of understanding the objective of the elective process; or places the incumbent under guardianship or limited guardianship unless the court finds the incumbent is competent to exercise the right to vote. 
(6)  A person elected, reelected, appointed or reappointed neglects or refuses to take and file the official oath or to execute or renew the official bond if required, or to file the oath or bond as prescribed by law. 
(7)  The incumbent neglects or refuses to execute and file an additional bond, whenever lawfully required, as prescribed by law. 
(8)  A person elected or appointed to fill a vacancy or for a full term declines the office in writing or dies before qualifying or before the time when, by law, the person should enter upon the duties of the office to which elected or appointed. 
(9)  The incumbent accepts another incompatible public office. 
(10)  The incumbent's term expires if the office is elective. 
(11)  Any other event occurs which is declared by any special provision of law to create a vacancy. 
(12)  An elected or appointed official enters the active component of the Armed Forces of the United States and removes himself/herself temporarily from the city or district for which that person is an officer or employee. Vacancies arising out of any such military service shall be temporary and be filled in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 17.035(3). 
(13)  An elected or appointed official becomes temporarily incapacitated or is required to absent himself/herself from the city for an extended period. Vacancies arising out of any such temporary incapacity or absence shall be temporary. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.71(1)) 
State Law reference Terms of municipal officers and substitutes, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5).  
Sec. 8-3. - SameHow filled. 
Except when a recall election is held or the common council by resolution orders a special election, a vacancy in the office of mayor or alderperson shall be filled by a majority vote of the common council who are present and voting. A vacancy in the office of municipal judge shall be filled by special election pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 8.50. Vacancies in other elective offices shall be filled by appointment by the mayor. Vacancies in appointed offices or on any committee, board, or commission shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. If the vacancy occurs on or after January 1 of a regular election for that seat, the seat shall remain vacant until after the election. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.71(2)) 
State Law reference Terms of municipal officers and substitutes, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5).  
Sec. 8-4. - Term of person filling office. 
(a)  An appointee to an elective office shall hold office until a successor is elected and qualified or as set forth in section 8-3. A successor shall be elected for the residue of the unexpired term on the first Tuesday of April next after the vacancy happens, in case it happens no later than December 1 preceding the first Tuesday in April, but if the vacancy happens after December 1 preceding the first Tuesday in April and before that day, then the successor shall be elected on the first Tuesday in April of the next ensuing year; but no election to fill a vacancy in such office may be held at the time of holding the regular election for that office. 
(b)  Temporary vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as other vacancies are filled, except that no election need be held to fill any part of a temporary vacancy. The term of the person appointed temporarily shall not extend beyond the expiration of the term of the vacant office or position and shall expire upon when person whose temporary disability, military service or absence created the vacancy files a statement with the city clerk that the cause for the vacancy no longer exists and that he/she elects to resume the office or position. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.71(3)) 
State Law reference Terms of municipal officers and substitutes, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5).  
Sec. 8-5. - Procedure for filling. 
(a)  Upon notification and verification of a mayoral or alderperson vacancy, the city clerk shall, in writing, immediately notify the common council and mayor of the vacancy. The clerk shall also immediately publish legal notice of the vacancy with one insertion in the official newspaper (unless it is the Wisconsin State Journal) and three insertions in the Wisconsin State Journal and ask for qualified candidates to fill the vacancy. Publication in the newspapers shall occur within seven days following notification to the mayor and common council of the vacancy. 
(b)  Qualified and interested individuals shall submit within 14 days of the last published notice of the vacancy a resume detailing personal history, and completed nomination papers in accordance with statutory election requirements for incorporated municipalities. Upon return of the documents to the city clerk, the clerk shall verify the accuracy of the documents and forward them to the committee of the whole. 
(c)  The committee of the whole shall be convened within 14 days of receipt of the documents from the city clerk and shall interview the prospective candidates. 
(d)  At the first common council meeting following the committee of the whole meeting the common council shall vote the appointment. Immediately following the common council appointment, the individual shall be sworn in and take office. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.71(4)) 
State Law reference Manner of choosing municipal officers, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3).  
Sec. 8-6. - Removal from office. 
(a)  Elected officials may be removed by the common council as provided in Wis. Stats. § 17.13(2), 17.16, or 17.12(1)(a). Appointed officials may be removed as provided in Wis. Stats. § 17.13(1), 17.12(1)(c) or 17.16. 
(b)  Absence of a member from any committee, board or commission meeting for three consecutive meetings, unless authorized by the head of such committee, board or commission shall, upon recommendation of the chairperson following consultation with the mayor, constitute cause for removal of such member from the committee, board or commission. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.72)  
Sec. 8-7. - Bonds to be filed by city officers. 
Every bond required of a city officer shall be executed with sufficient sureties in a sum fixed by the common council when not otherwise prescribed and be approved by the mayor. Whenever the common council shall deem any bond insufficient it may require an additional bond to be executed and filed in a sum and within a time to be set by them. No city officer shall be accepted as a surety on any bond, note, or other obligation of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.73) 
State Law reference Official bonds required by certain municipal officers, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4)(b).  
Sec. 8-8. - Oaths of office. 
Elected and appointed officials shall take and file the official oath within ten days after notice of their election or appointment as provided in Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.74) 
State Law reference Official oath of office, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4)(a).  
Sec. 8-9. - Elections. 
(a)  Spring election. The spring elections for judicial and municipal officers shall be held on the first Tuesday in April. 
(b)  General elections. The general election prescribed in the state constitution shall be held on the Tuesday next succeeding the first Monday in November in even-numbered years. 
(c)  Nonpartisan primary. Candidates for elective city offices shall be nominated by a nonpartisan primary conducted pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 8.11. Such candidate shall file with his/her nomination papers a declaration that he/she will qualify for the office if elected. Nomination papers shall be signed by electors as required in Wis. Stats. § 8.10. If the number of candidates for an elective city office does not exceed twice the number to be elected to such office, no primary shall be held for such office and the names of such candidates shall be printed on the official ballot for the ensuing election. When required, the primary election shall be held on the third Tuesday in February. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.75) 
State Law reference Selection of mayor and alderpersons by election, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3)(a); spring primary elections, Wis. Stats. § 8.11.  
Secs. 8-108-36. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MAYOR 
 
Sec. 8-37. - Election. 
During the spring election in 2019 only, the mayor shall be elected for a one-year term commencing on the third Tuesday of April 2019 and continuing for a one-year term or until a successor is elected and qualified. 
Commencing with the 2020, the mayor shall be elected every three years for a term of office commencing on the third Tuesday of April in the year of election and continuing for three years or until a successor is elected and qualified. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.09(1); Ch. Ord. No. 4, § 5, 1-9-2018) 
State Law reference Election and term of mayor, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.09(3)(a), 62.09(5)(b).  
Sec. 8-38. - Powers and duties. 
(a)  The mayor shall be the chief executive officer of the city and shall have all of the powers and duties delegated to a mayor by state law or city ordinance. 
(b)  The mayor shall take care that city ordinances and state laws are observed and enforced and that all city officers and employees discharge their duties. 
(c)  The mayor shall preside at all common council meetings and shall sign all ordinances, rules, bylaws, regulations, contracts, and proclamations adopted or authorized by the common council and all orders drawn on the treasury except as otherwise prescribed by law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.09(2)) 
State Law reference Powers and duties of mayor, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(8).  
Sec. 8-39. - Veto power. 
(a)  The mayor shall have the authority to veto all acts of the common council, including all resolutions, ordinances, and other actions. The mayor may only veto entire actions, and does not have the authority to veto individual provisions of common council actions. Specifically, the mayor does not have a line-item veto authority. However, the mayor shall have the authority to veto any budget amendment or any amendment to the capital improvement plan. 
(b)  Any action the mayor wishes to veto must be vetoed within five calendar days of the time the common council passed such action. In computing the five-day veto period the first day should be excluded and the last day should be included, as set forth under Wis. Stats. § 990.001(4), if the last day falls on a Sunday or holiday, as listed in Wis. Stats. § 995.20, the mayor may exercise a veto on the next succeeding secular day. 
(c)  The clerk shall immediately inform all common council members of the veto, and any two common council members may request that the item be placed on the agenda for override at the next regular common council meeting. Any request for an override vote not submitted by the agenda deadline as set forth in chapter 4, article II, division 2, shall not be permitted. 
(d)  A two-thirds vote of the entire common council shall be required to override any mayoral veto. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.09(3)) 
State Law reference Powers and duties of mayor, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(8); computation of time, Wis. Stats. § 990.001(4); legal holidays, Wis. Stats. § 995.20.  
Sec. 8-40. - Emergency powers. 
The mayor shall have such emergency powers as set forth in section 4-33(d). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.09(4))  
Sec. 8-41. - Nominations. 
Any mayoral nomination shall be subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the common council. All confirmed appointees shall be directly subordinate to the mayor and subject to the policy direction of the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.09(5))  
Sec. 8-42. - Committees, boards, and commissions. 
(a)  The mayor shall make all nominations to committees, boards, and commissions, except standing committees, in a timely manner. All nominations should be made before April 30 each year. All nominations to committees, boards, and commissions are subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the common council. 
(b)  In the event that there is difficulty finding residents who wish to serve a full term, the mayor may nominate interim members to fill citizen positions on committees, boards, and commissions. If an interim nomination is made, the original term for that seat shall not change. 
(c)  If a vacancy or term expiration occurs in such committees, boards, or commissions, the mayor shall nominate a replacement within three months of notification of vacancy or date of term expiration, subject to confirmation by a majority of the common council. If the mayor does not nominate a replacement who is confirmed by the common council within three months, the common council may, by resolution and a two-thirds vote of those present and voting, appoint someone to fill a vacancy. The mayor continues to have the power of nomination unless the common council exercises its authority under this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.09(6))  
Secs. 8-438-72. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MUNICIPAL JUDGE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference Municipal courts, Wis. Stats. § 755.001 et seq. 
 
Sec. 8-73. - Office created. 
Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 755.01, the office of municipal judge for the city is hereby created. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.10(1)) 
State Law reference Authority for creation of office of municipal judge, Wis. Stats. § 755.01(1); method of filling office of municipal judge, Wis. Stats. § 8.50(4)(fm).  
Sec. 8-74. - Qualifications; election; term. 
The municipal judge shall be licensed to practice law in the State of Wisconsin and have been so licensed for at least five years immediately prior to election or appointment. The municipal judge shall be elected at large at the spring city election for a term of four years, in the year following the presidential election, or until a successor is elected and qualifies. The term of office shall commence on May 1 of the year of the judge's election. Mid-term vacancies in the office of municipal judge shall be filled by election under Wis. Stats. § 8.50. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.10(2); Ord. No. 2018-O-18, § 1, 4-10-2018) 
State Law reference Term of municipal court judge, Wis. Stats. § 755.02.  
Sec. 8-75. - Salary. 
The municipal judge shall receive such salary as may be set from time to time by the common council, which shall be in lieu of fees and costs. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.10(3)) 
State Law reference Salary and fees with regard to municipal judge, Wis. Stats. § 755.04.  
Sec. 8-76. - Training. 
Except as otherwise provided in Wis. Stats. § 755.18(3), the municipal judge shall participate in the program of continuing judicial education as required by the state supreme court at city expense. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.10(4)) 
State Law reference Municipal judge training, Wis. Stats. § 755.18.  
Sec. 8-77. - Oath; bond or dishonesty insurance policy. 
The municipal judge shall, after election, designation or appointment, take and file the official oath as prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 757.02(1) and at the same time execute and file an official bond in the amount of no less than the judge's salary. In the alternative, the governing body, acting through the city clerk, shall obtain a dishonesty insurance policy or other appropriate insurance that covers the judge, in the amount of no less than the judge's salary, in lieu of the bond requirement. The governing body shall pay the costs of the bond or insurance policy. 
Within ten days after a municipal judge takes the oath, the judge shall file the oath and, if required to do so, the official bond with the city clerk and shall also file a certified copy of the oath with the office of director of state courts in accordance with Wis. Stat. § 755.03(2). No judge may act as such until the oath and bond, if required, have been so filed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.10(5); Ord. No. 2019-O-04, § 1, 2-12-2019) 
State Law reference Oath and bond of municipal judges, Wis. Stats. § 755.03; oath of office of justices and judges, including municipal judges, Wis. Stats. § 757.02; oaths and bonds of public officials, Wis. Stats. § 19.01.  
Sec. 8-78. - Jurisdiction. 
The municipal judge shall preside over the municipal court created by chapter 18 and shall have such jurisdiction as is conferred by statute and this Code. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.10(6)) 
State Law reference Jurisdiction of municipal courts, Wis. Stats. § 755.045.  
Secs. 8-798-99. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - APPOINTED OFFICERS 
 
Sec. 8-100. - City administrator. 
(a)  Appointment. An administrator shall be nominated by the mayor pursuant to the terms and conditions of a written contract between the city and the nominee. Any such nomination shall be subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the common council. 
(b)  Term, compensation and benefits. The term of the administrator shall not have a fixed end date. The terms, compensation, and benefits of the administrator shall be as provided in a written contract. The contract may be terminated at any time, with or without cause, by a majority vote of the entire common council. If the contract is terminated without cause, there may be severance provisions established in the contract. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities. The administrator shall perform such duties as are from time to time assigned by the mayor, by the common council, or by ordinance. Unless otherwise provided by contract, the administrator shall oversee the day-to-day operations of the city, shall be directly responsible for the day-to-day operations of city facilities, shall supervise the city staff, and shall assist the mayor in preparing the annual budget for review by the common council. 
(d)  Acting as city comptroller. The powers outlined under Wis. Stats. § 62.09(10) are hereby assigned to and shall be performed by the administrator during the term of his/her appointment and any extension thereof. Any reports submitted by the city comptroller shall be submitted to the finance committee. 
(e)  Subordinate to the mayor. The administrator shall be directly subordinate to the mayor and subject to the policy direction of the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.11) 
State Law reference Authority for consolidation of city offices, Wis. Stats. §§ 66.0101, 62.09(3)(c).  
Sec. 8-101. - City assessor. 
(a)  Selection. An assessor shall be selected in accordance with the procedure outlined in chapter 16 whenever a vacancy in that office occurs. No person shall hold the office of assessor unless certified by the department of revenue under Wis. Stats. § 73.09 as qualified to perform the function of the office of assessor. 
(b)  Duties. The assessor shall make the assessments of general property for taxation as required by and in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. ch. 70 and shall perform such other duties as may be prescribed by statute, by ordinance, by the mayor or by the common council. 
(c)  Subordinate to the mayor and administrator. The assessor shall be subordinate to the mayor, subject to the policy directions of the common council, and shall act under the direct supervision of the administrator. 
(d)  Civil service position. The assessor shall be entitled to the benefits and protection afforded by chapter 16. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.12) 
State Law reference Requirement for appointment and exceptions, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a)(c); certification required, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.09(1)(d), 73.09; qualifications, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(2); appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3); oath and bond, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4); term, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5).  
Sec. 8-102. - City attorney. 
(a)  Appointment. An attorney shall be nominated by the mayor pursuant to the terms and conditions of a written contract between the city and the nominee. Any such nomination shall be subject to confirmation by a majority vote of the common council. 
(b)  Term, compensation and benefits. The term of the attorney shall not have a fixed end date. The terms, compensation and benefits of the attorney shall be as provided in a written contract. The contract may be terminated at any time with or without cause, upon the recommendation of the mayor and by a majority vote of the entire common council. If the contract is terminated without cause, there may be severance provisions established in the contract. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities. The attorney shall have the duties and responsibilities of the city attorney as is provided in Wis. Stats. § 62.09(12), along with such other similar services as are from time to time requested or delegated by the mayor or common council. 
(d)  Subordinate to the mayor. The attorney and any assistant attorneys shall be directly subordinate to the mayor and subject to the policy direction of the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.13) 
State Law reference Requirement for appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a); qualifications, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(2); appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3); oath and bond, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4); term, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5); duties, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(12).  
Sec. 8-103. - Building inspector. 
(a)  Selection. A building inspector shall be selected in accordance with the procedure outlined in chapter 16 and the qualification requirements of chapter 35, article II, division 2 whenever a vacancy in that office occurs. 
(b)  Duties. The building inspector shall have the duties and responsibilities assigned by chapter 35 and such other duties as may be prescribed by statute, by ordinance, by the mayor or by the common council. 
(c)  Subordinate to the mayor and administrator. The building inspector shall be subordinate to the mayor, subject to the policy directions of the common council, and shall act under the direct supervision of the administrator. 
(d)  Civil service position. The building inspector shall be entitled to the benefits and protection afforded by the chapter 16. 
(Comp. Ord. 2009, § 1.14) 
State Law reference Authority to establish and fill office of building inspector, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.09, 62.23(9).

Editor's note Ord. No. 2011-O-22, § 2, adopted November 8, 2011, amended the Code by repealing former § 8-104. Former § 8-104 pertained to the cable director, and derived from the Compiled Ordinances of 2009, § 1.15.  
Sec. 8-105. - Clerk. 
(a)  Selection. A clerk shall be selected in accordance with the procedure outlined in chapter 16 whenever a vacancy in that office occurs. 
(b)  Duties. The clerk shall perform the duties prescribed in Wis. Stats. §§ 62.09(11) and 7.30 and such other duties as may be prescribed by statute, by ordinance, by the mayor or by the common council. The clerk shall submit such written reports as may be requested from time to time by the mayor or common council concerning the operations of the department for the previous fiscal year. The clerk shall provide, by the last day of February, to the mayor, all common council members, all department heads, and all staff contacts to committees, boards, and commissions, a list of all board, committee, and commission members whose terms will be expiring in April of each year. 
(c)  Deputy clerks. The clerk may, in writing filed in the clerk's office, appoint deputies, who shall act under the clerk's direction, and in the clerk's absence or disability or in case of a vacancy shall perform the clerk's duties and shall have power to administer oaths and affirmations. The deputies shall receive such compensation as the common council shall provide. The clerk and the clerk's sureties shall be liable on the clerk's official bond for the acts of such deputies. 
(d)  Subordinate to the mayor and administrator. The clerk shall be subordinate to the mayor, subject to the policy directions of the common council, and shall act under the direct supervision of the administrator. 
(e)  Civil service benefits. The clerk shall be entitled to the benefits and protection afforded by the chapter 16. 
(f)  Bond. The city clerk shall be covered by a fidelity bond of not less than $5,000.00. 
(g)  Compensation. The salary of the clerk shall be as fixed by the city council. 
(h)  Deposit of fees collected. The salary of the clerk shall be in full compensation for all services of any kind rendered by the clerk and all fees paid to and received by the clerk shall be turned in to the city treasurer for deposit into the city treasury. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, §§ 1.16, 2.03(5), (6)) 
State Law reference Requirement for appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a); qualifications, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(2); appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3); oath and bond, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4); term, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5); duties, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(11).  
Sec. 8-106. - Treasurer. 
(a)  The city treasurer shall be covered by a fidelity bond of not less than $250,000.00 for collection of taxes. 
(b)  The salary of the city treasurer shall be fixed by the council. The salary of the city treasurer shall be in full compensation for all services of any kind rendered by the treasurer for the city, and all fees paid to and received by the treasurer shall be deposited by the treasurer into the city treasury. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.03(5), (6)) 
State Law reference Requirement for appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a); qualifications, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(2); appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3); oath and bond, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4); term, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5); duties, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(9).  
Sec. 8-107. - Economic development coordinator. 
(a)  Selection. An economic development coordinator shall be selected in accordance with the procedure outlined in chapter 16 whenever a vacancy in that office occurs. 
(b)  Subordinate to the mayor and administrator. The economic development coordinator shall be subordinate to the mayor, subject to the policy direction of the common council, and shall act under the direct supervision of the administrator. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities. The economic development coordinator shall be responsible for initiating activities designed to promote job growth, new investment, and economic growth in the city, shall facilitate and encourage existing firms to expand facilities in the city, shall encourage new industries and business to locate in the city and shall promote development. The economic development coordinator shall be the executive director of the community development authority. 
(d)  Civil service position. The economic development coordinator shall be entitled to the benefits and protection afforded by chapter 16. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.17; Ord. No. 2018-O-08, § 1, 2-13-2018; Ord. No. 2019-O-24 , § 1, 9-24-2019)

Sec. 8-108. - Engineer/director of public works. 
(a)  Selection. An engineer shall be selected in accordance with the procedure outlined in chapter 16 and the qualification requirements of chapter 35, article II, division 2 whenever a vacancy in that office occurs. 
(b)  Acting as director of public works. The engineer shall also act as and have the title of director of public works. 
(c)  Duties. The engineer shall have such powers and duties as prescribed by statute and this Code for the engineer and for the director of public works. The engineer shall also have any other duties as may be assigned by the mayor or by the common council.

Sec. 8-109. - Fire chief and subordinates. 
(a)  Appointment. The board of police and fire commissioners shall appoint the fire chief in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 62.13 and on the basis of demonstrated qualifications in fire prevention, control, and management, and shall be a resident of the city within 60 days of the time his/her probationary period ends. 
(b)  Term of office. The fire chief shall hold office during good behavior, subject to suspension or removal by the board of police and fire commissioners for cause. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities. The fire chief shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  Shall have command of the fire department under the direction of the mayor and administer the fire department under the supervision of the mayor and common council; 
(2)  May appoint and promote subordinates and firefighters subject to approval by the board of police and fire commissioners. Such appointments shall be made by promotion when this can be done with advantage, otherwise from an eligible list provided by examination and approval by the board and kept on file by the police and fire commission. Any such appointment shall be in accordance with the personnel policies of the city, the rules and regulations of the board and the policies and procedures of the fire department; 
(3)  Shall administer and enforce all laws relating to fire prevention and control; 
(4)  Shall develop organizational structure, policies, and procedures to achieve the goals of the department; 
(5)  Shall develop and implement policies for operating the department at the highest levels of safety and for the prevention of accidents, injuries, and occupational illnesses both within the department and in any activities of the department; 
(6)  Shall develop and administer the annual department budget in accordance with this chapter; 
(7)  Shall provide the mayor and common council with projections of the goals and needs of the department over a five-year time span. Such projections shall include anticipated personnel, equipment and facility requirements and anticipated budget requests; and shall be supplemented, modified, or revised whenever any change in circumstances or conditions dictates; 
(8)  Shall identify the need for, negotiate and draft mutual and/or automatic aid agreements with agencies of other communities. Such agreements shall be submitted to the mayor and common council for review, consideration and approval; 
(9)  Shall maintain liaison with other city departments on matters of importance to the goals of the fire department; and 
(10)  Shall provide a written quarterly report to the public safety and human services committee regarding the status of the department as directed by the public safety and human services committee. 
(d)  Civil service benefits. The fire chief shall be afforded the fringe benefits provided to city employees by chapter 16, article III. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.19) 
State Law reference Requirement for appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a); qualifications, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(2); appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3); oath and bond, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4); term, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5); municipal police and fire departments, Wis. Stats. § 62.13; fire chief defined, Wis. Stats. § 990.01(7g).  
Sec. 8-110. - Parks director. 
(a)  Selection. A parks director shall be selected in accordance with the procedure outlined in chapter 16 whenever a vacancy in that office occurs. 
(b)  Subordinate to the mayor and administrator. The parks director shall be subordinate to the mayor, subject to the policy direction of the common council, and shall act under the direct supervision of the administrator. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities. The parks director shall be responsible for formulating and implementing all policies, procedures and practices relating to city parks and recreation including the planning, design, construction, maintenance and usage of all parks, green ways, highway boulevards, municipal building grounds, cemetery, and golf course. 
(d)  Civil service position. The parks director shall be entitled to the benefits and protection afforded by the chapter 16. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.20) 
State Law reference Authority for appointment of discretionary officers, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1).  
Sec. 8-111. - Police chief and subordinates. 
(a)  Appointment. The chief of police shall be appointed by the board of police and fire commissioners in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 62.13 and shall be a resident of the city within 60 days of the time his/her probationary period ends. 
(b)  Term of office. The chief of police shall hold office during good behavior, subject to suspension or removal by the board of police and fire commissioners for cause. 
(c)  Powers, duties and responsibilities of chief of police. The chief of police shall: 
(1)  Have command of the police department of the city under the direction of the mayor, shall obey all lawful written orders of the mayor or common council and may appoint subordinates subject to approval by the board of police and fire commissioners. Such appointments shall be made by promotion when this can be done with advantage, otherwise from an eligible list provided by examination and approval by the board and kept on file by the police and fire commission. 
(2)  Develop organizational structure, policies, and procedures to achieve the goals of the department. 
(3)  Develop and implement policies for operating the department at the highest levels of safety and for the prevention of accidents, injuries and occupational illnesses both within the department and in any activities of the department. 
(4)  Develop and administer the annual department budget in accordance with this chapter. 
(5)  Provide the mayor and common council with projections of the goals and needs of the department over a five-year time span. Such projections shall include anticipated personnel, equipment and facility requirements and anticipated budget requests and shall be supplemented, modified, or revised whenever any change in circumstances or conditions dictates. 
(6)  Identify the need for, negotiate and draft cooperative agreements with other departments and communities. Such agreements shall be submitted to the mayor and common council for review, consideration and approval. 
(7)  Maintain liaison with other city departments on matters of importance to the goals of the police department. 
(8)  Provide a written quarterly report to the public safety and human services committee regarding the status of the department as directed by the public safety and human services committee. 
(d)  Powers, duties and responsibilities all police personnel. The chief of police and each police officer shall: 
(1)  Possess the powers, enjoy the privileges and be subject to the liabilities conferred and imposed by law upon constables, and be taken as included in all writs and papers addressed to constables. 
(2)  Arrest with or without process and with reasonable diligence take before the municipal judge or other proper court every person found in the city engaged in any disturbance of the peace or violating any state law or city ordinance. 
(3)  Collect the same fees prescribed for sheriffs by Wis. Stats. § 814.70 for similar services unless a higher fee is applicable under Wis. Stats. § 814.705(2). 
(4)  Administer and enforce all laws as provided by state statutes and city ordinances. 
(e)  Civil service benefits. The chief of police shall be afforded the fringe benefits provided to city employees by chapter 16, article III. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.21) 
State Law reference Requirement for appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a); qualifications, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(2); appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3); oath and bond, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4); term, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5); duties, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(13); municipal police and fire departments, Wis. Stats. § 62.13; sheriff's fees, Wis. Stats. § 814.70; authority for establishment of higher fees by local governments, Wis. Stats. § 814.705.  
Sec. 8-112. - Senior center director. 
(a)  Selection. A senior center director shall be selected in accordance with the procedure outlined in chapter 16 whenever a vacancy in that office occurs. 
(b)  Subordinate to the mayor and administrator. The senior center director shall be subordinate to the mayor, subject to the policy direction of the common council, and shall act under the direct supervision of the administrator.

Sec. 8-113. - Treasurer/finance director. 
(a)  Appointment. A treasurer/finance director shall be appointed by the mayor in accordance with the procedure outlined in chapter 16 and the qualification requirements of Wis. Stats. § 62.09 whenever a vacancy in that office occurs. 
(b)  Duties. The treasurer/finance director shall: 
(1)  Be responsible for managing and directing the city's accounting functions, formulating and implementing policies and procedures to maintain accounting controls, investing the city's funds, and preparing and presenting financial reports on the city's financial status. 
(2)  Submit such written reports as may be requested from time to time by the mayor or common council concerning the operations of the department or the city. 
(3)  Have the duties assigned to the treasurer by Wis. Stats. § 62.09(9) and such other duties as may be assigned by statute, by ordinance, by the mayor or by the common council. Any reports submitted by the treasurer shall be submitted to the finance committee. 
(4)  Present the annual audit report to the finance committee by April 15 of each year, but may receive up to two 60-day extensions, approved separately, by a majority vote of the finance committee, of those present and voting. 
(c)  Deputy treasurer. The treasurer/finance director may in writing, filed in the office of the clerk, appoint deputies who shall act under the treasurer's direction and in the treasurer's absence or disability, or in case of a vacancy shall perform the treasurer's duties. The deputies shall receive such compensation as the common council shall provide and the acts of the deputies shall be covered by official bond, as the common council shall direct. 
(d)  Subordinate to the mayor and administrator. The treasurer/finance director shall be subordinate to the mayor, subject to the policy directions of the common council, and shall act under the direct supervision of the administrator. 
(e)  Civil service benefits. The treasurer/finance director shall be entitled to the benefits and protection afforded by the chapter 16. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 1.23) 
State Law reference Requirement for appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(1)(a); qualifications, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(2); appointment, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(3); oath and bond, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(4); term, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(5); duties, Wis. Stats. § 62.09(9).

ARTICLE II. - FINANCIAL MANAGEMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY
