The city has established, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0617, a water facilities impact fee. 
(Ord. No. 2009-O-34, § 1, 1-12-2010) 
State Law reference Municipal impact fees, Wis. Stats. § 66.0617.  
Secs. 10-2010-41. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUDGET 
 
Sec. 10-42. - Preparation of budget. 
(a)  Budget schedule. Before the end of June of each year the mayor shall recommend and the common council shall adopt a schedule for the preparation and consideration of the budget for the next fiscal year. The budget schedule shall include specific dates for completion of commission, committee, board, and department consideration of the budget; all public hearings including the statutorily required common council public hearing on the budget. 
(b)  Recommendations. Each of the various boards, committees, commissions, departments and authorities shall prepare a budget for their respective financial activities including expenditures and anticipated revenues for the next fiscal year together with recommended policy changes and priorities. Department heads functioning as staff contacts shall prepare budgets for their respective commissions, committees and boards these recommendations shall be submitted to the mayor for consideration prior to drafting of the mayor's executive budget. 
(c)  Mayor's budget submitted to finance committee. The mayor shall on the date indicated in the budget schedule, submit to the finance committee the consolidated budget of expenditures and anticipated revenues and be present to explain the document and respond to questions. 
(d)  Finance committee deliberations and optional hearing. The finance committee shall review the budget, may hold a public hearing and shall submit their recommendations on the mayor's budget to the council at a regular meeting prior to the required public hearing. The mayor, department heads, commission, committee and board chairpersons and members shall participate in the finance committee deliberations. 
(e)  Common council review and public hearing. The common council shall hold one or more meetings to review the proposed budget and recommendations of the finance committee. The common council shall also hold a public hearing on the budget in accordance with state statutes and the budget schedule as developed under this division. 
(f)  Recommendation for referendum. The finance committee shall recommend and the common council shall take action on any request for a public referendum pertaining to the budget. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.01(1)) 
State Law reference Municipal budgets, Wis. Stats. §§ 62.12(2), 65.90.  
Sec. 10-43. - Contents. 
(a)  Summary format. The budget shall provide a complete financial picture for the ensuing year. It shall be in tabular form, and shall include: 
(1)  A general summary prepared in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 65.90; 
(2)  Detailed estimates of all anticipated revenues applicable to proposed expenditures; 
(3)  All proposed expenditures; 
(4)  A compensation schedule to provide uniform rates of pay for offices and positions in the city service; 
(5)  The total of such proposed expenditures shall not exceed the total of such anticipated revenues. 
(b)  Projected revenues and expenditures. Such budget shall list all existing indebtedness and all anticipated revenue from all sources during the ensuing year and shall likewise list all proposed appropriations for each committee, commission, board, authority and department, and any activity accounts during the ensuing year. 
(c)  Historical revenues and expenditures. The budget shall also show actual revenues and expenditures for the last completed year, actual revenues and expenditures for not less than the first six months of the current year combined with estimated revenues and expenditures for the balance of the current year, and the current year budget. 
(d)  Personnel cost schedule. The budget shall also include a schedule of the proposed salary for each department and position of the city. This schedule shall be considered part of the budget when adopted as an estimate of departmental personnel costs, but shall not be construed to imply a granting of individual increases. 
(e)  Fund balances. The budget shall also show for informational purposes any anticipated, unexpended, or unappropriated balances and surpluses. 
(f)  Capital expenditures. The budget shall list all proposed capital improvements for the succeeding year as set forth in the capital improvement plan adopted under division 3 of this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.01(2))  
Sec. 10-44. - Public inspection and hearing. 
(a)  Official public hearing before council. This section pertains only to the common council public hearing referred to in section 10-42(c). 
(b)  Publication of notice. A summary of such budget and notice of the place where such budget is available for public inspection and notice of the time and place for holding the public hearing thereon shall be published in the official city newspaper at least 15 days prior to the time of such public meeting. All notices and copies of the budget summary shall indicate that a detailed budget is available for inspection at the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  Public hearing. Not less than 15 days after the publication of the proposed budget and the notice of hearing thereon a public hearing shall be held at the time and place stipulated at which time any resident or taxpayer of the city shall have an opportunity to be heard on the proposed budget. The budget hearing may be adjourned from time to time. 
(d)  Public inspection. Copies of the summary budget shall be available to all who attend the public hearing or who make a specific request following the 15-day notice in subsection (c) of this section. Copies of the detailed budget shall be made available to the press prior to the public hearing, and at least three copies of the detailed budget shall be available for the public at the hearing. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.01(3)) 
State Law reference Procedure for adoption of municipal budget, Wis. Stats. § 65.05.  
Sec. 10-45. - Amendments to mayor's proposed budget. 
(a)  Authority to amend. The common council, by a vote of the majority of all the alderpersons, may make such changes in the proposed budget submitted, either as to purposes or amounts for which money may be expended and as to purposes or amounts for which bonds or notes may be issued as it may deem best. 
(b)  Submission of amendments for consideration. Council members may offer amendments in accordance with timeframes, as stated on the budget schedule. All such amendments shall be in writing, utilizing the budget amendment form available from the city administrator. 
(c)  Omnibus amendment. The mayor or the finance committee shall be permitted to introduce one housekeeping or omnibus amendments to deal with prior year audit findings, year-end fund deficits, technical corrections or other necessary adjustments which have little or no fiscal impact on the general levy. 
(d)  Introduction of amendments. At the annual budget meeting, the finance chairperson will introduce and request a second for the annual levy resolution, necessary to adopt the final budget, prior to any debate and action on any amendments. 
(e)  Debate limitations. Debate on each proposed amendment will be limited to five minutes, with each council member speaking no more than twice on each amendment. A majority vote of the common council may extend debate to ten minutes. A separate vote must be taken for each added extension. 
(f)  Closing statements. Council members wishing to make closing statements prior to their vote on the budget shall be limited to a total of five minutes for explanation of votes. 
(g)  Floor amendments prohibited. New budget amendments offered the night of council consideration will not be accepted. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.01(4)) 
State Law reference Procedure for adoption of municipal budget, Wis. Stats. § 65.05.  
Sec. 10-46. - Adoption. 
(a)  Council adoption. Following the public hearing, the common council shall adopt the annual budget. Adoption of the budget shall require a majority vote of the entire council. The vote shall be taken by roll call vote. 
(b)  Mayoral veto. Following the adoption of the budget, the mayor shall have five days to veto the entire budget or any specific line items in the adopted budget. The mayor may delete a dollar amount within a line item and substitute a lower dollar amount. 
(c)  Council override of veto. The common council may override the veto of the mayor by a two-thirds vote of the council. The vote shall be taken on each item separately and shall be by a roll call vote. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.01(5)) 
State Law reference Procedure for adoption of municipal budget, Wis. Stats. § 65.05.  
Sec. 10-47. - Amendments to adopted budget. 
(a)  Internal adjustment by department heads. Department heads are authorized, with the consent of the mayor, to make internal adjustment to their respective department budgets up to a maximum of $5,000.00 or five percent of the department budget, whichever is less. 
(b)  Amendment that does not alter total revenue and expenses. The common council may shift funds in making internal alterations of the budget without changing the adopted totals for all revenues and expenditures by a majority vote. 
(c)  Amendment that alters total revenue and expenses. The authorization of funds or any change to the budget which would alter total revenues and expenditures shall require a two-thirds vote of the entire council. 
(d)  Publication of budget amendments. Any changes made to the total revenues or expenditures shall be published within ten days after the change is approved by Class 1 notice in accordance with Wis. Stats. ch. 985. Failure to give notice shall preclude any changes in the proposed budget and alterations thereto made under subsection (c) of this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.01(7)) 
State Law reference Amendments to municipal budget, Wis. Stats. § 65.05.  
Secs. 10-4810-67. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CAPITAL IMPROVEMENTS AND EQUIPMENT 
 
Sec. 10-68. - Capital improvement plan. 
(a)  Items included in plan. A five-year capital improvement plan setting forth the capital improvements, estimated costs and proposed funding sources for each project or capital expenditure shall be maintained. All capital improvements and capital expenditures which are expected to exceed $10,000.00 in value, and which are likely to have a useful life of five years or more shall be included in the five-year capital plan. 
(b)  Retained on file permanently. The capital improvement plan, as amended annually, shall be kept permanently on file in the office of the city clerk. 
(c)  Annual review required. The capital improvement plan shall be reviewed by the board of public works, plan commission and finance committee, generally in May of each year and the plan may be modified, supplemented, altered, extended or amended from time to time by the common council by majority vote. 
(d)  Amendments to the annual capital improvements plan. The mayor shall provide the common council members, at the time of submittal of the budget to the committee, a statement setting forth any project or amount in the capital improvement plan for that budget year which has not been included in the annual budget submitted to the committee and the mayor's reasons for not including such project or amount. Such statement shall be in writing and a copy filed in the office of the city clerk. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.01(6))  
Sec. 10-69. - Protection of general obligation borrowing capacity. 
Borrowing for the purpose of funding the capital improvements in the plan shall not exceed an aggregate of three percent of the total equalized value of taxable property within the city without two-thirds vote to amend said percent of the total equalized value. The vote shall be by roll call vote. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.02(3))  
Sec. 10-70. - Financing of capital equipment. 
Debt incurred for the purchase of capital equipment shall be payable in not more than five annual installments unless specifically authorized by a majority vote of the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.02(4))  
Sec. 10-71. - Matching of revenues and expenditures and non-debt capital financing sources. 
Debt incurred for the financing of public improvements for which special assessments are intended to be used to offset the cost of the debt shall be payable in annual installments with a term similar to that allowed for the repayment of the special assessments, unless specifically authorized by a majority vote of the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.02(5)  
Sec. 10-72. - Special assessment B bonds. 
As a complete alternative to any other financing method the common council may provide for the payment of the initial cost of any public improvement from the proceeds of special assessment B bonds issued under Wis. Stats. § 66.54(10) and (11). Special assessments to retire such bonds and pay the interest thereon shall be levied under Wis. Stats. § 66.60, payable in not more than ten annual installments unless specifically authorized by a majority vote of the common council, bearing interest at the rate directed by the city council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.02(6))  
Secs. 10-7310-102. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - REVENUE COLLECTION AND INVESTMENT 
 
Sec. 10-103. - Internal controls. 
The city treasurer shall review and update as necessary, a policy for the collection of money from any source, including the internal controls established and the segregation of duties for receipting, recording and reconciling said funds. Such policy shall be approved by the finance committee and common council by resolution, and kept on file with the city clerk. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.03(1))  
Sec. 10-104. - Treasurer to issue receipt for payments into treasury. 
The city treasurer or his/her designee shall not receive any money into the treasury from any source, except on account of taxes levied and collected during the fiscal year, without issuing a receipt therefor. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.03(2))  
Sec. 10-105. - Treasurer to charge proper account. 
Upon the receipt of any money (except for taxes as provided in this chapter), the city treasurer or designee shall prepare a receipt in duplicate for the money so received. The treasurer shall charge the amount thereof to the treasury and credit the proper account. The payment of the money to any receiving agent of the city or to the city treasurer shall be safeguarded in such manner as the council shall direct. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.03(3))  
Sec. 10-106. - Investments. 
The treasurer is hereby authorized to invest any funds which are not immediately needed in any of the investments authorized under the investment policy of the city, or as listed under Wis. Stats. § 66.0603. Said investment policy shall be reviewed and updated as necessary, approved by the finance committee and common council by resolution, and kept on file with the city clerk. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.03(4))  
Sec. 10-107. - Payment of financial obligations as prerequisite to grant of license or permit. 
(a)  Issuance prohibited; exception. No license or permit, except a dog license or a bicycle license may be granted for any premises for which taxes, assessments, utility bills or other claims of the city are delinquent and unpaid, or to any person delinquent in payment of such claims, including unpaid forfeiture judgment, except where hardship is demonstrated claiming specifications in article III of this chapter. 
(b)  Notice. Prior to final action by the common council the city clerk shall notify in writing an applicant whose license or permit the common council is required by this section to refuse prior to final action by the common council that the license or permit cannot be granted because of outstanding delinquent claims, specifying them. The notice shall also inform the applicant of the right to a hearing as provided in this section. 
(c)  Request for hearing. If a written request is filed by the applicant within ten days of the date of the clerk's notice, the clerk shall schedule a hearing before the common council on the proposed refusal to grant the license or permit. Hearings on proposed refusals to renew alcohol beverage licenses shall be conducted in accordance with the procedures of Wis. Stats. § 125.12. 
(d)  When seller's permit required. No license or permit may be issued by the city clerk for any business involving the sale of tangible personal property unless proof of a valid seller's permit, if required, is provided pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 77.61(11). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.04)  
Secs. 10-10810-127. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - GRANTS 
 
Sec. 10-128. - Summary of funding request required. 
Prior to completing full application, summary of funding request should be submitted to mayor for approval and should include the following information: 
(1)  Proposed program benefits. Identification of proposed funding use, including goals and objectives of new projects or programs, and benefit to city (i.e., number of persons served); 
(2)  Cost estimates. Identification of costs of program including administrative personnel, audit, space and insurance costs in addition to direct costs associated with grant, and percent which would be reimbursed; 
(3)  Duration of funding. Identification of duration of grant funding, approximate cost to continue program and likelihood of program continuance once grant funding has been depleted. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.05(1))  
Sec. 10-129. - Authorization to submit grant application. 
Application for grant funding must be authorized in writing by the mayor prior to submission. If grant requires application authorization by the common council, such authorization shall be in the form of a resolution. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.05(2))  
Sec. 10-130. - Mayor and clerk to sign acceptance; records retention. 
Mayor and clerk shall sign all grant acceptance contracts. All grant contracts shall be retained in the clerk's office, along with copies of all funding draw requests and receipts of funding in a separate file for each grant accepted. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.05(3))  
Sec. 10-131. - Accounting and audit of grant funds. 
All grants shall be logged and recorded in a central file maintained by the treasurer. The treasurer shall assign separate accounts for the recording of revenues and expenditures as necessary to provide a clear audit trail of grant transactions. All grants shall be audited during the course of the annual audit, in accordance with any state, federal or other guidelines governing such audits. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.05(4))  
Secs. 10-13210-160. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - DONATIONS AND SOLICITATIONS 
 
Sec. 10-161. - Official acceptance. 
The city must officially accept all donations of funds or equipment. If it is determined that the donation is not in the best interest of the citizens of the city, the donation shall be refused. If donation is refused, return of equipment or refund by city check shall be accomplished as soon as practicable. Policies included under article II of chapter 14 shall also apply and take precedence over this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.06(1)) 
State Law reference Authority for municipality to accept gifts, Wis. Stats. § 62.22(1).  
Sec. 10-162. - Review prior to acceptance. 
A staff committee consisting of the city planner, parks director and city administrator shall review all donations for appropriateness and best use. Report of donations shall be made to the common council at least annually. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.06(2))  
Sec. 10-163. - Specific use donations. 
All donated funds which are given for a specific use shall be recorded in such a manner as to easily identify the intended use. Donations shall be receipted by the treasurer, and a budget notation shall be prepared for all donations in excess of $1,000.00 specifying the intended revenue and expenditure accounts to be increased. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.06(3))  
Sec. 10-164. - Memorials, donations in honor of individuals. 
Donations which are contingent upon recognition of an individual by plaque, sign or other insignia shall be accepted only after approval of the proposed plaque, sign or other insignia by the donation review committee. Such plaque, sign or other insignia shall not be attached to a public facility unless approved by the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.06(4))  
Sec. 10-165. - Nonspecific use donations. 
Donations shall be receipted by the treasurer, and a budget notation shall be prepared for all donations in excess of $1,000.00 specifying the intended revenue and expenditure accounts to be increased. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.06(5))  
Sec. 10-166. - Solicitations for community events. 
All solicitations on behalf of the city, or which are distributed on the official letterhead of the city, shall be approved by the mayor prior to solicitation. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.06(6))  
Secs. 10-16710-175. - Reserved.

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY

DIVISION 2. - PROPERTY TAXES[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference General property taxes, Wis. Stats. § 70.01 et seq.; tax, property tax collection, Wis. Stats. § 74.01 et seq. 
 
Sec. 10-186. - Taxes levied against real and personal property. 
The common council shall have the power as authorized under state statute to levy annually, a tax upon all the taxable property in the city for the operating and capital improvement needs of the city, or for any other purpose authorized under Wis. Stats. § 65.07. The adoption of the annual tax levy shall be by a two-thirds vote of the entire council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.02(1))  
Sec. 10-187. - Time for payment of taxes. 
Real property taxes in excess of $100.00, may be paid in two installments, on January 31 and July 31 in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 74.11. Personal property taxes, special assessments and special charges shall be paid in full on or before January 31. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.02(2))

DIVISION 3. - SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference Special assessments generally, Wis. Stats. § 66.0703; special assessments by local ordinance, Wis. Stats. § 66.0701. 
 
Sec. 10-213. - Annual installments. 
Whenever any special assessments shall be levied to defray the cost of any public improvement, such special assessments may be paid in annual installments as determined by the council. 
(1)  Interest to be added. Installments shall include a proportionate part of the principal of the special assessment determined by the number of installments. All installments shall also include interest at a rate to be determined by the council on the deferred balance of principal. Interest during the initial year of the installment shall be as stated in the final assessment resolution adopted by the common council. Each subsequent installment shall include a like proportion of the deferred principal and interest at the rate determined by the council upon the unpaid deferred balance of such assessment. 
(2)  Certification to the tax roll. The first installment shall be entered in the first tax roll prepared after such installments have been determined as a special tax on the property upon which the special assessment was levied, and thereafter this tax shall be treated in all respects as any other municipal tax. All of the subsequent installments shall be entered in a like manner and with like effect in each of the annual tax rolls thereafter until all are levied. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.07(1))  
Sec. 10-214. - Delinquent special assessment installments. 
If any deferred installment so entered in the tax roll shall not be paid to the treasurer with the other taxes, it shall be returned to the county as delinquent and accepted and collected by the county on behalf of the city in the same manner as delinquent general taxes on real estate. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.07(2))  
Sec. 10-215. - Use of alternate special assessment procedures authorized. 
In addition to other methods provided by law, special assessments for any public work or improvement or any current service may be levied in accordance with the provisions of this section, and with the special assessments policy adopted by the city. 
(1)  Resolution to be adopted. Whenever the council determines that any public work or improvement or any current service shall be financed in whole or in part by special assessments levied under this section, it shall adopt a resolution specifying this intention and the time, either before or after completion of the work or improvement, when the amount of the assessments will be determined and levied, the number of annual installment, if any, in which assessments may be paid, the rate of interest to be charged on the unpaid balance and the terms on which any of the assessments may be deferred while no use of the improvement is made in connection with the property. 
(2)  Estimated costs to be provided prior to public hearing. The provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.0703 shall apply to special assessments levied under this section; when the Council determines by resolution that the hearing on the assessments shall be held subsequent to the completion of the work or improvement or the rendering of the service, the report required by Wis. Stats. § 66.070(5) shall contain a statement of the final cost of the work, service or improvement in lieu of an estimate of the cost. 
(3)  Public hearing notice. Notice of the time and place of the public hearing on any special assessment proposed to be levied; a notice of the final assessment; and terms of payment thereof shall be given in the manner prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 66.0703. 
(4)  Lien against property. Any special assessment levied under this section shall be a lien against the property assessed from the date of the final resolution by the council determining the amount of the levy. 
(5)  Appeal of special assessment. Any person against whose property a special assessment is levied under this section may appeal therefrom in the manner prescribed by Wis. Stats. § 66.0703(12) within 40 days of the date of the final determination by the council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.07(3))  
Sec. 10-216. - Exception in cases of financial hardship. 
(a)  Findings. The common council of the city hereby finds: 
(1)  In the interest of public health, welfare and safety, it is often necessary to construct improvements in areas in which property owners reside for whom the payment of the special assessments for the improvements could be considered as a severe financial hardship. 
(2)  It is in the public interest for the city to temporarily assume the cost of special assessments for public improvements in those instances where the high cost of such assessments might result in a severe economic burden on the property owner and possibly force sale and loss of a home. 
(b)  When city treasurer to pay or defer assessments. To ensure that persons will not be unduly economically burdened or forced to move from their homes by reason of a decision of the city authorities ordering construction of public improvements at the cost of the property benefitted, the city treasurer is hereby directed and authorized to pay or defer any special assessment legally charged against the real estate of any individual for whom the immediate payment of the assessment would be a severe financial hardship as determined under subsection (c) of this section. 
(c)  Qualifying individual. For the purpose of this section, an individual described in subsection (b) of this section is defined as any individual property owner or owners within a household who meets all of the following criteria: 
(1)  An individual who owns and resides on a property located within or abutting a special assessment improvement district whose property has been specially assessed for said improvement. 
(2)  An individual who has an annual gross income equal to or less than 72 percent of the median income of the county as most recently determined by the United States Department of Housing And Urban Development. 
(3)  An individual who has less than $25,000.00 in liquid assets. Liquid assets are defined as cash, marketable securities (stocks, bonds, treasury bills, notes and commercial papers), savings bonds, savings accounts and the cash surrender value of life insurance policies. 
(4)  An individual who certifies to the city clerk that payment of the special assessment or any installment of the special assessment is a financial hardship, and that the individual meets the criteria set forth in subsections (c)(1), (2) and (3) of this section. 
(5)  An individual who executes to the city consent to have the city record a lien, as provided in subsection (d) of this section. 
(d)  Payment recorded as lien against property benefitted. A copy of such resolution with a statement of the amount and date paid and description of the properties certified by the city clerk shall be recorded with the register of deeds of the county, and the amount shall thereby become a lien upon such real property in favor of the city prior to any other lien other than prior outstanding tax certificates or prior liens hereunder for the amount paid, with legal interest, and shall be enforceable after transfer of title of the property by sale, inheritance or will, in the manner provided by law, except when such transfer is to a surviving spouse who meets the criteria set forth in subsection (c) of this section. 
(e)  Lien to be discharged on sale. The owner of such property, or the owner's heirs, personal representative or assigns shall discharge such lien at any time the owner fails to meet the criteria set forth in subsection (c) of this section or upon sale or transfer of the property by will, bequest or in any other manner, whichever comes sooner, by paying the total amount of the outstanding special assessments against the property with accrued interest to the city treasurer, who shall execute a proper satisfaction which may be duly recorded with the county register of deeds. 
(f)  Annual review of program. The treasurer shall annually no later than December 15 report to the council on the impact of this section, including the level of current activity in comparison to previous years and a summary of unpaid liens. 
(g)  Owner to pay interest. The interest for such liens shall be simple interest paid by either of the methods set forth in this subsection. The owner shall elect the method of payment at the time the application for payment by the city under this section is made. The interest rate shall be the rate in effect for a special assessment at the time the assessment was approved. 
(1)  Interest may be accrued and paid in its entirety at the time the lien is discharged. 
(2)  Interest may be paid annually until the lien is discharged. 
(h)  Applicant to attest to qualifications. All applicants will annually file with the city clerk an affidavit attesting to continued compliance with the criteria set forth in subsection (c) of this section. Until such time as the lien is discharged, the qualifications of said owner pursuant to the criteria enumerated in subsections (c)(1) through (4) of this section shall be reviewed annually by the city clerk. 
(i)  Foreclosure of lien. In the event the owner no longer meets any of the criteria, the assessment, together with accrued interest, shall become due and payable according to the full established payment schedule for said assessment and the city clerk shall place the same on the next tax roll as a special charge and deliver an executed copy of the lien to the city attorney for collection in the usual manner of foreclosure of a lien in circuit court. False information furnished on the affidavit will be subject to penalties for violation of this chapter and the entire amount of the special assessment plus interest will be due immediately. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.07(4))  
Secs. 10-21710-240. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - ROOM TAX AND PERMIT[5] 
Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
State Law reference Municipal room tax, Wis. Stats. § 66.0615. 
 
Subdivision I. - In General 
 
Sec. 10-241. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Gross receipts has the meaning as defined in Wis. Stats. § 77.51(4)(a), (b) and (c) insofar as applicable. 
Hotel or motel means a building or group of buildings in which the public may obtain accommodations for consideration including, without limitation, such establishments as inns, motels, tourist homes, tourist houses or courts, bed and breakfast establishments, lodginghouses, roominghouses, summer camps, apartment hotels, resort lodges and cabins and any other building or group of buildings in which accommodations are available to the public, except accommodations, including mobile homes as defined in Wis. Stats. § 66.0435(1)(d), rented for a continuous period of more than one month and accommodations furnished by any hospitals, sanatorium, or nursing homes, or by corporations or associations organized and operated exclusively for religious, charitable or educational purposes, provided that no part of the net earnings of such corporations and associations inures to the benefit of any private shareholder or individual. 
Lodging marketplace means an entity that provides a platform through which an unaffiliated 3rd party offers to rent a short-term rental to an occupant and collects the consideration for the rental from the occupant. 
Occupant means a person who rents a short-term rental through a lodging marketplace. 
Operator means a person who is the owner or lessee of property being used as both a short-term rental and their primary residence and who is conducting the short-term rental business by, among other things, interacting digitally and in person with guests and is identified in short-term listings and advertisements as the short-term rental "host." An operator may not be a LLC, trust, non-profit, or other corporate entity. 
Primary residence means a dwelling unit that serves as an individual's true, fixed and permanent home for at least 183 days in a calendar year and to which, whenever absent therefrom, that individual intends to return. Additional characteristics of a primary residence include, but are not limited to, where an individual receives mail, claims residence for purposes of voter registration, pays for utilities, and lists as their address on state issued identification cards. An individual can have only one primary residence. 
Short-term rental means a residential dwelling that is offered for rent for a fee and for fewer than 28 consecutive days. 
Transient means any person residing for a continuous period of less than one month in a hotel, motel or other furnished accommodations available to the public. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(1); Ord. No. 2020-O-04 , § 1, 1-28-2020)  
Sec. 10-242. - Levy. 
Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0615, a tax is hereby imposed on the privilege and service of furnishing, at retail, except sales for resale, rooms or lodging to transients or occupants by hotel keepers, motel operators, lodging marketplaces, and operators of short-term rentals, and any other persons furnishing accommodations that are available to the public, irrespective of whether membership is required for the use of the accommodations. For rentals made through lodging marketplaces, the lodging marketplace shall collect and remit the tax to the city treasurer, according to the provisions of this chapter 10 article III division 4. Beginning January 1, 2017, such tax shall be as set by the annual budget appendix fee schedule. Such tax shall not be subject to the selective sales tax imposed by Wis. Stats. § 77.52(2)(a)1. and may not be imposed on sales to the federal government and persons listed under Wis. Stats. § 77.54(9a). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(2); Ord. No. 2016-O-22, § 1, 9-13-2016; Ord. No. 2020-O-04 , § 1, 1-28-2020)  
Sec. 10-243. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 2016-O-22, § 1, adopted September 13, 2016, amended the Code by repealing former § 10-243 in its entirety. Former § 10-243 pertained to disposition of proceeds, and derived from the Comp. Ords. of 2009, § 2.17(3).  
Sec. 10-244. - Administration; payment; returns; extensions. 
(a)  This section shall be administered by the city treasurer. 
(b)  The tax imposed for each calendar quarter is due and payable on the last day of the month next succeeding the calendar quarter for which imposed. 
(c)  A return shall be filed with the city treasurer, by those furnishing at retail such rooms and lodging, on or before the same date on which such tax is due and payable. Such return shall show the gross receipts of the preceding calendar quarter from such retail furnishing of rooms or lodging, the amount of taxes imposed for such period, and such other information as the city treasurer deems necessary. 
(d)  Every person required to file such quarterly return shall, with his/her first return, elect to file an annual calendar-year or fiscal-year return. Such annual return shall be filed within 90 days of the close of each such calendar or fiscal year. The annual return shall summarize the quarterly returns, reconcile and adjust for errors in the quarterly returns, and shall contain certain such additional information as the city treasurer requires. Such annual returns shall be made on forms as prescribed by the city treasurer. All such returns shall be signed by the person required to file a return or his/her duly authorized agent, but need not be verified by oath. 
(e)  The city treasurer may, for good cause, extend the time for filing any return, but in no event longer than one month from the filing date. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(4))  
Sec. 10-245. - Disposition of proceeds and oversight by community and economic development authority. 
(a)  The city's community and economic development authority, ("CEDA"), shall monitor, by reviewing quarterly reports from the city treasurer, collection and allocation of room taxes from hotels and motels located within the city. 
(b)  CEDA shall establish a contract with a tourism entity, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 66.0615(1)(f), to assist with tourism promotion and tourism development. 
(c)  CEDA shall provide the tourism entity contracted with pursuant to subsection (b) of this section with 70 percent of the room tax revenue on a quarterly basis within 45 days following collection of that quarter's room tax, to carry out the activities set forth in subsection (b) of this section. 
(d)  The tourism entity contracted with pursuant to subsection (b) of this section shall submit an annual report to CEDA by March 1 each year detailing how their percentage of the hotel room tax revenue was spent on tourism promotion and tourism development in the preceding year. This report shall, at the minimum, include the information required to be filed with the Wisconsin Department of Revenue pursuant to subsection (f) of this section. 
(e)  The 30 percent of the hotel room tax retained by CEDA shall be distributed according to the fee schedule. 
(f)  Beginning May 1, 2017, on or before May 1 of each year, CEDA shall file an annual report with the Wisconsin Department of Revenue, using the form created and provided by the Department of Revenue. The report shall include all of the following: 
(1)  The amount of room tax collected and the room tax rate imposed in the previous year; and 
(2)  A detailed accounting of the amounts of revenue forwarded to the tourism entity pursuant to subsection (c) of this section and a detailed accounting of expenditures of $1,000.00 or more made by the tourism entity; and 
(3)  A list of each member of the governing body of the tourism entity and the name of the business entity each member owns, operates, or is employed by, if any. 
(g)  CEDA shall submit an annual report to the city common council by May 1 each year detailing and summarizing how the room tax revenue was spent on tourism promotion and tourism development. 
(h)  Neither CEDA nor the tourism entity contracted with pursuant to subsection (b) of this section may use any of the room tax revenue it receives to construct or develop a lodging facility. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(19); Ord. No. 2016-O-22, § 1, 9-13-2016)  
Sec. 10-246. - Sale of business. 
If any person liable for any amount of tax under this section sells out his/her business or stock of goods or quits the business, his/her successors or assigns shall withhold sufficient of the purchase price to cover such amount until the former owner produces a receipt from the city treasurer that it has been paid or a certificate stating that no amount is due. If a person subject to the tax imposed by this section fails to withhold such amount of tax from the purchase price as required, he/she shall become personally liable for payment of the amount required to be withheld by him/her to the extent of the purchase price valued in money. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(9))  
Sec. 10-247. - Office audits. 
The city treasurer may, by office audit, determine the tax required to be paid to the city or the refund due to any person under this section. This determination may be made upon the basis of the facts contained in the return being audited or on the basis of any other information within the city treasurer's possession. One or more such office audit determinations may be made of the amount due for anyone or for more than one period. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(10))  
Sec. 10-248. - Field audits. 
The city treasurer or designee may, by field audit, determine the tax required to be paid to the city or the refund due to any person under this section. The determination may be made upon the basis of the facts contained in the return being audited or upon any other information within the city treasurer's possession. Whenever the city treasurer has probable cause to believe that the correct amount of room tax has not been assessed or that the tax return is not correct, the city treasurer, and designees, is authorized to examine and inspect the books, records, memoranda, and property of any person in order to verify the tax liability of that person or of another person. Nothing herein shall prevent the city treasurer from making a determination of tax at any time. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(11); Ord. No. 2016-O-22, § 1, 9-13-2016)  
Sec. 10-249. - Required recordkeeping. 
Every person liable for the tax imposed by this section shall keep or cause to be kept such records, receipts, invoices and other pertinent papers in such form as the city treasurer requires. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(15))  
Sec. 10-250. - Records confidential; exceptions. 
(a)  All tax returns, schedules, exhibits, writings or audit reports relating to such returns on file with the city treasurer are deemed to be confidential, except the city treasurer may divulge their contents to the following, and no others: 
(1)  The person who filed the return. 
(2)  Officers, agents, or employees of the Federal Internal Revenue Service or the Wisconsin Department of Revenue. 
(3)  Officers, employees, or agents of the city administrator. 
(4)  Such other public officials of the city, when deemed necessary. 
(5)  Pursuant to a valid subpoena or search warrant. 
(b)  Any person who violates or is in noncompliance with, any of the provisions of this section or section 10-251 shall be subject to a forfeiture of not less than $100.00, nor more than $500.00. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(16); Ord. No. 2016-O-22, § 1, 9-13-2016)  
Sec. 10-251. - Disclosure prohibited. 
No person having an administrative duty under this section shall make known in any manner the business affairs, operations or information obtained by an investigation of records of any person on whom a tax is imposed by this section, or the amount or source of income, profits, losses, expenditures, or any particular thereof, set forth or disclosed in any return, or to permit any return or copy thereof to be seen or examined by any person, except as provided in section 10-250. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(17))  
Sec. 10-252. - Failure to file return; estimated tax. 
If any person fails to file a return as required by this section, the city treasurer shall make an estimate of the amount of the gross receipts under section 10-242. Such estimate shall be made for the period for which such person failed to make a return and shall be based upon any information which is in the city treasurer's possession or may come into his/her possession. On the basis of this estimate the city treasurer shall compute and determine the amount required to be paid to the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(12))  
Sec. 10-253. - Penalties and interest for failure to pay. 
A forfeiture of 25 percent of the room tax due for the previous year or $5,000.00, whichever is less, of the tax imposed, is hereby established and due and owing in the event that the room tax is not paid within 30 days after the due date of return. In addition to this forfeiture, all unpaid taxes under this section shall bear interest at the rate of one percent per month from the due date of the return until the first day of the month following the month in which the tax is paid or deposited with the city treasurer. An extension of time within which to file a return shall not operate to extend the due date of the return for purposes of interest computation. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(13))  
Sec. 10-254. - Penalties for refusal to permit inspection and audit. 
Any person who is subject to the tax imposed by this section who fails to obtain a permit as required in section 10-274, or who fails or refuses to permit the inspection of his/her records by the city treasurer after such inspection has been duly required by the city treasurer, or who fails to file a return as provided in this section, or who violates any other provisions of this section, shall be subject to a forfeiture not to exceed $250.00. Each day, or portion thereof, that such violation continues is hereby deemed to constitute a separate offense. The total forfeiture imposed shall not exceed five percent of the tax imposed by this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(18))  
Sec. 10-255. - Late filing fees. 
Delinquent tax returns shall be subject to a late filing fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. The tax imposed by this section shall become delinquent if not paid by the due date of the return. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(14))  
Secs. 10-25610-273. - Reserved.  
Subdivision II. - Permits 
 
Sec. 10-274. - Business permit required; application; fee. 
(a)  Every person furnishing rooms or lodging shall file with the city clerk an application for a permit for each place of business. Every application for a permit shall be made upon a form prescribed by the city clerk and shall set forth the name under which the applicant transacts or intends to transact business, the location of his/her place of business, and such other information as the city clerk requires. The application shall be signed by the owner if a sole proprietor and, if not a sole proprietor, by the person authorized to act on behalf of such sellers. At the time of making an application the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. 
(b)  Once issued, such permits need not be renewed, however, permits shall be subject to suspension and revocation for violations of any provisions of this section as provided herein. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(5))  
Sec. 10-275. - Determination by council; procedure upon denial. 
The common council shall grant or deny an application for a permit no later than 45 days after application. If the application for a permit is denied, the applicant shall be given written notice of the reasons for denial and shall be given an opportunity to be heard thereon. If the applicant desires a public hearing, he/she shall file a written request therefor with the city clerk, and the council shall hold a public hearing thereon no later than the second council meeting following filing of the request for hearing. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(6))  
Sec. 10-276. - Issuance; transfer; display. 
After compliance with section 10-274 by the applicant, and approval by the common council under section 10-275, the city clerk shall grant and issue to each applicant a separate permit for each place of business within the city. Such permit is not assignable and is valid only for the person in whose name it is issued and for the transaction of business at the place designated therein. It shall at all times be conspicuously displayed at the place for which issued. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(7); Ord. No. 2016-O-22, § 1, 9-13-2016)  
Sec. 10-277. - Notice of intended suspension or revocation; reissuance after revocation; fees. 
(a)  Whenever any person fails to comply with this section, the city clerk may, upon ten days notification and after affording such person the opportunity to show cause why his/her permit should not be revoked, revoke or suspend any or all of the permits held by such person. The city clerk shall give to such person written notice of the suspension or revocation of any of his/her permits. 
(b)  The city clerk shall not approve a new permit after the revocation of a permit unless he/she is satisfied that the former holder of the permit will comply with the provisions of this section. 
(c)  A fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule shall be imposed for the renewal or issuance of a permit which has been previously suspended or revoked. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.17(8); Ord. No. 2016-O-22, § 1, 9-13-2016)  
Secs. 10-27810-282. - Reserved.  
Subdivision III. - Short-Term Rentals 
 
Sec. 10-283. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this subdivision is to ensure short-term rentals operating within the city are adequate for protecting public health, safety and general welfare, including establishing minimum standards for human occupancy; determining the responsibilities of operators offering these properties for rent; to provide minimum standards necessary for the health and safety of persons occupying or using buildings, structures or premises as well as the surrounding community; and provisions for the administration and enforcement thereof. 
(Ord. No. 2020-O-04 , § 1, 1-28-2020)  
Sec. 10-284. - Short-term rental annual license required; application; fee. 
(a)  Every person who wishes to establish, operate, or maintain, or permit to be established, operated, or maintained upon any property owned, leased or controlled by him/her, a short-term rental within the city shall, on an annual basis, file with the city clerk an application for a license for each short-term rental. 
(b)  Every application for a short-term rental license shall be made upon a form prescribed by the city clerk and shall set forth the following information: name and address of the operator, the location of his/her short-term rental, the maximum proposed occupancy of the short-term rental, a statement that the proposed short-term rental is the primary residence of the operator, and such other information as the city clerk requires. 
(c)  The application shall be signed by the operator. 
(d)  The application shall include proof of a valid and current tourist rooming house license, as required by Wis. Stats. 66.1014(2)(d)2.a, issued by the Wisconsin Department of Agriculture, Trade, and Consumer Protection or an agent thereof. 
(e)  The application shall include proof that the applicant has successfully completed an annual city building inspection department inspection to ensure compliance with Fitchburg Ordinances and Wisconsin Administrative Code ATCP Chapter 72. Said inspection must be conducted by the city building inspection department for each short-term rental location. In the event that the building inspection department identifies violations of Fitchburg Ordinances or Wisconsin Administrative Code ATCP Chapter 72, the applicant shall correct all violations prior to a license being issued. 
(f)  At the time of making an application, the applicant shall pay to the city clerk a fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. 
(g)  Each application shall be accompanied by a signed and notarized affidavit stipulating that the short-term rental is the operator's primary residence. 
(h)  No license shall be issued unless the applicant meets all of the requirements of subsections (a) through (g). 
(i)  The annual short-term rental license shall expire on June 30 of each year unless sooner revoked. 
(j)  No license shall be required for any short-term rental operated for a total of ten or less nights in a calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 2020-O-04 , § 1, 1-28-2020)  
Sec. 10-285. - Issuance; transfer; display. 
After the applicant fully complies with section 10-284, the city clerk may either deny the application or grant and issue to applicant a separate license for each applied short-term rental, which shall indicate the maximum occupancy for the short-term rental. Any such granted license is not assignable and is valid only for the person in whose name it is issued, and only for the transaction of business at the place designated therein. The license shall at all times be conspicuously displayed at the place for which it was issued. 
(Ord. No. 2020-O-04 , § 1, 1-28-2020)  
Sec. 10-286. - Procedure upon denial. 
If the application for a license is denied, the applicant shall be given written notice of the reasons for denial and shall be given an opportunity to be heard thereon. If the applicant desires a public hearing, he/she shall file a written request therefor with the city clerk, and the public safety and human services committee shall hold a public hearing thereon no later than the second public safety and human services committee meeting following filing of the request for hearing. Public safety and human services commission will make a recommendation to the council and refer the matter to council for final determination. 
(Ord. No. 2020-O-04 , § 1, 1-28-2020)  
Sec. 10-287. - Failure to obtain license. 
(a)  Unless exempted by section 10-284(j), it shall be unlawful for any person to establish, operate or maintain, or permit to be established, operated or maintained upon any property owned, leased or controlled by him/her a short-term rental within the city without having first secured a valid and current license for each such short-term rental as provided in this subdivision. 
(b)  Unless exempted by section 10-284(j), it shall be unlawful for any person to list, advertise, or otherwise offer, whether via a lodging marketplace or in any other manner, a short-term rental within the city without having first secured a valid and current license for each such short-term rental as provided in this subdivision. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, operate, or maintain, or permit to be established, operated, or maintained upon any property owned, leased, or controlled by him or her a short-term rental which exceeds the maximum occupancy listed in the license or allowed under Fitchburg Ordinances or Wisconsin Administrative Code ATCP Chapter 72, whichever is smaller. 
(d)  It shall be unlawful for any person to list, advertise, or otherwise offer, whether via a lodging marketplace or in any other manner, a short-term rental which exceeds the maximum occupancy listed in the license or allowed under Fitchburg Ordinances or Wisconsin Administrative Code ATCP Chapter 72, whichever is smaller. 
(e)  For the purpose of enforcing compliance with the provisions of this subdivision, the building inspector or his or her designees may issue citations to the operator for violations of this subdivision in the amount specified in the city fee schedule. Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2020-O-04 , § 1, 1-28-2020)  
Sec. 10-288. - Revocation process. 
(a)  The operator may be notified of any noncompliance of this chapter or any City of Fitchburg Ordinances or ATCP Chapter 72 violations by the building inspection department using the contact information provided by the operator on their annual short-term rental license application. The building inspection department may specify a deadline to correct the violation between one and five business days, depending on the violation. 
(b)  Within the time specified in the notice of noncompliance, the operator shall correct the violation to the satisfaction of the building inspection department. 
(c)  If the operator fails to timely correct the violation as required by subsection (b), the building inspection department may notify the city administrator of noncompliance and request permission to proceed with the revocation process. 
(d)  Upon approval from the city administrator, a hearing will be scheduled before the public safety and human services committee, who shall hear the matter and make a recommendation to the common council for final determination. The clerk shall notify the operator at the address provided on the license application at least two weeks prior to the hearing dates. 
(e)  Common council will conduct the final revocation hearing. The operator may be represented by an attorney. All other interested parties may also give testimony to the public safety and human services committee and/or the common council. A written decision of the common council will be made and will be provided to the operator. 
(f)  If the license is revoked, the operator may not apply for a new license for a period of 12 months from the date of the revocation. 
(Ord. No. 2020-O-04 , § 1, 1-28-2020)  
Secs. 10-28910-302. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PURCHASING AND PUBLIC CONTRACTS[6] 
Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
State Law reference Local government purchasing, Wis. Stats. § 66.0131. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 10-303. - Definitions. 
As used in this division, the following terms shall have the following meanings unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
Committee means the finance committee of the common council. 
Council means the common council. 
Department means one of the following 13 city divisions as identified in the annual city budget: 
(1)  Finance; 
(2)  City clerk; 
(3)  Assessor; 
(4)  Building inspection; 
(5)  Zoning/planning; 
(6)  Public works; 
(7)  Senior center; 
(8)  Parks and recreation; 
(9)  Police; 
(10)  Fire; 
(11)  Cable; 
(12)  Administration; 
(13)  Economic development. 
Purchase of goods and services means any transaction between the city and any other party by which the city receives a tangible commodity or property, or a professional or nonprofessional service, except legal services. 
Purchased services means all nonconstruction purchased services including, but not limited to, financial services, consulting services, working bank, computer repair and janitorial services. 
Purchasing agent means the staff person designated by the city finance director to control the purchase of materials, machinery, equipment, services and supplies for the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(1))  
Sec. 10-304. - Duties of the purchasing agent. 
Under the supervision of the city finance director, the purchasing agent shall: 
(1)  Supervise, manage and control the purchase of supplies, materials and equipment for various city departments; 
(2)  Advertise for bids for purchases when required by state law or city ordinances or other directives of the city council; 
(3)  Maintain records and submit reports as directed by the city finance director, mayor or council; and 
(4)  Act as liaison with the state department of administration concerning city orders for bulk purchasing. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(2))  
Sec. 10-305. - Purchase of common goods and office supplies. 
All city departments shall order common office supplies, including copier paper, paper towels, stationery, etc., through the city purchasing agent. The city purchasing agent shall attempt to obtain discounts on common goods and office supplies through coordinating city orders with those of the state or other governmental agency for bulk purchasing. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(3))  
Sec. 10-306. - Purchase of services. 
All existing contracts for purchased services, regardless of degree of satisfaction, shall be reviewed by the finance committee no less frequently than once every three years, and shall be renegotiated or rebid as directed by a majority vote of the finance committee, under the direction of the city administrator and department heads responsible for the oversight of such purchased services. Selection of provider of a purchased service shall not be contingent solely on the lowest proposal received, but shall also consider the provider's qualifications, experience, and level of understanding of the scope of services to be performed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(4))  
Sec. 10-307. - General purchasing procedure. 
Purchases of city goods or services authorized by the adopted or amended city budget shall be accomplished as follows: 
(1)  Exceptions. Common goods and office supplies, monthly utility bills, monthly payments for employee benefits, payroll or payroll taxes, insurance, bonds, tax settlements with other taxing authorities, debt service payments, EMS contributions and metro bus payments and where the procedure would conflict with the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 62.15, 66.29, 66.295, other applicable state or federal laws or division 5 of this article. 
(2)  Major repairs or purchases. Repairs to infrastructure which exceed $10,000.00, or repairs which accumulate to and in a period of six months exceed $10,000.00 shall be reported to the finance committee prior to undertaking further repairs. 
(3)  Life cycle estimate. Purchase orders or contracts for materials, supplies or equipment may be awarded on the basis of life cycle cost estimates whenever that action is appropriate. The terms, conditions and evaluation criteria to be applied shall be incorporated into the solicitation of bids or proposals. The life cycle cost formula may include, but is not limited to, the applicable costs of energy efficiency, acquisition and conversion, money, transportation, warehousing and distribution, training, operation and maintenance, and disposition or resale. 
(4)  Intergovernmental or surplus stores purchases without bids. Notwithstanding any statute requiring bids for public purchases, the city may make purchases from another unit of government, including local, state or federal government, without the intervention of bids. This shall include the use of vendors identified through the state, county or other unit of government bid process. 
(5)  Sole source supplier without bids. Notwithstanding any statute requiring bids for public purchases, the city may make purchases from single source suppliers without the intervention of bids upon proof of exclusive product. Such documentation shall accompany purchase order or contract, and may be in memo form. 
(6)  Rejection of bids. The city reserves the right to reject any and all bid proposals so long as such rejections are reasonable and written explanations are provided. 
(7)  Purchase orders or contracts approved by finance director. Monthly utility bills, monthly payments for employee benefits, payroll or payroll taxes, insurance, bonds, tax settlements with other taxing authorities, debt service payments, EMS contributions and metro bus payments shall be considered usual and customary, regardless of amount, and shall be approved by the finance director. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(5); Ord. No. 2009-O-27, § 2.08(5)(i), (j), 12-8-2009) 
State Law reference Similar provisions, Wis. Stats. § 66.0131.  
Sec. 10-308. - Purchase orders or contractsFor less than $2,500.00. 
Purchase orders for goods or services costing less than $2,500.00 may be signed by the department head and the administrator with commitment toward obtaining the best value for the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(5); Ord. No. 2009-O-27, § 2.08(5)(i), (j), 12-8-2009)  
Sec. 10-309. - SameFor $2,500.00 to $25,000.00. 
Purchases or contracts for expenditure of $2,500.00 to $25,000.00 must receive at least three written estimates. The low quote shall be taken unless the department head provides written justification for exemption based on such issues as quality, prior performance, life-cycle cost and etc. All purchase orders in excess of $2,500.00 must be signed by the mayor. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(5); Ord. No. 2009-O-27, § 2.08(5)(i), (j), 12-8-2009)  
Sec. 10-310. - SameOver $25,000.00 but less than $50,000.00. 
(a)  Prior approval required. Purchase orders or draft contracts for capital equipment or projects over $25,000.00 but less than $50,000.00 must go to the finance committee for approval prior to the placing of any purchase order or final preparation of any contract documents for council consideration. A list of items to be presented to the finance committee for approval shall be included with the common council packet, and the finance committee shall report to the common council the action to be taken on those items. 
(b)  Solicitations for purchases of services. Service contracts over $25,000.00 but less than $50,000.00 must be publicly advertised in the official city newspaper and in either a recognized publication or in a Class 1 newspaper. 
(c)  Solicitations for purchases of goods and equipment. All city purchases of goods or equipment involving city expenditures of more than $25,000.00 but less than $50,000.00 shall be authorized only in accordance with the following procedures: 
(1)  Formal bid specifications shall be prepared by city staff and made available to all bidders through the appropriate department. 
(2)  Notice of availability of bid specifications shall be published in the official city newspaper and in a Class 1 newspaper and subject to a sealed bid opening at city hall with the city clerk present, with determination of low bidder contingent upon analysis of life-cycle costs as appropriate. 
(3)  A copy of the contract proposed to be approved must be provided to the clerk and available for public review at least five days prior to action of the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(5); Ord. No. 2009-O-27, § 2.08(5)(i), (j), 12-8-2009)  
Sec. 10-311. - SameFor services, goods or equipment over $50,000.00. 
All city purchases of services, goods or equipment involving city expenditures of more than $50,000.00 shall be authorized only in accordance with the following procedures: 
(1)  Specifications for bids, request for proposals or request for qualifications. Formal specifications or proposals shall be prepared by city staff and made available to all bidders through the purchasing agent. 
(2)  Notice required. Notice of availability of specifications or request for proposals shall be published in the official city newspaper and in a Class 1 newspaper and subject to a sealed bid opening at city hall with the city clerk present, with determination of low bidder contingent upon full analysis of life-cycle costs. 
(3)  Public review period. A copy of the contract proposed to be approved must be provided to the clerk and available for public review at least five days prior to action of the city council. 
(4)  Resolution required. A formal resolution shall be submitted for review and action by the committee and the city council. 
(5)  Performance bond required. Bidders on goods and contracts of $50,000.00 or more must provide a performance bond equal to or in excess of the contract as set forth in the bid specification, or, the city will reserve ten percent of the contract price to be released only upon verification of satisfactory performance. 
(6)  Letters of credit. The city may require a letter of credit equal to ten percent of the contract price for a period of one year following completion of a project. 
(7)  Insurances required. Contractors and any subcontractors shall be required to carry their own worker's compensation coverage and liability insurance coverage of at least $1,000,000.00 per incident. 
(8)  Role of finance committee in reviewing and approving bids. The department head or city administrator shall refer three or more bids or quotes to the committee, with sufficient information to permit the committee to determine the low bidder. The committee shall make a recommendation for the most qualified low bid or quote to the common council in the form of a resolution. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(5); Ord. No. 2009-O-27, § 2.08(5)(i), (j), 12-8-2009)  
Sec. 10-312. - Local businesses encouraged to bid. 
The purchasing agent shall maintain an up-to-date list of businesses and concerns in the city and the products and services which they sell, and consult such list when soliciting quotes for items to be purchased. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(6))  
Sec. 10-313. - Women and minority-owned businesses to be encouraged to bid. 
The city will actively seek bids from minority- and women-owned and operated business. This policy will be promoted by keeping lists of interested minority- and women-owned businesses which contact the city and by contacting, in advance, appropriate vendors who are listed in the state department of development pamphlets titled "Wisconsin Minority-Owned Business" and "Wisconsin Women-Owned Businesses." 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(7))  
Sec. 10-314. - Purchasing of recycled products. 
The city will, to the extent practicable, make purchasing selections based on the extent to which the products contain recovered or recycled material and are recyclable. The recovered or recycled product shall always be preferred, providing that it does not exceed the price of a similar nonrecovered or nonrecycled product or compromise established standards for desired quality. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(8))  
Sec. 10-315. - Paper purchases. 
(a)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Recovered or recycled products to be procured include, but are not limited to: 
(1)  Writing, computer and copy paper; 
(2)  Envelopes; 
(3)  Paper toweling and toilet tissue; 
(4)  Shop rags and/or wiping cloths; 
(5)  Motor oil and gear lubricant; 
(6)  Tires; 
(7)  Plastic bags and/or can liners; and 
(8)  Recycling bins. 
(b)  State guidelines applicable. The city shall adhere to state guidelines for paper purchasing, such that the recovered or recycled fiber content, by weight, of all paper purchases is not less than 40 percent. 
(c)  Printing. All purchases of printing, such as newsletters, mailings, and all other purchased printing, shall conform to the specifications listed in subsection (a) of this section. 
(d)  Notice in bid specification required. All bid specifications shall contain a notice specifying that recycled products are preferred and will receive preference in the bid process. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(7))  
Sec. 10-316. - Restrictions on December purchases. 
No purchases shall be made in December of equipment, professional services or nonessential items without written approval of the city administrator. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.08(9))  
Secs. 10-31710-335. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - EXPENDITURE OF CITY FUNDS 
 
Sec. 10-336. - Financial authority limited; records. 
(a)  Except as provided in this article, no agent of the city shall have any authority to employ labor or to purchase materials, supplies or any other commodities, bind the city or incur any indebtedness for which the city may become liable. 
(b)  Each such employment or purchase order shall be drawn against a specific appropriation, the money for which shall be available in the city treasury and not subject to any prior labor claims or material purchase orders at the time when such employment is negotiated or purchase order drawn. 
(c)  The city treasurer shall keep a record of such employment and purchase orders and shall charge them against the proper appropriation. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.09(3))  
Sec. 10-337. - State law applicable. 
All disbursements from the city treasury in satisfaction or payment of any bills, charges against the budget or other financial claims against the city shall be made pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0607 except as modified or supplemented by this section or other provisions of this Code or state law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.10(1))  
Sec. 10-338. - Issuance of city purchase orders. 
Purchase orders shall be issued and signed by department heads. It is the responsibility of the department head requesting the purchase order to provide all needed information, to ensure that funds have been budgeted to cover the requested expenditure and to designate the account to which the expenditure is to be charged. The department head has the responsibility and authority to refer any item to the city administrator where a question as to price, budget, adequacy, time of purchase, etc., exists. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.10(2))  
Sec. 10-339. - Payment of city funds. 
(a)  Documentation. The following documentation is required: 
(1)  A completed purchase order. 
(2)  Proof that the item or service has been received and is satisfactory. 
(3)  An invoice or other documentation from the vendor as authorized in the accounting procedures manual which has been verified as to quantity and price. 
(b)  Comptroller to review. The city comptroller shall review the documentation in subsection (a) of this section to ensure that all are in proper order and have been submitted. The city comptroller shall have the authority to request additional documentation when needed. 
(c)  Payment authorized and made. Payment will be authorized by Wis. Stats. § 66.0607(1) and made by the treasurer following the satisfactory completion of the procedure in subsection (a) of this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.10(2))  
Sec. 10-340. - Finance committee review of payments and city financial reports. 
Reports of payments and scheduled payments, except utility payments and employee salary payments, shall be regularly submitted to the common council and committee for their review. The reports shall contain the following information: check or invoice number, vendor, a description. The report of scheduled payments submitted to the committee shall also contain the account numbers. The committee may request additional information if needed to complete its review of the payments. The committee shall make recommendation to the common council based on its review. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.10(3))  
Sec. 10-341. - Common council review and approval. 
A list of payments shall be distributed to the common council members along with any comments or recommendations from the committee. Payments made in any other manner than prescribed in this subsection shall be subject to the special two-thirds vote of the common council and roll call requirements of Wis. Stats. § 66.0607(7). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.10(4))  
Sec. 10-342. - Facsimile signatures authorized. 
The signature of the mayor, clerk, and treasurer affixed to order checks of the city may be facsimile signatures of such officers adopted by them and approved by the common council on motion. The use of such facsimile signatures shall not relieve any of such officials from any liability to which they are otherwise subject, including the unauthorized use thereof. Upon enactment of this section and council approval of facsimile signatures adopted by the mayor, clerk and treasurer, the clerk shall file a certified copy of this section and of the approved facsimile signatures with the public depositories of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.10(5))  
Sec. 10-343. - Vouchers. 
All vouchers or orders against the city treasury shall be signed by the clerk (and mayor when required) attesting that the provisions of this division have been complied with. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.10(6))  
Sec. 10-344. - Tort claims. 
Compliance with the provisions of this division shall not relieve any claimant from compliance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 62.25, 893.80 or 895.46. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.10(7))  
Sec. 10-345. - Payment of regular wages or salaries. 
Payment of regular wages or salaries pursuant to the budget and salary schedule adopted by the common council shall be made by payroll, verified by the finance director and available in time for payment on the regular payday. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.10(8))  
Sec. 10-346. - Investments. 
The provisions of this division shall not apply to disbursements of city funds for purposes of investment under Wis. Stats. § 66.04(2). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.10(9))  
Secs. 10-34710-365. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - ASSETS 
 
Sec. 10-366. - Maintenance of accurate fixed asset reporting. 
(a)  All purchases of individual assets with an estimated useful life of five or more years, and an original value greater than $1,500.00 but less than $10,000.00, shall be listed on the fixed asset inventory maintained by department. Departmental fixed asset inventory list shall be reviewed by the department head and submitted annually in May to the finance director, showing additions and deletions of assets for the period since the last physical inventory. 
(b)  All purchases of assets with an estimated useful life of one or more years, and an original value greater than $10,000.00, shall be listed on the capitalized fixed asset inventory, which shall be maintained by the finance director. Upon physical delivery of an asset as described herein, the department head shall submit to the finance director a completed inventory description, including the make, model, vendor purchased from, estimated useful life, purchase price, and replacement value if significantly different from purchase price. A detailed listing of all additions and deletions of these assets will be completed annually. 
(c)  Physical inventory of assets except as noted in subsections 10-366(d), (e), and (f) shall be done annually in June. Departmental physical inventory shall be completed by a member of the department and a member of the finance department. Discrepancies between reported assets and physical inventory shall be reconciled and reported to the city administrator. 
(d)  Infrastructure assets of land, street lights, streets, sidewalks, bike paths, bridges, play structures affixed in parks, buildings and building improvements, will be listed separately and included as capitalized assets, if the original value exceeds $10,000.00, but will not be physically inventoried annually. A detailed listing of all additions and deletions of these assets will be completed annually. 
(e)  Intangible assets including easements, water rights, timber rights, patents, trademarks, and computer software (either purchased or internally written) will not be physically inventoried. A detailed listing of all additions and deletions of these assets will be completed annually.
