(f)  Utility assets and infrastructure will be recorded in compliance with public service commission rules. A detailed listing of all additions and deletions of these assets, with a useful life greater than five years and an original value of greater than $10,000.00 will be completed annually. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.11(1); Ord. No. 2014-O-08, 3-18-2014)  
Sec. 10-367. - Management and sale of surplus assets. 
(a)  Disposal. Disposal of surplus assets shall be prohibited, except as authorized in this division. 
(b)  Notification and listing of surplus assets. Should a department replace an asset which may still be of use to another city department, or which is anticipated to be sold; such asset should be reported in writing to the finance director as surplus. Notification shall include a description of the asset, including asset number, approximate value, location where the surplus item is to be stored and date the asset is no longer in service. The finance director shall prepare a notice of the surplus asset, and distribute to all departments. 
(c)  Request for transfer of surplus item to active use. Should a surplus asset be of value to a city department, department head should notify the finance director in writing. Notification shall include a description of the asset, including asset number, location where the surplus item is to be used and date the asset is put into service. 
(d)  Trade-in exception. Should an asset be utilized as a trade-in to reduce the cost of a newly purchased replacement item, department head should notify the finance director in writing. Notification shall include a description of the asset, including asset number, trade-in allowance, and date the asset is no longer in service. 
(e)  Obsolescence or items for disposal. Should an asset that has been previously included on either a departmental fixed asset inventory or the capitalized fixed asset inventory be deemed of no value due to obsolescence, damage or disrepair, the department head should notify the finance director in writing of the desire to dispose of such item. Notification shall be through completion of a disposal of fixed asset form available from the finance director. Fixed assets may not be disposed of until approved by the city administrator in writing. 
(f)  Sale of assets. Should an asset be deemed of value, but not of use to the city, the city administrator shall direct that a notice be posted to offer the item to the highest bidder via a sealed bid process. The city retains the right to reject any or all bids. 
(g)  Contents of notice. The notice shall contain a description of the asset, minimum bid if any, and the date, time and location of the bid opening. Copies of the notification of asset sale shall be provided to the mayor and common council. 
(h)  Establishing minimum bid. If the value of the asset is estimated to be less than $5,000.00, the city administrator shall set the minimum bid. If the value of the asset is estimated to be greater than $5,000.00, the finance committee shall set the minimum bid. If the minimum bid is greater than $10,000.00, notice shall also be placed in newspapers, magazines or other media as deemed appropriate to obtain sufficient bid responses. The finance committee must approve the sale of assets with a minimum bid value greater than $10,000.00. 
(i)  Surplus auction exception. If the asset is placed for sale through a bona fide surplus auction, requirements in subsections 10-367(f) (sealed bid), (g) (bid notice) and (h) (minimum bid), may be waived. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.11(2), (3); Ord. No. 2014-O-08, 3-18-2014)  
Sec. 10-368. - Insurance coverage. 
The finance director shall notify the city clerk of assets which should be added to or removed from city insurances. All fixed assets shall be insured for property damage; vehicles, apparatus and contractor's equipment shall also be reported to the general liability insurer. The city clerk shall maintain a central file for warranties and other information related to the servicing under warranty for fixed assets. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.11(4))  
Sec. 10-369. - Repair logs and vehicle records. 
Departments shall maintain a detailed log of in-house and out-sourced repairs and maintenance, including time out of service and costs associated with repairs, to assist in determining the need for equipment replacement. The city clerk shall maintain a central file for each vehicle including certification of insurance coverage, title, and copy of fixed asset inventory card listing. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.11(5))  
Sec. 10-370. - Use of city facilities. 
Policies for the rental or other private use of each city owned facility shall be reviewed and updated as necessary, including any fees or charges established. Such policy shall be approved by the finance committee and common council by resolution, and kept on file with the city clerk. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.11(6))  
Secs. 10-37110-398. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - AUDITS[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference Local government audits and reports, Wis. Stats. § 66.0605. 
 
Sec. 10-399. - Annual audit of city accounts. 
The council shall budget for and require an annual detailed audit of financial transactions and accounts by the bureau of municipal audit in the state department of revenue or by a certified public accountant, licensed by the state, with expertise in municipal audits. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.12(1))  
Sec. 10-400. - Contents of audit. 
The audit shall include a separate review of the city's financial records and a statement of opinion on the financial reports together with a management letter detailing improvements that can be made in the financial administration of the city, and the city water utility. An audit contract may be made to include an operational review of one or more aspects of the city, or city water utility operations. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.12(2))  
Sec. 10-401. - Distribution of audit report. 
Copies of the completed audit report shall be transmitted to the mayor and council members within ten days of receipt. Copies will also be placed on file with the city clerk. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 2.12(3))  
Secs. 10-40210-430. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - PUBLIC WORKS PROJECTS[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference Municipal public works, contracts, and bids, Wis. Stats. § 66.0901. 
 
Sec. 10-431. - Contracts; how let. 
(a)  Purpose. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 62.15(1) and (6) and 66.0901, whenever the city lets public works by contract with an estimated construction cost greater than $1,000,000.00, the contract must be awarded to the lowest responsible bidder. What constitutes a responsible bidder is a determination that requires the exercise of discretion by the city. This section is intended to ensure that bids are reviewed by the city and its departments, officials or employees under reasonably consistent responsible bidder criteria when exercising its discretion. 
(1)  Definitions. In this section, the following definitions shall apply. 
Contractor means a person, corporation, partnership or any other business entity that performs work on a public works contract as a general contractor, prime contractor or subcontractor at any tier. 
Public works contract means a contract for the construction, alteration, execution, repair, remodeling or improvement of a public work or building, where the contract is required to be bid pursuant to Wis. Stats. § [59.52(29) for counties; 62.15(1) and (6) for cities; 61.54 and 62.15(1) and (6) for villages; 60.47(3) for towns]. 
(2)  Responsible bidder criteria. In order to be a responsible bidder for purposes of being awarded a public works contract, the contractor must meet the following criteria. 
a.  The contractor maintains a permanent place of business. 
b.  The contractor is authorized to do business in the State of Wisconsin. 
c.  The contractor shall participate in a State of Wisconsin approved apprenticeship program, or participates in a State of Wisconsin-certified pre-apprenticeship program in lieu of (or in addition to) registered apprentices, or have a written alternative training program sufficient to ensure that its employees may safely perform the work required by the public works contract. 
d.  The contractor, or agent, partner, employee or officer of the contractor, is not debarred, suspended, proposed for debarment or declared ineligible from contracting with any unit of federal, state or local government. 
e.  The contractor is in compliance with provisions of Section 2000e of Chapter 21, Title 42 of the United States Code and Federal Executive Order No. 11246 as amended by Executive Order No. 11375 (known as the Equal Opportunity Employer provisions). 
f.  The contractor has general liability, workers' compensation, unemployment, and automobile insurance at levels sufficient to protect the city given the size of the public works. 
g.  The contractor has complied with all provisions of Wisconsin prevailing wage law and federal Davis-Bacon related Acts, and all rules and regulations therein, for projects undertaken by the contractor that are covered by these laws, for the past five years. 
h.  The contractor has a written substance abuse prevention program meeting the requirements of Wis. Stats. § 103.503. As required by Wis. Stats. § 103.503, all employees must be subject to drug and alcohol testing before commencing work on the public works project, except that testing of an employee before commencing work on a project is not required if the employee has been participating in a random testing program during the 90 days preceding the date on which the employee commenced work on the public works project. 
i.  The employees who will perform work on the project are properly classified as employees or independent contractors under all applicable state and federal laws. 
j.  The contractor has not been the subject of any investigation, order or judgment from any state or federal agency or court concerning an employment practice, including, but not limited to, classification of employees, unemployment insurance, or discrimination. If the contractor has been the subject of any investigation, order or judgment from any state or federal agency or court concerning an employment practice, the contractor must provide copies of the investigation, order or judgment. The city shall review the investigation, order or judgment and determine whether the facts and circumstances are such that the contractor is not a responsible bidder. 
k.  The contractor's employees who will perform work on the project are: 
1.  Covered under a current workers' compensation policy; and 
2.  Properly classified under such policy. 
l.  The contractor possesses all applicable professional and trade licenses required for performing the public works. 
m.  The contractor has adequate financial resources to complete the public works contract, as well as all other work the bidder is presently under contract to complete. 
n.  The contractor is bondable for the terms of the proposed public works contract. 
o.  The contractor has a record of satisfactorily completing at least five projects of similar size and complexity within the last five years. Criteria which will be considered in determining satisfactory completion of projects may include, but are not limited to: 
1.  Completion of contracts in accordance with drawings and specifications; 
2.  Diligent execution of the work and completed contracts according to the established time schedules unless extensions are granted by the owner; and 
3.  Fulfilled guarantee requirements of the contract documents. 
For projects that are unique and/or utilize new technology, the public works director may accept a list of comparable projects to satisfy this requirement. 
p.  The contractor has, and diligently maintains, a written safety program. 
q.  The contractor was not placed in OSHA's severe violator enforcement program in the previous two years. 
(3)  No restriction on discretion. If information other than what must be disclosed by the contractor in subsection (2) is discovered by the city or the department, official or employee responsible for awarding the public works contract, and such information calls into question the contractor's capacity or competence to faithfully and responsibly comply with the terms of a public works contract, that information shall be considered in determining whether the contractor is a responsible bidder. 
(4)  Affidavit of compliance. The general or prime contractor bidding on a public works project must include in its sealed bid; its own affidavit swearing compliance with the criteria set forth in subsection (2) on the form required by the city. 
Failure to submit the required affidavit, or providing incorrect, false, or misleading information shall automatically disqualify the contractor's bid. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.01; Ord. No 2009-O-33, § 1, 12-8-2009; Ord. No. 2020-O-06 , § 1, 1-28-2020)  
Sec. 10-432. - Escalator clauses. 
(a)  Contracts may include escalator clauses providing for additional charges for labor and materials if as a result of general inflation the rates and prices of the same to the contractor increase during performance of the contract. Such escalator provision shall be applicable to all bidders and shall not exceed 15 percent of the amount of the firm bid nor the amount of the increase paid by the contractor. 
(b)  Each bid on a contract which is to include an escalator provision shall be accompanied by a schedule enumerating the estimated rates and prices of items of labor and materials used in arriving at the bid. Only as to such items as are enumerated shall an increased charge be allowed the contractor. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.02)  
Sec. 10-433. - Exception as to public emergency. 
The notice and bidding requirements of this division and the preapproval provisions of Wis. Stats. § 281.41 are not mandatory for the repair and reconstruction of public facilities when damage or threatened damage thereto creates an emergency in which the public health or welfare of the city is endangered, as determined by resolution of the board of public works. Whenever the common council determines by majority vote at a regular or special meeting that such emergency no longer exists, this subsection no longer applies. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.03)  
Sec. 10-434. - Increased quantity clauses. 
Contracts may include clauses providing for increasing the quantity of construction required in the original contract by an amount not to exceed 15 percent of the original contract price. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.04)  
Sec. 10-435. - Plans; contract; bond. 
When the work is required or directed to be let to the lowest responsible bidder, the board of public works shall oversee the preparation of plans and specifications for the same, containing a description of the work, the materials to be used and such other matters as will give an intelligent idea of the work required and file the same with the city clerk for the inspection of bidders, and shall also oversee the preparation of a form of contract and bond with sureties required, and furnish a copy of the same to all persons desiring to bid on the work and shall in other respects follow the procedures of Wis. Stats. §§ 62.15, 66.0901, and 66.0903. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.05)  
Sec. 10-436. - Advertisement for bids; bid bonds. 
(a)  After the plans, specifications, and form of contract have been prepared, the board of public works shall advertise for proposals for doing such work by publishing a Class 2 notice under Wis. Stats. ch. 985. 
(b)  No bid shall be received unless accompanied by a certified check or a bid bond equal to at least five percent but not more than ten percent of the bid payable to the city as a guaranty that if the bid is accepted the bidder will execute and file the proper contract and bond within the time limited by the city. 
(c)  If the successful bidder so files the contract and bond, upon the execution of the contract by the city the check shall be returned. In case the successful bidder fails to file such contract and bond, the amount of the check or bid bond shall be forfeited to the city as liquidated damages. 
(d)  The notice published shall inform bidders of this requirement. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.06)  
Sec. 10-437. - Sureties justification; cash in lieu of surety. 
The sureties shall justify as to their responsibility and by their several affidavits show that they are worth in the aggregate at least the amount mentioned in the contract in property not by law exempt from execution. A certified check in amount equal to five percent of the bid, and a provision in the contract for the retention by the city of 20 percent of the estimates made from time to time may be accepted in place of sureties. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.07)  
Sec. 10-438. - Substantial compliance. 
If any certified check or bid bond is in substantial compliance with the minimum guaranty requirements of this division, the board of public works may, in its discretion, accept such check or bid bond and allow such bidder 30 days to furnish such additional guaranty as may be required by said authority. Substantial compliance hereunder may be found if said check or bond is insufficient by not more than one-fourth of one percent of the bid. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.08)  
Sec. 10-439. - Rejection of bids. 
The power to reject any and all bids shall exist unless expressly waived. The board of public works may reject any and all bids, if, in its opinion, any combination has been entered into to prevent free competition. The common council may, if it be of the opinion that any of the bids are fraudulent, collusive, excessive or against the best interests of the city, by resolution adopted by two-thirds of its members, reject any or all of the bids received and order the work done by the city directly under the supervision of the board of public works. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.09)  
Sec. 10-440. - Incompetent or unreliable bidders. 
Whenever any bidder shall be, in the judgment of the board of public works, incompetent or otherwise unreliable for the performance of the work on which it bids, the board shall report to the common council a schedule of all the bids for such work, together with a recommendation to accept the bid of the lowest responsible bidder, with reasons; and thereupon the common council may direct the board either to let the work to such competent and reliable bidder or to readvertise the same. Failure to let such contract to the lowest bidder in compliance with this provision shall not invalidate such contract or any special assessment made to pay the liability incurred thereunder. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.10)  
Sec. 10-441. - Patented material or process. 
Any public work, whether chargeable in whole or in part to the city, or to any lots or parcels of land therein, may be done by the use of a patented article, materials or process, in whole or in part, or in combination with articles, materials, or processes not patented, when the city shall have obtained from the owner of the patented article, materials or process, before advertising for bids for such work, an agreement to furnish to any contractor desiring to bid upon such work as a whole, the right to use the patented article, materials and processes in the construction of said work, and also to furnish to any contractor the patented article itself upon the payment of what the board of public works shall determine to be a reasonable price therefor, which price shall be publicly stated and furnished upon application to any contractor desiring to bid on said work. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.11)  
Sec. 10-442. - Alternative plans and specifications. 
Different plans and specifications requiring the use of different kinds of materials, whether patented or not, may be prepared for any public work under the supervision of the board of public works, thereby bringing one kind of article, material or process in competition with one or more other kinds of articles, materials or processes designed to accomplish the same general purpose; and bids may be received for each such kind of article, material or process; and thereafter, a contract let for one kind of article, material or process; provided, before any contract is let, all the bids received shall be opened and considered before the kind of article or process to be used in such work shall be decided upon by the board, and thereupon the city engineer shall determine which kind of article, material or process shall be used in the work, and the contract shall be let to the lowest responsible bidder for the kind of article, material or process so selected for use in the proposed public work. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.12)  
Sec. 10-443. - Guaranty. 
Any contract for doing public work may contain a provision requiring the contractor to keep the work done under such contract in good order or repair for not more than five years after completion. The inclusion in the contract of any such provision shall not invalidate any special assessment or certificate thereof or tax sale certificate based thereon. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.13)  
Sec. 10-444. - Estimates; deposit; default; completion. 
(a)  As the work progresses under any contract for the performance of which a surety bond has been furnished, Wis. Stats. § 66.0901 shall apply. 
(b)  All contracts shall contain a provision authorizing the board of public works, in case the work under any contract is defaulted or not completed within the time required, to take charge of or authorize the surety to take charge of the work and finish it at the expense of the contractor and the sureties, and to apply the amounts retained from estimates to the completion of the work. In no case shall the five percent deposit described in this division be returned to a successful bidder until the contract is performed; but it, together with the retained amounts, shall be used in whole or in part to complete the work. 
(c)  Any amount remaining from the deposit or from retained estimates after the completion of the contract shall be paid to the contractor. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.14)  
Sec. 10-445. - Street obstruction. 
All contractors doing any work which shall in any manner obstruct the streets or sidewalks shall put up and maintain barriers and lights to prevent accidents, and be liable for all damages caused by failure so to do. All contracts shall contain a provision covering this liability, and also a provision making the contractor liable for all damages caused by the negligent digging up of streets, alleys or public grounds, or which may result from his/her carelessness in the prosecution of such work. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.15)  
Sec. 10-446. - Contracts; how executed. 
All contracts shall be signed by the mayor and city administrator unless otherwise provided by resolution or ordinance, and approved as to form by the city attorney. No contract shall be executed on the part of the city until the city administrator shall have countersigned the same and made an endorsement thereon showing that sufficient funds are in the treasury to meet the expense thereof, or that provision has been made to pay the liability that will accrue thereunder. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.16)  
Sec. 10-447. - Report to common council of nonbid contracts. 
(a)  Whenever the common council shall have provided that any class of public work or any part thereof may be done directly by the city without submitting the same for bids, and any such public work shall be done in accordance with such ordinance, the board of public works shall keep an accurate account of the cost thereof, including the necessary overhead expense. 
(b)  Upon the completion of such work the board of public works shall make a complete report thereof to the common council, stating in detail the items of cost and the total cost of doing such work, and the city clerk shall publish such report as part of the proceedings of the common council. 
(c)  Any member of the board of public works who fails to comply with the provisions of this section shall be liable to a forfeiture of $50.00 to be recovered as in the case of other penalties. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 18.17)  
Chapter 12 - CITY RECORDS AND PROPERTY  
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 12-1. - Custody and delivery of public records and property. 
(a)  The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Property and things includes, but not be limited to, the following: documents, records, files, papers, handwritten, typed or printed pages, drafts, notes, informal notations, preliminary computations, points with authorities, and other materials prepared either as records or for the purpose of preserving remembrance or memory of what the author had done to discharge the duties of his/her office or employment, files, maps, surveys, charts, photographs, films, recordings, tapes (including computer tapes), computer printouts, monies, books, and furniture, pertaining to, belonging to, or preserved in his/her office of employment. 
Record means any material on which written, drawn, printed, spoken, visual or electromagnetic information is recorded or preserved, regardless of physical form of characteristics, which has been created or is being kept by said authority. 
(b)  Except as provided under article IV of this chapter, each and every officer and employee of the city is the legal custodian of and shall safely keep and preserve without exception all property and things: 
(1)  Which are received from his/her predecessor or other persons and required by law to be filed, deposited or kept in his/her office; 
(2)  Which are in the lawful possession or control of his/her deputies; or 
(3)  Which possession, or control he/she may be lawfully entitled, as such officers or employees. 
(c)  Upon the expiration of his/her term of office or employment, or whenever his/her office or position of employment becomes vacant, each such officer or employee or on his/her death, his/her legal representative shall deliver to his/her successor all such property and things without exception then in his/her custody, and his/her successor shall receipt to said officer or employee, who shall file said receipt with the city clerk. 
(d)  If a vacancy occurs before such successor is qualified, all such property and things without exception shall be delivered to and be receipted for by the city clerk, on behalf of the successor, to be delivered to such successor upon the latter's receipt. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.02; Ord. No. 2016-O-03, 1-26-2016)  
Secs. 12-212-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC ACCESS TO RECORDS 
 
Sec. 12-21. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Authority means any of the following having custody of a city record: a local office, elected or appointed official, agency, board, commission, committee, council, department or public body corporate and politic created by constitution, law, ordinance, rule or order; or a formally constituted subunit of any of the foregoing. The term "authorities" include, but is not limited to, the city clerk, who shall also have custody of the records of the city council; the deputy clerk, the treasurer, police chief, fire chief, clerk of municipal court, director of welfare, utility manager, the assessor, the building inspector, the superintendent of highways, the parks commission, the civil service commission, the attorney, the accountant, the engineer, the environmental inspector, the civil defense commission, the cable commission and such other authorities as may be established or created from time to time unless at the time of their establishment or creation some other custodian is expressly designated. 
Record means any material on which written, drawn, printed, spoken, visual or electromagnetic information is recorded or preserved, regardless of physical form or characteristics, which has been created or is being kept by an authority. The term "record" includes, but is not limited to, handwritten, typed or printed pages, maps, charts, photographs, films, recordings, tapes (including computer tapes), and computer printouts. The term "record" does not include drafts, notes, preliminary computations and like materials prepared for the originator's personal use or prepared by the originator in the name of a person for whom the originator is working unless and until such materials are submitted to an authority for its review, consideration or action; materials which are purely the personal property of the custodian and have no relation to his/her office; materials to which access is limited by copyright, patent or bequest; and published materials in the possession of an authority other than a public library which are available for sale, or which are available for Inspection at a public library. 
Requester means any person who requests inspection or copies of a record. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.04)  
Sec. 12-22. - Declaration of policy. 
(a)  In recognition of the fact that a representative government is dependent upon an informed electorate, it is declared to be the public policy of the city that all persons are entitled to the greatest possible information regarding the affairs of government and the official acts of those officers and employees who represent them. Further, providing persons with such information is declared to be an essential function of a representative government and an integral part of the routine duties of officers and employees whose responsibility it is to provide such information. 
(b)  To that end, this article shall be construed in every instance with a presumption of complete public access, consistent with the conduct of government business. The denial of public access generally is contrary to the public interest, and only in an exceptional case may access be denied. 
(c)  Any matters pertaining to public access to records which are not included in this article is governed by Wis. Stats. §§ 19.31 through 19.39 and other applicable sections of state law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.03)  
Sec. 12-23. - Legal custodians; authorities and their designates. 
(a)  An elected or appointed official is the legal custodian of his/her records and the records of his/her office, but the official may designate an employee of his/her staff to act as the legal custodian. 
(b)  The chairperson of a committee, commission or board of elected or appointed officials, or the designee or the chairperson, is the legal custodian of the records of the committee. 
(c)  The co-chairpersons of a joint committee, commission or board of elected or appointed officials, or the designee of the co-chairpersons, are the legal custodians of the records of the joint committee, commission or board. 
(d)  Every authority not specified in this section shall designate in writing one or more positions occupied by an officer or employee of the authority or the unit of government of which it is a part as a legal custodian to fulfill its duties under this article. In the absence of a designation the authority's highest ranking officer and the chief administrative officer, if any, are the legal custodians for the authority. 
(e)  The legal custodian shall be vested by the authority with full legal power to render decisions and carry out the duties of the authority under this article. Each authority shall provide the name of the legal custodian and a description of the nature of his/her duties under this article to all employees of the authority entrusted with records subject to the legal custodian's supervision. 
(f)  The legal custodian of records maintained in a publicly owned or leased building or the authority appointing the legal custodian shall designate one or more deputies to act as legal custodian of such records in his/her absence or as otherwise required to respond to requests as provided in this article. 
(g)  The designation of a legal custodian does not affect the powers and duties of an authority under this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.05)  
Sec. 12-24. - Right of inspection. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided by law, any requester has a right to inspect any record. Substantive common law principles construing the right to inspect, copy or receive copies of records shall remain in effect. The exemptions to the requirement of a governmental body to meet in open session under section Wis. Stats. § 19.85 are indicative of public policy, but may be used as grounds for denying public access to a record only if the authority or legal custodian makes a specific demonstration that there is a need to restrict public access at the time that the request to inspect or copy the record is made. 
(b)  Except as otherwise provided by law, any requester has a right to inspect a record and to make or receive a copy of a record which appears in written form. If a requester requests a copy of the record, the authority having custody of the record may, at his/her option, permit the requester to photocopy the record or provide the requester with a copy substantially as readable as the original. 
(c)  Except as otherwise provided by law, any requester has a right to receive from an authority having custody of a record which is in the form of a comprehensible audio tape recording, a copy of the tape recording substantially as audible as the original. The authority may instead provide a transcript of the recording to the requester if he/she requests. 
(d)  Except as otherwise provided by law, any requester has a right to receive from an authority having custody of a record which is in the form of a videotape recording a copy of the tape recording substantially as good as the original. 
(e)  Except as otherwise provided by law, any requester has a right to inspect any record not specified in this section the form of which does not permit copying. If a requester requests permission to photograph the record, the authority having custody of the record may permit the requester to photograph the record. If a requester requests that a photograph of the record be provided, the authority shall provide a good quality photograph of the record. 
(f)  This section does not apply to a record which has been or will be promptly published with copies offered for sale or distribution. 
(g)  Notwithstanding any provision of this section to the contrary, a legal custodian may impose reasonable restrictions on the manner of access to an original record if the record is irreplaceable or easily damaged. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.06(1); Ord. No. 2016-O-03, 1-26-2016)  
Sec. 12-25. - Facilities. 
The authority shall provide any person who is authorized to inspect or copy a record with facilities comparable to those used by city employees to inspect, copy, and abstract the record during established business hours. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.06(2))  
Sec. 12-26. - Fees. 
(a)  The requester shall be charged for photocopying. The fees charged by custodians for photocopies shall be uniform, shall be set by the city council, and shall not exceed the actual, necessary, and direct cost of reproduction 
(b)  The requester shall be charged the actual, necessary, and direct cost of photographing and photographic processing if the custodian provides a photograph of any record, the form of which does not permit copying. 
(c)  The requester shall be charged the actual, necessary, and direct cost of transcribing any tape recording whenever a transcript has not been and would not ordinarily be prepared by the authority but for the request. 
(d)  The requester shall be charged the actual, necessary and direct, cost of reproducing any film, computer printouts, and audio or video recordings. 
(e)  The requester shall be charged the actual, necessary and direct cost of mailing or shipping. 
(f)  The charge for locating a record shall be established as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule, in which case the actual, necessary, and direct cost of location shall be determined by the authority and charged to the requester. 
(g)  An authority may require prepayment by a requester of any fees imposed under this subsection if the total amount exceeds the amount as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. 
(h)  Elected and appointed officials of the city shall not be required to pay for copies of records reasonably required for the proper performance of their official duties. 
(i)  An authority may provide copies of a record without charge or at a reduced charge where he/she determines that waiver or reduction of the fee is in the public interest. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.06(3))  
Sec. 12-27. - Access procedure. 
(a)  Availability of records. A requester may have access to records during all regular office hours at the location where the records are kept. If a record of any authority is occasionally taken to a location other than the location where records of that authority are regularly kept, the record shall be made available for inspection at the place where it is regularly kept upon one business day's notice. 
(b)  Making a request. A request to inspect or copy a record shall be made to the authority or custodian. A request shall be deemed sufficient if it reasonably describes the requested record or the information requested. However, a request for a record without a reasonable limitation as to subject matter or length of time represented by the record does not constitute a sufficient request. A request may be made orally or in writing. 
(c)  Filling a request. Each custodian, upon request for any record, shall, as soon as practicable and without delay, either fill the request or notify the person making the request of the custodian's determination to deny the request in whole or in part and the reasons therefor. If the custodian determines that a written request is so general as to be unduly time consuming, the party making the request may first be required to itemize his/her request in a manner which would permit reasonable compliance. 
(d)  Denial of a request. If a request is made orally, the custodian may deny it orally unless a demand for a written statement of the reasons for denying the request is made by the requester within five business days of the oral denial. If a written request is denied in whole or in part, a written statement of the reasons for denying the request shall be given to the requester. Every written denial of a request shall inform the requester that where a request is made in writing, the denial is subject to review upon petition for a writ of mandamus in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 19.37(1). 
(e)  Restrictions on inspection. The authority or custodian may require supervision during inspection or may impose other reasonable restrictions on the manner of access to an original record if the record is irreplaceable or easily damaged. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.07)  
Secs. 12-2812-57. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - LIMITATIONS ON ACCESS TO RECORDS 
 
Sec. 12-58. - Exempt records. 
The following records shall be exempt from inspection: 
(1)  Records specifically exempted from disclosure by state or federal law or authorized to be exempted from disclosure by state law. 
(2)  Any record relating to investigative information obtained for law enforcement purposes if federal law or regulations require exemption from disclosure or if exemption from disclosure is a condition to receipt of aids by the state. 
(3)  Computer programs, although the material used as input for a computer program or the material produced as a product of the computer program shall be subject to inspection. 
(4)  A record or any portion of a record containing information qualifying as a common law trade secret. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.08(1))  
Sec. 12-59. - Potential harm to public interest. 
An authority may deny a request to inspect a record which is not specifically exempt from disclosure, in whole or in part, only if he/she determines that the harm to the public interest resulting from disclosure would outweigh the public interest in full access to the requested record. Inspection may be denied, for example, when the requisite determination has been made and: 
(1)  The records were obtained under official pledges of confidentiality which were necessary and given in order to obtain the information contained in them. 
(2)  The record relates to current deliberations in a quasi-judicial hearing. 
(3)  The record relates to current deliberations concerning employment, dismissal, promotion, demotion, compensation, performance or discipline or any city officer or employee, or the investigation of charges against a city officer or employee, unless such officer or employee consents to disclosure. 
(4)  The record relates to the formulation of current strategy for crime detection or prevention. 
(5)  The record relates to current deliberations or negotiations concerning the purchase of public property, investment of public funds, or other public business whenever competitive or bargaining reasons require nondisclosure. 
(6)  The record contains financial, medical, social or personal histories or disciplinary data of specific persons which, if disclosed, would be likely to have a substantial adverse effect upon the reputation of any person referred to in such history or data. 
(7)  The record contains communications between legal counsel for the city and any officer, agent or employee of the city, wherein advice is rendered concerning strategy with respect to litigation in which the city or any of its officers, agents or employees is or is likely to become involved. 
(8)  The record is subject to any privilege created by Wis. Stats. ch. 905. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.08(2); Ord. No. 2016-O-03, 1-26-2016)  
Sec. 12-60. - Mixed records. 
If a record contains a mixture of information that may be made public and of information that may not be made public, the authority shall provide the information that may be made public and delete the information that may not be made public from the record before permitting the record to be inspected. If, in the judgment of the authority, there is no feasible way to separate the exempt material from the nonexempt material without unreasonably jeopardizing nondisclosure of the exempt material, the entire record shall be withheld from disclosure. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.08(3))  
Sec. 12-61. - Confidentiality of certain financial records provided to the city assessor. 
(a)  Whenever the assessor, in the performance of the assessor's duties, requests or obtains income and expense information pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 70.47(7)(af) or any successor statute thereto, then, such income and expense information that is provided to the assessor shall be held by the assessor on a confidential basis; except, however, that the information may be revealed to and used by persons in the discharging of duties imposed by law, in the discharge of duties imposed by office (including, but not limited to, use by the assessor in performance of official duties of the assessor's office and use by the board of review in performance of its official duties), or pursuant to order of a court. 
(b)  Income and expense information provided to the assessor under Wis. Stats. § 70.47(7)(af), unless a court determines that it is inaccurate, is pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 70.47(7)(af) not subject to the right of inspection and copying under Wis. Stats. § 19.35(1). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.08(4))  
Secs. 12-6212-80. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DESTRUCTION OF RECORDS 
 
Secs. 12-81. - Retention schedule. 
Records shall be retained pursuant to the schedule attached as approved by the State of Wisconsin Public Records Board on August 19, 2013. Following expiration of the retention period approved by the public records board, obsolete records may be destroyed.

Legend: 
CR: Creation date 
EVT: Event 
FIS: Fiscal Year 
J: Job hire date 
P: Permanent 
T: Termination 
ACT: Active 
SUP: Suspended 
SHSW: State Historical Society of Wisconsin 
WMRM: Wisconsin Municipal Records Manual 
§: State Statute 
SCR: Supreme Court Rule 
PSC: Public Service Commission 
NR: Natural Resources 
W: Notification requirement waived 
N: Notification required 
N/A: Not applicable and applies to any record designated for permanent retention with the original custodian 
****** Due to the increasing use of electronic media, the majority of records will be saved in this format - 12-87 City Code of Ordinances ****** 
(Ord. No. 2016-O-03, 1-26-2016) 
Editor's note Ord. No. 2016-O-03, adopted January 26, 2016, amended the Code by repealing former §§ 12-8112-83. Former §§ 12-8112-83 pertained to financial records, utility records, and obsolete records, respectively, and derived from the Compiled Ordinances of 2009, §§ 19.09(1)(3). Ord. No. 2016-O-03 also added provisions designated as a new § 12-81 at the discretion of the editor.  
Secs. 12-82, 12-83. - Reserved.  
Sec. 12-84. - Historical records. 
Under Wis. Stats. § 19.21(4)(a) local governments must notify the State Historical Society of Wisconsin (SHSW) 60 days prior to destroying records. The SHSW has waived the required 60-day notice for any record designated "waived" (notification requirement waived) in the city's record retention schedule. The SHSW must be notified 60 days prior to destruction of any record designated with "Notify" (notification required). The term "N/A" indicates not applicable and applies to any record designated for permanent retention with the original custodian. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.09(4); Ord. No. 2016-O-03, 1-26-2016)  
Sec. 12-85. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 2016-O-03, adopted January 26, 2016, amended the Code by repealing former § 12-85. Former § 12-85 pertained to tape recordings and derived from the Compiled Ordinances of 2009, § 19.09(5).  
Sec. 12-86. - Police department records. 
City officers may destroy police department records as described in the "City Police Department Records Retention Schedule" dated July 9, 1998, as revised May 20, 2006. The police department will follow their records retention policy and procedure for the destruction of records. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.09(6))  
Sec. 12-87. - Preservation on microfilm. 
Any authority or custodian may, subject to the approval of the city council, keep and preserve public records in its possession by means of microfilm or other photographic reproduction method. Such records shall meet the standards for photographic reproduction set forth in state law and shall be considered original records for all purposes. Such records shall be preserved along with other files of the department or division and shall be open to public inspection and copying according to the provisions of state law and this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 19.10)  
Chapter 14 - CODE OF ETHICS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Code of ethics for public officials and employees, Wis. Stats. § 19.41 et seq.; codes of ethics for local government officials, employees and candidates, Wis. Stats. § 19.59. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 14-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Anything of value means any money or property, favor, service, payment, advance, forbearance, loan, or promise of future employment, but does not include compensation and expenses paid by the city, fees honorariums and expenses which are permitted and reported under Wis. Stats. § 19.56, political contributions which are reported under Wis. Stats. ch. 11, or hospitality extended for a purpose unrelated to city business by a person other than an organization. 
Associated , when used with reference to an organization, includes any organization in which a person or a member of his/her immediate family is a director, officer or trustee, or owns or controls, directly or indirectly, and severally or in the aggregate, at least ten percent of the outstanding equity. 
Candidate for public office means any person who files nomination papers and a declaration under Wis. Stats. ch. 8 for the purpose of appearing on the ballot for election as a city public official or any person nominated for the purpose of appearing on the ballot for election as a city public official through the write in process and who files a declaration under Wis. Stats. ch. 8. 
City public office means all officers of the city established pursuant to Wis. Stats. ch. 62 who are elected by the voters or appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the common council. 
City public official means any person holding a city public office. 
Gift means the payment or receipt of anything of value without valuable consideration. 
Immediate family means a person's spouse and a person's relative by marriage, lineal descent or adoption who receives, directly or indirectly, more than one-half of his/her support from such person or from whom such person receives, directly or indirectly, more than one-half of his/her support. 
Income has the meaning given under the U.S. Internal Revenue Code, 26 USC 1 et seq. 
Ministerial action means an action that a person performs in a given state of facts in a prescribed manner in obedience to the mandate of legal authority, without regard to the exercise of the person's own judgment as to the propriety of the action being taken. 
Nominee means any person who is nominated by the mayor for appointment to a city public office and whose nomination requires the confirmation of the city council. 
Organization means any corporation, partnership, proprietorship, firm, enterprise, franchise, association, trust, self employed individual or other legal entity which engages in profit making activities. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.08) 
State Law reference Similar definitions, Wis. Stats. § 19.42.  
Sec. 14-2. - Enforcement. 
Any person having concerns or complaints related to this ethics chapter can bring them to the common council for remedy. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.07)  
Sec. 14-3. - Policy. 
(a)  It is declared that high ethical standards among city public officials and city employees are essential to the conduct of free government. The common council believes that a code of ethics for the guidance of city public officials and city employees will help them avoid conflicts between their personal interests and their public responsibilities, will improve standards of public service and will promote and strengthen the faith and confidence of the people of this city in their city public officials and city employees. 
(b)  In recognition of these goals, there is hereby established a code of ethics for all city officials and employees, whether elected or appointed, paid or unpaid, including members of boards, committees and commissions. The purpose of this chapter is to establish guidelines for ethical standards of conduct for all such officials and employees by setting forth those acts or actions that are incompatible with the best interests of the city. The provisions and purposes of this chapter and such rules and regulations as may be established are hereby declared to be in the best interest of the city. 
(c)  It is the intent of the common council that the rights of individuals affected shall be protected to the fullest extent possible. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.01)  
Sec. 14-4. - Responsibility of public office. 
Public officials and employees are agents of public purpose and hold office for the benefit of the public. They are bound to uphold the state and federal constitutions and to carry out impartially the laws of the nation, state, and municipality and thus to foster respect for all government. They are bound to discharge faithfully the duties of their office regardless of personal considerations, recognizing that the public interest must be their primary concern. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.02)  
Sec. 14-5. - Standards of conduct. 
(a)  This chapter does not prevent any city public official from accepting other employment or following any pursuit which in no way interferes with the faithful discharge of his/her duties to the city. The common council recognizes that: 
(1)  In a representative democracy, the representatives are drawn from society, and therefore, cannot and should not be without personal and economic interests in the decisions and policies of government; 
(2)  Citizens who serve as city public officials retain their rights as citizens to interests of a personal or economic nature; that standards of ethical conduct for city public officials need to distinguish between those minor and inconsequential conflicts that are unavoidable in a free society, and those conflicts which are substantial and material; and 
(3)  City public officials need to engage in employment, professional, personal or business activities, other than official duties, in order to support themselves or their families and to maintain a continuity of professional or business activity, or may need to maintain investments, which activities or investments do not conflict with specific provisions of this chapter. 
(b)  Appointed officials and employees should adhere to the rules of work and performance established as the standard for their positions by the appropriate authority. Officials and employees should not exceed their authority or breach the law or ask others to do so, and they should work in full cooperation with other public officials and employees unless prohibited from doing so by law or by officially recognized confidentiality of their work. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.03)  
Sec. 14-6. - Fair and equal treatment; use of public property. 
(a)  Interest in appointments. Canvassing the members of the common council in order to obtain preferential consideration in connection with any appointment to the municipal civil service shall disqualify the candidate for appointment. 
(b)  Use of public property. No official or employee shall request or permit the use of city-owned vehicles, equipment, materials or property for personal convenience or profit, except when such services are available to the public generally and except where otherwise authorized by action of the common council. 
(c)  Obligations to citizens. No official or employee shall grant any special consideration, treatment, or advantage to any citizen beyond that which is available to every other citizen. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.04)  
Secs. 14-714-30. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - CONFLICTS OF INTEREST 
 
Sec. 14-31. - Incompatible activities generally. 
No official or employee, whether paid or unpaid, shall engage in any business or transaction or shall have a financial or other personal interest, direct or indirect, which is incompatible with the proper discharge of official duties in the public interest. Personal as distinguished from financial interests include an interest arising from blood or marriage relationships or close business or political association. Specific conflicts of interest are enumerated in this article for the guidance of officials and employees. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.05(1))  
Sec. 14-32. - Incompatible employment. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no official or employee shall engage in or accept private employment or render service for private interests when such employment or service is incompatible with the proper discharge of official duties or would tend to impair independence of judgment or action in the performance of official duties. 
(b)  The city attorney, municipal court judge, or any other legally qualified city official or employee may engage in the private or public practice of law during the period in which they hold their respective offices. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.05(1)(A))  
Sec. 14-33. - Disclosure of confidential information. 
No official or employee shall, without proper legal authorization, disclose confidential information concerning the property, government, or affairs of the city, nor shall such information be used to advance the financial or other private interest of the official, employee or others. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.05(1)(B))  
Sec. 14-34. - Gifts and favors. 
(a)  No official or employee shall accept any gift, whether in the form of service, loan, thing, or promise, from any person which to his/her knowledge is interested directly or indirectly in any manner whatsoever in business dealings with the city. 
(b)  No city public official or employee may use a public position or office to obtain financial gain or anything of substantial value for the private benefit of himself/herself or his/her immediate family or for an organization with which he/she has a financial interest. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.05(1)(C))  
Sec. 14-35. - Representing private interests before city bodies. 
(a)  Except as otherwise provided in this section, no official or employee whose salary is paid in whole or in part by the city shall appear on behalf of private interests before any agency, board, authority, commission, or other official body of the city. He/she shall not represent private interests in any action or proceeding against the interest of the city in any litigation to which the city is a party. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed as prohibiting the appearance of officials or employees when subpoenaed as witnesses by parties involved in litigation which also may involve the city. 
(c)  An alderperson may appear before city agencies on behalf of constituents in the course of his/her duties as a representative of the electorate or in the performance of public or civic obligations. However, no alderperson or other official or employee shall accept a retainer or compensation that is contingent upon a specific action or decision by a city agent. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.05(1)(D))  
Sec. 14-36. - Contracts with the city. 
(a)  No city public official or employee, member of his/her immediate family, nor any organization with which the city public official and employee or a member of his/her immediate family owns or controls at least ten percent of the outstanding equity, voting rights, or outstanding indebtedness may enter into any contract or lease involving a payment or payments of more than $3,000.00 within a 12-month period, in whole or in part derived from city funds unless the city public official or employee has first made written disclosure of the nature and extent of such relationship or interest to the board of ethics and to the department acting for the city in regard to such contract or lease. Said public official or employee shall refrain from voting upon or otherwise participating in the transaction or the making of such contract or sale. 
(b)  Any contract or lease entered into in violation of this section may be voided by the city in an action commenced within three years of the date on which the board of ethics, or the department or officer acting for the city in regard to the allocation of city funds from which such payment is derived, knew or should have known that a violation of this subsection had occurred. 
(c)  This section does not affect the application of section Wis. Stats. § 946.13. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.05(1)(E)) 
State Law reference Private interest in public contract prohibited, Wis. Stats. § 946.13.  
Sec. 14-37. - Disclosure of interest in legislation. 
(a)  An alderperson who has a financial or other private interest in any legislation shall disclose on the record to the common council or the board of ethics the nature and extent of such interest. This provision shall not apply if the alderperson disqualifies himself/herself from voting. 
(b)  An alderperson shall disqualify himself/herself from voting if the matter under consideration involves his/her personal or financial interest to the extent that such interest may conflict with his/her official duties or would impair independence of judgment. 
(c)  Any other public official or employee who has a financial or other private interest in legislation, and who participates in discussion with or gives an official opinion to the council, shall disclose on the records of the common council and the board of ethics the nature and extent of such interest. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, §§ 23.05(1)(F), 23.06)  
Sec. 14-38. - Event attendance. 
The common council declares that it is in the public interest for city employees and city public officials to attend the following events: ribbon cuttings, grand openings, seminars, workshops, conferences, and Fitchburg Business Appreciation luncheons. As such, notwithstanding section 14-34, city employees and city public officials may attend such events and may accept food and beverages incidentally served at such events along with small items such as cups and t-shirts of nominal value. Additionally, city employees and city public officials may accept food, beverage, and other items of nominal value incidental to events that are deemed to be in the public interest by the mayor and the city administrator or as expressly authorized by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 2017-027, § 1, 12-12-2017)  
Secs. 14-3914-62. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - POLITICAL ACTIVITY 
 
Sec. 14-63. - Civil service and nonelected employees. 
(a)  No person employed with the city shall during the hours when on duty engage in any form of political activity calculated to favor or improve the chances of any political party or any person or candidate seeking or attempting to hold political office, nor engage in any political activity when not on duty to such an extent that efficiency during working hours will be impaired or will result in being tardy or absent from work. 
(b)  No person in the civil service, or nominee or person seeking admission thereto, shall be employed, promoted, demoted, or discharged, or in any way favored or discriminated against, because of political opinion or affiliation or because of age, race, color, religious belief, handicap, marital status, sex, national origin, ancestry, sexual orientation, or arrest or conviction record. 
(c)  No person holding a civil service position shall directly or indirectly solicit or receive subscriptions or contributions of money for any candidate for city office or a campaign committee for such candidate or actively campaign for candidates for city office. However, the prohibition against the receipt of contributions shall not apply to any such employee who holds an office in a political organization and receives money in the course of performing duties in said office. This exemption does not authorize the solicitation or receipt of political contributions during hours the employee is on duty. 
(d)  No person holding a civil service position shall use an official title or job designation to favor or improve the chances of any political candidate or any person seeking or attempting to hold political office. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.05(2)(A))  
Sec. 14-64. - Police officers and firefighters. 
Police officers and firefighters shall observe strictly the applicable rules of the police and fire departments relating to political activity, providing such rules pertain only to hours on duty. No person holding a position in the police or fire service shall use an official title or a job designation in the form of any political activity calculated to favor or improve the chances of any political candidate or any person seeking or attempting to hold political office. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.05(2)(B))  
Sec. 14-65. - Promise of reward of civil service appointment prohibited. 
No official or employee, whether elected or appointed, shall promise a civil service appointment to any municipal position as a reward for any political activity. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 23.05(2)(C))  
Chapter 16 - PERSONNEL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note Ord. No. 2011-O-18, §§ 1, 2, adopted September 25, 2011, amended the Code by, in effect, repealing former ch. 16, §§ 16-116-15, 16-34-16-40, and 16-6916-77, and added a new ch. 16. Former ch. 16 pertained to similar subject matter, and derived from the Compiled Ordinances of 2009, §§ 16.0116.21. 
 
Sec. 16-1. - Application. 
The provisions of this chapter shall apply to all employees of the city hired on or before June 29, 2011 who are not elected or appointed to their position for a fixed term of office, are not members of any collective bargaining unit, are not contract employees, are not volunteer firefighters, and are not temporary or seasonal employees. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-18, § 2, 9-25-2011)  
Sec. 16-2. - Disciplinary action. 
(a)  Cause required. No employee, hired on or before June 29, 2011, shall be suspended without pay, discharged, or demoted without cause. 
(b)  Right to discipline. The common council, administrator, and each department head shall, subject to the provisions of this section, is allowed full freedom with respect to disciplinary action, it being the intent and spirit of this chapter to provide a fair and just approach to municipal employment but in no sense to handicap or curtail responsible administrative officers in securing efficient service. Accordingly, all employees shall be subject to reprimand, suspension without pay, discharge, or demotion for misconduct, incompetency, inefficiency, or failure to perform duties or to observe the rules and regulations of their department, or of the common council. In all such cases, except reprimand, the employee shall have the right to appeal. 
(c)  Statement of reasons. Prior to, or concurrent with, the taking of any disciplinary action against an employee who has completed probation, the common council, administrator or department head, as appropriate, shall provide the employee with a written statement of the reasons for such action, a copy of which shall be filed with human resources. No hearing on such disciplinary action shall be held unless requested by the employee within seven calendar days after the effective date of the suspension, discharge, or demotion. 
(d)  Appeal. Any employee who has completed probation and is suspended, discharged, or demoted may appeal to the administrator by filing a written notice of appeal with human resources within seven calendar days after the effective date of such disciplinary action. The notice shall identify the employee, shall specify the action appealed, and shall contain the employee's response to the reasons given for the disciplinary action. Human resources shall forward a copy of the notice together with a copy of the written statement of the reasons for the disciplinary action to the administrator for his/her review. The administrator shall meet with the employee within ten working days of receiving the appeal and shall respond, in writing, to the employee within five working days of the hearing. If dissatisfied with the administrator's decision, the employee may appeal that decision to the civil service commission within seven calendar days after the date of the administrator's decision in the same manner as described in this subsection. 
(e)  Hearing. The commission shall set a date for a hearing, which shall not be less than ten nor more than 21 calendar days, following the filing of the notice of appeal. At the hearing, the proponent of the disciplinary action may be represented by the city attorney and shall present his/her testimony and evidence first. The employee, who may be represented by counsel, shall then have the opportunity to be heard in person and to present witnesses and testimony on his/her behalf. Both the proponent of the disciplinary action and the employee shall have the right to cross examine adverse witnesses and to compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoenas which shall be issued by the commission chairperson upon request. 
(f)  Prerogatives of the commission. If the commission determines that the disciplinary action was taken without cause, the employee, if he/she has been suspended, discharged, or demoted shall be immediately reinstated and all lost pay restored. If the commission determines that the disciplinary action was taken with cause, the discipline shall be upheld. 
(g)  Findings/decision required. The findings, determinations, and decision of the civil service commission shall be in writing and shall be filed with Human Resources within ten calendar days of the hearing. The commission shall forward a copy thereof to the proponent of the disciplinary action and to the employee by certified mail with return receipt requested. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-18, § 1, 9-25-2011)  
Sec. 16-3. - Layoffs and reemployment. 
(a)  Order of layoff. When the common council determines a layoff is necessary, because of need for economy, lack of work or funds, or for other causes to reduce the number of employees, the city administrator will determine the classifications in which the reduction will take place. Seasonal and temporary employees, if any, within the classifications shall be laid off first, subject to program restrictions. Thereafter employees in the classifications shall be laid off in the order of the shortest length of service with the city, provided the remaining employees are qualified to perform the work. 
(b)  Reemployment preference. The name of any employee laid off for any reason set forth in subsection (a) of this section shall be left on an eligible reemployment list for a period of one year after the date of layoff. If any vacancy occurs, or if the number of employees in the department is increased within said period, persons on such list, if then competent, shall be eligible to be appointed in preference to any qualified persons who apply for such position in the inverse order of their layoff. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-18, § 1, 9-25-2011)  
Sec. 16-4. - Civil service commission. 
The personnel committee shall serve as the civil service commission as defined in section 6-265 of the Fitchburg Code of Ordinances. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-18, § 1, 9-25-2011)  
Chapter 18 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Municipal courts generally, Wis. Stats. § 755.001 et seq.; municipal court procedure, Wis. Stats. § 800.001 et seq.; procedure in forfeiture actions, Wis. Stats. § 23.50; authority for municipal citations for certain ordinance violations, Wis. Stats. § 66.0113; form of citation in municipal court, Wis. Stats. § 800.02; contempt of court generally, Wis. Stats. § 785.01 et seq.; municipal court contempt procedure, Wis. Stats. § 800.12; application by municipal court for remedial or punitive sanctions, Wis. Stats. § 785.06; arrests, bails, and penalties generally, Wis. Stats. § 345.11 et seq.; sentencing of juveniles, Wis. Stats. § 345.18; sentencing in traffic forfeiture actions, Wis. Stats. § 345.20l; deposits, Wis. Stats. § 345.26. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 18-1. - Created. 
There is created and established, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 755.01 in and for the city, a municipal court which shall be designated as the "Municipal Court for the City of Fitchburg." 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(1))  
Sec. 18-2. - Term and election of judge. 
The term and election of the municipal judge shall be as set forth in article III of chapter 8. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(2))  
Sec. 18-3. - Oath and bond of judge. 
The judge shall, after election or appointment to fill a vacancy, take and file the official oath as prescribed in Wis. Stats. § 757.02(1) and at the same time execute and file an official bond in an amount to be fixed by the common council. No judge may act as such until his/her oath and bond have been filed as required by Wis. Stats. § 19.01(4)(c) and the requirements of Wis. Stats. § 755.03(2) have been complied with. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(3))  
Sec. 18-4. - Salary and fees. 
(a)  The annual city meeting shall fix a salary for the judge, which shall be in lieu of fees and costs. The salary may be increased by the annual city meeting before the start of the second or a subsequent year of service of the term of the judge, but shall not be decreased during a term. The salary shall be paid in equal biweekly installments, but the judge shall not be paid a salary for any time during the term during which the judge has not executed his/her official bond or official oath, as required by Wis. Stats. § 755.03 and filed under Wis. Stats. § 19.01(4)(c). 
(b)  Fees and taxable costs shall be paid into the city treasury as the common council may direct. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(4))  
Sec. 18-5. - Jurisdiction. 
(a)  The municipal court shall have exclusive jurisdiction over any action in which the city seeks to impose forfeitures for violations of city ordinances, unless the action is transferred under Wis. Stats. § 800.04 or 800.05 to a court of record. If equitable relief is demanded the municipal court shall not have jurisdiction and the action shall be brought in a court of record. 
(b)  The municipal judge may issue civil warrants to enforce matters which are under the jurisdiction of the municipal court and may issue inspection warrants under Wis. Stats. § 66.0119. 
(c)  The territorial jurisdiction of the municipal judge shall be countywide. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(5))  
Sec. 18-6. - Sessions of court. 
The municipal court shall be open and in session at such times as may be determined by the municipal judge. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(6))  
Sec. 18-7. - Location of office, court. 
The municipal judge shall keep his/her office and hold court at the Fitchburg City Hall, 5520 Lacy Road, Fitchburg, Wisconsin. The judge may issue process or perform ministerial functions at any place in the county. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(7))  
Sec. 18-8. - Employees. 
The municipal judge shall, in writing, appoint such clerks and deputy clerks as are authorized by the common council. Their salaries shall be fixed by the common council. The clerks shall, before entering upon the duties of their offices, take the oath provided by Wis. Stats. § 19.01 and give a bond if required by the common council. The cost of the bond shall be paid by the city. Oaths and bonds of the clerks shall be filed with the city clerk. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(8))  
Sec. 18-9. - Illness; absence or vacancy. 
(a)  If the municipal judge is to be temporarily absent or is sick or disabled, the municipal judge may by written order, filed in the court and with the chief judge of the judicial administrative district for approval, designate another municipal judge of the county to perform his/her duties for a single period not to exceed 30 days or the municipal judge may deliver the docket and all papers relating to any pending action to the county circuit court and the circuit court may try the action and enter judgment as though the action was begun before that court. 
(b)  If the municipal judge becomes incompetent or is unable or fails to act or in the event of a vacancy, Wis. Stats. § 751.03(5) shall apply. The parties and their attorneys shall be notified of the transfer to another municipal judge or to circuit court prior to trial. The municipal judge designated or the circuit judge to whom the case is transferred, may, while in possession of the docket, issue execution upon or give a certified transcript of any unsatisfied judgment appearing therein. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(9))  
Sec. 18-10. - Municipal court docket and transcript entries. 
(a)  The municipal judge shall keep a docket in which he/she shall enter, in actions to which they relate: 
(1)  The title of every action commenced before the municipal judge, including the name and address of the defendant; 
(2)  The process issued, date and place where it issued, when returnable and the return of the officer; 
(3)  A brief statement of the charges, including the nature and time of the offense and the section of law violated; 
(4)  Every adjournment, stating at whose request and to what time; 
(5)  The date and time trial was held; 
(6)  The names of witnesses sworn, stating at whose request; 
(7)  The judgment rendered by the municipal judge, including the penalties imposed, the date and time of rendering judgment and the costs assessed in the action; 
(8)  The record of contempt convictions under article VII of this chapter; 
(9)  The amount of bail and names and addresses of sureties, if any; 
(10)  The time of ordering any stay of execution; 
(11)  The time of issuing execution and the name of the officer to whom delivered; 
(12)  The return of every execution and when made and every renewal of an execution, with the date thereof; 
(13)  The date and reason of removal of the action to another court; 
(14)  The date of giving transcript of judgment; 
(15)  The date of an appeal made from judgment; and 
(16)  All motions made in the action, the decision thereon and all other proceedings in the action which the municipal judge may think useful. 
(b)  Failure of the municipal judge to keep a docket properly shall not affect the jurisdiction of the municipal court or render the judgment void. 
(c)  The transcript of judgment shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and location of the court. 
(2)  The title of action. 
(3)  The name, address and vocation of defendant. 
(4)  The date of judgment. 
(5)  The amount of judgment, costs and fees. 
(6)  The certification that it is a true copy of the judgment. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(10))  
Sec. 18-11. - Recording in municipal court. 
Every proceeding in which testimony is taken under oath in the municipal court shall be recorded by electronic means for purposes of appeal. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(11))  
Sec. 18-12. - Dispositions and sanctions for juveniles which may be imposed by the municipal court. 
(a)  If the municipal court finds that a juvenile violated an ordinance, the court may impose any of the dispositions listed in Wis. Stats. §§ 938.343 and 938.344 in accordance with the provisions of those statutes. 
(b)  If the municipal court finds by a preponderance of the evidence that a juvenile has violated a dispositional order authorized by Wis. Stats. §§ 938.343 and 938.344 the court may impose any of the sanctions listed in Wis. Stats. § 938.355(6)(d) in accordance with the provisions of that statute. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.01(12))  
Secs. 18-1318-42. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 18-43. - Use of citations, etc. 
The ordinances of the city may be enforced through the issuance of citations, complaints, summons, warrants, and by arrest. Citations, complaints, summons, and warrants shall be in the form prescribed in this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 7.02(1))  
Sec. 18-44. - Citation form. 
(a)  The citation shall be issued and signed by a law enforcement officer, by a peace officer, or by any other city official authorized to issue citations with respect to ordinances which are directly related to their official responsibilities, or endorsed by a municipal attorney, or if applicable, signed by a conservation warden and shall contain substantially the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and date of birth of the defendant. 
(2)  The name and department of the issuing officer.
