All curved lines shall show, either on the lines or in an adjoining table, the radius of the circle, the central angle subtended, the chord bearing, the chord length and the arc length for each segment. The tangent bearing shall be shown for each end of the main chord for all circular lines. When a circular curve of 30-foot radius or less is used to round off the intersection between two straight lines, it shall be tangent to both straight lines, and in such event, it is sufficient to show on the plat the radius of the curve and the tangent distances from the points of curvature to the point of intersection of the straight lines. 
(13)  Existing zoning on and adjacent to the proposed subdivision. 
(14)  Corporate limits lines. 
(15)  Any proposed lake and stream access with a small drawing clearly indicating the location of the proposed subdivision in relation to the access. 
(16)  Approximate dimensions of all lots and outlots together with proposed lot, outlot, and block numbers. 
(c)  Street plans and profiles. The subdivider shall provide street plans and profiles showing existing ground surface, proposed and established street grades, including extensions for a reasonable distance beyond the limits of the proposed subdivision when requested. All elevations shall be based upon USGS data, and plans and profiles shall meet the approval of the city engineer. 
(d)  Testing. 
(1)  Where sanitary sewers are not available the city engineer shall require that borings and soundings be made in specified areas to ascertain subsurface soil, rock and water conditions, including depth to bedrock and depth to groundwater table. 
(2)  Where sanitary sewers are unavailable, the soil and percolation tests required by Wis. Admin. Code § DHS 65.06 shall be performed and the results shall be submitted with the preliminary plat. After approval of the preliminary plat but prior to submitting an application for approval of the final plat, each individual lot shall be tested for percolation as specified in Wis. Admin. Code § DHS 62.20 and the results of such tests shall be submitted to the plan commission. 
(e)  Covenants. The plan commission may require submission of a draft of any protective covenants which the subdivider intends to record regulating land use in the proposed subdivision or otherwise protect the proposed development. 
(f)  Affidavit. The surveyor preparing the preliminary plat shall certify on the face of the plat that it is a correct representation of all existing land divisions and features and that he/she has fully complied with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.04, 10-12-2010)  
Sec. 24-5. - Final plat. 
(a)  Generally. A final plat prepared by a land surveyor, registered in this state, shall be required for all subdivisions. It shall comply in all respects with the requirements of Wis. Stats. § 236.20. 
(b)  Information required. The plat shall show correctly on its face, in addition to the information required by Wis. Stats. § 236.20 and section 24-4, the following: 
(1)  Exact length and bearing of the centerline of all streets. 
(2)  Exact street width along the line of any obliquely intersecting street. 
(3)  Railroad rights-of-way within and abutting the plat. 
(4)  Setbacks or building lines required by the city plan commission. 
(5)  All lands reserved for future public acquisition or reserved for the common use of property owners within the plat. 
(6)  Special restrictions required by the city plan commission relating to access control along public ways or to the provision of planting strips. 
(7)  The rural fire number assigned to each lot. 
(c)  Deed restrictions. The plan commission may require that deed restrictions be filed with the final plat. 
(d)  Survey accuracy. The accuracy of the final plat must be certified by the state department of development. 
(e)  Surveying and monumenting. All final plats shall meet all the surveying and monumenting requirements of Wis. Stats. § 236.15. 
(f)  Certificates. A final plat shall contain all the certificates required by Wis. Stats. § 236.21, and, in addition, the surveyor shall certify that he/she has fully complied with all the provisions of this chapter. 
(g)  Application for approval. The plat shall be accompanied by a written application for approval and, if they have not been previously submitted, by the plans, profiles and specifications required by sections 24-4(c) and 24-10(a) and by the results of the soil and percolation tests required by section 24-4(d). 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.05, 10-12-2010)  
Sec. 24-6. - Certified survey map. 
(a)  Generally. A certified survey map prepared by a land surveyor registered in this state shall be required for all land divisions. It shall comply in all respects with the requirements of Wis. Stats. § 236.34. 
(b)  Information required. The map shall show correctly on its face, in addition to the information required by Wis. Stats. § 236.34, the following: 
(1)  All existing buildings, septic systems, wells, watercourses, wetlands, floodplains and flood storage areas, wooded areas, rock outcrops, drainage ditches and other features pertinent to ensure proper division. 
(2)  Setbacks or building lines required by the city plan commission. 
(3)  All lands reserved for future acquisition. 
(4)  Date of the map. 
(5)  Graphic scale. 
(6)  Name and address of the owner, subdivider and surveyor. 
(c)  Certificates. 
(1)  The surveyor shall certify on the face of the map that he/she has fully complied with all the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  The following certificate of approval shall be typed, lettered or otherwise reproduced legibly on the face of the map: 
This certified survey, including any dedications shown thereon, has been duly filed with and approved by the common council of the city of Fitchburg, Dane County, Wisconsin. 
___________ City Clerk 	
 
(3)  Dedication. Dedication of streets and other public areas shall require the owner's and the mortgagee's, if any, certificate in substantially the same form as required by Wis. Stats. § 236.21(2)(a). 
(d)  Critical building locations. Any building or structure and its location on the lot shall be dimensioned to the nearest 0.1 foot where the location of such building or structure will be critical in relation to proposed property boundaries or to the zoning yard requirements. 
(e)  Dedications, testing, and improvements required. Any land division effectuated by a certified survey shall be subject to the provisions of section 24-2(d) concerning the reservation and dedication of land; and the provisions of sections 24-9, unless a waiver is granted to section 24-9 requirements pursuant to sections 24-9(g), and 24-10 concerning required improvements; and to the provisions of section 24-4(d) concerning borings, soundings, and percolation tests. In no case shall a new building site or new habitable building be allowed if sanitary service is required by a holding tank. 
(f)  Application for approval. The certified survey map shall be accompanied by a written application for approval. Where a change in zoning classification is being or will be requested in connection with the land division, a map showing the present zoning of the land and all lands adjacent thereto and the proposed zoning shall be submitted with the application for approval. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.06, 10-12-2010)  
Sec. 24-7. - Comprehensive development plans. 
(a)  Requirements. Any comprehensive development plan shall include the following: 
(1)  A plan, drawn to a scale of one inch equals 200 feet which shows all lands under the control of the applicant which are contiguous or separated only by existing public roads or railroad rights-of-way. The plan shall show the information required by section 24-4(a) and (b) and all proposed collector and arterial streets, and approximate number and layout of lots. 
(2)  Identification of land uses consistent with the method used in the comprehensive plan future land use map. Provide the projected population broken down into single-family and multifamily units. In addition, provide residential density for each development area. For nonresidential areas provide intended floor area ratio, and building stories, or other measures of density as may be required. 
(3)  The multifamily dwelling units broken down into the number of units in each bedroom category on a percentage basis. 
(4)  Development schedule clearly indicating the time of completion for the proposed development and each phase thereof, if known. Discussion of how the development schedule will be in keeping with requirements of the comprehensive plan. 
(5)  A draft preliminary plat, meeting the requirements of this chapter for the portion proposed to be platted within 18 months from the date of submittal. 
(6)  Outlots proposed to be created for later replat to meet staging requirements of public improvements. 
(7)  Soil conditions, slope, current ground cover and environmental corridor areas. 
(8)  Proposed public lands, and any proposed public or private outlots, and their purpose. 
(9)  Sufficient information necessary to indicate compatibility with adjoining buildings and uses, drainage and transportation and utility connections. 
(10)  Any other information that may be required by the zoning administrator/city planner or plan commission to ascertain consistency with the comprehensive plan. 
(b)  Design standards. The design standards set forth in section 24-8 shall apply to a comprehensive development plan. 
(c)  Dedications, testing, and improvements required. Comprehensive development plans shall be subject to the provisions of section 24-2(d) concerning the reservation and dedication of land; to the provisions of section 24-9 concerning required improvements; and to the provisions of section 24-4(d) concerning borings, soundings, and percolation tests. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.07, 10-12-2010)  
Sec. 24-8. - Design standards. 
(a)  Street arrangement. Unless the area is subject to SmartCode zoning of chapter 23, street layouts shall conform to the arrangement, width and location indicated on any applicable official map, comprehensive plan or component neighborhood development plan. Streets, alleys or other roadways constructed in the SmartCode zoning district shall follow the regulations of chapter 23 and as allowed through plans approved under chapter 23. In areas for which such plans have not been completed, the street layout shall recognize the functional classification of the various types of streets and shall be developed and located in proper relation to existing and proposed streets, to the topography, to such natural features as streams and tree growth, to public convenience and safety, to the proposed use of the land to be served by such streets, and to the most advantageous development of adjoining areas. The land division or subdivision shall be designed so as to provide each lot with satisfactory access to a public street. 
(1)  Arterial streets shall be arranged so as to provide ready access to centers of employment, centers of governmental activity, community shopping areas, community recreation, and points beyond the boundaries of the community. They shall also be properly integrated with and related to the existing and proposed system of major streets and highways and shall be, insofar as practicable, continuous and in alignment with existing or planned streets with which they are to connect. 
(2)  Collector streets shall be arranged so as to provide ready collection of traffic from residential areas and conveyance of this traffic to the major street and highway system and shall be properly related to the mass transportation system, to special traffic generators such as schools, churches, shopping centers and other concentrations of population, and to the major streets into which they feed. 
(3)  Local streets shall be arranged to conform to the topography, to discourage use by through traffic, to permit the design of efficient storm and sanitary sewerage systems, and to require the minimum street area necessary to provide safe and convenient access to abutting property. 
(4)  Proposed streets shall extend to the boundary lines of the tract being subdivided unless prevented by topography or other physical conditions or unless, in the opinion of the plan commission, such extension is not necessary or desirable for the coordination of the layout of the subdivision or for the advantageous development of the adjacent tracts. Temporary turnarounds may be required where the street ends at the boundary of the subdivision. 
(5)  Whenever the proposed subdivision contains or is adjacent to a major street or highway, adequate protection of residential properties, limitation of access and separation of through and local traffic shall be provided by reversed frontage, with screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line, or by the use of frontage streets. 
(6)  Stream or lake shores shall have 60 feet of public access platted to the low water mark at intervals of not more than one-half mile as required Wis. Stats. § 236.16(3). The city shall not be required to improve any lands provided for public access pursuant to this subsection. 
(7)  Reserve strips controlling access to streets or alleys are prohibited except where control of such strips is placed with the city under conditions approved by the plan commission. 
(8)  Alleys shall be provided in commercial and industrial districts for off-street loading and service access when required by the plan commission. When used, alleys shall not be less than 24 feet wide and shall be continuous through blocks. Dead-end alleys shall not be approved, and alleys shall not connect to a major thoroughfare. 
(9)  Cul-de-sacs shall be limited to generally no more than one cul-de-sac for every 50 lots in the land division. Cul-de-sacs location shall be related to natural environmental features or excessive topography. 
(b)  Street names and building numbers. 
(1)  Street names and building numbers shall be assigned in accordance with the numbering sequence in use by the city. 
(2)  Duplication of existing street names in the Madison Metropolitan area by similar word, spelling, or sound shall not be permitted. 
(3)  Where a street maintains the same general direction except for curvilinear changes for short distances, the same name shall continue for the entire length of the street. House numbering difficulties shall be considered the determining factor in considering whether a change of name is necessary due to curvilinear changes. 
(4)  A street name shall be changed when required to conform to the proposed or existing house numbering base. 
(5)  A name which is assigned to a street which is not presently a through street, due to intervening land over which the street extension is planned, shall be continued for the separate portions of the planned through street. 
(6)  The following designations shall be used only in the situations indicated: 
a.  Boulevard: A street with a divided pavement either existing or planned. If the divided pavement ends, but the street continues, the same street name and suffix shall continue. 
b.  Lane: A street, one block long, not ending in a cul-de-sac. 
c.  Circle: A cul-de-sac of nine lots or more. 
d.  Court: A cul-de-sac of eight lots or less. 
e.  Parkway: A street abutting a park or greenway or creek. 
f.  Way: A private street. 
(7)  The maximum number of street names at one intersection shall be three. 
(8)  Street names shall be assigned so that no two intersections have the same exact street names, except for loop streets approved as part of a land division. 
(9)  The name of any projection of a street shall remain unchanged even if the projection terminates in a cul-de-sac. 
(10)  The changing of a street name that does not duplicate an existing street name shall only be approved where such change will eliminate conflicts with other provisions of this section. 
(11)  Service roads and highways served by them shall have the same street name and designation. 
(12)  Approval of street names on a preliminary plat will not reserve the names nor shall the city be required to accept such names at the time of final platting. 
(13)  A minimum number of letters is desirable in a street name. The maximum number of letters, not including the prefix or suffix shall not exceed 12. 
(c)  Limited access highways and railroad rights-of-way. Unless the area is subject to SmartCode zoning of chapter 23, whenever the proposed subdivision, land division, or comprehensive development plan contains or is adjacent to a limited access highway or railroad right-of-way, the design shall provide the following treatment: 
(1)  In residential districts a buffer strip at least 30 feet in depth, in addition to the normal lot depth required, shall be provided adjacent to a railroad right-of-way or a limited access arterial street. The lot depth required, including such buffer strip, shall not be less than 150 feet. The strip shall be a part of the platted lots, but shall have the following restrictions lettered on the face of the plat: 
"This strip reserved for the planting of trees or shrubs by the owner; the building of structures hereon is prohibited, and the rear 30 feet of the strip shall not be counted as any required yard. Maintenance of this strip is a responsibility of the lot owner." 
(2)  Commercial and industrial districts shall have, on each side of the limited access highway or railroad, streets approximately parallel to and at a suitable distance from such highway or railroad for the appropriate use of the land between such streets and highway or railroad, but not less than 150 feet. 
(3)  Streets parallel to a limited access highway or railroad right-of-way shall, when intersecting a major street and highway or collector street which crosses said railroad or highway, be located at a minimum distance of 250 feet from said highway or railroad right-of-way. Such distance, where desirable and practicable, shall be determined with due consideration of the minimum distance required for the future separation of grades by means of appropriate approach gradients. 
(4)  The location of local streets immediately adjacent and parallel to railroad rights-of-way, and in residential areas immediately adjacent to arterial streets and highways and to railroad rights-of-way shall be avoided. 
(d)  Street design standards. 
(1)  Minimum right-of-way. The minimum right-of-way of all proposed streets and alleys shall be of the width specified by either the comprehensive plan or official map or if not so specified shall follow the provisions noted below. Land subject to SmartCode zoning under chapter 23 shall have right-of-way widths in accordance with that chapter. 
Type of Street 	R.O.W. Width 
Principal and primary arterials 	120 feet 
Standard arterial and collector streets 	80 feet 
Local streets 	66 feet 
Marginal access streets 	66 feet 
Alleys 	24 feet 
 
(2)  Cul-de-sac streets. 
a.  Streets designed to have one end permanently closed shall not exceed 600 feet in length, and which end shall be clearly visible from the intersection street. However, where feasible, a 20-foot-wide outlot with a shared use path shall be put in place to connect the cul-de-sac bulb to a through street or other public area in a manner approved by the plan commission. 
b.  Except as provided in section 24-8(d)(2)c, streets which are designed to have one end permanently closed shall terminate in a circular turnaround having a minimum right-of-way diameter of 120 feet, and a minimum outside curb diameter of 86 feet. The reverse curve on a cul-de-sac shall have a 50-foot minimum radius when the bulb is centered on the street. No offset bulb is allowed. 
c.  All streets which are designed to have one end permanently closed, in business, commercial, industrial and manufacturing areas, shall terminate in a circular turnaround having a minimum right-of-way diameter of 130 feet, and a minimum outside curb diameter of 96 feet. The reverse curve on a cul-de-sac shall have a 50-foot minimum radius when the bulb is centered on the street and a 100-foot minimum radius when the bulb is offset. 
(3)  Street grades. 
a.  Unless necessitated by exceptional topography and subject to the approval of the city engineer, the maximum street grades shall not exceed the following: 
1.  Arterial streets and highways: four percent. 
2.  Collector and local streets and alleys: eight percent. 
3.  Pedestrian ways: ten percent unless steps of acceptable design are provided. 
b.  The grade of any street shall in no case exceed ten percent or be less than 0.48 percent. 
c.  All changes in street grades shall provide sight distances as conditions require as determined by the city engineer. 
d.  Street grades shall be established wherever practicable in such a manner to avoid excessive grading, the promiscuous removal of ground cover and tree growth and general leveling of the topography. 
(4)  Radii of curvature. 
a.  When a continuous street centerline deflects at any one point by more than ten degrees, a circular curve shall be introduced having a radius of curvature on said centerline of not less than the following: 
1.  Arterial streets and highways: 450 feet. 
2.  Collector streets: 250 feet. 
3.  Local streets: 70 feet. 
b.  A tangent at least 150 feet in length shall be provided between reverse curves on arterial and collector streets, and 100 feet in length between reverse curves on local streets. 
c.  Subsections (d)(4)a and (d)(4)b of this section shall not apply to land subject to SmartCode zoning under chapter 23, except where required by the city engineer/director of public works to address SmartCode street connections with existing or non-SmartCode streets. 
(5)  Half streets. Where an existing dedicated or platted half street is adjacent to the tract being subdivided, the other half of the street shall be dedicated by the subdivider. Streets less than full width on the boundary of the tract being subdivided shall not be less than a width sufficient to produce a full pavement, a full terrace on the plat side and a reserve strip as determined by the plan commission. 
(e)  Street intersections. 
(1)  Streets shall intersect each other at as nearly right angles as topography and other limiting factors of good design permit. 
(2)  The number of streets converging at one intersection shall not be more than two. 
(3)  The number of intersections along principal, primary and standard arterials and collector streets shall be held to a minimum. Wherever practicable the distance between such intersections shall not be less than 1,200 feet. 
(4)  Property lines at street intersections shall be rounded with a minimum radius of 15 feet except that at all intersections along collector and arterial streets the radius shall be increased to 25 feet. The plan commission may require a larger radius where desirable. 
(5)  Local streets shall not necessarily continue across arterial or collector streets; but if the centerlines of such minor streets approach the major streets from opposite sides within 300 feet of each other, measured along the centerline of the arterial or collector street, then the location shall be so adjusted that the adjoinment across the major or collector street is continuous; and a jog is avoided. 
(6)  Whenever practicable, the distance between local street intersections shall be no less than 250 feet measured from centerline to centerline. 
(7)  The point of curve of the centerline of a curved street which intersects another street shall not be less than 15 feet, on the property side of the property line of the intersected street. 
(8)  Requirements of this subsection (e) shall not apply to land subject to SmartCode zoning under chapter 23. 
(f)  Blocks. 
(1)  The widths, lengths, and shapes of blocks shall be suited to the planned use of the land; zoning requirements; walkability; need for convenient access, control and safety of street traffic; and the limitations and opportunities of topography. 
(2)  Blocks in nonindustrial areas shall not be less than 500 feet nor more than 1,000 feet in length unless otherwise dictated by exceptional topography or other limiting design factors. 
(3)  Pedestrian ways of not less than ten feet in width may be required near the center and entirely across any block over 800 feet in length where deemed essential by the plan commission to provide adequate pedestrian circulation or access to schools, retail locations, churches, transportation facilities, parks and playgrounds, or other residential areas. 
(4)  Blocks shall have sufficient width to provide for two tiers of lots of appropriate depth except where otherwise required to separate residential development from through traffic. Width of lots or parcels reserved or laid out for commercial or industrial use shall be adequate to provide for off-street service and parking required by the use contemplated and the area zoning restrictions for such use. 
(5)  All utility lines for electric power and telephone service shall be placed on mid-block easements along rear lot lines whenever carried on overhead poles. 
(6)  Blocks shall be arranged, to the extent feasible, so that streets form a grid-like pattern. 
(7)  Requirements of this subsection (f) shall not apply to land subject to SmartCode zoning under chapter 23. 
(g)  Lots. 
(1)  The size, shape, and orientation of lots shall be appropriate for the location of the subdivision and for the type of development and use contemplated. The lots should be designed to provide an aesthetically pleasing building site and a proper architectural setting for the buildings contemplated. Except as may be provided by chapter 23, flag lots shall be prohibited, unless the common council approves a waiver, to be included as part of the approving resolution for such a lot, with a vote as required in this subsection (g). 
(2)  Double frontage and reverse frontage lots shall be prohibited except where necessary to provide separation of residential development from through traffic or to overcome specific disadvantages of topography and orientation. 
(3)  Lot sizes shall conform to the area and width requirements prescribed for the zoning district in which the land is located except for lots situated in commercial or industrial districts, or for lots zoned Planned Development District, the dimensions and area of which shall be those deemed by the plan commission, in its sole discretion, to be appropriate for the proposed use of the land. Where land is subject to SmartCode zoning, lots shall conform to that approved through chapter 23. 
(4)  Residential lots to be served by private sewage disposal facilities shall comply with the requirements of the state department of health and social services and the state board of health. 
(5)  Every lot shall front or abut on a public street for a distance of at least 50 feet, except for the following: 
a.  Zero lot line projects created under chapter 22 in which case the zero lot line parcels shall front or abut on a public street for a distance of at least 30 feet. 
b.  Land zoned SmartCode under chapter 23, which shall follow the regulations provided by chapter 23. 
c.  Projects zoned Planned Development District on sites of 30 acres or more, which are subject to construction demolition and debris landfill; subject to ingress/egress maintenance agreements. 
d.  Projects zoned Planned Development District may allow lots that font or abut a public street for a distance of less than 50 feet. 
(6)  Side lot lines shall, as nearly as practicable, be at right angles to straight streets or radial to curved street lines. 
(7)  Lots shall follow municipal boundary lines rather than cross them whenever practicable. 
(8)  Corner lots shall have sufficient width to permit adequate building setbacks from side streets. 
(9)  Excessive depth in relation to width shall be avoided and a proportion of 2 to 1 shall be considered as a desirable ratio under normal conditions. This provision shall not apply to areas zoned SmartCode under chapter 23. 
(10)  Lot drainage patterns shall be indicated on the plat and shall take into account flow conditions from off-site as well as outflow on to downstream properties. Any drainage system shall be constructed and designed to handle the volume and velocity of the off-site stormwater. Downstream drainage easements shall be provided as required to properly handle the flow. 
(11)  Depth and width of properties reserved or laid out for commercial or industrial use shall be adequate to provide for the off-street service and parking facilities required by the type of use and development contemplated. 
(12)  Whenever a tract is subdivided into large parcels, such parcels shall be arranged and dimensioned as to allow the future division of any such parcel into normal lots in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(13)  Lands lying between the meander line and the water's edge and any otherwise unplattable lands which lie between a proposed subdivision and the water's edge shall be included as part of lots, outlots or public dedications in any plat abutting a lake or stream. 
(h)  Building setback lines. Where not adequately controlled by zoning regulations, building setback lines appropriate to the location and type of development contemplated shall be established as required by the plan commission. 
(i)  Utility and drainage easements. 
(1)  Adequate easements shall be provided and dedicated on each side of all rear lot lines, and on side lot lines where necessary, for the installation of storm and sanitary sewers, gas, water mains, electric lines, telephone and cable television communication lines. 
(2)  Easements for electric, telephone, gas, and cable television communication lines shall be noted as "Utility Easements" on the final plat or certified survey map. Prior to approval of the final plat or certified survey map, the concurrence of the electric and communications companies serving the area as to the location and width of the utility easements shall be noted on the final plat or certified survey map. 
(3)  All easements for storm and sanitary sewers, water mains, and pedestrian walks, and other public purposes shall be noted on the plat or certified survey as "Public Easement for" followed by reference to the use or uses for which they are intended. 
(4)  Where the electric or communications facilities or both are to be installed underground, a plat restriction shall be recorded with the final plat or certified survey map stating that the final grade established by the subdivider on the utility easements shall not be altered by more than six inches by the subdivider, his/her agent, or by subsequent owners of the lots on which such utility easements are located, except with written consent of the utility or utilities involved. The purpose of this restriction shall be to notify initial and future lot owners of the underground facilities at the time of purchase and to establish responsibility in the event of damage to such facilities or to the need to alter such facilities. When the utility company uses a service application, said application should also notify the initial and subsequent lot owners of their responsibility regarding such underground facilities. 
(5)  Drainage easement. Where a land division, subdivision or comprehensive development plan is traversed by a watercourse, drainageway. channel or stream, an adequate drainageway or easement shall be provided as required by the plan commission. The location, width, alignment and improvement of such drainageway or easement shall be subject to the approval of the plan commission and parallel streets or parkways may be required in connection therewith. Wherever possible, the stormwater drainage shall be maintained by landscaped open channels of adequate size and grade to hydraulically accommodate maximum potential volumes of flow, these sizes and design details to be subject to review and approval by the city engineer and plan commission. Where feasible, drainage easements should substantially maintain existing water flow patterns onto neighboring lands. If outflow is different than existing patterns the developer/subdivider shall provide all necessary easements and facilities to transport the water. 
(j)  Electromagnetic radiation fields. Consideration shall be given to the layout of the land division such that no residential structure or place of employment shall be located within 50 yards of a 69,000-volt or greater transmission line. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.08, 10-12-2010; Ord. No. 2013-O-09, § 1, 6-25-2013; Ord. No. 2018-O-06, § 1, 2-27-2018; Ord. No. 2019-O-26 , §§ 13, 8-27-2019)  
Sec. 24-9. - Required improvements. 
(a)  Streets. Standard street improvements, including connector and feeder streets and intersections where necessary to safely and efficiently carry the additional traffic anticipated from full development of the subdivision shall be constructed, upgraded or rebuilt for all subdivisions and, where required, in any land division. 
(b)  Sanitary sewers and water mains. 
(1)  Within urban service area. Where the development is within an urban service area and public utilities are available, sanitary sewers and water mains and all required appurtenances, including, when required by the board of public works, interceptors, force mains, lift stations, booster pumps, wells, and water main loops, shall be installed in all subdivisions and, where required, in any land division, in accordance with the plans approved and permit issued by the board of public works. Where the development is within the urban service area and public utilities are not available, sanitary sewers, water mains and all appurtenances necessary to extend and provide effective, efficient, safe and portable public water and sewer service to the development, as determined by the city engineer and approved by board of public works, shall be installed at the cost of the subdivider or developer. Costs of extensions of water and sewer services through undeveloped lands shall be recorded as special assessments against the benefitted properties and collected from developers or customers upon attachment to the system within 20 years of completion of construction of the improvements. 
(2)  Outside urban service area. Except for Rural Cluster zoning, no subdivision or multifamily development shall be approved for lands outside of an urban service area. 
(c)  Water supply system. 
(1)  Where a municipal water supply is not available, a closed loop water supply and distribution system capable of serving the entire subdivision designed and constructed in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 111, which regulations and any subsequent amendments thereto are incorporated herein and adopted by reference, shall be installed in all subdivisions notwithstanding the fact that the number of service connections may be less than 15. 
(2)  Prior to commencing construction of a water supply system, the subdivider shall obtain a permit from the board of public works and submit the proposed plans, specifications, construction schedule, and contract to the city engineer for review and approval. 
(d)  Storm sewers and stormwater drainage facilities. 
(1)  Storm sewers and all necessary stormwater transportation, detention or retention facilities to serve the plat as determined by the city engineer, shall be constructed or caused to be constructed, within or without the plat, by the subdivider/developer. 
(2)  Ditches shall be constructed where required by the plan commission. 
a.  Roadside ditches shall not exceed ten percent of grade nor have less than a one percent grade. The maximum single ditch capacity for a five-year intensity storm shall be not more than the values tabulated as follows: 
Ditch Grade (%) 	Q (c.f.s) 
1 	2.34 
2 	3.78 
3 	4.14 
4 	4.86 
5 	5.22 
6 	5.76 
7 	6.30 
8 	6.84 
9 	7.20 
10 	7.74 
 
b.  Ditches shall be restored with six-inch topsoil, fertilizing, and anchored sodding in accordance with the current standard specifications for road and bridge construction, state department of transportation. All sod shall be free of sedges, quackgrass and bentgrass. 
c.  Where ditches are utilized, concrete curb and gutter shall not be required and streets shall be constructed as indicated in figure 3. The thickness of the pavement shall be determined and prescribed by the city Engineer in accordance with the functional classification of the proposed street and soil subgrade data available. Any soil subgrade data required by the city engineer shall be obtained by the developer's soils engineer and furnished to the city engineer without cost. 
(3)  At the time of submittal to the plan commission of the comprehensive development plan, preliminary plat or plans for any condominium, group housing project or other development, the developer/subdivider shall submit a study of the drainage basin or sub-basin in which the plat or project is located showing the proposed design and routing of storm sewer and stormwater management facilities, such as detention ponds, retention ponds, greenways and/or other green infrastructure facilities necessary to provide adequate drainage, infiltration, evapotranspiration, or collection of stormwater to and from the plat or development if such a study has not already been previously prepared by the city engineer. If such study or any previous study or studies as approved by the city engineer determine that it is necessary to increase the capacity of stormwater facilities which are to be constructed within the plat or project to enable them to serve the entire basin or sub-basin of which the plat or development is a part, the developer or subdivider shall construct such facilities in accordance with a plan and specifications approved by the city engineer. The city engineer shall determine the incremental portion of the estimated cost of constructing the required storm sewers and stormwater management facilities which is attributable to future development in the basis or sub-basin on lands not owned or controlled by the subdivider/developer. The developer or subdivider shall be entitled to recover any portion of the costs of stormwater facilities attributable to future development as future developments occur from area changes levied by the city against developers and subdividers. Area changes shall be subject to adjustment based upon the Engineering News-Record construction price index using the year that the area charges for the drainage basin or sub-basin were established as the base year. A copy of the construction price index shall be kept on file at the office of the city engineer and made available to the public for inspection and copying upon request. 
(4)  The developer/subdivider shall pay any outstanding area charges levied pursuant to subsection (d)(3) or (5) of this section before the final plat is inscribed by the city clerk or before any building permit is issued. 
(5)  Where a study completed under subsection (d)(3) of this section determines that it is not necessary to increase the capacity of the facilities to be constructed in the plat or project to enable them to serve the entire basin or subbasin but that the stormwater generated from the plat or project will necessitate future stormwater improvements to lands outside of the plat or project, the city engineer shall determine what portion of the estimated cost of constructing the required storm sewers and stormwater drainage facilities outside the plat or project is attributable to the plat or project and the developer shall pay a stormwater charge in such amount prior to inscribing of the final plat by the city clerk. 
(e)  Improvements to boundary lines. All required street, sidewalk, sanitary sewer, water main, and storm sewer improvements shall be installed to the boundary line of the subdivision or land division unless the topography or other physical conditions make it impossible to do so. 
(f)  Partition fences. When the land included in the plat or certified survey map abuts upon or is adjacent to land used for farming or grazing purposes, the subdivider may be required to erect, keep and maintain partition fences, satisfying the requirements of the state law for a legal and sufficient fence, between such land and the adjacent land. When partition fences are required, a covenant binding the subdivider, its grantees, heirs, successors, and assigns to erect and maintain such fences, without cost to the adjoining property owners, so long as the land is used for farming or grazing purposes shall be included upon the face of the final plat or certified survey map. 
(g)  Waiver to section requirements. 
(1)  Where, in the judgment of the common council, it would be inappropriate to apply the provisions of this section to a land division outside the urban service area because exceptional or undue hardship would result, the common council on recommendation of the plan commission may, subject to the following provisions, waive or modify the requirements of this section to the extent deemed just and proper. 
(2)  Such relief will be granted only where it will not be detrimental to the public good, impair the intent and purpose of this chapter, or impair the desirable general development of the community in accordance with the comprehensive plan. An affirmative vote of six members of the common council shall be required to grant any waiver or modification. 
(3)  Any waiver which is granted pursuant to this section shall be made in writing, shall state the reasons which justified it, and shall be filed with the records relating to the land division. 
(4)  The waiver allowed by this subsection may not be granted to subdivisions. 
(h)  Sidewalks. 
(1)  Sidewalks shall be installed to city specifications on all streets within the land division, except for: 
a.  Cul-de-sacs where such cul-de-sac has no dedicated land or easement for a recreation path or walkway. 
b.  Certified survey maps where the upgrading or installation of the streets within such certified survey map are not required to meet full city standards (e.g., curb and gutter) by the common council at the time of approval, or where there is no existing sidewalk system. 
(2)  For cul-de-sacs and for certified survey maps located in the urban service area, all driveways, unless exempted by the common council, shall contain a sidewalk cross-section and have all terraces graded to city specifications. 
(3)  For all lots not required by subsection (h)(1)a and (1)b of this section to have sidewalk, the land divider shall file with the city clerk, prior to recording of the plat or certified survey map, signed waivers of notice, hearing and right to contest future assessments for sidewalks under Wis. Stats. § 66.60 or 66.615 and this Code for such affected lots. Such waivers shall be recorded at the expense of the land divider. 
(4)  As used in subsection (i) of this section, street frontage shall include any and all improvements placed in the public right-of-way, including, but not limited to, the street, curb and gutter and sidewalk improvements. 
(5)  Areas zoned to the SmartCode District under chapter 23 shall not be subject to this section, but instead shall provide sidewalks in accordance with the SmartCode District, chapter 23. 
(i)  Street frontage for dedicated parkland. 
(1)  Street frontage for dedicated parklands shall be provided and paid for by the developer or subdivider in the amount of 150 lineal feet of frontage or in accord with the following, whichever is greater. 
a.  For development projects or land divisions of less than 80 dwelling units, the developer or subdivider shall provide frontage in accord with the following table: 
Single-family residential 	6.0 lineal feet per dwelling unit 
Two-family residential 	3.0 lineal feet per dwelling unit 
Multifamily 	0.75 lineal feet per dwelling unit 
 
b.  For development projects or land divisions of 80 or more dwelling units, lineal street frontage shall be provided in accord with the following: 
Single-family 	Square root of the square footage required to be dedicated 
Two-family 	Square root of the square footage required to be dedicated with this factor multiplied by 0.50 
Multifamily 	Square root of the square footage required to be dedicated with this factor then multiplied by 0.13 
 
(2)  The council, upon receiving a recommendation from the parks commission and plan commission, shall have the authority to allow alternative dimensions for frontages and the park if it can be found that the objectives of access and visibility can be fulfilled. 
(3)  In calculating the required frontage for multifamily residential projects the maximum number of two bedroom units allowed under the zoning ordinance shall be used unless a different number is committed to by agreement with the city or by city approved deed restriction. 
(4)  Areas zoned to the SmartCode District, and which meet the minimum acreage for the specific community unit type in chapter 23 shall not be subject to this section, but instead shall provide and install street frontage as required for all civic or open space lands through the approved regulating plan. For situations where the community unit type is less than the required minimum size in chapter 23, the above regulations of this subsection (i) shall apply. 
(j)  Street trees. 
(1)  The subdivider/developer of any land division requiring public street improvements shall, prior to installation of any public improvements, prepare a street tree planting plan to be approved by the city engineer. The tree planting plan shall, at a minimum, provide one street tree for every lot, or for every 80 feet of street frontage (whichever produces the greater number of trees), with the trees being a minimum of two-inch caliper. 
(2)  The subdivider/developer shall notice the existence of the planting plan to lot owners by deed restriction and through other measures the developer may deem appropriate. 
(3)  Upon substantial installation and completion of homes and yards within any phase of the improvements for the plat or certified survey map (CSM), the developer in consultation with the city engineer shall cause the installation of the street trees. The final tree location and species, which shall be approved by the city engineer, shall recognize existing trees, driveways, utility facilities, streetlights, signs and other similar features. The trees shall be guaranteed by the developer for at least one year from the date of planting. If less than 50 percent of the original canopy survives, the city engineer may recommend replacement. 
(4)  Upon acceptance of the last phase of subdivision improvements (or where no phasing, the acceptance of the improvements), the developer shall post a letter of credit, or other acceptable measures of security equal to the estimated cost of the remaining street trees to be installed as a guarantee to the city that the developer will undertake such improvements. 
(5)  Where the upgrading or installation of a street under a CSM or plat is not required to meet full city standards by the common council at the time of approval, the street trees need not be installed. However, the developer/subdivider shall, prior to signing the CSM or plat, provide signed waivers of notice, hearing, and right to contest future assessments for street trees under Wis. Stats. § 66.60 or 66.615 and this Code for all such affected lots. Such waivers shall be recorded. 
(6)  In regard to section 24-16, it is the intent to require street trees along public or private streets at a minimum level or number noted in subsection (j)(1) of this section. However, such trees may be located in a more varied and nonlinear manner that would complement the proposed development. The planting locations and species are to be determined at the time of city approvals for the specific implementation plan (under PDD zoning) or the conditional use. Agreements or conditions shall provide for proper installation of the street trees. 
(7)  Subdivider/developer shall reimburse the city for all costs incurred by the city to institute these street tree requirements, including any consulting costs incurred in review of the tree plan. 
(8)  Areas zoned to the SmartCode District shall not be subject to this section, but instead shall provide street trees as required by the SmartCode District, chapter 23. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.09, 10-12-2010; Ord. No. 2012-O-18, § 3, 12-11-2012; Ord. No. 2014-O-06, § 1, 3-25-2014; Ord. No. 2018-O-38, § 1, 11-27-2018)  
Sec. 24-10. - Required improvements procedure. 
(a)  Plans and construction specifications. Prior to commencing construction of any required improvement, the subdivider shall prepare construction plans and specifications and submit them to the city engineer for review and approval. The city engineer may require the submission of the following plans and accompanying construction specifications before authorizing construction or installation of the improvements: 
(1)  Street plans and profiles showing existing and proposed grades, elevations and cross sections of required improvements. 
(2)  Sanitary sewer plans and profiles showing the locations, grades, sizes, elevations and materials of required facilities. 
(3)  Storm sewer plans and profiles showing the locations, grades, sizes, cross sections, elevations and materials of required facilities. 
(4)  Plans and specifications for any required water supply system. 
(5)  Water main plans and profiles showing the locations, sizes, elevations and materials of required facilities. 
(6)  Plans and specifications for all utilities and underground facilities. 
(7)  Planting plans showing the locations, age and species of any required street trees. 
(8)  Such additional special plans or information as may be required by the city engineer. 
(b)  Private contracts. The developer shall engage one general contractor whose qualifications have been approved by the city engineer for each major phase of construction (grading, utilities, streets) or one general contractor for a contract which includes more than one phase of construction. No private contract shall be awarded until all bids have been reviewed by the city engineer. 
(c)  Scheduling. The construction schedule for all required improvements shall be approved by the city engineer. Construction cannot be commenced on any phase of construction until all approvals and conditional requirements are satisfied and a copy of the private contract has been filed with and approved by the council. In addition, a preconstruction meeting shall be held prior to commencement of any work. 
(d)  Street grading. 
(1)  The developer shall furnish standard drawings which indicate the existing and proposed grades of streets shown on the plat, and after review of design engineering work on the streets and approval of street grades by the city engineer, the subdivider shall grade or cause to be graded the full width of the right-of-way of the streets proposed to be dedicated, including the vision clearance triangle on corner lots. In those cases where existing street right-of-way is made a part of the subdivider's plat or abuts the plat, he/she shall grade or cause to be graded that portion of the right-of-way between the existing pavement and the property line. The bed for the roadways in the street right-of-way shall be graded to subgrade elevation. The city engineer shall approve all grading within rights-of-way and said grading shall extend for a sufficient distance beyond the right-of-way to ensure that the established grade will be preserved. The grading of rights-of-way for principal and primary arterials shall only be required where necessary to provide access to the streets or lots in the plat. Lots which abut principal and primary arterials shall be graded to proposed street grade or to a grade approved by the city engineer prior to the sale of affected properties. 
(2)  The developer shall engage a registered engineer to set sub-base grade in accordance with approved centerline grade and cross section; and to set grades necessary to comply with other grading requirements, including vision clearance on corner lots, centerline and lot line grades for greenways, terrace grading for abutting streets and other required grades. The grading program shall consist of the following elements: 
a.  The stripping and removal of all topsoil, debris and vegetation within the road bed. 
b.  Grading of full street rights-of-way to a tolerance of zero to 0.5 feet below proposed centerline grade. Fill sections shall be constructed of approved materials, which do not include topsoil, debris, or vegetation. 
c.  Grading beyond right-of-way to ensure that the established grade will be preserved. Slopes shall be 1:1 for cut sections and 2:1 or less for fill sections. 
d.  Grading of vision clearance triangle on corner lots (maximum embankment of three feet above curb elevation within a triangle formed by two intersection street lines or their projections and a line joining points on such street lines located 25 feet from the street intersection). 
e.  Where a public greenway is included in the land division or subdivision, the subdivider shall provide for an acceptable continuous drainageway in the greenway as determined by the city engineer. 
f.  All additional plat grading, where applicable, lot abutting greenways, terraces of streets abutting plat, public easements for sanitary sewer and sidewalk, and other requirements of ordinances and special conditions of plat approval. 
g.  Compliance with chapter 30, article II, erosion control and stormwater management. 
(e)  Utilities and underground facilities. 
(1)  Upon approval of the subgrading and erection of barricades, the developer shall install the water mains, storm and sanitary sewers, and other utilities. Prior to commencing construction of any required utilities, the subdivider shall submit the construction schedule, plans, and specifications therefor, to the city engineer for review and approval and shall furnish proof that such arrangements as may be required under applicable rates and rules filed with the state public service commission have been made with the owner or owners of the utility lines or services for placing their respective facilities underground. 
(2)  All new electric distribution lines (excluding lines of 12,000 volts or more), all new telephone lines from which lots are individually served, all new telegraph lines, television cables and services, installed within a newly platted area shall be underground unless the plan commission shall specifically find after study that: 
a.  Location, topography, soil, water table, solid rock, boulders, stands of trees, hedges or other physical conditions would make underground installation unreasonable or impracticable; or 
b.  The lots to be served by said facilities can be served directly from existing overhead facilities. 
(3)  Associated equipment and facilities which are appurtenant to underground electric and communications systems, such as but not limited to, substations, pad-mounted transformers, pad-mounted sectionalizing switches and above-grade pedestal-mounted terminal boxes may be located above ground. 
(4)  Temporary overhead facilities may be installed to serve a construction site or where necessary because of severe weather conditions. In the latter case, within a reasonable time after weather conditions have moderated or upon completion of installation of permanent underground facilities, such temporary facilities shall be replaced by underground facilities and the temporary facilities removed unless an exception is granted by the plan commission. 
(5)  Where the electric and communications facilities are to be installed underground, the utility easements shall be graded to within six inches of final grade by the subdivider, prior to the installation of such facilities, and earth fill, piles or mounds of dirt shall not be stored on such easement areas. Utility facilities when installed on utility easements whether overhead or underground shall not disturb any monumentation in the plat. 
(6)  Mechanical compaction of all underground utility ditches or trenches situated within the street right-of-way is required. 
(7)  Ornamental streetlights as prescribed by the city engineer shall be installed at locations identified in the subdivision contract. SmartCode zoned areas shall provide streetlights as allowed and approved under chapter 23. 
(f)  Greenways. Where greenways are included within the land division or subdivision: 
(1)  The subdivider shall be responsible for an acceptable continuous drainageway through the proposed plat as determined by the city engineer. The subdivider shall furnish the city engineer with a plan outlining the greenway boundaries and location of existing drainageways, if any. In addition, the subdivider shall furnish to the city engineer a set of cross sections (on 50-foot stations) of the greenway oriented upon a base line as prescribed by the city engineer. Where a natural drainageway exists which has acceptable hydraulic capacities including alignment and grade as determined by the city engineer, construction will not be required and the existing natural growth shall be preserved. Where such natural growth is not preserved by action of the subdivider or subdivider's agent, he or she shall be responsible for repairing the disturbed areas by sodding. However, in certain locations, as determined by the city engineer, where the hydraulic capacities including alignment and grade are not acceptable, such alignment, grade and slopes shall be improved by the subdivider to the interim minimum requirements of a ten-foot wide ditch bottom with four to one side slopes, all to be sodded. 
(2)  The subdivider shall install permanent pipes or culverts at a grade designated by the city engineer under all streets crossing a greenway or drainageway. Said installation shall be in accordance with the standard specifications for road and bridge construction of the state department of transportation. All costs of the installation shall be the responsibility of the subdivider. The permanent pipe or culvert shall not be installed previous to the installation of the sanitary sewer on a street crossing a greenway unless done pursuant to written agreement between the city and the subdivider. Culverts required across intersections for temporary street drainage, shall be furnished and installed by the developer at his or her expense. All temporary culverts installed by the developer shall be completely removed when the streets are constructed to standards and the area restored to as near to original condition as possible as determined by the city engineer. 
(3)  All ditching and culvert installation shall be done in strict accordance with grades approved by the city engineer. The subdivider's engineer shall be responsible for setting the required grades in the field for construction purposes. 
(4)  In order to ensure proper drainage, the ground elevation along any lot line common with the boundary of a greenway shall not be less than four feet above the flowline of the greenway, or where designated to an elevation established by the city engineer, prior to the sale of affected properties. The flowline grade shall be established by the city engineer. All lot grading and building elevations shall provide for positive drainage. Grading or filling within the greenway limit is prohibited except as authorized by the city engineer. 
(g)  Street construction. 
(1)  Generally. After completion of the underground utilities and approval thereof, the streets shall be constructed. 
(2)  Standard street improvements. 
a.  Standard street improvements shall include concrete curb and gutter, bituminous base course and bituminous surface course; and when required by the plan commission ornamental streetlights, pedestrian walkways, and curb ramping as required by Wis. Stats. § 66.616 for all streets in the plat and all connector and feeder streets and intersections serving the plat. 
b.  The construction of standard street improvements can begin only when the construction of underground utilities, including mechanical compaction and compaction tests, has been approved by the city engineer. 
c.  The developer/subdivider's engineer shall determine and prescribe the thickness of the pavement in accordance with the functional classification of the proposed street and soil subgrade data subject to the approval of the city engineer. In no case shall the thickness of asphalt be less than four inches on 12 inches of stone. The first 2¼ inches of asphalt shall be applied in the initial construction phase, with the final 1¾ inches applied approximately one year after the completion of the initial 2¼-inch paving. 
d.  Upon written approval by the city engineer, the developer may proceed with the construction of the standard street improvements. Standard street improvements shall be installed to the boundary line of the subdivision unless the street culminates in a cul-de-sac, the topography or other physical conditions make it impossible to do so. Streets, roadways, and alleys constructed in areas zoned SmartCode, under chapter 23 shall follow the prescribed street type in the approved regulating plan. 
1.  Streets shall be constructed in accordance with the city standard specifications for public works construction, latest edition on file with the city engineer's office. Local streets shall be constructed to a width of 32 feet between face of curb and face of curb. However, a greater width may be required by the city engineer where necessary to ensure uniformity to an existing street due to or based on anticipated traffic or land use (e.g., 36-foot-wide streets for duplex or multifamily lots). A lesser road width may be approved but only where necessary to ensure uniformity of street width connection to an existing street. 
2.  The roadway width for collector and arterial streets shall be as prescribed by the city engineer based upon anticipated land use, traffic volume, and any applicable federal, state or county requirements. 
e.  Driveways. 
1.  Driveway regulations as identified in chapter 27, article IV, driveways and street access, shall be complied with. 
2.  Where street improvements do not include curbs and gutters driveways shall have a culvert at the ditch line, the diameter of which shall be as specified by the city engineer. 
3.  No accessway to a street or highway shall be established or constructed until all required driveway and access permits have been obtained by the subdivider. 
f.  Walkways. 
1.  Surfaces. The surface of walkways shall possess stability and firmness, be relatively smooth in texture, and have a nonslip surface. 
2.  Drainage structures. Drainage structures should be placed flush with the surface on which they occur, and grates having narrow parallel bars or patterns with openings larger than three-quarter inch should not be used. Drainage structures should not be located between a curb ramp and the corner of a street or immediately downgrade from a curb ramp. 
3.  Lighting. Lighting along walkways shall vary from one-half to five footcandles, depending on the intensity of pedestrian use, hazards present, and relative need for personal safety. 
4.  Ramps. Steps and stepped ramps shall be avoided if possible in order to facilitate servicing with wheeled vehicles. To facilitate movement over low barriers, a ramp should be installed. Surfaces should be nonslip but not corrugated. 
5.  Wheel stops. Wheel stops shall be installed where wheeled vehicles may roll into a hazardous area. They should be two inches to three inches high, six feet wide, and should have breaks in them every five feet to ten feet to allow for water drainage off of the walk. 
(h)  Erosion control. Erosion control measures shall comply with chapter 30, article II, erosion control and stormwater management. 
(i)  Inspection. Prior to commencing any work within the subdivision, the subdivider shall make arrangements with the city engineer to provide for adequate inspection. The city engineer shall inspect and approve all completed work prior to the city's acceptance of the improvements or any release of the security deposited pursuant to section 24-2(c). 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.10, 10-12-2010)  
Sec. 24-11. - Acceptance of improvements. 
After all required improvements have been installed, except for the final 1¾ inches of asphalt surface layer, the subdivider shall notify the city engineer, in writing, that the work is complete and ready for final inspection; and shall file lien waivers or affidavits, in a form acceptable to the city and approved by the city attorney, evidencing that there are no claims, actions, or demands for damages, based upon contract or tort arising out of or in any way related to the project and that no monies are owed to any surveyor, mechanic, contractor, subcontractor, materialman, or laborer after all required improvements have been installed. The city engineer shall inspect the improvements and forward a letter to the subdivider indicating their approval or disapproval. After the improvements have been approved by the city engineer, the clerk will prepare a final billing for engineering, inspection, and legal fees and submit it to the subdivider for payment. When the engineering, inspection, and legal fees have been paid and when the necessary lien waivers and affidavits have been filed, a resolution conditionally accepting the project shall be presented to the common council for action. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.11, 10-12-2010)  
Sec. 24-12. - Release of security. 
(a)  The security furnished pursuant to section 24-2(c) shall remain in full force for a period of one year after the completion of the required improvements and acceptance by the common council unless partially released as hereinafter provided. The security shall be held to guarantee the work performed pursuant to private contracts against defects in workmanship and materials. If any defect appears during the period of the guarantee, the subdivider or its contractor shall, at its expense, install replacements or perform acceptable repairs. In the event that the subdivider fails to install the replacement or perform the repairs, the city may do so and deduct the cost thereof from the security deposit. Unless defects have appeared and have not been repaired, the city will release the security to the subdivider upon expiration of the one year guarantee period. 
(b)  The city engineer may upon acceptance of the improvements release up to 85 percent of the security pursuant to section 24-2(c) when: 
(1)  An application for partial release of security has been filed with the city engineer. The engineer shall have 30 days in which to approve or deny the request. 
(2)  The reduced security deposit will be sufficient to guarantee against defects in material and workmanship. 
(c)  A bond or letter of credit shall be posted upon completion of the final 1½-inch asphalt surface layer as required by section 24-10(g)(2)c to cover the cost of such work plus 15 percent. This letter of credit shall last for one year from the date of the city engineer's written acknowledgment that the 1½-inch asphalt surface layer has been properly accomplished. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.12, 10-12-2010; Ord. No. 2013-O-17, § 1, 8-7-2013)  
Sec. 24-13. - Signing of certificate. 
After entering the contract to provide all required improvements; after posting the security required by section 24-2(c); after payment of any fee imposed pursuant to section 24-2(d)(2); after payment of any area charges for storm sewer and stormwater drainage facilities; after payment of all outstanding charges due against the lands for local sewers, interceptors, force mains, and lift stations previously installed by the city, Madison Metropolitan Sewerage District or any other sewerage district; after payment for water system improvements; after payment of all required park dedication and park improvement fees; and after the subdivider has met all other requirements, the clerk shall execute the certificate inscribed upon the face of the plat or certified survey attesting to the approval thereof and return it to the subdivider for recording. The subdivider shall provide three copies of the recorded plat, restrictions, waiver of any other documents required by the city that relate to the plat to the city. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.13, 10-12-2010)  
Sec. 24-14. - Building permits. 
(a)  Building permits. Except as provided in subsections (b) and (f) of this section, building permits shall not be issued for construction on a parcel created by any division, subdivision, or comprehensive development of land until all public safety improvements have been made and installed and have been inspected and approved by the city engineer, in consultation with the fire chief and police chief and until all other required improvements have been substantially completed as defined in Wis. Stats. § 236.13(2)(am)2. Prior to issuing any building permit, other than as provided in subsection (b) of this section, all fees and charges due to the city shall have been paid by the subdivider. 
(b)  Major construction building permits. The plan commission may authorize the issuance of building permits for major construction projects if, in the opinion of the plan commission, the proposed building is a major undertaking such that under normal construction circumstances and pacing, construction would be expected to last approximately seven months and the commission finds and determines that: 
(1)  Sufficient water service exists, in the opinion of the fire chief, so that proper fire service can be provided; 
(2)  The subdivider provides and maintains temporary roads that meet at a minimum the requirements of the fire department and are sufficient to permit access by emergency vehicles; 
(3)  All required fees have been paid and proper security posted, and barricades provided. 
(c)  Indemnification required for all permits. Prior to the issuance of any permit, the subdivider or developer shall provide an agreement to be recorded whereby the subdivider agrees to indemnify and save the city harmless from any and all claims, actions, demands, or judgments for personal injuries or property damages, together with the actual expenses incurred in connection therewith, arising out of or in any way related to the issuance of such building permits, or construction within the subdivision including any such claim, action, demand or judgment premised upon the negligence of the city or any of its officers, agents, servants, or employees. 
(d)  Consequence of violation. No building permit shall be issued for construction on any site created in violation of the requirements of this chapter. 
(e)  Occupancy requirements. The building owner shall agree in a written affidavit that occupancy shall not occur, nor shall occupancy permits be issued, prior to the completion, inspection and acceptance of all required improvements. 
(f)  Early start permits. Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 236.13(2)(am)3.c., upon application signed by the subdivider, and subject to the requirements below, the zoning administrator may authorize the issuance of early start permits if all public improvements related to public safety are complete and the subdivider has posted the necessary security required 24-2(c)(2). 
(1)  The early start permit may authorize only site grading, utilities, footings, and foundation installation. Other noncombustible construction, such as steel, may be authorized only if no heat source is required for construction. Combustible building materials shall not be stored on site. Material stockpiling shall not occur in any easement areas. 
(2)  The public improvements related to public safety may be deemed to be complete only if all of the following conditions have been met: 
a.  The subdivider shall provide and at all times maintain adequate road access for public safety, including a minimum of road base course, that meets the requirements of the fire department and accommodates the weight, width, and turning radius of the fire apparatus, and is sufficient to permit access by emergency vehicles. 
b.  The subdivider's engineer has assigned the top of foundation wall elevation. After completion of foundation and prior to and as condition of issuance of any additional building permits for vertical construction, the subdivider's or builder's engineer shall certify with their professional license stamp that the top of foundation wall elevation has been constructed in accordance with the approved subdivision plat drainage plan. 
c.  Erosion control for each applicable building site has been designed and installed. 
d.  Lot corner monuments have been installed for each applicable site. 
e.  Street name signs have been installed, and reflective address plates are present at the building site. 
(3)  All fees and charges due to the city, including, but not limited to, park fees and impact fees, shall be paid, proper security posted, and barricades provided, prior to the issuance of any permit including early start permit for construction of foundations and other noncombustible structure. 
(4)  All activities within the plat or CSM shall conform to all requirements of the latest edition to the City of Fitchburg Standard Specifications for Public Works Construction. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.14, 10-12-2010; Ord. No. 2019-O-29 , § 1, 8-27-2019)  
Sec. 24-15. - Fees. 
(a)  Generally. The subdivider shall pay the city all fees hereinafter required and at the times specified. 
(b)  Preliminary plat, final plat, comprehensive development plan and contract fees. 
(1)  The subdivider shall pay an application fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule to the city treasurer at the time the application for approval is filed. 
(2)  In addition to the above fees, the subdivider shall pay all engineering, inspection, consulting and legal fees incurred by the city for services performed by or on behalf of the city in conjunction with the design, inspection and review of any preliminary plat, final plat, comprehensive development plan, or contract, to ensure that the construction of the required improvements in compliance with the plans, specifications and ordinances of the city or any other governmental authority. Engineering, inspection, consulting, and legal fees shall be the actual cost of the city. Such fees may be billed monthly, or upon completion of the project as determined by the city council. It is intended that the application fee provided for in subsection (b)(1) of this section will sufficiently reimburse the cost of city staff time and expenditures. 
(3)  Payment guarantee. To guarantee payment of the engineering, inspection, consulting and attorneys fees required in subsections (b)(1) and (2) of this section, the subdivider shall deposit a fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule with the city treasurer at the time that the application for approval is first filed. If the required fees are paid timely, the deposit will be refunded at the time that the final plat is approved by the common council or 30 days after the preliminary plat or final plat is rejected. In the event that the subdivider fails to pay such required fees within 14 days of the time when the city submits its bill therefor, the city may deduct the amount of such fees from the security deposit. 
(c)  Certified survey fees. 
(1)  The subdivider shall pay an application fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule to the city treasurer at the time the application for approval for any certified survey is filed. 
(2)  The subdivider shall pay all consulting and legal fees incurred by the city for services performed by or on behalf of the city in conjunction with the design, inspection and review of any certified survey to ensure that the construction of the required improvements is in compliance with the plans, specifications and ordinances of the city or any other governmental authority. Consulting and legal fees shall be the actual cost to the city. Such fees may be billed monthly or upon completion of the project as determined by the common council. It is intended that the application fee set forth in subsection (c)(1) of this section will cover all city staff time and expenditures and all consulting fees and expenditures for the city engineer. 
(d)  Parkland improvement fees. 
(1)  The developer or subdivider shall pay prior to signing the final plat or survey, or in the case of a multifamily housing development, the developer shall pay, prior to issuance of a zoning permit a parkland improvement fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. The collected fees shall be utilized to construct park facilities for the plat, survey or development. The park commission shall give priority to establishing the proper neighborhood park facilities according to the plan for parks and open spaces and the generally accepted standards prior to expenditure for facilities in area or community parks. The collected fee shall go into special segregated funds. 
(2)  In a neighborhood park the facilities shall be substantially constructed to the extent practicable within one year of acceptance of improvements of the final phase of the plat, or survey, or issuance of a certificate of completion of a multifamily project's last building. However, facilities adequate to serve the development's growing population shall be constructed within three years of the acceptance date of the first phase of improvements or the first certificate of completion. 
(3)  In the case of expenditures for area and community parks the money shall be expended within six years of acceptance of improvements of the final phase of the plat, or survey, or issuance of a certificate of completion of a multifamily project's last building on those facilities that are proper for area and community parks. The funds shall not be expended on neighborhood park facilities in an area or community park, unless such area or community park serves the developments neighborhood park needs. 
(4)  Facility as used in this subsection (d). The term "facilities" as used in this subsection (d) means recreational equipment and structures, and the related support service infrastructure; it also includes grading, seeding and landscaping. 
(5)  Parkland improvement fee schedule. 
Single-family residential: 	As set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule 
Two-family residential: 	As set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule 
Multifamily residential: 	As set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule 
 
The fee shall be adjusted as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. 
(6)  This fee shall be above and beyond the land dedication or payment-in-lieu of dedication as required under section 24-2(d)(2). 
(e)  Reserved. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-09, § 15.15, 10-12-2010; Ord. No. 2013-O-09, § 2, 6-25-2013; Ord. No. 2018-O-38, § 2, 11-27-2018)  
Sec. 24-16. - Administrative. 
(a)  Appeals of administrative decisions under this chapter may be made to the zoning board of appeals following the procedure in section 22-643.
