However, the engineer may, with the advice and consent of the comptroller, establish a fee collection process from governmental agencies and private utilities in order to expedite the permitting system and recognize that certain excavations are deemed emergencies. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(9))  
Sec. 27-208. - Waiver of fees. 
Fees shall not be waived unless the work involved is a direct result of the engineer's demand that a plant owned by a utility be removed or relocated or unless waived by the board of public works on appeal. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(10))  
Sec. 27-209. - Fee schedule. 
(a)  The minimum fee for each excavation permit for a single address shall be set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. The fee for a permit issued after commencing work, except in cases of emergency as determined by the engineer, shall be double the fees set forth herein. This permit fee shall be in addition to any forfeiture provided elsewhere in this article. 
(b)  For those permit applications which provide for a substantial undertaking of excavation within the public right-of-way attended by disruption of the general public and traffic, the engineer is authorized to assess the actual cost of the city employee's time engaged in the review and inspection of the anticipated work multiplied by a factor determined by the respective department to represent the city's cost for statutory expense, benefits, insurance, sick leave, holidays, vacation and similar benefits, overhead and supervision, said factor not to exceed 2.0, plus the cost of mileage reimbursed to city employees which is attributed to the work, plus all consultant fees associated with the work at the invoiced amount plus ten percent for administration. 
(c)  The city and its contractors shall not pay degradation fees for excavations due to general government functions. 
(d)  Permit fees paid for a permit that the department has revoked are not refundable. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(11))  
Sec. 27-210. - Right-of-way repair and restoration. 
(a)  Required. The permittee shall be required to repair the public right-of-way to department specifications, subject to inspection and acceptance by the department, and to pay a degradation fee, as per section 27-211, unless the permittee elects to restore the right-of-way pursuant to section 27-212. In addition to repairing its own work, the permittee must repair the general area of the work, and the surrounding areas, including the paving and its foundations, to the specifications of the department. The department shall inspect the area of the work and accept the work when it determines that proper repair has been made, per specifications of the department. 
(b)  Guarantees. The permittee guarantees its work and shall maintain it for 36 months following its completion. During this period it shall, upon notification from the department, correct all work to the extent necessary, using the method required by the department. Said work shall be completed within ten calendar days of the receipt of the notice from the department, not including days during which work cannot be done because of circumstances constituting force majeure. 
(c)  Failure to repair/restore. If the permittee fails to repair/restore the right-of-way in the manner and to the condition required by the department, or fails to satisfactorily and timely complete all work required by the department, the department at its option may do such work. In that event the permittee shall pay to the city, within 30 days of billing, the cost of repairing/restoring the right-of-way. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(12))  
Sec. 27-211. - Degradation. 
The general formula for computing the degradation fee shall be the cost per square yard for street, overlay and seal coat multiplied by the appropriate depreciation rate for that street multiplied by the area of the patch. The area of the patch shall be calculated by adding one foot to each side of the actual street cut. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(13))  
Sec. 27-212. - Restoration in lieu of repair and degradation. 
The permittee may elect to restore the excavation and surrounding pavement in lieu of repair and a degradation fee. The restoration shall be in accordance with the standard specifications for public works construction and the plans and specifications of the department. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(14))  
Sec. 27-213. - Notice of completion. 
When the work under any permit hereunder is begun and completed, the permittee shall notify the department. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(15))  
Sec. 27-214. - Site inspection. 
Permittee shall make the work site available to the department and to all others as authorized by law for inspection at all reasonable times during the execution of and upon completion of the work. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(16))  
Sec. 27-215. - Authority of department. 
At the time of inspection the city may order the immediate cessation of any work which poses a threat to the life, health, safety or well-being of the public. The city may issue an order to the registrant or permittee for any work that does not conform to the applicable city standards, conditions or codes. The order shall state that failure to correct the violation will be cause for revocation of the permit. Within ten days after issuance of the order, the registrant or permittee shall present proof to the department that the violation has been corrected. If such proof has not been presented within the required time, the department may revoke the permit pursuant to section 27-217. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(17))  
Sec. 27-216. - Compliance with other laws. 
Obtaining a permit to excavate and/or occupy the right-of-way does not relieve permittee of its duty to obtain all other necessary permits, licenses, and authority and to pay all fees required by any other city, county, state, or federal rules, laws or regulations. A permittee shall comply with all requirements of local, state and federal laws. A permittee shall perform all work in conformance with all applicable codes and established rules and regulations, and is responsible for all work done in the right-of-way pursuant to its permit, regardless of who does the work. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(18))  
Sec. 27-217. - Revocations, suspensions, refusals to issue or extend permits. 
The department may refuse to issue a permit or may revoke, suspend or refuse to extend an existing permit if it finds any of the following grounds: 
(1)  The applicant or permittee is required to be registered per section 27-173 and has not done so; 
(2)  Issuance of a permit for the requested date would interfere with an exhibition, celebration, festival or other event; 
(3)  Misrepresentation of any fact by the applicant or permittee; 
(4)  Failure of the applicant or permittee to maintain required bonds and/or insurance; 
(5)  Failure of the applicant or permittee to complete work in a timely manner; 
(6)  The proposed activity is contrary to the public health, safety or welfare; 
(7)  The extent to which right-of-way space where the permit is sought is unavailable as determined by the engineer; 
(8)  The competing demands for the particular space in the right-of-way; 
(9)  The availability of other locations in the right-of-way or in other rights-of-way for the facilities of the permittee or applicant; 
(10)  The applicability of ordinances or other regulations of the right-of-way that affect location of facilities in the right-of-way; 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(19))  
Sec. 27-218. - Discretionary issuance. 
The department may issue a permit where issuance is necessary to: 
(1)  Prevent substantial economic hardship to a customer of the permittee or applicant; 
(2)  Allow such customer to materially improve its utility service; or 
(3)  Allow the permittee or applicant to comply with state or federal law or city ordinance or an order of a court or administrative agency. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(20))  
Sec. 27-219. - Appeals. 
Any person aggrieved by a decision of the department revoking, suspending, refusing to issue or refusing to extend a permit may file a request for review with the board of public works. A request for review shall be filed within ten days of the decision being appealed. Following a hearing, the board of public works may affirm, reverse or modify the decision of the department. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(21))  
Sec. 27-220. - Emergency situations/work done without a permit. 
(a)  Each registrant shall immediately notify the city by verbal notice on an emergency phone number provided by the city of any event regarding its facilities that it considers to be an emergency. The registrant may proceed to take whatever actions are necessary to respond to the emergency. Within two business days after the occurrence of the emergency the registrant shall apply for the necessary permits, pay the fees associated therewith and otherwise fully comply with the requirements of this article. 
(b)  If the city becomes aware of any emergency regarding a registrant's facilities, the department may attempt to contact the local representative of each registrant affected, or potentially affected, by the emergency. The city may take whatever action it deems necessary to protect the public safety as a result of the emergency, the cost of which shall be borne by the registrant whose facilities occasioned the emergency. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(22))  
Sec. 27-221. - Nonemergency situations/work without a permit. 
Except in an emergency, any person who, without first having obtained the necessary permit, excavates a right-of-way must subsequently obtain a permit, and shall in addition to any penalties prescribed by ordinance, pay double the normal fee for said permit, pay double all the other fees required by this article or other chapters of this Code, deposit with the department the fees necessary to correct any damage to the right-of-way and comply with all of the requirements of this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(23))  
Sec. 27-222. - Discontinued operations. 
A registrant who has determined to discontinue its operations in the city must either: 
(1)  Provide information satisfactory to the department that the registrant's obligations for its facilities under this article have been lawfully assumed by another registrant; or 
(2)  Submit to the department a proposal and instruments for dedication of its facilities to the city. If a registrant proceeds under this section, the city may, at its option: 
a.  Accept the dedication for all or a portion of the facilities; 
b.  Require the registrant, at its own expense, to remove the facilities in the right-of-way at ground or above ground level; or 
c.  Require the registrant to post a bond or provide payment sufficient to reimburse the city for reasonably anticipated costs to be incurred in removing the facilities. 
However, any registrant who has unusable and abandoned facilities in any right-of-way shall remove it from that right-of-way within two years, unless the department waives this requirement. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(24))  
Sec. 27-223. - Abandoned facilities. 
(a)  Facilities of a registrant who fails to comply with this article, and which, for two years, remains unused shall be deemed to be abandoned. Abandoned facilities are deemed to be a nuisance. In addition, to any remedies or rights it has at law or in equity the city may, at its option: 
(1)  Abate the nuisance; 
(2)  Take possession of the facilities; or 
(3)  Require removal of the facilities by the registrant, or the registrant's successor in interest. 
(b)  This section shall not apply to a public utility that is required to follow the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 196.81. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(25))  
Secs. 27-22427-254. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - TEMPORARY PERMITS 
 
Sec. 27-255. - Temporary occupancy or obstruction permit. 
(a)  Any person desiring to occupy or obstruct any right-of-way for any reason other than construction, excavation, or similar acts described elsewhere in this article shall apply for a temporary occupancy permit. The application for such permit shall include the following information: 
(1)  Name and contact information of person applying for permit. 
(2)  Purpose of permit. 
(3)  Location of occupation or obstruction. 
(4)  Dates of proposed occupancy of right-of-way. 
(5)  Fee for temporary occupancy permit. The department shall charge a fee for temporary occupancy permits, as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. 
(6)  The department shall issue or deny permits for temporary occupancy consistent with the purposes of this article. 
(b)  Temporary occupancy or obstruction permit. No occupancy permit shall be granted for a period exceeding three days, unless written justification is provided to the satisfaction of the Director of Public Works as to why additional permit duration is warranted. The Director of Public Works may authorize occupancy permit durations up to 30 days. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.025(26); Ord. No. 2015-O-33, 12-8-2015)  
Secs. 27-25627-273. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - DRIVEWAYS AND STREET ACCESS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 27-274. - Purpose and intent. 
The purpose of this article is to promote the safe and efficient ingress and egress to and traffic upon public streets and roadways and establish standards for access driveways and curbs in the city in the interest of public safety, convenience and general welfare. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.01)  
Sec. 27-275. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Access means the recognized point of vehicular entry onto a roadway. 
Commercial access means access on public or private property which is used for commercial, industrial, mercantile purposes or for any use and purpose which cannot be defined as residential access under this section. 
Controlled access highway means a roadway on which traffic is such that the common council has found, determined and declared it to be necessary, in the interest of public safety, convenience and general welfare to regulate entrance upon and departure from the roadway except at places specifically designated and provided for such purposes, and to exercise special controls over traffic on such roadways. All highways listed in section 27-333 are found, determined and declared to be controlled access highways. 
Curb cut means that section of the concrete curb removed to permit ingress and egress from adjacent property and shall be measured between the points of tangency of the driveway approach at radii with the normal street curbing. 
Department means the city public works department. 
Driveway means every way or area in private ownership and used for vehicular driveway back of the street or highway right-of-way line. 
Driveway approach means an area improved for vehicular traffic on a public street right-of-way which connects the traveled portion of the street with a driveway. 
Permit means a permit to construct a driveway entrance and approach granted by the department upon application therefor in accordance with this article. 
Private roadway means any nonpublic roadway where more than two dwelling structures, or more than two commercial structures under separate ownership have access. 
Residential access means access to a residence, barn, private garage or other improved property and ordinarily used only the by owner or occupant of the premises, his/her guests and necessary service vehicles. Residential access does not include a single access to be used by three or more families to either single- or multiple-unit dwellings. 
Rural road means a street or highway on which the legal speed limit exceeds 35 miles per hour. 
Sight distance means stopping sight distance according to the design speed of a particular highway as indicated in the AASHTO, "A Policy on Geometric Design of Highways and Streets," 1984, page 138, Table III-1 (Rounded for Design Values). 
Street, highway and roadway have the meanings set forth in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(64), (22) and (54), respectively, as incorporated in this Code by section 68-1. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.03)  
Sec. 27-276. - Variances. 
Where the zoning board of appeals finds that unnecessary hardship or practical difficulty from strict compliance with this article, it may vary the application of this article; provided: 
(1)  The public interest is secured; and 
(2)  The board finds that: 
a.  Such variation will not establish an undesirable precedent; and 
b.  Will not have the effect of nullifying the intent and purpose of this article or chapter 22, pertaining to zoning, chapter 24, pertaining to land division or chapter 25, pertaining to architectural control. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.10)  
Secs. 27-27727-300. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PERMITS 
 
Sec. 27-301. - Required. 
A permit shall be required before commencing any construction, repair or alteration of any access drive, driveway, driveway approach, curb or gutter whether or not such action is temporary or for the purpose of permanent construction, repair or alteration. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.08(1))  
Sec. 27-302. - Application. 
Application for a driveway or access permit shall be made on a form prescribed by the department and filed with the head of the department. A processing fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule shall be paid at the time the application is filed. In addition to the application, the department may require the submission of a scale drawing, showing the location of existing and proposed structures, and any other appropriate supporting data deemed necessary for adequate review of the application. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.08(2))  
Sec. 27-303. - Approval by head of department. 
The authority to approve, conditionally approve, or reject applications for driveway access permits is delegated to the head of the department. The head of the department shall render a written determination on the permit application within 30 days. If the application is rejected or conditionally approved, the determination shall state the reasons therefor. Prior to issuance, the department head shall refer all permit applications to the city zoning administrator for determination of compliance with the review requirements of chapter 22, pertaining to zoning, chapter 24, pertaining to land division, and chapter 25, pertaining to architectural control. No permit shall be issued until the zoning administrator notifies the head of the department in writing that all required approvals by the plan commission and common council have been given. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.08(3))  
Sec. 27-304. - Inspection. 
Before the work authorized by a permit issued pursuant to this article is commenced, the permittee shall notify the department. No person shall commence work on a driveway approach or use or permit the use of a driveway or access until such work is inspected and approved in writing by the department or its authorized agent. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.08(4))  
Sec. 27-305. - Restrictions and responsibilities. 
(a)  A permit issued under this article shall expire one year from the date of issuance. 
(b)  The permittee shall assume all responsibility for any injury or damage to persons or property resulting, directly or indirectly, during the construction, repair or alteration of any driveway approach or driveway under a permit issued under this section. 
(c)  No driveway or driveway approach shall be relocated or its dimensions altered without reapplication for a permit under this section. 
(d)  A driveway entrance and approach constructed for one type of use shall not be used under a different use until a permit for such different use at that location is obtained. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.08(5))  
Sec. 27-306. - Appeal. 
(a)  Time to file. If approval of any proposed or previously permitted driveway or access is denied or rescinded by the head of the department for any reason other than failure to obtain required approval under chapters 22, 24 and 25, the applicant, owner, lessor or lessee may appeal to the zoning board of appeals for review of the denial under Wis. Stats. ch. 68 by filing a notice of appeal with the city clerk within 30 days after such denial. 
(b)  Filing fee. At the time of filing the appeal, the appellant shall pay a fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule to assist in defraying the cost of the review. 
(c)  Procedure. The appeal shall be conducted as a review of a final determination in accordance with Wis. Stats. §§ 68.10 to 68.12. 
(d)  Other appeals. Appeals under this article may be consolidated with appeals under chapter 22 relating to the same lot or parcel. Combined appeals shall be conducted in accordance with procedures established by the board of appeals pursuant to chapter 22. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.08(6))  
Sec. 27-307. - Repair and restoration of concrete curb and gutter. 
(a)  Where applicable, all permittees shall restore and repair to city standards all concrete curb and gutters removed, broken, or altered and all terrace areas damaged or disturbed by the construction, repair or alteration of any driveway pursuant to a permit under this article. The permittee shall be responsible for all such restoration and repair caused by work done pursuant to permit regardless of whether the area disturbed or curb and gutter damages abut the property of the permittee adjacent or other property. 
(b)  Upon the failure of any permittee to comply with subsection (a) of this section, the city may make such repairs as necessary and charge the cost of such repairs to the permittee under Wis. Stats. § 66.0703 as well as seek civil penalties or forfeitures under law. 
(c)  The provisions of Wis. Stats. § 66.0703 and chapter 10, article II, division 6, shall be followed as a police power action in the case of reconstruction and repair of concrete curb and gutter damaged by ordinary wear and tear or weathering. Property deemed benefited by such reconstruction or repair shall be assessed 50 percent of the cost of the work and the city shall assume the remaining 50 percent of the cost. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.09)  
Secs. 27-30827-332. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CONTROLLED ACCESS HIGHWAYS 
 
Sec. 27-333. - Designation of controlled access highways. 
The following streets within the city limits are hereby designated as controlled access highways: 
(1)  All highways or portions of highways now located within the corporate boundaries of the city which were previously designated controlled access highways by the Dane County Board pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 83.027, including county highways MM, PD, D, M and B. 
(2)  All rural roads within the corporate boundaries of the city. 
(3)  All state trunk highways or connecting streets and all interstate highways within the corporate limits of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.04(1))  
Sec. 27-334. - Adoption by city. 
By adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived, the city approves and confirms the designation of the roadways listed in section 27-333 as controlled access highways and hereby administers them as such. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.04(2))  
Sec. 27-335. - Easement of access limited. 
No owner or occupant of abutting land shall have the right of easement of access by reason of the fact that their property abuts on the controlled access highway, unless otherwise approved by the department. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.04(3))  
Sec. 27-336. - Alternate access routes to be utilized. 
Every owner and occupant of land abutting the controlled access highway shall utilize alternative access routes. If the department determines that no alternative access is available, there shall be allowed by the department one access onto the controlled access highway per abutting lot existing on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.04(4))  
Sec. 27-337. - Lawful existing access grandfathered; effect of discontinuance. 
All legally authorized existing points of access in use on the effective date of the ordinance from which this article is derived as shown in the records of the county highway department or the city may be continued after the implementation of the provisions of this article; provided if the use of an established point of access is discontinued for a period of one year, the department may revoke the access privilege or require alterations or improvements to achieve compliance with the standards set forth in this article. Modifications to points of access which were established prior to the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived shall be subject to the requirements set forth herein. Nothing in this section shall be construed to constitute approval of an access shown on any approved plat or certified survey map unless such access was in use at the time of the designation of the highway as a controlled access highway by the authority then in charge of the highway. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.04(5))  
Sec. 27-338. - Revocation of access control. 
A controlled access highway designation shall remain in force until the access control is revoked by an action of the common council. The council shall revoke access control on a controlled access highway or any portion thereof, when, after traffic engineering surveys, investigations and studies and a public hearing, it finds that the revocation of access control on such highway or portion thereof is in the public interest. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.04(6))  
Sec. 27-339. - Review of point of access. 
Any point of access permitted under this article shall be subject to review and approval by the department where the department determines that there has been a change in the use which will affect safe and efficient ingress and egress to, and use of, a controlled access highway. This determination shall be based primarily on a significant change in the volume of traffic or the type of vehicle using the point of access. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.04(7))  
Secs. 27-34027-366. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - NUMBER AND LOCATION OF DRIVEWAYS 
 
Sec. 27-367. - Number of driveways limited. 
(a)  Residential. Residential access shall be controlled by the following: 
(1)  Single-family residential: No more than one driveway access per dwelling. 
(2)  Two-family: One driveway for each dwelling unit, provided there is a minimum of five feet of separation between driveways. 
(3)  Multifamily: A maximum of one driveway for every 200 feet of street frontage not to exceed three total driveways per project, with the final level determined by the department in consultation with the plan commission during architectural and design review. 
(4)  Access onto county roadways and major collector streets shall be determined by a traffic impact analysis. Where possible, driveways shall be set a minimum of 250 feet from an intersection. 
(b)  Industrial. A maximum of one driveway approach for every 200 feet of frontage shall be permitted for industrial access. 
(c)  Commercial. A maximum of one driveway approach for every 125 feet of frontage, but not to exceed a total of two driveway approaches, shall be permitted for commercial (including office and multifamily) uses. A lesser or greater distance may be set by the department in consultation with the plan commission during architectural and design review. Access onto county roadways and major collector streets shall be determined by a traffic impact analysis. Where possible, driveways shall be set a minimum of 250 feet from an intersection. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.05)  
Sec. 27-368. - Sight distance. 
All driveways and driveway approaches shall be so located as to provide adequate sight distance in both directions along the street without interfering with vehicular or pedestrian traffic on the street, as required and approved by the department. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.06(1))  
Sec. 27-369. - Joint driveway approaches. 
No driveway approach shall be so constructed that any part of the same extends in front of property belonging to a person other than the permittee unless both property owners sign a joint application for a permit. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.06(2))  
Sec. 27-370. - Separation of driveways. 
Except when a greater distance is required by the department because of special safety concerns, the following minimum separation distances shall be maintained between driveway approaches: 
(1)  Residential: ten feet, but not less than the sum of the approach radii. 
(2)  Nonresidential: 50 feet on highways with maximum speed limit of 35 m.p.h. 
(3)  Nonresidential: 200 feet, on highways with speed limits in excess of 35 m.p.h. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.06(3))  
Secs. 27-37127-398. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - GRADES, STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS 
 
Sec. 27-399. - General construction and improvement specifications. 
All driveways, driveway approaches, curb cuts, curb construction or improvements shall be done under specifications prepared and approved by the department and in accordance with elevation and grades from time to time established by the department and filed in the office of the department and filed in the office of the department. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.07(1))  
Sec. 27-400. - Culverts. 
Culverts, aprons and walls shall be installed at all driveway approaches where storm sewer improvements have not been constructed. The size and installation of culverts shall be in accordance with specifications from time to time established by the department and filed in its office. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.07(2))  
Sec. 27-401. - Length. 
No driveway, except for those used for agricultural operations, shall exceed 300 feet in length (as measured along the centerline of such drive beginning at the pavement edge of the intersecting public street) unless such driveway is at least 20 feet in width, has an all-weather surface and has an approved fire department turnaround. If the driveway serves more than two separate dwelling structures, or two or more commercial buildings under separate ownership, it shall be classified as a private roadway and subject to the requirements of section 27-433. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.07(3))  
Sec. 27-402. - Curb openings. 
(a)  Curbs shall not be interrupted by openings for driveways or other accessways to private property unless the number and location of such interruptions have been approved by the department. 
(b)  When allowed, curb openings (excluding tapers) shall be no less than 14 feet nor more than 24 feet in width for single-family and multifamily dwellings. The curb opening (excluding tapers) for each driveway at a two-family dwelling unit shall not exceed 20 feet in width (40 feet total). The curb opening (excluding tapers) intended to afford access to commercial or industrial property shall be as determined and prescribed by the department, but no greater than 37 feet in width. The applicant may request an administrative variance for a commercial or industrial curb opening (excluding tapers) that is greater than 37 feet in width by providing documentation that demonstrates the following: 
(1)  Is needed to accommodate truck turning movements to the property to avoid impacts to the orderly flow of traffic on adjacent road. Applicant should supply: 
a.  Size of vehicle and frequency of truck activity; 
b.  Turning path exhibit for truck movements at the driveway; and 
c.  Designation of primary access for truck traffic to the site. 
(2)  Will not have an adverse impact upon properties adjacent to the property upon which the proposed driveway is located; 
(3)  Has been designed to address all public safety impacts associated with the increased curb opening width. 
The director of public works may require special conditions for the additional curb opening width such as, but not limited to, pavement markings, colored concrete, or signage. 
If the director of public works declines to approve a request for a larger commercial or industrial curb opening width, such request shall be referred to the board of public works for recommendation and to the council for action. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.06(4); Ord. No. 2015-O-28, § 1, 10-22-2015)  
Secs. 27-40327-432. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - PRIVATE ROADWAYS 
 
Sec. 27-433. - Design and construction specifications. 
Private roadways shall be at least 24 feet in width, and constructed with either standard concrete curb and gutter or concrete ribbon curb and gutter. The required 24-foot width shall be measured from flow line to flow line of the curb and gutter. In addition, the private roadways shall meet the specifications as set forth in sections 27-43427-440. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.06(5))  
Sec. 27-434. - Construction materials. 
All private roadways shall be constructed of asphalt or concrete and shall provide for subbase and pavement design equal to or greater than that for local public streets. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.07(4)(a))  
Sec. 27-435. - Turnarounds required for certain roads. 
If a private roadway is over 300 feet in length (centerline measurement) from the public street access and has a dead end, it shall provide a turnaround to meet the minimum following specifications: A cul-de-sac turnaround shall be accomplished with a minimum radius of 50 feet. A T-shape turnaround shall be at least 30 feet in length to each side of the edge of the main private roadway pavement (the total top of the T would be 84 feet). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.07(4)(b))  
Sec. 27-436. - Road names. 
Private roadways shall be named with a suffix ending in "way." All names shall comply with section 24-8(b). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.07(4)(c))  
Sec. 27-437. - Grade and curvature. 
Private roadway street grades shall not exceed eight percent, or be less than 0.48 percent. A road grade of up to ten percent may be approved for unique and special circumstances by the city engineer. Curvature of the private roadways shall have a radius of at least 100 feet. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.07(4)(d), (e))  
Sec. 27-438. - Intersections. 
Where there is an intersection of private roadways, the intersection shall provide a radius of at least 20 feet. At the private roadway intersection with a public street, the appropriate sidewalk section and grades shall be maintained. Drive openings shall not exceed those allowed under this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.07(4)(f), (g))  
Sec. 27-439. - Maintenance agreement required. 
The owners of the private roadways shall provide a maintenance agreement dealing with standard annual maintenance and longterm reconstruction maintenance to the city engineer for review and approval. The owners shall also be required to provide and maintain any and all private roadway signage for the users of the private roadway. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.07(4)(h))  
Sec. 27-440. - Plan commission may impose additional requirements. 
The plan commission, for projects requiring its approval may require parking stalls, pedestrian access, aesthetic improvements, pervious pavement or other measures to provide for the safe and efficient movement of persons and vehicles within the area served by the private roadway. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 25.07(4)(i))  
Chapter 29 - HISTORIC PRESERVATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Historic preservation program, Wis. Stats. § 44.30 et seq.; definitions relating to historic preservation, Wis. Stats. § 44.31; city planning and zoning, Wis. Stats. § 623.23; comprehensive municipal planning, Wis. Stats. § 66.1001. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 29-1. - Purpose and intent. 
It is hereby declared a matter of public policy that the protection, enhancement, perpetuation and use of improvements of special character or special historical interest or value is a public necessity and is required in the interest of health, prosperity, safety and welfare of the people. The purpose of this chapter is to: 
(1)  Effect and accomplish the protection, enhancement and perpetration of such improvements which represent or reflect elements of the city's cultural, social, economic, political, engineering and architectural history; 
(2)  Safeguard the city's historic and cultural heritage, as embodied and reflected in such historic structures and sites; 
(3)  Foster civic pride in the beauty and noble accomplishments of the past; 
(4)  Protect and enhance the city's attractions to residents and visitors and serve as a support and stimulus to business and industry; 
(5)  Strengthen the economy of the city; and 
(6)  Promote the use of historic districts and landmarks for the education, pleasure and welfare of the people of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.01)  
Sec. 29-2. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Alteration means any act or process that changes one or more of the exterior features of a structure or site including, but not limited to, the erection, construction, reconstruction, or removal of any structure or site. 
Commission means the landmarks preservation commission created under chapter 6, article II, division 2. 
Construction means the act of adding an addition to an existing structure or the erection of a new principal or accessory structure on a lot or property. 
Demolition means any act or process that destroys in part or in whole a historic site or structure. 
Historic site means any parcel of land whose historic significance is due to a substantial value in tracing human history, or whose archaeological significance is able to be documented, or upon which a historic event has occurred and which has been designated as a historic site pursuant to the provisions of this chapter, or an improvement parcel, or part thereof, on which is situated a landmark and any abutting improvement parcel, or part thereof, used as and constituting part of the premises on which the landmark is situated. 
Historic structure means any improvement which has a special character or special historic interest or value as part of the development, heritage or cultural characteristics of the city, state or nation and which has been designated as a historic structure pursuant to provisions of this chapter. 
Improvement means any building, structure, place of work or art or other object constituting a physical betterment of property, or any part of such betterment. 
Improvement parcel is the unit or property which includes a physical betterment constituting an improvement and the land embracing the site thereof, and is treated as a single entity for the purpose of levying real estate taxes; provided, however, that the term "improvement parcel" shall also include any unimproved area of land which is treated as a single entity for tax purposes. 
Removal means any relocation of a structure on its site or to another site. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.02)  
Sec. 29-3. - Conditions dangerous to life, health and property. 
Nothing contained in this chapter shall prohibit the making of necessary construction, reconstruction, alteration or demolition of any historic structure, any improvement on a historic site pursuant to order of any governmental agency or pursuant to any court judgment, for the purpose of remedying emergency conditions determined to be dangerous to life, health or property. In such cases, no approval from the commission shall be required. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.12)  
Sec. 29-4. - Landmarks preservation commission. 
This landmarks preservation commission shall have composition and membership as defined in sections 6-272 and 6-273. 
(1)  In addition to the powers and duties set forth in section 6-273, the commission shall have the power subject to section 29-5, to designate historic structures and historic sites within the city limits. Property owners or their designees may apply, at no cost, to be considered for designation, or the commission may undertake the designation procedure upon the majority vote of the commission members. Such designations shall be based upon criteria set forth in article III, division 2, of this chapter. Once designated by the commission, and approved by the common council, such historic structures and sites shall be subject to all the provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  Whenever a historic structure or historic site is designated, the commission shall provide a brief cultural and/or architectural analysis supporting the historical significance of the structure or site, specific guidelines for development if appropriate and a statement of preservation objectives. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, §§ 29.03, 29.05(1))  
Sec. 29-5. - Procedure for designation or rescission of historic structures and sites. 
(a)  The commission may, after notice and public hearing, establish historic structures and sites or rescind such designation after application of the criteria in sections 29-68 and 29-69. 
(b)  At least ten days prior to such hearing, the commission shall notify the owners of record of such property, as listed in the office of the city assessor and any person holding a claim or encumbrance against such property according to the record in the register of deeds, as well as persons who are owners of property in whole or in part, as listed in the office of the city assessor, situated within 300 feet of the boundaries of such property. Notice of such hearing shall also be published as a Class 1 notice, under the state statutes. 
(c)  The commission shall also notify the following: the parks and recreation department, fire department, police department, zoning and planning department and the councilmember from the district in which the proposed designation is located. Each aforementioned city department noted shall respond to the commission within 15 days of notification with its comments on the proposed designation or rescission. Failure to respond shall not delay the hearing. 
(d)  The commission shall then conduct such public hearing and, in addition to the notified persons, may hear expert witnesses, and shall have the power to subpoena such witnesses and records as it deems necessary. The commission may conduct an independent investigation into the proposed designation or rescission. 
(e)  Within ten days after the close of the public hearing, the commission may designate the property as either a historic structure or a historic site. In the case where the commission has had a request to rescind a designation, the commission shall make its determination within ten days after the close of the public hearing. The common council shall act to approve or disapprove a designation within 60 days of the date of the commission's recommendation. 
(f)  After such designation or rescission has been made, notification shall be sent to the property owner or owners, and to such other persons as appeared at the public hearing. Notification shall also be given to the city clerk, the parks and recreation department, zoning and planning department, assessing department, building inspection department, fire department, police department and the plan commission. The commission shall cause such designation or rescission to be recorded, at the city's expense, in the office of the Dane County Register of Deeds. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(2))  
Secs. 29-629-26. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - HISTORIC PRESERVATION FUND 
 
Sec. 29-27. - Established. 
To facilitate proper maintenance of historic buildings and sites, the city shall establish a special interest-earning segregated account to receive monies earmarked for preservation from grants, donations or other funding sources, including any monies designated during the yearly budget process. Such funds may be issued on a grant basis to persons who may request financial assistance in order to maintain their historically designated property in the manner prescribed by this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.13(1))  
Sec. 29-28. - Grant application procedure. 
Grant application materials shall be formulated by and kept on file in the zoning/planning department. Applications for the monies in the account shall be reviewed by the landmarks preservation commission. The commission shall make recommendations to the zoning administrator/city planner who shall make the final determination to award, modify or not award a grant. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.13(2))  
Sec. 29-29. - Limitations. 
No grants may be submitted until the monies in the account total at least $5,000.00. If the funds fall below $1,000.00, a moratorium shall be placed on grant applications until the fund again reaches $5,000.00. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.13(3))  
Secs. 29-3029-46. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - DESIGNATION OF HISTORIC SITES AND STRUCTURES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 29-47. - Recognition plaques. 
At such time as a historic structure or historic site has been designated in accordance with the provisions of this article, such structure or site is eligible to have erected on it, at city expense, a suitable plaque declaring that such property is a designated historic structure or site. If a plaque is requested by the owner, and approved by the commission, the plaque shall state the accepted name of the landmark, the date of its construction, and other information deemed appropriate by the commission. In the case of a historic site which is not the site of a historic building, such plaque shall state the common name of the site, and such other information deemed appropriate by the commission. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.07)  
Secs. 29-4829-67. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CRITERIA 
 
Sec. 29-68. - For structure and site designation. 
For purposes of this article, a historic structure or historic site designation may be placed on any site, natural or improved, including any building, improvement or structure located thereon, or any area of particular historic, architectural, cultural, archaeological, or geographical significance to the city such as historic structures or sites that: 
(1)  Exemplify or reflect the broad cultural, political, economic, geographical, prehistory, or social history of the nation, state or community; 
(2)  Are identified with historic personages or with important events in the national, state or local history; 
(3)  Embody the distinguishing characteristics or an architectural type or specimen, inherently valuable for a study of a period, style, method of construction, or of indigenous materials or craftsmanship; or 
(4)  Are representative of the notable work of a master builder, designer or architect whose individual genius influenced an age. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.04(1))  
Sec. 29-69. - Operating guidelines may be adopted by commission. 
The commission may adopt specific operating guidelines for landmark sites designation providing such are in conformance with the provisions in this division. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.04(2))  
Secs. 29-7029-96. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - CERTIFICATES OF APPROPRIATENESS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 29-97. - Required. 
(a)  No owner or person in charge of a historic site or structure shall undertake alteration, construction, removal or demolition upon such designated property or cause or permit any such work to be performed upon such property unless a certificate of appropriateness has been granted by the landmarks preservation commission. Any proposal for alteration, construction, removal or demolition involving a designated historic site or structure shall be filed with the landmarks commission, and no other city permits which may be required shall be granted until the landmarks commission has granted a certificate of appropriateness. 
(b)  If a project is undertaken without receiving a certificate of appropriateness, the commission may require that the work be removed and the structure or site returned to its appearance before alteration. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(3)(a))  
Sec. 29-98. - Initial review of application. 
Upon filing of any application with the landmarks commission, for alteration, construction or removal, the landmarks commission shall determine: 
(1)  Whether, in case of a designated historic site or structure, the proposed work would detrimentally change, destroy or adversely affect the significance of the site based on the analysis of the site made at the time of its designation; 
(2)  Whether, in the case of a designated historic structure, the proposed work would detrimentally change, destroy or adversely affect any exterior architectural feature of the improvement upon which said work is to be done; 
(3)  Whether, in the case of the construction of a new improvement upon a historic site, the new improvement would adversely affect the physical appearance of the site, or not harmonize with the external appearance of existing improvements on the site; and 
(4)  Whether the proposed alteration, construction, or removal does not conform to the guidelines for development or preservation objectives outlined in the analysis made at the time of designation. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(3)(b))  
Sec. 29-99. - Standards from grant or denial. 
In determining whether to grant approval of any application for alteration, construction or removal, the commission shall consider the following standards: 
(1)  Interiors. In general, the commission shall not regulate or find cause to deny an application for a certificate of appropriateness if the alternation or construction proposed for the interior of a structure does not affect the exterior of the structure. 
(2)  Height. All additions shall be no higher than the existing or original building. 
(3)  Second exit platforms. Second exit platforms shall not be applied to the front or side of a building, unless they are not visible from the street. 
(4)  Solar apparatus. Passive and active solar apparatus will be allowed only if such devices do not detract from the architectural integrity of the building and are as unobtrusive as possible. Solar apparatus will not be permitted if such devices hide from street view significant architectural features of the building or neighboring building, if their installation requires the loss of significant architectural features, or if they are of such a large scale that they become a major feature of the design. 
(5)  Repairs. Repairs in materials that exactly duplicate the original in composition, texture and appearance are encouraged. Repairs in new materials that duplicate the original in texture and appearance are also permitted. Repairs in materials that do not duplicate the original in appearance will be permitted on an individual basis if the repairs are compatible with the character and materials of the existing structure and if repairs that duplicate the original in appearance are prohibitively expensive. 
(6)  Restoration. Projects that will return the appearance of the building to an earlier appearance are encouraged and will be permitted if such projects are documented by photographs, architectural or archaeological research or other suitable evidence. 
(7)  Residing with aluminum or vinyl. Residing with aluminum or vinyl that replaces clapboards or nonoriginal siding on buildings originally sided with clapboards will be permitted only of the new siding imitates the width of the original siding within one inch, provided that all architectural details (such as window trim, wood cornices, and ornament) either remain uncovered or are duplicated exactly in appearance. Siding that imitates wood graining may be permitted. If more than one layer of siding exists on the building, all layers except the first must be removed before new siding is applied. If insulation is applied under the new siding, all trim must be built up so that it projects from the siding as in the original. 
(8)  Storms, screens and storm doors. The repair and retention of original storms, screens and storm doors, or the replacement of same with new units that duplicate the original in materials and appearance is encouraged. Replacements with nonoriginal materials, such as combination metal components, may also be permitted. If metal components are used, owners are encouraged to use metal components which have been factory enameled. Painting of raw aluminum storms after a year of weathering of the finish is encouraged. Storm doors that imitate a specific style shall be permitted only if the style matches the style of the building. 
(9)  Addition and alterations. 
a.  The appearance of street facades of a building shall not be altered unless the design is sensitive to the historic character of the building. Contemporary design for alterations and additions to existing properties shall not be discouraged when such alterations and additions do not destroy significant historical, architectural, or cultural materials, and such design is compatible with the size, scale, color, materials, and character of the structure or site. 
b.  Whenever possible, new additions or alterations shall be done in such a manner that, if such additions or alterations were to be removed in the future, the essential form and integrity of the structure would be unimpaired. 
c.  Roof alterations, resulting in an increased building volume, to provide additional windows, headroom, or area are not permitted, unless such alterations return the structure to an original documented condition. If the existing roofing material is the same as the original, changes in the appearance of roofing materials (not including color) will not be permitted except when the repair of the existing roof is unfeasible and the cost of replacing it in kind is prohibitive. The new roof shall match the original in appearance (not including color) as closely as economically possible. If the existing roofing material is not original to the house, the new roofing materials shall harmonize in color with the house. Thick wood shakes, rolled roofing and hexagonal shingles will not be allowed. Restoration to a documentable earlier appearance is encouraged. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(4))  
Sec. 29-100. - Determination. 
(a)  Time for making. The commission shall make a determination as to whether to grant a certificate of appropriateness within 30 days of an application. 
(b)  Grant of application. If the commission finds that the provisions in sections 29-97 through 29-100 have been satisfied, the commission shall grant approval to the application and issue a certificate of appropriateness to the applicant. Upon such approval, any other necessary city permits may be issued. 
(c)  Denial of application. A denial of a certificate of appropriateness shall be accompanied by a statement of the reasons for the denial. The commission shall make recommendations to the applicant concerning changes, if any, in the proposal that would cause the commission to reconsider its denial and shall confer with the applicant and attempt to resolve as quickly as possible the differences between the owner and commission. The applicant may resubmit an amended application which incorporates the commission's concerns or suggestions. 
(d)  Appeal. The commission's action to approve or deny an application for a certificate of appropriateness may be appealed to the board of appeals according to the procedure in division 2 of this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(5))  
Sec. 29-101. - Rescission of designation. 
Any party who is listed as the owner of record of a historic structure or site at the time of its designation, who can demonstrate to the commission that by virtue of such designation he/she is unable to find a buyer willing to preserve such historic structure or site, even though he/she had made reasonable attempts in good faith to find and attract such a buyer, may petition the commission for a rescission if it designation. Following the filing of such petition with the secretary of the commission, the procedure outlined in section 29-5 shall be followed and in addition: 
(1)  The owner and the commission shall work together in good faith to locate a buyer for the subject property who is willing to abide by its designation. 
(2)  If, at the end of a period not exceeding one year from the date of such petition, no buyer can be found, and if the owner still desires to obtain such rescission, the commission shall rescind its designation of the subject property. 
(3)  In the event of rescission, the commission shall notify the city clerk, the building inspection department and the city assessor of same, and shall cause the same to be recorded, at its own expense, in the office of the county register of deeds. 
(4)  Following any such rescission, the commission may not redesignate the subject property a historic structure or site for a period of not less than five years following the date of rescission. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.09)  
Secs. 29-10229-130. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - APPEAL 
 
Sec. 29-131. - Persons entitled to appeal. 
An appeal of a decision of the commission to approve or deny a certificate of appropriateness may be taken to the board of appeals by the applicant for the certificate of appropriateness or by the councilmember from the district in which the subject structure or site is located. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.06(1))  
Sec. 29-132. - Procedure. 
Such appeal shall be initiated by filing a petition to appear, specifying the grounds therefor, with the board of appeals within ten days of the date the decision of the commission is made. The board of appeals shall follow its rules and procedures for hearing of appeals, including scheduling of a public hearing within 30 days and the notification of property owners within 300 feet of the subject property. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.06(2))  
Sec. 29-133. - Decision. 
After a public hearing the board may, by favorable vote of four members, reverse or modify the decision of the landmarks commission if, after balancing the interest of the public in preserving the subject property and the interest of the owner in using it for his/her own purposes, the board finds that, owing to special conditions pertaining to the specific piece of property, failure to approve or modify the proposal will preclude any and all reasonable use of the property and/or will cause serious hardship for the owner, provided that any self-created hardship shall not be a basis for reversal or modification of the landmarks commission's decision. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.06(3))  
Secs. 29-13429-164. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - DEMOLITION 
 
Sec. 29-165. - Permit, approval of commission and certificate of appropriateness required. 
No permit to demolish all or part of a designated historic structure or site shall be granted by the city except as provided in this article. No owner or operator of a historic structure or site shall be granted a permit to demolish such property unless approval therefor has been granted by the landmarks commission and a certificate of appropriateness has been issued. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(6)(a))  
Sec. 29-166. - Application. 
An application for a permit to demolish all or part of a historic structure or site shall be filed with the landmarks commission either prior to or concurrent with the filing of a demolition permit from the building inspection department. Such application shall be made in all cases, both when demolition is considered in conjunction with a special development plan, a rezoning plan or a conditional use plan. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(6)(a)(1))  
Sec. 29-167. - Suspension of action on application; effect of failure to suspend or issue determination. 
Upon filing of an application for a permit to demolish such property, the landmarks commission may suspend action on the application for a period not to exceed one year from the date of the filing of application for the demolition permit. Failure to grant approval, or to issue a written determination to suspend action on the application within 30 days of the application date shall be deemed approval for the demolition, provided that the determination period may be extended an additional 30 days by written stipulation of the applicant and the commission. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(6)(a)(2))  
Sec. 29-168. - Applicant's rights and duties upon suspension of action on application. 
If the commission determines to suspend action on the application, the commission and the applicant shall undertake negotiations to find a mutually agreeable method of saving the subject property. During negotiations, the owner shall take whatever steps are necessary to prevent further deterioration of the structure or site. At the end of the one-year period the commission shall act on the suspended application by either granting or refusing to grant approval for the proposed demolition. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(6)(a)(3))  
Sec. 29-169. - Standards to be applied in considering application. 
In determining whether to grant approval of any demolition, the commission shall consider and may give decisive weight to any or all of the following: 
(1)  Whether the building or structure is of such architectural or historic significance that its demolition would be detrimental to the public interest and contrary to the general welfare of the people of the city and the state; 
(2)  Whether demolition of the subject property would be contrary to the purpose and intent of this chapter as set forth in section 29-1 and the objectives outlined in the analysis made at the time of designation; 
(3)  Whether the building or structure is of such old and unusual or uncommon design, texture and/or material that it could not be reproduced or be reproduced only with great difficulty and/or expense; 
(4)  Whether retention of the structure or site would promote the general welfare of the people of the city and the state by encouraging the study of American history, architecture and design or by developing an understanding of the American culture and heritage; 
(5)  Whether the structure or site is in such a deteriorated condition that it is not structurally or economically feasible to preserve or restore it, provided that any hardship or difficulty claimed by the owner is not self-created or the result of any failure to maintain the property in good repair. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(6)(b))  
Sec. 29-170. - Appeal. 
An appeal from the decision of the landmarks commission to approve or deny a demolition application shall be made to the board of appeals as set forth in article IV, division 2, of this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.05(6)(c))  
Secs. 29-17129-193. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - MAINTENANCE 
 
Sec. 29-194. - Duty to keep in good repair. 
Every person in charge of a historic structure or historic site shall keep in good repair all of the exterior portions of such improvement and all interior portions thereof, which, if not so maintained, may cause or tend to cause the exterior portions of such improvement to fall into a state of disrepair. This provision shall be in addition to all other provisions of law requiring such improvement to be kept in good repair. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.08)  
Sec. 29-195. - City's right to inspect. 
Every person in charge of any historic structure or historic site shall maintain same or cause or permit same to be maintained in a condition with the provisions of this chapter. The common council may appoint the building inspection department or any other individual or group of individuals to enforce this article. The duties of the inspection officer shall include periodic inspection at intervals provided by the common council of designated historic structures and sites. These inspections may include physical entry upon the property and improvement, with permission of the owner, to ensure that interior alterations or maintenance will not jeopardize the exterior appearance or structural stability of the improvement. If an owner refuses permission for the enforcement officer to enter for purposes of inspection, the inspection officer may obtain a warrant of entry pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0119 and take any other reasonable measures to further enforcement of this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 29.10)  
TITLE III BUILDING AND ENVIRONMENTAL CONTROL  
Chapter 30 - ENVIRONMENT[1]
