(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 27.16(app. A); Ord. No. 2014-O-06, § 2, 3-25-2014)  
Secs. 30-3630-58. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - WELL ABANDONMENT 
 
Sec. 30-59. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this article is to prevent contamination of groundwater and to protect the public health, safety and welfare by ensuring that unused, unsafe or noncomplying wells or wells which may serve as conduits for contamination or wells which may be illegally cross-connected to municipal water systems, are properly abandoned. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 21.01)  
Sec. 30-60. - Applicability. 
This article applies to all wells on premises served by or adjacent to city utility district no. 1, within the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 21.02)  
Sec. 30-61. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Municipal water system means the water supply and distribution system owned and operated by the city. 
Noncomplying means a well or pump installation which does not comply with the provisions of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 812 in effect at the time the well was constructed, a contamination source was installed, the pump was installed or work was done on either the well or pump installation. 
Pump installation means the pump and related equipment used for withdrawing water from a well including the discharge piping, the underground connections, pitless adapters, pressure tanks, pits, sampling faucets and well seals or caps. 
Unsafe means a well or pump installation which produces water which is bacteriologically contaminated or contaminated with substances in exceedance of the standards of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 109 or 140 or for which a health advisory has been issued by the department of natural resources. 
Unused means a well or pump installation which is not in use or does not have a functional pumping system. 
Well means an excavation or opening into the ground made by digging, boring, drilling, driving, or other methods for the purpose of obtaining groundwater for consumption or other use. 
Well abandonment means the filling and sealing of a well according to the provisions of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 811. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 21.03)  
Sec. 30-62. - Abandonment required. 
All wells located on premises served by the city utility district no. 1 shall be abandoned in accordance with the terms of this article and Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 811 by or no later than one year from the date of connection to the municipal water system, unless a well operation permit has been obtained by the well owner from the city utility district no. 1. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 21.04)  
Sec. 30-63. - Annexation. 
Upon annexation of lands to city utility district no. 1, the owners of such lands shall immediately identify to the director of public works, by filing a report with city utility district no. 1, all existing wells located on such lands. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 21.05)  
Sec. 30-64. - Well operation permit. 
City utility district no. 1 may grant a permit to a private well owner to operate a well for a period not to exceed five years providing the conditions of this section are met. An owner may request renewal of a well operation permit by submitting information verifying that the conditions of this section are met. City utility district no. 1, or its agent, may conduct inspections or have water quality tests conducted at the applicant's expense to obtain or verify information necessary for consideration for a permit application or renewal. Permit applications and renewals shall be made on a form provided by the city utility district no. 1. The following conditions must be met for issuance or renewal of a well operation permit: 
(1)  The well and pump installation meet or are upgraded to meet the requirements of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 812. 
(2)  The well construction and pump installation have a history of producing bacteriologically safe water as evidenced by at least two samplings taken a minimum of two weeks apart. No exception to this condition may be made for unsafe wells, unless the department of natural resources approves, in writing, the continued use of the well. 
(3)  There are no cross-connections between the well and pump installation and the municipal water system. 
(4)  The proposed use of the well and pump installation can be justified as being necessary in addition to water provided by the municipal water system. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 21.06)  
Sec. 30-65. - Abandonment procedures. 
(a)  All wells abandoned under the jurisdiction of this article or rules of city utility district no. 1 shall be abandoned according to the procedures and methods of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 812. All debris, pump, piping, unsealed liners and any other obstructions which may interfere with sealing operations shall be removed prior to abandonment. The material for filling the abandoned well shall be concrete. 
(b)  The owner of the well, or the owner's agent, shall notify the utility superintendent at least 48 hours prior to commencement of any well abandonment activities. The abandonment of the well shall be observed by city utility personnel. 
(c)  An abandonment report form, supplied by the department of natural resources, shall be submitted by the well owner to city utility district no. 1 and the department of natural resources within ten days of the completion of the well abandonment. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 21.07)  
Sec. 30-66. - Fuel storage facilities. 
Gasoline or fuel oil storage tank installations shall not be constructed within a 2,000-foot radius of an existing or proposed public water system well. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 21.08)  
Sec. 30-67. - New private wells prohibited. 
(a)  Except as hereinafter provided, new private wells shall not be constructed within the city utility district system when a water main exists less than 200 feet from the nearest point of the property to the city utility district main. In such cases service shall be provided by city utility district extensions and connection charges shall be paid in accordance with article II of chapter 40. 
(b)  Notwithstanding the prohibition set forth in subsection (a) of this section, the director of public works may authorize, subject to common council approval, the construction and operation of a private well on property situated within 200 feet of a city utility district main when all of the following circumstances exist: 
(1)  The private well is not used to obtain or provide water for human consumption; 
(2)  The municipal water supply is unsuitable for the intended use of water obtained from the private well; 
(3)  Use of the municipal water supply would impose an unreasonable hardship upon the property owner; 
(4)  The well poses no threat to the public good or to the health, safety, and welfare of the city; 
(5)  The owner of the well obtains and maintains a well operation permit in accordance with section 30-64. 
(c)  Any well constructed and operated under the circumstances listed in subsection (b) of this section shall be abandoned in accordance with section 30-62 when any of those circumstances cease to exist. 
(d)  The director of public works shall maintain a written record documenting the facts relied upon in authorizing the construction and operation of any private well within the city utility district. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 21.09)  
Chapter 32 - MANUFACTURED AND MOBILE HOMES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Municipal regulation of manufactured and mobile home communities, Wis. Stats. § 66.0435 et seq. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 32-1. - Definitions. 
Whenever used in this chapter, the words and phrases which follow shall be construed as indicated unless a different meaning expressly appears from the context: 
Anchoring equipment means straps, cables, turnbuckles, and chains, including tensioning devices, which are used with ties to secure a mobile home to ground anchors. 
Anchoring system means a combination of ties, anchoring equipment, and ground anchors that will, when properly designed and installed resist overturning and lateral movement of the mobile home from wind forces. 
Commission means the Fitchburg Mobile Home Commission. 
Existing park means a mobile home park the construction of which was commenced prior to the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. 
Expansion means to enlarge, to increase the size of the park (does not include replacing units on existing lots). 
Ground anchor means any device at the mobile home site designed to transfer mobile home anchoring loads to the ground. 
Licensee means any person licensed to operate and maintain a mobile home park under this section. 
Licensing authority means the city. 
Manufactured home means a structure, transportable in one or more sections, which in traveling mode, is eight body feet or more in length, or, when erected on site, is 320 or more square feet, and which is built on permanent chassis and designed to be used as a dwelling with or without a permanent foundation when connected to the required utilities, and includes the plumbing, heating, air conditioning, and electrical systems contained therein. 24 CFR 3280.2(a)(16). Manufactured homes should be certified and labeled as a "manufactured home" under 42 USC 5401 to 5426, or state law in conformity with federal law. 
Mobile home means a vehicle or trailer which is, or was originally, designed, constructed and equipped for primary use as sleeping, eating and living quarters, or which is intended for such use. The term shall include any additions, attachments, annexes, foundations and appurtenances unless the assessed value of such additions, attachments, annexes, foundations and appurtenances equals or exceeds 50 percent of the assessed value of the vehicle or trailer. 
Mobile home park means a plot or plots of ground upon which two or more units, occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes are located, regardless of whether or not a charge is made for such accommodation. 
New park means a mobile home park constructed after the effective date of the ordinance from which this chapter is derived. 
Occupant means a person residing in a mobile home. 
Park means a mobile home park. 
Site means a plot of ground designed for the accommodation of one mobile home. 
Tie means a strap, cable or securing device used to connect the mobile home to ground anchors. 
Unit means a mobile home. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.01)  
Secs. 32-232-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - MOBILE HOME COMMISSION 
 
Sec. 32-21. - Creation and duties. 
The Fitchburg Mobile Home Commission is hereby created to: 
(1)  Enforce the provisions of this chapter and all other ordinances, laws, orders and regulations which relate to the operation and maintenance of mobile homes, mobile home parks, and mobile home sites. 
(2)  Examine all applications for mobile home park licenses and permits and all mobile home park plans to determine whether or not they comply with the requirements of this chapter. 
(3)  Inspect or direct such agent or supervisor as it shall designate to inspect, all mobile home parks, mobile home sites, and facilities thereon, together with all records of registration required by this ordinance, prior to the issuance of any license or permit and at least quarterly thereafter, and to make written reports of all such inspections to the city council. For these purposes the commission or its designated agent or supervisor shall have the right at all reasonable times to inspect all mobile home parks, mobile home sites, and the facilities thereon. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.02(1))  
Sec. 32-22. - Composition; officers. 
The mobile home commission shall be composed of the following city officers: police chief, fire chief, city clerk, building inspector, and zoning administrator or their designees. The commission shall elect a chairperson and secretary. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.02(2))  
Sec. 32-23. - Review of mobile home commission actions. 
(a)  The following decisions of the mobile home commission may be appealed to the city council: 
(1)  Rejection of an application for a mobile home park license or license renewal; and 
(2)  Rejection of an application for a temporary permit to locate a mobile home outside a mobile home park. 
(b)  A written notice of appeal must be filed with the city clerk within 14 days of the date when notice of the action of the mobile home commission which is being appealed is mailed to the petitioner. 
(c)  The notice of appeal shall state the action of the mobile home commission appealed from, shall specify the reasons stated by the commission for taking such action, and shall specify the reasons why the petitioner believes that action was inappropriate. 
(d)  The city clerk shall file the notice of appeal with the common council shall schedule the appeal for consideration by the common council at a meeting, open to the public, within 45 days of the filing of the notice of appeal. The clerk shall send notice of the time scheduled for consideration of the appeal to the petitioner at least ten days prior to the hearing of the appeal. 
(e)  Within 30 days-of the appeal hearing, the common council shall affirm, modify, or reverse the action of the mobile home commission or shall refer the matter back to the commission for further consideration. Notice of the decision of the common council shall be sent to the petitioner and the commission. 
(f)  The provisions of Wis. Stats. ch. 68 shall not be applicable to any determination made pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.20)  
Secs. 32-2432-49. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - MOBILE HOME PARKS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 32-5032-71. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - LICENSES 
 
Sec. 32-72. - Required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, operate or maintain, or permit to be established, operated or maintained upon any property owned, leased or controlled by him/her, a mobile home park within the city without having first secured a license for each such park from the city council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.03)  
Sec. 32-73. - Application. 
Any person desiring a mobile home park license shall file an application with the city clerk. The application shall be in writing, signed by the applicant and shall contain the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The location and legal description of the mobile home park. 
(3)  A complete site plan of the park. 
(4)  Evidence of proper zoning destination for the proposed mobile home park site (if necessary, any rezoning process shall be completed prior to application for a mobile home park license). 
Application fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.04(1))  
Sec. 32-74. - Plans and specifications to be filed. 
The following items shall be filed with an original application for a mobile home park license: 
(1)  Site drawings showing: (scale one-quarter inch to foot or larger) 
a.  The area and extent of the proposed mobile home park; 
b.  The location of all proposed mobile home sites; 
c.  Landscaping plan; 
d.  The location of all sites having anchoring systems as required by section 32-146; 
e.  The location of all sewer and water pipes; 
f.  The recreation area required by division 4 of this article. 
(2)  Plans and specifications for: 
a.  Storm sewers and stormwater drainage facilities; 
b.  All roadways and driveways; 
c.  The water supply system; and sanitary sewer system; 
d.  The electrical system. 
(3)  A written explanation of the manner in which garbage will be collected and disposed of, including how recycling will be promoted and enforced. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.04(2))  
Sec. 32-75. - Review by commission. 
The city clerk shall forward the application and plans to the mobile home commission which shall examine them for conformity with the requirements of this article and with the requirements of any other ordinances, statutes or administrative rules and regulations which may be applicable to mobile home or trailer parks. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.04(3))  
Sec. 32-76. - Action of the commission. 
(a)  The mobile home commission shall recommend approval or conditional approval of the application to the common council or shall reject the application. If approval or conditional approval is recommended, the application shall be referred to the common council for consideration. The common council shall then approve, conditionally approve, or reject the application. 
(b)  If the commission rejects the application the applicant may appeal the committee recommendation. 
(c)  One copy of the plan shall be returned to the applicant with the date and action endorsed thereon and if approved conditionally or rejected, the conditions for approval or reasons for rejection shall be endorsed thereon or attached thereto. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.04(4))  
Sec. 32-77. - Right to inspect. 
Any time application for a license issuance or renewal is made the city shall have the right to inspect the mobile home park and the applicant shall cooperate with providing for such inspection upon request. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.04(5))  
Sec. 32-78. - Clerk to issue license. 
When the application has been approved by the common council or when the conditions for approval have been satisfied; and when construction has been completed according to the plans and specifications submitted with the application, the city clerk shall issue a license to the applicant. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.05)  
Sec. 32-79. - License fees. 
Fees for original issuance and renewal of licenses under this article shall be as provided in the city fee schedule. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.09)  
Sec. 32-80. - Surety bond. 
No license shall be issued until the applicant has posted a surety bond in the sum of $1,000.00 to guarantee the collection and payment of the monthly parking permit fees required by section 32-294, by the licensee. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.10)  
Sec. 32-81. - Term of license. 
A mobile home park license shall expire one year after its issuance unless sooner revoked. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.06)  
Sec. 32-82. - Renewal of license. 
(a)  Upon application by any licensee and after approval by the mobile home commission, with submitted evidence of occupancy permits for all mobile homes installed within the last 12 months, satisfactory DNR water quality tests results within the last 12 months, copy of a satisfactory inspection report from the county health department, evidence from the county health department that permits have been issued for all connections of units to the sewage disposal system and upon payment of the annual license fee, the city clerk shall issue a certificate renewing the license for another year, unless sooner revoked. 
(b)  The application for renewal shall be in writing, signed by the applicant and on forms furnished by the city. If an existing park is to be remodeled or expanded, the application for renewal shall be accompanied by the plans and specifications required by section 32-74 for the part that has been remodeled or expanded. Common council approval of the remodeling or expansion is required in accordance with sections 32-73 through 32-77. 
(c)  If unable to obtain satisfactory DNR water quality test results, the mobile home park shall supply water on a temporary basis in a manner approved by the public works director if safe water cannot be obtained from the well, until the well can be rebuilt or replaced. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.07)  
Sec. 32-83. - Transfer of license. 
Upon application for a transfer of license and after approval of the application by the city council, the city clerk shall issue a transfer upon payment of the required fee. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.08)  
Secs. 32-8432-109. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SUSPENSION OR REVOCATION OF LICENSES 
 
Sec. 32-110. - Complaint. 
(a)  Upon the filing of a verified complaint by any police, health, or fire officer or by any resident with the city clerk alleging that any person licensed under section 32-72 has violated any provision of this chapter the mobile home commission shall issue a summons commanding the licensee to appear before them on a day and at a place in such summons named, not less than five nor more than ten days from its date, and show cause why the license should not be revoked or suspended. 
(b)  The summons and a copy of the complaint shall be served at least five days before the date set for the appearance and may be served either personally upon the licensee or upon the person in charge of the mobile home park. Said complaint shall set forth each alleged offense, the date, time and place of each offense alleged and the facts constituting each offense alleged. The clerk shall give the complainant written notice of the time and date set for the hearing. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.19(1))  
Sec. 32-111. - Failure to appear for hearing. 
If the licensee does not appear as required by the summons, the allegations set forth in the complaint shall be deemed to be true and the common council may dismiss the complaint or suspend or revoke the license. Notice of the board's action shall be given to the licensee. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.19(2))  
Sec. 32-112. - Hearing procedure. 
If the licensee appears at the hearing and denies the allegations set forth in the complaint, each party may present testimony and evidence. The complainant shall be the first to proceed and the licensee, who may be represented by counsel, shall then have the opportunity to be heard in person and to present witnesses and testimony on its behalf. Both the complainant and the licensee shall have the right to cross examine adverse witnesses and to compel the attendance of witnesses by subpoena which shall be issued by the common council chairperson upon request. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.19(3))  
Sec. 32-113. - Prerogative of the city council. 
(a)  If the common council determines that allegations of the complaint to be true, it may suspend or revoke the license. If the common council determines that the allegations are untrue or, if true, are not sufficient grounds for the suspension or revocation it shall dismiss the complaint. 
(b)  If the common council determines that the allegations of the complaint were malicious and without probable cause the cost shall be paid by the complainant. The common council may require security for costs to be posted by the complainant before issuing the summons. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.19(4))  
Secs. 32-11432-139. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PARK PLAN 
 
Sec. 32-140. - Park location. 
Every mobile home and mobile home park shall be located on a well-drained area, and the premises shall be properly graded so as to prevent the accumulation of stormwaters or other waters. No mobile home or mobile home park shall be located in any area that is situated so that drainage of contaminated liquids or solids can be deposited on its location. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.15(1))  
Sec. 32-141. - Mobile home sites. 
(a)  Each site shall be clearly defined or delineated. The basic mobile home unit shall not occupy more than one-fourth of the area of the site and the complete unit, including all accessory structures, shall not occupy more than one-half of the area of the site. 
(b)  The units shall be so located on each site that there shall be at least a 20-foot clearance between each unit. No unit shall be located within ten feet of any building within the park or of any property line of the park. No unit shall be located within 25 feet of the right-of-way line of a highway or within ten feet of the right-of-way line of any public street or internal private street system of the park. 
(c)  Mobile home parks which, at the time of the adoption of the ordinance from which this section is derived existed lawfully with mobile home sites that do not comply with the foregoing minimum area requirements, may continue to operate. Any expansion and modification of such mobile home parks shall, however, comply with this section. 
(d)  Any new unit being installed in an preexisting mobile home park shall comply with all site requirements of this section. In addition a building permit shall be obtained in order to locate any new unit in an preexisting mobile home park. The building permit applicant shall be required to provide evidence that the unit will comply with all site requirements and also provide evidence that a sewer connection permit was issued from the county health department, if applicable. The electrical service for the site shall conform to the wiring requirements for the current addition of the National Electrical Code article 550. An occupancy permit shall be issued by the building inspector prior to the occupancy of the unit. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.15(2))  
Sec. 32-142. - Streets. 
(a)  All sites shall abut upon a street. A two-way street shall be at least 32 feet wide if parking is to be permitted on both sides of the street; 25 feet wide if parking is permitted on only one side; and 18 feet wide if parking on the street is prohibited. All one-way streets shall be at least 14 feet wide and shall be no longer than 500 feet. Parking on one-way streets shall be prohibited unless the width is increased by seven feet for each parking lane. 
(b)  Driveways shall be graveled or paved, maintained in good condition, have natural drainage, and be lighted at night. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.15(3))  
Sec. 32-143. - Parking. 
At least 1½ parking spaces shall be provided for each site. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.15(5))  
Sec. 32-144. - Recreation area. 
Each park shall contain a sufficient land area to provide adequate park, playground, recreation, and open space to meet the needs created by the mobile home park. At least one acre of land for each 100 sites or fraction thereof shall be provided to meet these needs. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.15(6))  
Sec. 32-145. - Landscaping. 
Landscape plans shall be developed in collaboration with and approved by the city plan commission. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.15(7))  
Sec. 32-146. - Anchoring. 
(a)  New parks. All new parks shall provide each site with an anchoring system meeting the standards specified in subsection (c) of this section. 
(b)  Existing parks. 
(1)  If an existing park is remodeled, anchoring systems meeting the standards specified in subsection (c) of this section shall be provided for each remodeled site. 
(2)  If an existing park is expanded, anchoring systems meeting the standards specified in subsection (c) of this section shall be provided for each new site. 
(3)  If a site in an existing park becomes vacant, anchoring systems meeting the standards specified in subsection (c) of this section shall be provided for each such site before it may be reoccupied. 
(4)  If a site is vacant or becomes vacant, a building permit shall be issued by the building inspector prior to the site being occupied by a mobile home. An occupancy permit shall be required issued by the building inspector prior to the mobile home being occupied. 
(c)  Standards. All anchoring systems shall comply with the standards of the American National Standards Institute, ANSI 119.3, parts 2 and 4, a copy of which shall be kept on file at the office of the city clerk and shall be made available to the public for inspection and copying upon request. 
(d)  Commission approval. No person may commence construction of a new park or expand or remodel an existing park unless the plans for such construction, expansion or remodeling contain provisions for anchoring systems meeting the standards specified in section 32-265(d) and are approved by the commission. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.14(1), (2), (4), (5))  
Sec. 32-147. - Connection to public water and sewer required if available. 
If a public sanitary sewer or water supply system becomes available to a mobile home park, the park shall be connected to the city utility district in accordance with articles II and III of chapter 40. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.12(1))  
Sec. 32-148. - Fire hydrant required; location. 
A fire hydrant shall be located at each street entrance to the park. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.12(1)(a))  
Sec. 32-149. - Private wells. 
Private wells shall be permitted where a public water supply system is not available to the mobile home park. Any such well shall be located on the premises of the mobile home park and shall be constructed and have pump and distribution lines which are installed in accordance with the regulations of the state department of natural resources governing well drilling and pump installation. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.12(2))  
Sec. 32-150. - Service line and shutoff valve for each home site required. 
A separate water service line shall extend to each site, and a shutoff valve shall be situated between the main supply line and each site whether the source of water is a public utility or a private well. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.12(3))  
Sec. 32-151. - Electrical outlets. 
Every site shall be furnished with an electrical service outlet. Such outlet shall be equipped with an externally operated switch or fuse of not less than 60 amperes capacity, and a heavy duty outlet receptacle. Electrical outlets shall be weatherproof and no power lines shall be less than 15 feet above the ground. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.15(4))  
Sec. 32-152. - Compliance with state, county and city regulations required. 
Except as otherwise provided in this division, all plumbing, electrical wiring and waste disposal systems shall conform to the building code of the city and to the rules and regulations of the county health department for the mobile home park and any additions to the mobile homes. All wiring shall conform to the city's electrical codes. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.13)  
Sec. 32-153. - Mobile home units constructed to federal standards exempt from local codes. 
The plumbing, wiring, and construction for the mobile homes units is preempted by the Federal Manufactured Home Construction and Safety Act of 1974, 24 CFR 3280.1 et seq. Mobile home units constructed to this standard are not subject to local building codes. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.13)  
Secs. 32-15432-174. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - PARK MANAGEMENT 
 
Sec. 32-175. - Management of the park. 
Each mobile home park shall have an office for the attendant or person in charge of said park. A copy of the park license and of this article shall be posted therein and the park register shall at all times be kept in said office. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.18(1))  
Sec. 32-176. - Duties of mobile home park operator. 
The operator of any mobile home park shall be required to: 
(1)  Keep a register of all occupants, open at all times to inspection by federal, state, and local officers, which shall show for all occupants: 
a.  Names and addresses; 
b.  Dates of entrance and departure; 
c.  License numbers of all mobile homes; 
d.  States issuing such licenses. 
(2)  Maintain the park in a safe, clean, orderly and sanitary condition at all times. 
(3)  Ensure that the provisions of this chapter are complied with and enforce and report promptly to the proper authorities any violation of this chapter or any other violations of law which may come to his/her attention. 
(4)  Maintain in convenient and readily accessible places, ten-pound, multipurpose ABC type dry chemical hand fire extinguishers in the ratio of one to each eight units, or any fraction thereof. 
(5)  Prohibit the lighting of open fires on the premises. 
(6)  Collect the monthly parking permit fee provided for in article V of this chapter and keep a true and accurate record showing the names of the persons paying said fee and the amount paid. 
(7)  Transmit the monthly parking fees to the city treasurer on or before the tenth day of the month following the month for which such fees are due. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.18(2))  
Secs. 32-17732-205. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - MOBILE HOMES OUTSIDE PARKS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 32-206. - Parking prohibited. 
Except as hereinafter provided, it shall be unlawful to park any mobile home on any street, alley or highway within the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.11(1))  
Sec. 32-207. - One hour parking. 
Emergency or temporary stopping or parking for not longer than one hour shall be permitted on any street, alley or highway subject to any prohibitions, regulations, or limitations imposed by the traffic and parking regulations or ordinances applicable to such street, alley or highway. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.11(2))  
Sec. 32-208. - Storage permitted. 
The parking or storage of one unoccupied mobile home in a private garage or in the rear yard is permitted; provided, however, that no living quarters shall be maintained or any business practiced within such mobile home while so parked or stored. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.11(3))  
Secs. 32-20932-239. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - TEMPORARY PERMITS 
 
Sec. 32-240. - When required. 
When it is temporarily necessary to locate a mobile home outside of a mobile home park for emergency housing, or for the housing of seasonally employed workers, or for business related to agriculture, the common council may issue a temporary permit allowing the mobile home to be so located. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.11(3)(a))  
Sec. 32-241. - Expiration. 
A temporary permit shall expire at the end of six months, unless issued for agriculture-related business, in which event it shall expire at the end of one year. Each permit shall clearly show the expiration date and the purpose for which it was issued. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.11(3)(a), (b))  
Sec. 32-242. - Application; filing; fee. 
An application for a temporary permit shall be filed with the city clerk and shall be accompanied by a fee as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. The permit shall be granted only upon the written consent of the owner, the legal agent of the owner, or the lessee of the location for which the permit is issued. The person to whom such permit is granted shall be subject to the regular parking permit fee required by section 32-294. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.11(3)(c))  
Sec. 32-243. - Approval, conditional approval or denial. 
The city clerk shall forward the application and consent to the mobile home commission for review. The mobile home commission shall recommend approval or conditional approval of the permit to the common council or shall reject the application. If the commission rejects the application the applicant may appeal the committee recommendation. If approval or conditional approval is recommended the application shall be referred to the common council for consideration. The common council shall then approve, conditionally approve, or reject the application. If the application is rejected or conditionally approved, written notice stating the conditions for approval or reasons for rejection shall be given to the applicant. If the application has been approved or when any conditions of approval have been satisfied, the city clerk shall issue the temporary permit. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.11(3)(d))  
Secs. 32-24432-264. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - STANDARDS AND SPECIFICATIONS 
 
Sec. 32-265. - Anchoring requirements. 
(a)  If a new site is located outside of a mobile home park, anchoring systems meeting the standards specified in subsection (c) of this section shall be provided before it may be occupied. 
(b)  If a site located outside of a mobile home park becomes vacant, anchoring systems meeting the standards specified in subsection (c) of this section shall be provided for such site before it is again occupied by a mobile home. 
(c)  All anchoring systems shall comply with the standards of The American National Standards Institute, ANSI 119.3, parts 2 and 4, a copy of which shall be kept on file at the office of the city clerk and shall be made available to the public for inspection and copying upon request. 
(d)  No person may commence construction of a new park or expand or remodel an existing park unless the plans for such construction, expansion or remodeling contain provisions for anchoring systems meeting the standards specified in this section and are approved by the commission. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.14(3)(5))  
Secs. 32-26632-293. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PARKING PERMITS 
 
Sec. 32-294. - Required; calculation of fee. 
(a)  In addition to the license fee, the city shall collect from each occupied mobile home occupying space or lots in a mobile home park within the city a monthly parking permit fee computed as provided in this section. 
(b)  On January 1, the city assessor shall determine the total fair market value of each occupied mobile home which is subject to the monthly parking permit fee. The fair market value, minus the tax exempt household furnishings thus established, shall be equalized to the general level of assessment on other real and personal property in the city. The value of each occupied mobile home thus determined shall be multiplied by the general property gross tax rate established on the preceding year's assessment of general property. The parking permit fee shall be reduced by the credit allowed under Wis. Stats. § 79.10. The total annual parking permit fee thus computed shall be divided by 12 and shall represent the monthly mobile home parking permit fee. 
(c)  The fee shall be applicable to occupied mobile homes moving into the city any time during the year. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.16(1))  
Sec. 32-295. - Responsibility of park licensee to collect parking fee. 
It shall be the full and complete responsibility of each licensee of a mobile home park to collect the proper fee from the owner or occupant of each occupied mobile home within the mobile home park. The licensee shall pay such parking permit fees to the city treasurer on or before the tenth of the month following the month for which such fees are due. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.16(2))  
Sec. 32-296. - Park licensee's duty to report changes in number of occupied mobile homes. 
(a)  The licensee of a mobile home park shall notify the city clerk and the city assessor of each increase or decrease in the number of occupied mobile homes situated in his/her park within five days of any change. The additional occupied units shall be reported on forms prescribed by the state department of revenue. 
(b)  As soon as the assessor receives the notice of such addition he/she shall determine its fair market value and notify the city clerk of his/her determination. The city clerk shall equalize the fair market value established by the city assessor and shall apply the tax rate for that year, divide the annual parking permit fee thus determined by 12 and notify the mobile home park licensee of the monthly fee to be collected from the unit. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.16(3))  
Sec. 32-297. - Landowner's duty to report occupied mobile homes and collect parking fee. 
For mobile homes permitted to be located outside of a licensed mobile home park, must be taxed as real property and are subject to a monthly parking permit fee the monthly parking permit fee shall be paid by the owner of the mobile home, the occupant thereof, or the owner of the land on which it stands, the same as, and, in the manner provided for mobile homes located in mobile home parks, and the owners of such land are required to comply with the collection and reporting requirements of sections 32-295 and 32-296. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.16(4))  
Sec. 32-298. - Fee rate and valuation to be reestablished annually. 
A new fee rate and a new valuation shall be established each January and shall continue for that calendar year. The valuation established shall be subject to review as are other values established under Wis. Stats. ch. 70. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.16(5))  
Sec. 32-299. - Effect of failure to pay monthly fee. 
Failure to pay the monthly parking permit fee in timely fashion shall be treated in all respects like a default in payment of personal property tax and shall be subject to all procedures and penalties applicable thereto under Wis. Stats. chs. 70 and 74. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.16(7))  
Sec. 32-300. - Exemptions. 
The monthly parking permit fee shall not apply where a mobile home park is owned and operated by the county or state under the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 59.07(13) or 70.11(1). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.17)  
Sec. 32-301. - Disposition of fee proceeds. 
The city shall retain ten percent of the monthly parking permit fees collected in each month to cover the cost of administration and shall pay to the school district in which the mobile home park or mobile home is located, within 20 days after the end of each month, such proportion of the remainder of the fees collected in the preceding month as the ratio of the most recent property tax levy for school purposes bears to the total tax levy for all purposes in the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.16(6))  
Secs. 32-30232-320. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 
 
Sec. 32-321. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  No person shall in the city erect, construct, alter, extend, repair, remove, or maintain any mobile home park or other structure or equipment regulated by this Code, or cause, permit or suffer the same to be done, in conflict with or in violation of any of the provisions of this Code or fail to timely comply with any lawful order issued hereunder. 
(b)  Any person violating any provision of this chapter, other than the reporting requirements set forth in article V of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit not less than $10.00 nor more than $100.00 per violation and the costs of prosecution, and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs shall be imprisoned in the county jail until payment of such forfeiture and the costs of prosecution, but not to exceed 30 days for each violation. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(c)  Any person who fails to comply with the reporting requirements of article V of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, forfeit $25.00 and in default of payment of such forfeiture and costs shall be imprisoned in the county jail until payment of such forfeiture and the costs of prosecution, but not to exceed 30 days for each violation. Each day of violation shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.21(1))  
Sec. 32-322. - Notice of violation and order. 
(a)  The building inspector may serve a notice of violation and order on any person responsible for the erection, construction, alteration, extension, repair, removal, or maintenance of any mobile home park or other equipment or structure in violation of the provisions of this Code, or in violation of a detail statement or a plan approved thereunder, or in violation of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this Code. Such notice or order shall direct the discontinuance of the illegal action or condition and the abatement of the violation. 
(b)  The building inspector may also recommend suspension or revocation to the mobile home commission suspend or revoke any permit for any building or structure on any property on which such noncompliance is discovered in accordance with section 35-55. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.21(2))  
Sec. 32-323. - Prosecution; defenses. 
(a)  If a notice of violation and order is not complied with promptly, the mobile home commission may request the city attorney to institute the appropriate proceeding at law or in equity to correct or abate such violation or require the removal or termination of the unlawful use violation of the provisions of this Code or of the notice or order made pursuant thereto. 
(b)  In any court action or legal proceeding, the fact that a license was issued shall not constitute a defense, nor shall any error, oversight or dereliction of duty on the part of the building inspector or mobile home commission constitute a defense. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.21(3))  
Sec. 32-324. - Citations. 
In the event that any person fails or neglects to comply with a lawful order issued under the provisions of this Code, the building inspector may issue a citation in accordance with chapter 18 imposing a forfeiture, as provided in section 32-326. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.21(4))  
Sec. 32-325. - Injunctions and restraining orders. 
As a substitute for, or in addition to, forfeiture actions, the city attorney may, on behalf of the city, seek enforcement of any and all parts of this Code by court actions seeking an injunction or restraining order against the person responsible for the violation for the purpose of ordering that person to do one or more, of the following: 
(1)  Restrain, correct or remove the violation or refrain from any further violation. 
(2)  Restrain or correct the construction or alteration of such a mobile home park. 
(3)  Require the removal of items in violation of the provisions of this Code. 
(4)  Prevent the occupation or use of the mobile home park or part thereof erected, constructed, installed, altered or maintained in violation of, or not in compliance with, with the provisions of this Code, or in violation of a plan or specification under which a license was issued. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.21(5))  
Sec. 32-326. - Forfeitures. 
Any person who violates any provision of this Code or any lawful order of the building inspector pursuant thereto shall be subject to penalties as provided in section 1-21. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.21(6))  
Sec. 32-327. - Relationship to nuisance actions. 
No provisions of this Code shall be construed to bar any private or public nuisance action to enjoin or abate the use or occupancy of any mobile home park under state law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.21(7))  
Sec. 32-328. - Assistance from other officials. 
The building inspector in the performance of his/her duties shall receive the assistance of the chiefs of the police and fire departments and of all other city officials, including the city attorney, in prosecuting violations hereof. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 5.21(8))  
Chapter 34 - NONMETALLIC MINING 
(RESERVED)  
Chapter 35 - BUILDINGS AND BUILDING REGULATIONS[1] 
Footnotes:

Stats. § 101.01 et seq.; one- and two-family dwelling code, Wis. Stats. § 101.60 et seq.; municipal authority regarding one- and two-family dwelling code, Wis. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 35-135-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 35-19. - Purpose and intent. 
This article provides certain minimum standards, provisions and requirements for safe and stable design, methods of construction and uses of materials in buildings and structures hereafter erected, constructed, enlarged, altered, repaired, moved, converted to other uses or demolished, and regulates the equipment, maintenance, use and occupancy of all such buildings and structures. The purpose of this article is to protect and foster the health, safety and well-being of persons occupying or using such buildings and the general public. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.00(3)) 
State Law reference Municipal authority to regulation construction and inspection of dwellings, Wis. Stats. § 101.60.  
Sec. 35-20. - Definitions. 
Unless the context clearly requires otherwise, when used in this article the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
Building means a structure for support, shelter or enclosure of persons or property. 
Building inspector means the executive official in charge of the city building inspection department as described in section 35-51(a) or any person officially authorized by the building inspector or the city to carry out the administrative and enforcement functions prescribed in this chapter. 
Structure means an assembly of materials forming a construction for occupancy or use. 
Swimming pool means any manmade depression in the ground, either temporary or permanent, or a container of water, either temporary or permanent and either above or below the ground, in which water more than 18 inches deep is contained and which is used primarily for the purpose of bathing or swimming. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.01)  
Sec. 35-21. - Scope. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to all buildings and structures in the city with the exception of the following: 
(1)  Recreational vehicles and mobile homes. On-site additions to recreational vehicles and mobile homes are not exempt. 
(2)  Historical buildings designated as such by the federal or state government. 
(3)  Temporary buildings used exclusively for construction purposes, not exceeding two stories in height and not used as living quarters. 
(4)  Buildings owned by the federal government. Buildings owned by other than the federal government but leased to the federal government are not exempt. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.00(4))  
Sec. 35-22. - Applicability. 
The provisions of this article shall apply to all new construction, all additions and alterations to existing buildings, all remodeling, repairs and maintenance of existing buildings, building use changes, buildings being moved from one location to another and to demolition of buildings. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.00(5))  
Sec. 35-23. - Responsibility. 
This article shall be binding alike upon every owner of a building; every person in charge of or responsible for or who causes the construction, repair or alteration of any building or structure; and every professional engineer, architect or other person who shall prepare plans for the construction, alteration or addition to any building or structure in the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.00(6))  
Sec. 35-24. - Performance code. 
This article shall be interpreted and administered as a performance code. No part of this article is intended to prohibit or discourage the construction of innovative buildings and structures. Minor variances from this article may be approved by the building inspector when those variances comply with the spirit and intent of the provisions specifically cited herein. The building inspector may approve alternative materials or methods of construction when he/she finds that the proposed design is satisfactory and complies with the intent of the provisions of this article, and that the material, method or work offered is, for the purpose intended, at least the equivalent of that prescribed in this article in quality, strength, effectiveness, fire-resistance, durability and safety. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.00(7))  
Sec. 35-25. - Relationship to other regulations. 
This article shall not affect violations of any other ordinance, code or regulation prior to the effective date hereof, and any such violation shall be governed and shall continue to be punishable to the full extent of the law under the provisions of those ordinances, codes or regulations in effect at the time the violation was committed. The provisions of this article shall not be construed to prevent the enforcement of other ordinances or regulations of the city or the state which prescribe standards other than are provided herein. In case of conflicts among such standards, the more restrictive standard shall apply. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.00(8))  
Sec. 35-26. - Matters not provided for. 
Any requirement essential for structural, fire or sanitary safety of an existing or proposed building or structure, or essential for the safety of the occupants thereof, and which is not specifically covered by this article, shall be determined by the building inspector. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.00(9))  
Sec. 35-27. - Workmanship. 
All work performed under the scope of this article shall be conducted, executed and completed in a workmanlike and acceptable manner so as to secure the results intended by this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.00(10))  
Sec. 35-28. - Maintenance. 
All buildings and structures and all parts thereof shall be maintained in a safe condition and all devices and safeguards which are required at the erection, alteration, addition, or repair of any building shall be maintained in good working order. This section shall not be construed as permitting the removal or nonmaintenance of any existing devices or safeguards unless authorized in writing by the building inspector. Such maintenance requirements shall apply to all buildings now existing or hereafter erected. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.00(11))  
Sec. 35-29. - Liability for damages. 
This article shall not be construed as assuming any liability on the part of the city for damages to anyone injured or for any property destroyed by a defect in any building or element. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.00(12))  
Sec. 35-30. - Code availability. 
A copy of this article shall be kept on file at the office of the building inspector and shall be made available to the public for reference, inspection and purchase upon request during normal business hours. A copy of the provisions of the Wisconsin Administrative Code adopted by reference in section 35-77 shall be kept on file at the office of the building inspector and shall be made available to the public for reference and inspection upon request during normal business hours. Copies of the Wisconsin Administrative Code referenced herein may be purchased from the state department of administration, document sales and distribution office. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.001(3))  
Sec. 35-31. - Permit fees. 
(a)  Fee schedule. A fee schedule for all permits issued by the building inspection department shall be as set forth in the annual budget appendix fee schedule. The fee schedule shall be kept on file in the building inspector's office and shall be referred to as the "building inspection permit fee schedule." The building inspection permit fee schedule shall be considered a supplement to this article and shall be made available for reference and public inspection during normal business hours. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in the event the city's work to review plans and grant a permit in a particular construction project is not proportionate to the fee provided in the inspection permit fee schedule, the director of public works may make a special determination to lower or waive the permit fee. 
(b)  Payment of fees. Permit fees shall be paid by the applicant prior to permit issuance. The building inspector shall collect all permit fees, keep an accurate account of all fees collected and turn all fees over to the city treasurer within 30 days of receipt. 
(c)  Delinquent permit penalty. Permit fees shall be doubled if any work is commenced prior to permit issuance. 
(d)  Waiver of permit fees. Permit fees shall be waived for buildings and structures owned by the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.08; Ord. No. 2015-O-29, 10-27-2015)  
Secs. 35-3235-50. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BUILDING INSPECTOR AND BUILDING INSPECTION DEPARTMENT 
 
Sec. 35-51. - Department created; building official as department head. 
(a)  Code official. The city building inspection department is hereby created and the executive official in charge thereof shall be known as the building inspector. 
(b)  Department head. The building inspector shall be a department head as defined in section 16-1 and shall be fully covered as a fulltime employee under the provisions of said chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.03(1), (2))  
Sec. 35-52. - Appointment, removal and qualifications of building inspector. 
(a)  The building inspector shall be appointed by the common council and shall not be removed from office except for cause and after full opportunity to be heard on specific and relevant charges by and before the common council. 
(b)  The building inspector shall possess the necessary qualifications and inspector certifications required by the city and the state to supervise the general construction of buildings and enforce the provisions of this Code. The assistant building inspector and other appointed department employees shall possess necessary inspector certifications as mandated by state law or rule and other qualifications as required by the building inspector and the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.03(3), (6))  
Sec. 35-53. - Appointment of assistant building inspector and other department personnel. 
(a)  The building inspector is authorized to designate a qualified employee as assistant building inspector who shall exercise all the powers of the building inspector during the temporary absence or disability of the building inspector. 
(b)  The building inspector shall appoint such number of officers, technical assistants, inspectors and other employees as shall be necessary for the administration and enforcement of this Code and as authorized by the city council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.03(4), (5))  
Sec. 35-54. - Powers and duties of the building inspector. 
(a)  State statute reference. The building inspector shall be held to be the same officer as referred to in state law as building inspector, and who shall have the same powers and duties. The building inspector shall enforce all the provisions of this article and all other state laws and city ordinances relating to the construction, alteration, repair, removal, safety and use of buildings and permanent building equipment, except as otherwise specifically provided for by statutory requirements or as provided in this article. The building inspector shall have full power to pass upon any question arising under the provisions of this article subject to the conditions contained herein. 
(b)  Rule making authority. The building inspector shall have the power as necessary in the interest of public health, safety and general welfare, to adopt and promulgate orders and directives, to interpret and implement the provisions of this article to secure the intent thereof, and to designate requirements applicable because of local climatic or other conditions; but such rules shall not have the effect of waiving structural or fire performance requirements specifically provided in this article or violating accepted engineering practice involving public safety. The building inspector shall also have the power as necessary to establish department policies, initiate administrative procedures and adopt rules to ensure effective and efficient department operation. 
(c)  Permits, inspections and correction orders. The building inspector shall be responsible for the issuance of all permits required by this article and for the inspection of all work for which such permits have been issued. The building inspector shall enforce compliance with the provisions of this article and shall issue necessary notices and correction orders to ensure compliance with all code requirements for the health, safety and general welfare of the public. 
(d)  Recordkeeping. The building inspector shall keep official records of applications received, permits and certificates issued, fees collected, reports of inspections, and notices and orders issued. Such records shall be retained in the official records so long as the building or structure to which they relate remains in existence unless otherwise provided by other regulations. 
(e)  Annual report. At least annually, the building inspector shall submit to the common council a written report and statement of operations in the form and content as shall be prescribed by the city administrator. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.04)  
Sec. 35-55. - Permit suspension or revocation. 
The building inspector may suspend or revoke a permit or approval issued under the provisions of this article where the building inspector or authorized department official is denied access to the premises, where the applicant has willfully refused to correct a violation of the provisions of this Code, or in case of any false statement or misrepresentation of fact in the application or in the plans on which the permit or approval is based. No construction activity shall take place on a job site after suspension or revocation of the permit, except such work as the building inspector shall order be done as a condition precedent to the issuance of a new permit, or which the building inspector may authorize as reasonably necessary to protect work already completed on the job site, existing property, adjoining property and the general public. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.07(6))  
Sec. 35-56. - Restrictions on employees. 
An official or employee connected with the building inspection department shall not be engaged in or directly or indirectly connected with the furnishing of labor, materials or appliances for the construction, alteration or maintenance of any building within the city, or the preparation of plans or of specifications thereof, unless that person is the owner of the building; nor shall such officer or employee engage in any work which conflicts with official duties or with the interest of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.03(7))  
Sec. 35-57. - Relief from personal responsibilities. 
(a)  The building inspector, assistant building inspector or other department employee charged with the enforcement of this Code, while acting on behalf of the city, shall not thereby be rendered liable personally, and the building inspector, assistant building inspector or department employee is hereby relieved of all personal liability for any damage accruing to persons or property as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of official duties. Any suit instituted against any department officer or employee because of an act performed by that person in the lawful discharge of duties and under the provisions of this article, shall be defended by the legal representative of the city until the final termination of the proceedings. 
(b)  The building inspector or any subordinates shall not be liable for any costs in any action, suit or proceeding that is instituted in pursuance of the provisions of this Code; and any officer of the building inspection department, acting in good faith and without malice, shall be free of liability for acts performed under any of its provisions or by reason of any act or omission in the performance of official duties in connection therewith. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.03(8))  
Sec. 35-58. - Appeals. 
(a)  Appealable matters. Any person aggrieved by an order, ruling or decision of the building inspector has a right of administrative appeal to the city zoning board of appeals pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 62.23(7), (8) and (9). 
(b)  Procedure. The procedure for administrative appeals under this article shall follow the provisions of sections 22-642 and 22-643 which are incorporated and adopted herein by reference. Such appeals shall be commenced within 20 days of receiving an order, ruling or decision from the building inspector. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.16)  
Sec. 35-59. - Violations and penalties. 
(a)  Unlawful acts. No person shall in the city erect, construct, alter, extend, repair, remove, demolish, use or occupy any building or structure or equipment regulated by this article, or cause, permit or suffer the same to be done, in conflict with or in violation of any of the provisions of this article or fail to timely comply with any lawful order issued hereunder. 
(b)  Notice of violation and order. The building inspector may serve a notice of violation and order on any person responsible for the erection, construction, alteration, extension, repair, removal, demolition, use or occupancy of a building or structure in violation of the provisions of this article, or in violation of a detail statement or a plan approved thereunder, or in violation of a permit or certificate issued under the provisions of this article. Such notice or order shall direct the discontinuance of the illegal action or condition and the abatement of the violation. The building inspector may also suspend or revoke any permit for any building or structure on any property on which such noncompliance is discovered in accordance with section 35-55. 
(c)  Prosecution. If a notice of violation and order is not complied with promptly, the building inspector may request the city attorney to institute the appropriate proceeding at law or in equity to correct or abate such violation or require the removal or termination of the unlawful use of the building or structure in violation of the provisions of this article or of the notice or order made pursuant thereto. In any court action or legal proceeding, the fact that a permit was issued shall not constitute a defense, nor shall any error, oversight or dereliction of duty on the part of the building inspector constitute a defense. 
(d)  Citations. In the event that any person fails or neglects to comply with a lawful order issued under the provisions of this article, the building inspector may issue a citation in accordance with chapter 18 imposing a forfeiture as provided in subsection (f) of this section. 
(e)  Injunctions and restraining orders. As a substitute for, or in addition to, forfeiture actions, the city attorney may, on behalf of the city, seek enforcement of any and all parts of this article by court actions seeking an injunction or restraining order against the person responsible for the violation for the purpose of ordering that person to do one or more, of the following: 
(1)  Restrain, correct or remove the violation or refrain from any further execution of work. 
(2)  Restrain or correct the erection, installation or alteration of such building or structure. 
(3)  Require the removal of work in violation of the provisions of this article. 
(4)  Prevent the occupation or use of the building or structure or part thereof erected, constructed, installed or altered in violation of, or not in compliance with, with the provisions of this article, or in violation of a plan or specification under which an approval, permit or certificate was issued. 
(f)  Forfeitures. See forfeiture/bond/deposit schedule for penalties for any person who shall violate or fail to comply with the provisions of this article or any lawful order of the building inspector issued pursuant thereto. 
(g)  Relationship to nuisance actions. No provisions of this article shall be construed to bar any private or public nuisance action to enjoin or abate the use or occupancy of any land or structure under state law. 
(h)  Assistance from other officials. The building inspector in the performance of his/her duties shall receive the assistance of the chiefs of the police and fire departments and of all other city officials, including the city attorney, in prosecuting violations hereof. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.17)  
Secs. 35-6035-76. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS 
 
Sec. 35-77. - Adoption of state codes by reference. 
The provisions of the following state codes and subsequent amendments and recodifications thereto are hereby adopted by reference and incorporated in this article as if fully set forth. Violations of the provisions hereby adopted shall be deemed a violation of this chapter and subject to enforcement and abatement procedures as set forth in section 35-59. 
(1)  Wis. Admin. Code SPS 316, Electrical Code. 
(2)  Wis. Admin. Code SPS 320-325, Uniform Dwelling Code, except Wis. Admin. Code SPS 320.05(1), 320.05 (3) and 320.05(5). 
(3)  Wis. Admin. Code SPS 361-365, Commercial Building Code. 
(4)  Wis. Admin. Code SPS 366, Existing Buildings. 
(5)  Wis. Admin. Code SPS 381-387, Plumbing Code. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.02(1); Ord. No. 2018-O-07, §§ 15, 2-13-2018) 
State Law reference One- and two-family dwelling code, Wis. Stats. § 101.60 et seq.  
Sec. 35-78. - Referenced standards. 
(a)  Conformance of construction with the "Basic Building Code," a publication of the Building Officials and Code Administrators, Inc., and its appendicized references, as well as the Wisconsin Uniform Building Code, shall be prima facie evidence of safe construction. 
(b)  Only those standards of workmanship and safety which are within the scope of, but are not clearly described, in the city and state codes and are more clearly detailed or described in the referenced code shall be considered recognized standards of good workmanship and safety. No requirement of reference more stringent than, or in conflict with, the city building code shall be in force, nor shall any definition or term in conflict with those of the city or state codes be applicable to the city building code. 
(c)  Where any requirements of the referenced code are more stringent than the standards of workmanship and safety described or implied in the city or state codes, the city and state code requirements on the particular item shall apply. 
(d)  Major topics appearing in the referenced code and not appearing in either the city or state codes may be considered recognized standards of workmanship and safety, at the discretion of the building inspector. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.02(3))  
Secs. 35-7935-99. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PERMITS GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 35-100. - Required; exemptions; compliance with construction standards. 
(a)  No person shall erect or construct any building or structure whatever or add to, enlarge, move, improve, alter, extend, convert or demolish any building or structure or cause the same to be done or commence any work covered by this article on any building or structure without first obtaining a building permit therefor from the building inspector except that building permits shall not be required for the following: 
(1)  Repairs required for the maintenance and upkeep of any building which do not exceed a cost of $2,000.00, do not involve a change in use, and do not affect the structural strength, fire hazard, exits, natural lighting or the replacement of a major piece of equipment. 
(2)  Residential accessory buildings and storage sheds not used to house motor vehicles and less than 64 square feet in floor area. 
(3)  Attached or detached uncovered wood decks with floor surfaces less than 24 inches above adjacent grade level. 
(4)  Satellite dishes and antennas intended for private residential use. 
(5)  Buildings and structures not within the scope of this Code. 
(b)  Construction referred to in this section shall comply with all applicable code sections and construction standards regardless of building permit requirements. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.05(1), (2))  
Sec. 35-101. - Electrical, plumbing and heating permits. 
No person shall commence any electrical, plumbing or heating work covered by this article without first obtaining an electrical permit therefor from the building inspector. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.05(3)(5))  
Sec. 35-102. - Demolition permit. 
(a)  No permit or renewal of a permit for the demolition of any building or structure shall be issued without the approval of the zoning administrator. Upon receipt of a demolition permit application, the zoning administrator shall provide materials to the mayor and district alderpersons allowing a minimum of five days of comment. The application for demolition permit shall include a rationale for removal of the building along with a detailed plan for the future use of the property on which the building or structure is located. The zoning administrator shall not approve the demolition permit unless he or she determines that the demolition will not: 
(1)  Have an adverse impact to the historical or cultural significance of the property upon which the building or structure is located; 
(2)  Have an adverse impact upon properties adjacent to the property upon which the building or structure is located; 
(3)  Be detrimental to or endanger the public health, safety, morals, comfort or general welfare; or 
(4)  Impede the normal and orderly development and improvement of the surrounding property. 
(b)  If the zoning administrator declines to approve a request for a demolition permit, such demolition permit request shall be referred to the plan commission for recommendation and to the council for action. 
(c)  Notwithstanding subsections (a) and (b) of this section, the building inspector may issue a demolition permit without zoning administrator approval where the building inspector orders the building demolished, or where by fire or other natural causes, the building or structure has suffered damage in excess of 50 percent of its assessed value. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.05(7); Ord. No. 2013-O-01, § 1, 2-26-2013)  
Sec. 35-103. - Waiver of permits. 
If, in his/her opinion, a proposed alteration to a building or equipment is insignificant, or the equipment or part is being replaced through normal maintenance, the building inspector may waive the requirement of a permit. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.05(6))  
Secs. 35-10435-134. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - APPLICATIONS AND SUPPORTING DOCUMENTATION 
 
Sec. 35-135. - Permit applications. 
Application for a permit shall be made by the owner of the building or structure or an authorized agent and shall be made in writing upon a blank form furnished by the building inspector. The permit application shall contain the name, mailing address and phone number of the owner of the building and land, the name, mailing address and phone number of the engineer, architect, designer or contractor responsible for the work, a general description of the proposed work, location of the proposed work, the use and occupancy of all parts of the building or structure, and such other information as required by the building inspector to enforce the provisions of this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.06(1))  
Sec. 35-136. - Plans required; review by other departments. 
(a)  Building plans, site plans and specifications shall accompany every application for a permit and shall be filed in duplicate with the building inspector. All plans submitted shall be legible, drawn to scale, fully dimensioned and shall contain sufficient information to determine compliance with this Code and all other applicable regulations. Plans shall be prepared in accordance with the provisions of this article, shall bear the name of the architect, engineer or designer who prepared them, if any, and shall be of sufficient clarity to clearly indicate the nature and character of the work proposed. 
(b)  Building plans requiring review by other city departments or state agencies such as the city planning and zoning department, city plan commission or the department of commerce shall be reviewed and stamped "Approved" or "Conditionally Approved" by said departments or agencies prior to submittal for permits. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.06(2), (3))  
Sec. 35-137. - Quality of materials. 
When the quality of materials is essential for conformity to this article, specific information shall be given on plans submitted to establish such quality; and this article shall not be cited, or the term "legal" or its equivalent be used, as a substitute for specific information. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.06(4))  
Sec. 35-138. - Waiver of plans. 
The building inspector may waive the requirement for the filing of plans when the work involved is of a minor nature, when plans would not sufficiently show the nature and character of the work, or when the work is adequately described on the permit application. A detailed written description of all work proposed may also be substituted for building plans at the discretion of the building inspector. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.06(5))  
Sec. 35-139. - Amendment to plans. 
Subject to the limitations described in section 35-140, amendments to a plan, application or other record accompanying the same shall be filed at any time before completion of the work for which the permit is sought or issued. Such amendments are subject to the same review and approval process as the original plans and shall be deemed part of the original application. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.06(6))  
Sec. 35-140. - Time limitations. 
An application for a permit for any proposed work shall be deemed to have been abandoned six months after the date of filing unless such application has been diligently prosecuted or a permit shall have been issued; except that the building inspector may grant one or more extensions of time for additional periods not exceeding 90 days each if there is reasonable cause. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.06(7))  
Secs. 35-14135-163. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - ISSUANCE 
 
Sec. 35-164. - Plan review and permit issuance. 
The building inspector shall examine all applications for permits, plans and amendments thereto within a reasonable time after filing. If the application, plans and specifications are in substantial conformity to the requirements of this article, with all applicable ordinances of the city, and with all laws and lawful orders of the state, the building inspector shall, upon receipt of the required fee, issue a permit for said work and shall sign, date and stamp the plans "Approved" or "Conditionally Approved." 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.07(2))  
Sec. 35-165. - Permit to start construction. 
The zoning administrator or designated appointee is authorized to issue a permit to start construction, for the construction of foundations or any other part of the building or structure, before the plans and specifications for the entire building or structure have been submitted, but work on any building shall not be commenced unless department approval has been granted or a permit has been issued. The holder of a permit to start construction shall proceed at the holder's own risk with the building operation and without assurance that a permit for the entire structure will be granted. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.07(5))  
Sec. 35-166. - Distribution of approved plans. 
One set of approved plans and specifications shall be retained by the building inspector and one set of approved plans and specifications shall be returned to the applicant, which set shall be kept at the job site at all times until the work authorized thereby is completed and shall be made available for inspection by any department official. Such approved plans and specifications shall not be changed, altered or modified in any respect which involves any of the laws, ordinances or administrative rules referred to in section 35-165, or which involves the safety of the building or its occupants, except with the consent of the building inspector. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.07(2))  
Sec. 35-167. - Building permit card. 
With every building permit issued, the building inspector shall issue to the applicant an appropriate card properly filled out as evidence of permit issuance and the applicant shall post the card in a conspicuous place on the job site not more than 15 feet above the grade of the building. The card shall be unobstructed from public view and shall remain posted until all the work covered under the permit is completed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.07(3))  
Sec. 35-168. - Lapse of permit. 
A permit issued under the authority of this article shall have lapsed and be void unless building operations are commenced within six months from the date thereon and shall be completed within one year of commencement of building operations unless otherwise extended by the building inspector, to a maximum of 24 months. Any exterior portion of a building project which is visible to the public and which is not completed within the allotted 24-month period shall constitute a public nuisance. It is unlawful for a person to commence but fail to complete all repairs during the time in which the permit is valid. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 40.07(4))  
Sec. 35-169. - Permit authority.
