(2)  Is greater than five percent of the total flow rate or design compatible pollutant loading received at the MMSD wastewater treatment plant and/or is subject to pretreatment standards for incompatible pollutants as defined in Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 211 (general pretreatment requirements); or 
(3)  Has been notified in writing by the DNR, the MMSD or the utility that it is necessary to provide information concerning the concentration and quantity of the pollutants discharged. 
Slug load means any substance released at a discharge rate and/or concentration which causes interference to the wastewater treatment processes. 
Standard Methods means the examination and analytical procedures set forth in the most recent edition of "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" as prepared, approved, and published jointly by the American Public Health Association, American Water Works Association, and the Water Pollution Control Federation and is in compliance with 40 CFR 1346, "Guidelines Establishing Test Procedures for Analysis of Pollutants," all as amended from time to time. 
Suspended solids (SS) means total suspended matter that either floats on the surface of, or is in suspension in, water, wastewater, or other liquids, and that is removable by laboratory filtering as prescribed in "standard methods" and referred to as nonfilterable residue. 
Total Kjeldahl nitrogen (TKN) means the quantity of organic nitrogen and ammonia as determined in accordance with 40 CFR 136, or as the EPA otherwise determines. 
Total phosphorus (TP) means the quantity of total phosphorus as determined in accordance with 40 CFR 136, or as the EPA otherwise determines. 
Unpolluted water means water of a quality equal to or better than the effluent criteria in effect or water that would not cause violation of receiving water quality standards and would not be benefitted by discharge to the sanitary sewers and wastewater treatment facilities provided. 
User means any person who discharges, or causes to be discharged, domestic wastewater or industrial discharges or any other wastewater into the utility's sewerage system. 
User charge means the charges levied on the utility customers, municipalities and/or users of the wastewater facilities. The user charge is a component of the sewer service charge. 
Utility means the city utility district no. 1. unless preceded by MMSD (Madison Metropolitan Sewerage District). 
Wastewater facilities means the structures, equipment and processes designed to collect, carry and treat domestic wastewater and industrial discharges. 
Wastewater parameters includes volume, BOD, suspended solids, actual customers, equivalent meters, and such additional parameters as may from time to time be determined by the utility. 
Wastewater treatment plant means an arrangement of devices and structures for treating domestic wastewater and industrial discharges. Sometimes used as synonymous with the terms "wastewater treatment" or "wastewater treatment works" or "water pollution control works." 
WPDES permit means a permit to discharge pollutants, obtained under the Wisconsin Pollutant Discharge Elimination System (WPDES) pursuant to Wis. Stats. ch. 147. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.02)  
Sec. 40-601. - Utility territory. 
(a)  Boundaries. The boundaries of the utility are as shown on the utility boundary map dated May 5, 2000, on file in the utility office, as from time to time amended in accordance with this article. 
(b)  Additions. Territory may be added to the utility by action of the common council pursuant to Wis. Stats. §§ 62.11(5) and 66.0827 after public hearing, review and recommendation of the board and compliance with the requirements of the MMSD. Territory which is not part of the city's urban service area as adopted and approved by the county regional planning shall not be eligible for attachment to the utility or connection to the sewers of the utility or the MMSD. 
(c)  Petition for annexation to utility. A petition for annexation of territory to the utility shall be filed in the office of the director and shall be accompanied by such information as required by the common council and by the board in order to act with respect to such petition. 
(d)  Connection charges and fees to added territory. Territory added to the utility in accordance with this section shall be subject to such connection charges or fees, including fees payable to the MMSD, as the common council and board may from time to time determine and file in the office of the director. Such connection charges or fees shall be paid by the petitioner or customers located in the added territory at such time or times as the board may determine. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.03)  
Sec. 40-602. - Use of revenues; repeal of inconsistent provisions. 
Revenues derived from the application of this article shall be used to defray the utility costs of operating and maintaining adequate wastewater collection and treatment systems and to provide sufficient funds for capital outlay, debt service costs and capital improvements of the utility and the MMSD. This article supersedes any previous ordinance and all prior rules or regulations of the utility or ordinances of the city that are inconsistent herewith. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.01(2))  
Sec. 40-603. - Special assessments. 
When authorized by resolution of the city council, the cost of any utility sewerage system work or improvement may be levied and collected by special assessment against benefitted property pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0703 or chapter 10, article II, division 6, or by connection charge. The allocation of interceptor connection charges shall be in accordance with the "Policy on Establishment and Allocation of Interceptor Connection Charges," an appendix to the city's policies and procedures for special assessments. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.11)  
Secs. 40-60440-624. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CONNECTIONS 
 
Sec. 40-625. - Direct connection to MMSD intercepting sewers. 
Any person desiring to connect property located within the utility directly with any intercepting sewer of the MMSD shall make application to the MMSD commission for permission to make such connection. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.04(1))  
Sec. 40-626. - Connection to utility sewers. 
(a)  Generally. Any person desiring to connect property located within the utility to a utility sewer shall apply to the board for permission to make such connection. The board shall not grant permission for connection where the sewer owned by the utility is not adequately sized to transport the additional flow or the MMSD indicates that the wastewater facilities do not have available capacity. Industrial connections must be pre-approved by the MMSD. 
(b)  Combined sewers. No combined sewers shall be connected to the utility sewers. 
(c)  Application for connection of building sewer to utility sewer. No person shall connect a building sewer to a utility sewer without obtaining a permit as herein provided. Applications for permission to connect a building sewer to a sewer owned by the utility shall be made in writing to the utility. The application shall be made by the owner or the owner's representative and shall include a statement giving the exact location of the premises, the purpose for which the connection is to be used, the time when the work is to be done and such other information as may be required by the board or director. No work of laying the building sewer shall be commenced or continued without the required connection permit being on the premises. At the time of the connection, each building sewer shall be inspected by the plumbing inspector or the utility's designee. Copies of all industrial waste discharge permit applications shall also be approved by the MMSD prior to connection to any utility sewer. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.04(2))  
Sec. 40-627. - Connection of new community sewers to existing utility sewer. 
(a)  Generally. Any developer or builder desiring to construct a sewer which will subsequently be dedicated to the city and connected to an existing utility sewer or MMSD sewer, shall make application for permission to make such connection. No work of laying the proposed community sewer shall be commenced or continued without first obtaining written final approval of the plans and specifications by the director and the required connection permit. The connection permit shall be on the premises or in the hands of a professional engineer licensed to practice in the state at all times during construction. The board shall not grant permission for connection when the capacity of downstream collection is inadequate. 
(b)  Application. An application for permission to construct a new community sewer which will subsequently be dedicated to the city and connected to an existing utility or MMSD sewer shall be made as follows: 
(1)  The application is to be made to the utility in writing by a professional engineer licensed to practice in the state. 
(2)  The application shall describe the location of the requested connection, the character of the wastewater to be transmitted, the time when the work is to be done and such other information as may be required by the board or director; and shall include a statement that the design, construction, operation and maintenance of the system will be subject to the lawful rules and regulations of the board and that all necessary connection charges, as described in section 40-626 shall be paid. 
(3)  The application shall be accompanied by three sets of plans and specifications for the connecting system. The plans and specifications shall be prepared by a professional engineer, licensed to practice in the state and shall conform to state and local plumbing codes and the requirements of the state department of natural resources. 
(4)  Municipal water supply piping may be included in the plans and specifications submitted to the director. All elevations given on the plans submitted to the director shall be based upon datum of the City of Madison, which is 845.6 feet above mean sea level, or United States Geological Survey datum, and all bearings shown shall refer to the true north and south meridian. Every plan submitted shall bear a sign showing the direction of true north in relation to the plan. 
(5)  The plans and specifications shall be submitted to the director. The director shall review said plans and specifications for conformity with all design standards as periodically adopted and approved by rule or regulation of the board. A copy of the design standards as established by rule or regulation of the board shall be on file at all times in the office of the director. 
(6)  The director shall review the plans and specifications for conformity with all ordinances, administrative rules and regulations and for any other matter. The director shall then either approve, conditionally approve or reject the plans and specifications. The applicant shall be informed in writing of the action taken and, if the plans and specifications are approved conditionally or rejected, the conditions of approval or reasons for rejection shall be given in writing. 
(7)  Unless the time is extended by written agreement between the applicant and the director, the director shall complete the action required herein within 90 days of the filing of the plans and specifications. Failure to act within such 90 days shall constitute approval of the plans and specifications by the director. However, in no event shall construction proceed until all required approvals are granted. 
(8)  The director's approval of the plans and specifications and the issuance of the connection permit shall be conditioned upon approval by the MMSD and State of Wisconsin. When plans and specifications have been approved by the director, they shall be transmitted to the MMSD commission according to the MMSD ordinance. Any changes or additions to the plans and specifications which are required by an approving authority, other than the director, shall be submitted by the applicant to the director as said changes or additions are made. 
(c)  Connection fees. All outstanding charges, including special assessments and interest thereon, due against the land for local sewers, interceptors, force mains and lift stations previously installed by the utility, the MMSD or other authority shall be paid in full prior to connecting any community sewer to a utility sewer. In the case of community sewers, all costs of services performed by or on behalf of the district as described in section 40-628(a) shall also be paid prior to connection to a district sewer. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.04(3))  
Sec. 40-628. - Supervision and construction of sewers. 
(a)  Community sewers. 
(1)  Construction of community sewers within the utility shall be under the direction of a professional engineer licensed to practice in the state. Such engineer shall keep accurate records of the location, depth, and length of sewers as built; the number and location of manholes, if any; the location of any "Y" branches or slants; and the location of building sewers. 
(2)  The developer or builder shall be charged for engineering, inspection, consulting and legal services performed by or on behalf of the utility in conjunction with the design, inspection and review of private construction of a proposed community sewer to be subsequently dedicated to the city. Engineering, inspection, consulting and legal fees shall be the actual cost to the utility on the basis of submitted invoices plus twice the actual payroll cost for time spent by employees of the city. Such fees may be determined by the utility. 
(3)  Upon acceptance by the common council of the construction covered by the plans and specifications for the new community sewer, the developer shall furnish to the director digital CADD files in a format suitable to the director, two complete sets of correct prints, and one complete set of correct Mylar reproducibles. 
(4)  In accordance with this article and the provisions of chapter 24, pertaining to land division, the developer shall be responsible for performing replacement or acceptable repairs of any defective workmanship or materials that appear during the one-year guarantee period following completion and acceptance by the council of the project. 
(b)  Building sewers. All building sewers served by the utility shall be constructed and inspected as required by Wis. Admin. Code ch. COMM 82. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.04(4))  
Sec. 40-629. - Records of connection to community sewers. 
Records of building sewer connections or other connections to utility sewers shall be kept by the director and information regarding the same shall be furnished to the MMSD at such times as the MMSD may require. Information to be furnished regarding building sewer connections shall consist of the number of connections for the reporting period, the size of each connection, the nature or character of the user and such additional information as the MMSD may require. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.04(5))  
Sec. 40-630. - Prohibited connections. 
(a)  Septic tanks. No connection shall be made to any utility sewer if the connection pipe is carrying any contents from a septic or holding tank except a septic tank serving as a pretreatment process which has been required or permitted by the MMSD. 
(b)  Building foundation drains. No connection shall be made to any utility wastewater collection facility if the connection pipe is carrying flow from a building foundation drain. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.04(6))  
Sec. 40-631. - Mandatory connections. 
(a)  When required. Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section every owner of a parcel of land within the city shall install, at the owner's expense, suitable plumbing facilities and connect to a utility sewer whenever the following conditions exist: 
(1)  The parcel of land is located within the utility adjacent to a utility sewer; 
(2)  There is located upon such parcel a building or other structure used for human habitation, recreation or occupancy, or for the conduct of any trade, business or industry; and 
(3)  Such building or structure is being served by a private sewage disposal or treatment works. 
Such connection shall be made within 90 days after the date of written notice by the board. As used in this subsection, the term "adjacent" means 50 percent or more of the frontage abuts upon a right-of-way or easement in which is installed a utility sewer. 
(b)  Waiver. The requirement to connect to the public sewer system may be temporarily waived by the board by a unanimous vote of the entire membership upon application of the property owner and a finding by the board that there is no evidence of a condition hazardous to health and that immediate connection would cause the property owner extraordinary hardship and expense. The period of temporary waiver shall be established by the board, but in no event shall a waiver period exceed one year after installation of the sewer adjoining such parcel. The granting of a temporary waiver will not delay the collection of special assessments unless the board so provides. The owner's application for a waiver must be accompanied by proof, in a form acceptable to the board, that the private sewerage system is operating satisfactorily in accordance with all applicable utility, MMSD and state regulations. A temporary waiver grant applies only to the property owner receiving the waiver. In the event ownership of the property is subsequently transferred, the temporary waiver will automatically expire upon such transfer and the new owner must immediately comply with the compulsory connection requirement. 
(c)  Deferred connection of exclusive agricultural lands. Upon application by the owner to the board, lands zoned for exclusive agricultural use or for which a farmland preservation agreement has been recorded as provided in Wis. Stats. ch. 91 (farmland preservation), shall be granted a compulsory connection waiver. This waiver shall remain in effect only so long as the property is either zoned for exclusively agricultural use or is covered by a recorded agricultural use or is covered by a recorded farmland preservation agreement. 
(d)  Waiver not to negate other requirements. The provisions of this section do not abrogate or alleviate the need for compliance with any other connection requirements that may be imposed by the state or the MMSD. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.04(7))  
Sec. 40-632. - Connection charge. 
For each connection made to the public sewage system, there shall be paid to the utility a connection charge as provided in section 40-627(c). Any person failing to pay such charge shall be subject to the penalties provided in article IV, division 2 of this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.04(8))  
Secs. 40-63340-652. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CHARGES AND BILLING 
 
Sec. 40-653. - General service charges; annual adjustment. 
(a)  Service charges to each utility customer shall be based on the quantity and quality of wastewater discharged by the customer to the utility sewers and on the size of the water meter(s) serving that user, as from time to time established by the board as listed in the city's fee schedule in accordance with wastewater parameters established by the MMSD. 
(b)  Sewer service charges shall consist of MMSD user charges and debt service rates and utility user charges and debt service charges in accordance with the city's fee schedule, such that each customer will bear its proportionate share of the costs of administration, operation, maintenance and debt service of all wastewater collection and treatment services provided by the utility and the MMSD. 
(c)  The sewer rates will be adjusted yearly to reflect an increase or decrease in rates charged by the Madison Metropolitan Sewerage District (MMSD). The adjustment will be effective for service rendered on or after December 15 of the year of the adjustment. The utility will provide notice to its customers of such charges in rates resulting from application of the purchased treatment adjustment. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.08(1))  
Sec. 40-654. - Service charge rates for domestic strength users. 
(a)  Service charges to each domestic strength user shall be determined and billed in accordance with the size of the water meters serving the user and the quantity of water used, as determined from regular water meter readings. The unit volume charge shall be derived from computations that allocate costs of collection and treatment on the basis of wastewater characteristics, including volume, CBOD, SS, TKN, and TP as supplied by the MMSD. 
(b)  As used in this section, "domestic strength" is defined as concentrations of/or less than the following: 
(1)  200 mg/l of CBOD (biochemical oxygen demand). 
(2)  250 mg/l of SS (suspended solids). 
(3)  40 mg/l of TKN (total Kjeldahl nitrogen). 
(4)  10 mg/l of TP (total phosphorus). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.08(2))  
Sec. 40-655. - Service charge rates for high strength users. 
Sewer service charges to each user with sewerage discharges in excess of domestic strength set forth in section 40-654 shall be calculated and billed on the basis of the measured quantity and quality of the wastewater discharged, taking into account the wastewater characteristics set forth in section 40-654, and on the size of the water meters serving the user. Wastes higher than normal domestic strength will be surcharged in accordance with the city's fee schedule. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.08(3))  
Sec. 40-656. - Service charge rate adjustments. 
Sewer service charge rates shall be reviewed by the board at least annually and be adjusted by the board whenever necessary to meet the utility cost of administration, operation, maintenance and debt service. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.08(4))  
Sec. 40-657. - Sewer service charge calculations. 
Sewer service charges for each utility customer shall be calculated based on the quantity and quality of wastewater contributed by such customer, as determined by the board, the number of actual customers and the equipment needed to provide service within the utility and such additional wastewater parameters as are established by the board. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.08(5))  
Sec. 40-658. - Biennial audit. 
The utility shall review, at least every two years, the wastewater contributions of its sewer users, the operation, maintenance, and replacement expenses of the wastewater collection facilities, and the sewer service charge system. Based on this review, the municipality shall revise the sewer service charge system, if necessary, to accomplish the following: 
(1)  Maintain a proportionate distribution of operation, maintenance, and replacement expenses among sewer users based on the wastewater volume and pollutant loadings discharged by the users; 
(2)  Generate sufficient revenues to pay the operation, maintenance, and replacement expenses of the wastewater collection facilities; and 
(3)  Apply excess revenues collected from a class of users to the operation, maintenance, and replacement expenses attributable to that class of users for the next year and adjust the sewer service charge rates accordingly. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.08(6))  
Sec. 40-659. - Annual notification of sewer rates. 
The utility shall notify its sewer users annually of the sewer service charge rates. The notification shall show what portions of the rates are attributable to the operation, maintenance, replacement, and debt service costs of the wastewater collection facilities. The notification shall occur in conjunction with the regular bill or public notice in the official newspaper. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.08(7))  
Sec. 40-660. - Utility operation, maintenance and replacement accounts. 
All sewer service charge revenues collected for replacement costs shall be deposited in a separate and distinct fund to be used solely for replacement costs of the sewer collection system, including pump stations. All sewer service charge revenues collected for other operation and maintenance expenses shall also be deposited in a separate and distinct fund. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.08(8))  
Sec. 40-661. - Special charges. 
Whenever any user discharges waste into the utility sewers or sewerage system which causes physical damage to the utility wastewater facilities or which causes the utility to incur unusual additional costs, the utility may assess a special charge against such user for the work required to repair the facilities or to recover the unusual additional cost. Special charges shall be in addition to the service charges levied under this division and shall be billed directly to the user. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.09)  
Sec. 40-662. - Billing and collection. 
(a)  Billing and due date. Sewer service charges of the utility shall be billed quarterly, unless circumstances require delayed billing. Charges are due on or before 20 days of the date of issuance of the bill. Connection fees and other special charges not included in the service billing shall be billed as incurred and due within 20 days of billing. 
(b)  Late payment. A late payment charge of one percent per month, compounded monthly, will be added to bills not paid within 20 days of the date of the bill. 
(c)  Collection of delinquent payments. In addition to all other methods provided by law, delinquent payments may be collected as a special tax against the property served in the manner provided by Wis. Stats. § 66.0821. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.10)  
Secs. 40-66340-682. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - USE REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 40-683. - Prohibited waste disposal methods. 
(a)  Land disposal of nonfarm waste prohibited. No person shall place, deposit, spread or permit to be placed, deposited or spread on public or private property within the utility or any area under the jurisdiction of the utility any human or nonfarm animal excrement, garbage or other objectionable waste. This does not prohibit the disposal of sewage sludge in accordance with Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 204. 
(b)  Discharge into natural outlets prohibited. No person shall discharge to any natural outlet within the utility in any area under the jurisdiction of the utility any wastewater or other polluted waters, except where suitable treatment has been provided in accordance with this article and all applicable federal, state and local statutes, ordinances and regulations. 
(c)  Privies, cesspools, etc., prohibited. No person shall construct or maintain any privy, privy vault, cesspool, holding tank or similar facility within the utility. Any such privy, privy vault, cesspool, holding tank or similar facility in existence at the time the provisions of this article with respect of mandatory connection to the utility sewers becomes effective shall be abandoned and filled in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Admin. Code § COMM 83.33. Septic tanks and other similar effluent absorption systems may be constructed and maintained only as provided in article IV, division 1 of this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.12)  
Sec. 40-684. - Prohibited discharges. 
(a)  Generally. No person shall discharge wastes to a utility sewer or MMSD intercepting sewer which cause or are capable of causing, either alone or in combination with other substances: 
(1)  A fire or explosion; 
(2)  Obstruction of flow or damage to the wastewater facilities; 
(3)  Danger to life or safety or welfare of persons; 
(4)  Air pollution as defined in Wis. Stats. § 144.01(1), as amended from time to time, and any regulations or orders of any regulatory agency issued thereunder; 
(5)  Prevention of effective maintenance or operation of the wastewater facilities; 
(6)  Any product of the utility treatment processes or any of the utility residues, sludges, or scums, to be unsuitable for reclamation and reuse or to interfere with reclamation processes; 
(7)  A detrimental environmental impact, a nuisance, or any condition unacceptable to any public agency having regulatory jurisdiction over the utility; 
(8)  Any sanitary sewer or the utility wastewater facilities to be overloaded; 
(9)  In the opinion of the director, excessive utility collection and treatment costs, or use of a disproportionate share of the utility facilities; 
(10)  Cause the utility to violate its WPDES permit. 
(b)  Specific. Prohibited discharges shall include, but not be limited to: 
(1)  Any gasoline, benzene, naphtha, fuel oil, or other flammable or explosive liquid, solid or gas; 
(2)  Any wastes containing toxic or poisonous solids, liquids or gases in sufficient quantity, either singly or by interaction or in combination with other wastes, to injure or interfere with any waste treatment process, constitute a danger to humans, flora or fauna, create a public nuisance, or create any hazard in the receiving waters of the MMSD wastewater treatment plant; 
(3)  Any waters or wastes having a pH lower than 5.5 or higher than 10.0, or having other corrosive property capable of causing damage or hazard to structures, equipment, or treatment works personnel of the utility or MMSD; 
(4)  Solids or viscous substances including, but not limited to, such substances as ashes, bones, cinders, sand, mud, straw, shavings, metal, glass, rags, feathers, tar, plastics, wood, improperly shredded garbage, whole blood, paunch manure, hair and fleshings, entrails, paper dishes, cups, mill containers, either whole or ground by garbage grinders; 
(5)  Any wastewater from industrial plants containing floatable oils, fats or greases; 
(6)  Any wastewater which contains organo-sulfur or organo-phosphate pesticides, herbicides or fertilizers. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.05(1))  
Sec. 40-685. - Storm drainage and groundwater discharge restricted. 
(a)  Unpolluted waters. Stormwater, groundwater, rain water, street drainage, roof runoff or subsurface drainage shall not be discharged into utility sewers without prior approval by the director and the MMSD or into MMSD intercepting sewers without prior approval by the MMSD. Such approval shall be granted only when no reasonable alternative method of disposal is available. 
(b)  Polluted stormwater. Polluted stormwater runoff from limited areas may be discharged to a utility sewer upon approval by the director and the MMSD director, payment of applicable charges and fees and compliance with conditions required by the board and the MMSD. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.05(2))  
Sec. 40-686. - Prohibition of unpolluted waters. 
Unpolluted water, including, but not limited to: cooling water, process water or blow-down from cooling towers or evaporative coolers, shall not be discharged into utility sewers without prior approval of the board and the MMSD, or into intercepting sewers without prior approval of the MMSD. Such approval shall be granted when no reasonable alternative method of disposal is available and upon payment of applicable charges and fees and compliance with conditions as required by the board and MMSD. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.05(3))  
Sec. 40-687. - Limitations on discharge characteristics. 
(a)  Limitations related to treatment plant influent. Discharge to the utility sewerage system of the following described substances, materials, waters or waste shall be limited to the following concentrations or quantities, provided such concentrations or quantities will not harm the utility or MMSD sewers, wastewater treatment process or equipment; will not have an adverse effect on the receiving stream; will not have an adverse effect on the MMSD sludge management program; will not endanger persons or property; will not cause air pollution or other detrimental environmental effects; and will not constitute a nuisance: 
(1)  Liquid having a temperature higher than 65 degrees Celsius (149 degrees Fahrenheit) or any wastewater having a temperature which will inhibit biological activity in the utility treatment plant, thereby resulting in interference. Notwithstanding the foregoing, in no case shall wastewater be discharged having a temperature that causes the to the utility treatment plant to exceed 40 degrees Celsius (104 degrees Fahrenheit), unless the MMSD director certifies that the treatment plant is designed to accommodate such temperature; 
(2)  Wax, grease, oil, plastic or any other substance that solidifies or becomes discernibly viscous; 
(3)  Radioactive wastes which, alone or with other wastes, result in releases greater than those specified by current United States Bureau of Standards Handbooks, or which violate rules or regulations of any applicable regulatory agency; 
(4)  Wastewater containing more than 50 milligrams per liter of petroleum oil, nonbiodegradable cutting oils, or products of mineral oil origin; 
(5)  Wastewater containing more than 300 mg/l of oil or grease of animal or vegetable origin; 
(6)  Wastewater which in concentration of any given constituent or in quantity of flow exceeds for any period of duration longer than 15 minutes more than five times the average 24-hour concentration or flows during normal operation; 
(7)  Wastewater which contains in excess of any of the following constituents in a 24-hour flow proportionate sample made up of an aggregate of the total discharge from all of the outfalls of the industrial user: 
a.  0.25 mg/l cadmium; 
b.  0.5 mg/l hexavalent chromium; 
c.  10.0 mg/l total chromium; 
d.  10.5 mg/l copper; 
e.  5.0 mg/lead; 
f.  0.02 mg/l mercury; 
g.  0.3 mg/l selenium; 
h.  3.0 mg/l silver; 
i.  8.0 mg/l zinc; 
j.  2.0 mg/l nickel; 
k.  0.1 mg/l cyanide. 
Samples shall be collected over the period of discharge if the discharge is less than 24 hours in duration. 
(8)  Industrial discharges exceeding applicable national categorical pretreatment standards, or state standards; 
(9)  Any substance with objectionable color not removed in the treatment process, such as, but not limited to, dye wastes and vegetable tanning solution; 
(10)  Any noxious or malodorous liquids, gases, or solids which either singly or by interaction are capable of creating a public nuisance or hazard to life or are sufficient to prevent entry into the sewers for their maintenance and repair; or 
(11)  Any discharge prohibited or limited by the MMSD by alteration, amendment or modification of the limitations established in section 5.2.1 of the MMSD ordinance determined by the board to be necessary to meet the objectives of this article or the conditions of the MMSD's WPDES permit. 
(b)  Discharge into utility sewerage system prohibited. No person shall cause or permit a discharge into the utility sewerage system that would cause, or significantly contribute to, either directly or indirectly, a violation of the conditions of the MMSD's WPDES permit and any modification or re-issuance thereof. 
(c)  Limitations superceded. Upon promulgation of National Categorical Pretreatment Standards for a particular industrial user subcategory, the federal standards (if more stringent than the limitations imposed under this article) shall immediately supersede the limitations imposed under this article; and such industrial user shall comply with the said federal standards upon notification by MMSD of the applicable requirements under 40 CFR 403.12. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.05(4))  
Sec. 40-688. - No dilution of industrial discharge. 
Dilution of an industrial discharge for purposes of reducing the pollutant characteristics or concentrations to below the limitations established in this section, or below other applicable pretreatment standards, is prohibited. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.05(5))  
Sec. 40-689. - Accidental discharge of prohibited wastewater. 
Any person who accidentally discharges into the utility sewerage system wastes or wastewater prohibited under this article shall immediately report such a discharge to the director and the MMSD. Such report shall describe the location, time and volume of the discharge, and the type of waste or wastewater discharged. Within 15 days of such discharge, a detailed written statement describing the cause of the discharge and the measure taken to prevent a future occurrence shall be submitted to the director and the MMSD. Such reporting shall not relieve the person causing the accidental discharge from any penalties imposed by this article. Where the director or MMSD deems necessary, industrial users shall provide facilities to prevent accidental discharges or spills of wastes or wastewater prohibited under this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.05(6))  
Sec. 40-690. - Alternatives to acceptance of wastewater. 
If any waters or wastes are discharged or are proposed to be discharged to the utility sewers, in excess of those limitations enumerated in section 40-687(a) and (b), the board shall, as directed by the MMSD: 
(1)  Reject the wastes; 
(2)  Require pretreatment; 
(3)  Control the quantities and rates of discharge; and/or 
(4)  Recover the increased costs of handling and treating such wastes. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.05(7))  
Sec. 40-691. - Industrial discharges. 
Industrial users shall comply with the provisions of sections 5.5 through 5.8 of the MMSD Sewer Use Ordinance No. 84-001 and all amendments thereto. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.05(8))  
Sec. 40-692. - Sand and grease trap installations. 
Grease, oil and sand interceptors shall be installed at repair garages, gasoline stations, car washes, and other industrial or commercial establishments, where necessary in the opinion of the board or MMSD to prevent discharge of sand, flammable wastes, oil or grease in amounts exceeding the limits of this section. All such traps shall be constructed and maintained by the owner at the owner's expense, in accordance with the state plumbing code and the specifications of the director, and shall be readily accessible for cleaning and inspection. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.05(9))  
Secs. 40-69340-712. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - MEASUREMENT AND SAMPLING 
 
Sec. 40-713. - Monitoring of wastewater. 
Wastewater characteristics and constituents shall be monitored to determine compliance with this article and the ordinance of the MMSD and to facilitate and equitable system of service charges. New users planning to discharge industrial waste shall submit a request to discharge form to the director and to MMSD at least 60 days prior to the planned discharge. 
(1)  New users. 
a.  A new user who expects to discharge, or who is capable of discharging wastewater having constituents or characteristics different from domestic wastewater shall install a monitoring facility. 
b.  Existing users planning to add to or change their industrial waste discharge shall submit a request to discharge form to the director and to MMSD at least 60 days prior to the planned discharge. 
(2)  Existing users. An existing user whose discharges are different from domestic wastewater may be required by the district to install a monitoring facility. Construction of such facility shall be completed within 90 days after the user has been notified in writing by the board, unless the board and the MMSD grant an extension of time. 
(3)  Voluntary monitoring. In addition to those required to monitor, any user who so desires may install and operate monitoring facilities and report its wastewater characteristics for billing purposed in accordance with this article. 
(4)  Monitoring facilities. All monitoring facilities shall be constructed at the owner's expense in accordance with plans approved by the board and the MMSD. The monitoring facility shall contain the necessary flow monitoring and sampling equipment to facilitate the observation, sampling and measurement of wastes and shall be maintained by the owner so as to be safe and accessible at all times. 
(5)  Waiver. The requirements of subsections (1), (2) and (4) of this section may be waived only by special written permission of the MMSD director and the board. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.07(1))  
Sec. 40-714. - Inspections. 
(a)  Access for inspection, observation, measurement, etc. Agents of the utility or of the MMSD shall be allowed access to all monitoring facilities and property served by the utility for the purpose of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing of discharges to the utility sewers and MMSD wastewater facilities; or for the purpose of inspection of records kept by industrial users relating to pretreatment requirements or reporting thereof. 
(b)  Agents to bear credentials. Agents of the utility exercising authority under this subsection shall bear proper credentials and identification. 
(c)  What information to constitute public record. Any effluent data submitted or supplied to the utility by any person or user is a public record within the meaning of Wis. Stats. § 19.21. All other information submitted to the utility shall be a public record unless the information is entitled to confidential treatment pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 283.55 and Wis. Admin. Code § NR 2.19. The utility may require any industrial user to provide information about industrial processes which may have an effect on the nature or composition of the industrial discharge and such information will be kept confidential if the requirements of the aforesaid statutes and administrative rule are satisfied. Any information or data obtained by the utility which is confidential or constitutes a trade secret shall not be disclosed to unauthorized persons. 
(d)  Surveys. In accordance with Wis. Stats. § 200.11 and this article, the MMSD director or his/her authorized or employees shall be permitted to enter upon any lands in the utility for the purpose of making surveys or examinations. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.07(2))  
Sec. 40-715. - Reporting requirements. 
(a)  User information. In order to carry out its responsibilities under this article, or the ordinances, rules and regulations of the MMSD, the director may require a user to provide information concerning, but not limited to: 
(1)  Volume, time and peak rate of discharges; 
(2)  Chemical analysis of discharges; 
(3)  Raw materials, processes and products relevant to discharge characteristics; 
(4)  Discharges of specific wastes such as sludge, oil, solvent, oil, or incompatible pollutants; 
(5)  Plot plans of sewers on the user's property showing locations of sewers, monitoring facilities, and pretreatment facilities; 
(6)  Details of pretreatment facilities; and 
(7)  Details of systems to prevent losses of materials through spills to the utility sewers. 
(b)  Reports of discharges requiring pretreatment. If any significant industrial user discharges any incompatible pollutants which require pretreatment prior to the discharge to the utility sewage system, the quality and quantity of the discharge shall be reported to the MMSD and the utility quarterly by March 15, June 15, September 15, and December 15. 
(c)  Measurement and testing standards. All measurements and test analyses of the characteristics of wastewater shall be determined or performed in accordance with "Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater" and/or established by the EPA pursuant to section 304(h) of the Clean Water Act, 33 USC 1314, and contained in 40 CFR 136 and amendments thereto, or with any other test procedures approved by the EPA. Sampling shall be performed in accordance with the techniques approved by the EPA. Where 40 CFR 136 does not include a sampling or analytical technique for the pollutant in question, sampling and analysis shall be performed in accordance with the procedures set forth in the EPA publication, "Sampling and Analysis Procedures for Screening of Industrial Effluents or Priority Pollutants, April 1977," and analytical procedures approved by the EPA. 
(d)  Reports to be signed. Any reports required to be submitted by an industrial user pursuant to the provisions of this article, shall be signed by the authorized representative of such user. The authorized representative shall be the chief operating officer of such user if a corporation, or a partner of such user if a partnership, or the sole owner of such user if a sole proprietorship. 
(e)  Reporting period. The reporting period shall not include the 30 days immediately preceding the day the report is due. All analyses shall be done on representative 24-hour composite samples taken during a typical operating day. 
(f)  Retention of user records. Each industrial user shall retain and preserve for no less than three years any records, books, documents, memoranda, reports, correspondence, and other information relating to monitoring, sampling and chemical analysis made by or on behalf of the industrial user in connection with its industrial discharge. All such records pertaining to matters which are the subject of any enforcement proceedings under this article or the subject of any litigation involving the utility or the MMSD shall be retained and preserved by the industrial user until such proceedings or litigation have been finally concluded and all periods of limitation with respect to appeals therefrom have expired. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.07(3))  
Secs. 40-71640-743. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - DISCHARGE REGULATIONS 
 
Sec. 40-744. - Discharge into community sewers. 
No person, including a licensed disposer, may discharge any holding tank wastes or any other liquid, gaseous or solid wastes determined by the director to be detrimental to the public sewerage system or to utility employees or to the process of sewage treatment, directly into a manhole or other opening in a public sewer, unless such person has been issued a permit for such discharge by the MMSD, which permit has been approved by the board. Such permit shall state the location, volume and characteristics of the discharge. The director shall record and report the volume and nature of all such discharges to the MMSD quarterly. The person making the discharge shall pay a charge or fee, based on the characteristics of the discharge. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.06(1))  
Sec. 40-745. - Limitations on discharge of holding tank wastes and other wastes. 
Any holding tank waste or other waste permitted to be discharged under this section shall be of domestic origin or contain compatible pollutants only. The person or licensed disposer making the discharge shall comply with the provisions of any and all applicable rules including this article. Without intending to limit the application of other provisions of this article, such person or licensed disposer shall not deposit or drain any gasoline, oil, acid, alkali, grease, rags, volatile or flammable liquids or other deleterious substances into any manhole, utility or MMSD sewer; nor shall such person or licensed disposer allow any grease, earth, sand or other solid materials to pass into any part of the utility or MMSD sewerage system; nor shall such person or licensed disposer discharge any liquid, gaseous or solid wastes determined by the director to be detrimental to the sewerage system or to the utility employees or to the process of sewage treatment. No discharges shall be permitted directly into any utility or MMSD interceptor sewers unless the MMSD so authorizes. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.06(2))  
Sec. 40-746. - Permits to discharge holding tank wastes. 
(a)  Permit application, term. No person or licensed disposer shall discharge wastes described in section 40-744 or 40-745 directly into the utility sewers unless the person or licensed disposer making the discharge has been issued a permit by the director. All applications for a permit shall be in writing; shall contain such information as the director deems appropriate; and shall be submitted to the director no later than September 1 of each year. No permit shall be issued without prior approval of the MMSD director. No permit once issued shall be assignable or transferrable by the person receiving the same. Permits shall be valid for a period of one year, beginning on October 1 of the year of issuance and expiring on September 30 of the succeeding year. No holder of a holding tank waste disposition permit shall acquire any vested right or privilege by reason thereof. This section does not permit connection of building sewers carrying septic or holding tank wastes to utility sewers. 
(b)  Permit conditions. If the director and/or the MMSD director determine to issue a permit, such permit may be issued upon such terms and conditions as the issuers may provide; but any such permit shall provide at a minimum the following: 
(1)  The permit shall be conditioned upon the holder's faithful compliance with the provisions of this article and the MMSD sewer use ordinance, as amended from time to time, and any other applicable ordinances of the city. 
(2)  The agreement of the holder thereof to indemnify the MMSD, the utility and the city from and against any and all liability for injury or damage arising out of or related to the activities of holder in exercising the rights granted. The board may require the holder of such permit to post a bond written by a bonding company, licensed to transact business in the state, to guarantee performance of the holder thereunder. 
(3)  Evidence that the holder thereof has in full force and effect sufficient worker's compensation insurance, public liability and property damage insurance. 
(c)  Fee. In the event the director issues a permit under this section, the board may require the applicant to pay an annual fee in such reasonable amount as it may determine as a condition precedent to the issuance of such permit. 
(d)  Summary revocation. Any permit issued under this division may be summarily revoked by the board for violation of the terms or conditions thereof. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.06(3))  
Sec. 40-747. - Special provisions applicable to licensed disposers. 
Any licensed disposer making application for a permit to discharge holding tank wastes into the utility sewers under section 40-746 shall, in addition to complying with all provisions of section 40-746, comply with the following provisions which shall be deemed incorporated into any permit issued to such disposer: 
(1)  The utility shall have the right to reject and refuse to accept holding tank wastes from the licensed disposer if: 
a.  Treatment of the waste would cause the utility or MMSD's sewerage systems to exceed its operating design capacity or to violate any applicable effluent limitations or standards, water quality standards or any other legally applicable requirements, including court orders or MMSD, state or federal statutes, rules, regulations or orders; 
b.  The waste is not compatible with the utility or MMSD's sewerage systems; 
c.  The licensed disposer has not applied for and received a permit under this section to dispose of the waste or the licensed disposer fails to comply with the permit so issued; 
d.  The licensed disposer fails to comply with waste disposal rules promulgated from time to time by the MMSD or the board; or 
e.  Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this subsection, the licensed disposer may discharge wastes offered for disposal which are not within the prohibitions set forth in subsections (1)a through d of this section. 
(2)  Reasonable terms and conditions for holding tank waste disposal imposed by the board or MMSD relating to the following: 
a.  Specific quantities, locations, times and methods for discharge of such wastes into the utility sewers; 
b.  Requirements to report the source and amount of such wastes placed in the utility sewers; and 
c.  Requirements that the licensed disposer analyze representative samples of the waste placed in the utility sewers in order to determine the characteristics of the waste and the compatibility of the waste with the utility and MMSD's sewerage system. Analysis of such waste from exclusively residential sources shall not be required. 
(3)  If the utility sewers can accept some, but not all, of the holding tank wastes offered for disposal, the director may accept such waste which is generated within the geographic boundaries of the utility before accepting such wastes which are generated outside of the boundaries of the utility. 
(4)  Provided the conditions of this section are satisfied, the director shall grant to a licensed disposer a permit to discharge holding tank wastes. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.06(4))  
Sec. 40-748. - Penalty for violation. 
See forfeiture/bond/deposit schedule for penalties for any person or licensed disposer violating the terms or conditions of a permit issued under this section or using or permitting the use of the utility sewers for a use for which a permit may be issued under this division without first obtaining a permit or continuing such use after notice of revocation of a permit. All forfeitures recovered by the city under this section shall be paid into the general account of the commission for the benefit of the utility. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.06(5))  
Secs. 40-74940-779. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - SPECIAL ORDERS, APPEALS AND PENALTIES 
 
Sec. 40-780. - Special orders. 
In the event of any known or threatened violation of the provisions of this article or any other rule or regulation promulgated by the board , the director may issue a special order in the name of the city directing the person causing or responsible for the violation to comply with such ordinance, rule or regulation within a specified time. All special orders shall be in writing and shall specifically state what action is required to comply with the order. Service and proof of service of any special order shall be made in the manner provided for service of summons in the county circuit court. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.21(1)  
Sec. 40-781. - Emergency orders. 
The director, city plumbing inspector or other person designated in writing by the board is hereby authorized and empowered to issue special orders in the name of the utility in an emergency to prevent damage to the utility sewers from misuse; injury to employees of the utility; interference with the process of sewage collection, treatment or disposal; or substantial risk to the public health, safety and welfare. A special order is effective and enforceable upon service. Service shall be made as provided in section 40-780. Special orders shall be in writing and shall specifically state the action required, and the time allowed for compliance. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.21(2))  
Sec. 40-782. - Appeals. 
Any person aggrieved by a special or emergency order may secure a review of such order by filing a written notice of appeal with the board within 30 days of the date of the order appealed stating the grounds of the appeal and attaching a copy of the order appealed. The procedure on appeal shall be as set forth in sections 40-783 through 40-786. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.21(3))  
Sec. 40-783. - Notice of hearing. 
The executive secretary of the board shall schedule a public hearing on the appeal to be held within 30 days of the filing of the notice of the appeal. The executive secretary shall mail notice of the time scheduled for consideration of the appeal to the appellant at least ten days prior to the hearing. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.21(3)(A))  
Sec. 40-784. - Conduct of hearing. 
In the case of appeals from orders of the city engineer or plumbing inspector, the appeal shall be conducted as provided in Wis. Stats. §§ 68.11 and 68.12. In the case of an appeal from an order of the board, the review shall be conducted as provided in Wis. Stats. § 68.09. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.21(3)(B))  
Sec. 40-785. - Decision. 
Within 30 days of the appeal hearing the board shall affirm, modify or reverse the action or decision appealed. Written notice of the board's decision shall be mailed to the applicant. In the case of appeals from orders of the city engineer or plumbing inspector, the board's decision shall be final. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.21(3)(C))  
Sec. 40-786. - Appeal to zoning board of appeals. 
Any person objecting to the decision of the commission on review of a board order may appeal to the city zoning board of appeals by filing written notice with the secretary of such board within 14 days of the date when notice of the final decision of the board is mailed. 
(1)  The notice of appeal shall be in writing and shall state the action appealed from, shall attach a copy of the board's written notice of decision and shall specify why the appellant believes said action was inappropriate or incorrect. The notice shall be accompanied by the fee established pursuant to chapter 22 for appeal to the zoning board of appeals. 
(2)  The secretary of the zoning board shall file the notice of appeal with such zoning board and shall schedule the appeal for consideration at a meeting open to the public within 15 days of the filing of the notice unless extended by written agreement of the appellant and the board. The written notice of the time and place of the hearing shall be given to the appellant and to the board of public works. 
(3)  The hearing shall be conducted in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 68.11 and 68.12. 
(4)  The decision of the zoning board of appeals on appeal shall be in writing and state the reasons therefor and shall be a final determination as provided in Wis. Stats. § 68.12. A concurring vote of all members of the zoning board is necessary to reverse any order, requirement or decision of the board. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.21(3)(D))  
Sec. 40-787. - Stay of order during appeal. 
Except when the board or the zoning board shall determine, on application, and on notice to the appellant and the board, that a stay of the order will cause imminent danger to life or health, the order shall be stayed during the pendency of the appeal. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.21(4))  
Secs. 40-78840-812. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PRIVATE WASTEWATER DISPOSAL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 40-813. - When allowed. 
Where a utility sanitary sewer is not available within the city, the building sewer shall be connected to a private wastewater disposal system complying with the provisions of this article and the state plumbing code as adopted by section 40-21 and with all federal, state and local statutes, ordinances and regulations. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(1))  
Sec. 40-814. - Permits required. 
Before starting construction of a private wastewater disposal system, the owner shall first obtain a written permit signed by the county sanitarian and a written permit signed by the county sanitarian and a written permit signed by the city plumbing inspector. Application for such permit shall be made on forms furnished by the county environmental health department and the plumbing inspector. The applicant shall supplement application by any plans, specifications, and other information required by the sanitarian or plumbing inspector. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(2))  
Sec. 40-815. - Approval required prior to use. 
No person shall use a private wastewater disposal system for disposal of wastewater until the installation is approved by the county sanitarian and the plumbing inspector, who shall be allowed to inspect the work at any stage of the construction. The applicant for the permit shall notify the sanitarian and the plumbing inspector when the work is ready for final inspection before any underground portions are covered. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(3))  
Sec. 40-816. - Holding tanks prohibited for new construction. 
Except as provided hereunder, no person shall on or after September 24, 1980, construct or install a holding tank or any similar facility to serve any building constructed within the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(4)(A))  
Sec. 40-817. - Holding tanks for existing buildings only where necessary to prevent health and safety problems. 
Installation of holding tanks to serve any building in existence on September 24, 1980, may be permitted only in accordance with the following procedure and conditions: 
(1)  Permit required. A person desiring to install a holding tank system to serve a building which existed on September 24, 1980, shall file with the city clerk an application for a holding tank permit along with a nonrefundable application in accordance with the city's fee schedule. The application shall be in writing, signed by the applicant, and shall contain the name and address of the applicant, the name and address of the owner of the property, the location of the proposed holding tank and buildings to be served thereby and a complete explanation as to why the installation of a holding tank is necessary to prevent health and safety problems. 
(2)  Review of application. The city clerk shall forward the application to the board for consideration and report to the city council. Upon receiving the report of the board, the common council shall approve, conditionally approve or reject the application. One copy of the application shall be returned to the applicant with written notification endorsed thereon of the council's action and the date thereof. If approved conditionally or rejected, the conditions of approval or reasons for rejection shall be attached thereto. 
(3)  Proof of council approval; pumping/maintenance agreement and escrow fund required before permit issuance. No holding tank permit shall be issued until the applicant files with the city clerk the following items: 
a.  Proof of common council approval; and if, conditionally approved, proof that the conditions have been satisfied; 
b.  A properly executed holding tank pumping/maintenance agreement satisfactory to the city attorney which shall be binding on the applicant and the owner of the premises and on their successors, heirs and assigns. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(4)(B))  
Sec. 40-818. - Term of permit and agreement. 
The term of the holding tank permit and pumping/maintenance agreement shall be for such period as specified by the city council; provided, however, that the permit may be rescinded or revoked by the council, after notice and hearing upon a determination that any of the provisions of this article or conditions imposed on the permit have been violated or, at any time, if the use of the property is discontinued for a period of 12 months. The permit and the obligations and conditions of the accompanying agreement shall automatically transfer during the term of the permit to any successors or assigns of the applicant. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(4)(C))  
Sec. 40-819. - Exception and waiver. 
(a)  Where in the judgment of the common council it would be inappropriate to strictly apply the provisions of this article because extraordinary or undue hardship would result, the council may allow holding tanks which would otherwise be prohibited by this section or waive or modify the requirements of this article to the extent deemed just and proper. 
(b)  Relief shall be granted under subsection (a) of this section only where it will not be detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare and is necessary to remedy a situation where extraordinary or undue hardship would otherwise occur. A unanimous vote of the entire membership of the common council is required to grant any such exception or waiver. No waiver shall be granted to any property within the utility which can be served by utility sewers. 
(c)  Any exception or waiver which is granted pursuant to this article shall be made in writing and shall state the reasons therefor and conditions of such exception or waiver. The common council may require an agreement as a condition of granting an exception or waiver. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(4)(D))  
Sec. 40-820. - Abrogation and greater restrictions. 
Nothing set forth in this article shall be construed as or is intended to be a waiver or release of any other agreements, rules, regulations, or permits previously adopted or issued pursuant to law. However, where this article imposes greater restrictions, the provisions of this article shall govern. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(4)(E))  
Sec. 40-821. - Connection to public sewer. 
At such time as public sewer becomes available to a property served by a private wastewater disposal system, a connection shall be made to the public sewer in compliance with this article and any septic tanks, holding tanks and other similar private effluent absorption systems shall be abandoned and filled in accordance with the provisions of state plumbing code. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(5))  
Sec. 40-822. - Operation and maintenance of private disposal facilities. 
The owner shall operate and maintain the private wastewater disposal facilities in a sanitary manner at all times at no expense to the city or the utility. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(6))  
Sec. 40-823. - Applicability of utility and county regulations. 
Nothing contained in this article shall interfere with any additional requirements that may be imposed by the county environmental health department, the state or the district. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.13(7))  
Secs. 40-82440-854. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 40-855. - Falsifying of information. 
No person shall knowingly make any false statement, representation, record, commission or report, plan, or other document filed with the utility, the board or the MMSD, or falsify, tamper with or knowingly render inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this article or MMSD Sewer Use Ordinance No. 84-001. Any person who violates this provision shall be subject to the penalties imposed under this division. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.14)  
Sec. 40-856. - Enforcement authority. 
This article shall be enforced by the board and the director. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.20(1))  
Sec. 40-857. - Penalties for violations. 
See forfeiture/bond/deposit schedule for penalties for any person who fails to comply with the provisions of this article or any rule, order or special order of the board or of the plumbing inspector. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.20(2))  
Sec. 40-858. - Violation constitutes a public nuisance. 
Any violation of the provisions of this article or any other rule, regulation or special order promulgated by the board shall constitute a public nuisance subject to injunction and abatement in accordance with the procedures of Wis. Stats. § 823.02. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.20(3))  
Sec. 40-859. - Restitution. 
Any person found in violation of this article or any other rule, regulation or special order shall pay to the utility such damages, losses or expenses as may be sustained by the utility as the result of the violation, together with such costs as may be collectible by law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.20(4))  
Sec. 40-860. - Remedies cumulative. 
The remedies provided by this division shall be in addition to all other remedies provided by this article or by any other law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.20(5))  
Sec. 40-861. - Duty of city attorney to prosecute. 
It shall be the duty of the city attorney, upon receipt of competent evidence from the director or plumbing inspector that a violation of this article constitutes a threat to the public health and safety, to commence an action in the county circuit court to abate such violation and nuisance. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.20(6))  
Sec. 40-862. - Notice of violation. 
Whenever, the director or plumbing inspector shall determine that a violation of any provision of this article or any rule or regulation promulgated by the board has occurred or is threatened, the director or plumbing inspector shall give written notice to the violator or other responsible person for stating the nature of the violation and the required remedy. Such notice may be in the form of a special order as provided in article III, division 7 of this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.20(7))  
Sec. 40-863. - Emergency suspension of service to industrial users. 
The board may suspend wastewater treatment service to an industrial user whenever it appears to the board that an actual or threatened industrial discharge presents or threatens an imminent or substantial danger to the health or welfare of persons; a substantial danger to the environment; an interference with the operation of the MMSD wastewater treatment plant; or violates any pretreatment limits imposed by this article. The board shall notify such industrial user in the event of a determination to suspend wastewater treatment service hereunder and such user shall cease all such discharges as soon as practicable. Actions under this subsection shall be implemented by issuance of special orders under article III, division 7 of this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 9.20(8))  
Secs. 40-86440-889. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - STORMWATER UTILITY  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 40-890. - Introduction. 
(a)  Authority. This article is adopted under the authority granted by Wis. Stats. chs. 62 and 66, including but not limited to Wis. Stats. §§ 62.04, 62.11, 62.16, 62.175, 62.18, 66.0621, 66.0809, 66.0811, and 66.0821. 
(b)  Findings and purpose. The city finds that the management of stormwater and other surface water discharges within and beyond the city is a matter that affects the health, safety, and welfare of the city, its citizens and businesses, and others in the surrounding area. Failure to effectively manage stormwater affects the sanitary sewer utility operations of the city by, among other things, increasing the likelihood of infiltration and inflow into the sanitary sewer system. Surface water runoff may cause erosion of lands, threaten residences and businesses with water damage, and create environmental damage to the streams and other water bodies within and adjacent to the city. The cost of operating and maintaining the city stormwater management system and financing the necessary repairs, replacements, improvements, and extensions thereof should, to the extent practicable, be allocated in relationship to the impact on and services received from the system. In order to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public, the city hereby exercises its authority to establish a stormwater utility and establish the rates for stormwater management services. 
(c)  Applicability. This article applies to all parcels within the incorporated boundaries of the city. 
(d)  Abrogation and greater restrictions. This article is not intended to repeal, abrogate, annul, impair, or interfere with any existing easement, covenants, deed restrictions, agreements, rules, regulations, ordinances or permits previously adopted or issued pursuant to law. However, wherever this article imposes greater restrictions, the provisions of this article shall govern. 
(e)  Interpretation. In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this article shall be liberally construed in favor of the city and shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other power granted by state law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.01) 
State Law reference Intent and construction of general charter law, Wis. Stats. § 62.04; common council, Wis. Stats. § 62.11; street grades and service pipes, Wis. Stats. § 62.16; sewer and water extensions in certain municipalities, Wis. Stats. § 62.175; municipal sewers, Wis. Stats. § 62.18; municipal revenue obligations, Wis. Stats. § 66.0621; municipal public utility charges, Wis. Stats. § 66.0809; municipal public utility revenues, Wis. Stats. § 66.0811; sewage and stormwater systems, Wis. Stats. § 66.0821.  
Sec. 40-891. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this article, the following definitions shall apply: 
Best management practice means a practice, technique, or measure that is an effective, practical means of preventing or reducing soil erosion or water pollution, or both, from runoff both during and after land development activities. These can include structural, vegetative or operational practices. 
Board means board of public works. 
Credit means a fee reduction that a stormwater utility customer may receive for implementing practices that reduce the city's cost for managing stormwater runoff. 
Customer means any person, owner or occupant, firm, partnership, corporation, municipality, cooperative organization, governmental agency, or political entity provided with stormwater management services by the city stormwater utility. 
Developed property means any property where: 
(1)  A certificate of occupancy has been issued, construction has been completed, or a final inspection performed if no such certificate was issued; or 
(2)  Construction is at least 50 percent complete and construction is halted for a period of three or more months. 
Director means the director of public works or his/her designee. 
Duplex means any residential space identified for habitation attached to only one other residential space or as classified by the city building code. 
Equivalent runoff unit (ERU) means the impervious area of a property relative to the statistical average impervious area of "single-family homes" within the city. One ERU is equal to 3,700 square feet of impervious surface. 
Grid reinforced pervious pavement system means a grid paving system designed to provide both load support and infiltration. 
Impervious area means a surface as measured on a horizontal plane which has been compacted or covered with a layer of material so that it is highly resistant to infiltration by rain water. It includes, but is not limited to, all areas covered by structures, roof extensions, patios, porches, driveways, loading docks, parking lots, sidewalks, and semi-impervious surfaces such as compacted clay and gravel which are used as driveways or parking lots. Vegetated or gravel driveways or parking lots which utilize a grid reinforced pervious pavement system approved by the director shall not be included as impervious area. 
Multifamily means any residential space identified for habitation attached to two or more residential spaces or as classified by the city building code. 
Nonresidential means a developed lot or parcel not exclusively residential, including, but not limited to, transient rentals (such as hotels and motels), commercial, industrial, institutional, and governmental properties and parking lots. 
On-site stormwater management system means a system designed to both mitigate flood impacts and provide adequate treatment of pollutants in stormwater runoff that has been constructed on the parcel for which the customer is billed. It includes, but is not limited to, rain gardens, cisterns, infiltration trenches, pretreatment systems, and wet basins. 
Parcel means the legal unit of land division as recorded by the county register of deeds. Multiple contiguous parcels with the same owner shall be considered to be one parcel for the purposes of calculating billing units. 
Public stormwater system means all public storm sewers, drainage conduits, drainage conveyances, roadside ditches, curb and gutter, and public greenways, and all improvements thereto which by this section are constituted as the property and responsibility of the stormwater utility, to be operated to, among other things, conserve water, control discharges necessitated by rainfall events, incorporate methods to collect, convey, store, absorb, inhibit, treat, use or reuse water to prevent or reduce flooding, environmental degradation and water pollution or otherwise affect the quality and quantity of discharge from such system. 
Rain garden means a shallow depression planted with deep rooted native prairie, wet prairie, or wetland vegetation, designed to infiltrate stormwater. 
Single-family means any residential space identified for habitation not attached to any other residential space or as classified by the city building code. 
Stormwater management services means the tasks required to control stormwater runoff to protect the health, safety, and welfare of the public, and comply with state and federal regulations. It includes, but is not limited to, street sweeping, erosion control, stormwater basin improvements and maintenance, culvert and storm sewer maintenance, stormwater testing, stormwater management planning and related public education. 
Stormwater utility means the utility established under this article for the purpose of managing stormwater and imposing charges for the recovery of costs connected with such stormwater management services. 
Undeveloped means a parcel with no impervious area. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.02; Ord. No. 2014-O-06, § 3, 3-25-2014)  
Sec. 40-892. - Creation and supervision. 
The city hereby establishes a stormwater utility. The operation of the stormwater utility shall be subject to the review of the city council. The director of public works shall be responsible for the maintenance and management of the stormwater utility under direction of the board of public works. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.03(1))  
Sec. 40-893. - Authority. 
The city, acting through the stormwater utility, may acquire, construct, lease, own, operate, maintain, extend, expand, replace, clean, dredge, repair, conduct, manage, and finance such facilities, operations, and activities, as are deemed by the city to be proper and reasonably necessary for a system of storm and surface water management. These facilities may include, but are not limited to, surface and underground drainage facilities, storm sewers, watercourses, ponds, ditches, and such other facilities relating to collection, runoff, and retention as will support a stormwater management system, whether such facilities are owned and operated directly by the city or are provided under statutory or contractual provisions and furnishings of which facilities create or impose a cost or charge upon the city for the services afforded by such facilities. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.03(2))  
Sec. 40-894. - Transfer of assets and outstanding debt. 
Effective January 1, 2002, the following assets and debts of the city are hereby transferred to the stormwater utility: 
(1)  The land rights and improvements of the city, or such rights determined to exist, for the following components of the public stormwater system: 
a.  Storm sewers, catchbasins, and culverts; 
b.  Retention and detention ponds, and related appurtenances; 
c.  Access structures; 
d.  Greenways. 
(2)  Debt service on all outstanding general obligation debt issued for stormwater management purposes. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.03(3))  
Sec. 40-895. - Enterprise account. 
The city shall separately account for the stormwater utility finances. The stormwater utility shall prepare an annual budget, which is to include all operation and maintenance costs, costs of borrowing, and other costs related to the operation of the stormwater utility. The budget is subject to approval by the city council. Any excess of revenues over expenditures in a year shall be retained in a segregated fund which shall be used for stormwater utility expenses in subsequent years. Stormwater utility fees collected shall be deposited in the stormwater enterprise fund and shall be used for no other purpose. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.03(4))  
Sec. 40-896. - Annual stormwater management/maintenance report. 
Each applicant who is granted a stormwater management permit, and who has signed a maintenance agreement for the best management practice on the property, shall submit to the director an annual report reviewing the condition of that practice and the maintenance performed during the past calendar year. This report shall be submitted and sealed by a professional engineer currently licensed in the State of Wisconsin or alternate certification approved by the city.
