Where a recorded maintenance agreement exists, the annual report should provide documentation that maintenance was performed in accordance with the annual inspection requirements of the recorded maintenance agreement on file with the city. If a stormwater management permit was grated but no maintenance agreement has been recorded, the property owner shall work with a professional engineer to develop a maintenance plan and submit the plan and subsequent annual review reports to the city. 
This report shall consist of the following: 
(1)  Documentation of the completion of the required annual maintenance, including copies of receipts from agents hired to perform the work and date the work was completed; 
(2)  Photos of the treatment device post completion of required maintenance. 
(Ord. No. 2014-O-06, § 3, 3-25-2014)  
Secs. 40-89740-923. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - CHARGES 
 
Sec. 40-924. - Service areas. 
In order to fairly and equitably reflect the variability in costs of providing stormwater management services to customers the city shall be organized into two service areas. A map, available in the office of the city clerk, shall be maintained by the stormwater utility showing the limits of the service areas. All lots and parcels within the city shall be classified into one of the following service areas: 
(1)  Urban service area. 
(2)  Rural service area. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(1))  
Sec. 40-925. - Customer classification. 
For the purpose of imposing the stormwater utility charges, all lots and parcels within the city shall be classified into one of the following customer classes: 
(1)  Residential, Single-Family Unit. 
(2)  Residential, Duplex Unit. 
(3)  Residential, Multifamily Unit. 
(4)  Nonresidential. 
(5)  Undeveloped. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(2))  
Sec. 40-926. - Measurement of impervious area. 
The director shall be responsible for determining the impervious area of a parcel based on the best available information, including but not limited to, data supplied by the city assessor, aerial photography, site or building plans submitted by the property owner, or actual on-site surveys. The director may require additional information as necessary to make the determination. The number of ERUs shall be updated by the director based on any additions to the impervious area of a parcel as approved through the building permit process. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(3))  
Sec. 40-927. - Intensity of development factor. 
For the purpose of imposing stormwater utility charges which reflect the customers relative impact on the public stormwater system, all parcels within the city shall be assigned an intensity of development factor. All single-family and duplex parcels shall be assigned an intensity of development factor of one. The intensity of development factor for nonresidential and multifamily parcels shall be determined from the percentage of impervious area of the parcel according to the following table: 
Multifamily and Nonresidential Percentage of Impervious Area 	Intensity of Development Factor 
09.9% 	0.6 
1054.9% 	1.0 
5569.9% 	1.7 
7089.9% 	2.9 
>90% 	4.8 
 
The percentage of impervious areas shall be determined as follows: Impervious Area of Parcel ÷ Total Area of Parcel. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(4))  
Sec. 40-928. - Rates. 
The fee structure as from time to time established by the board and listed in the city fee schedule may be modified by resolution. The fee shall be charged as follows: 
(1)  The city-wide rate shall be charged to all customers in both the urban service area and the rural service area. 
(2)  The urban service area base rate shall be charged only to customers in the urban service area. 
(3)  The urban service area intensity rate shall be charged only to customers in the urban service area. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(5))  
Sec. 40-929. - Fee calculation. 
The fees for each customer classification shall be determined as follows: 
(1)  Residential, single-family in urban service area: 
1 ERU x (City-Wide Rate + Urban Service Area Base Rate + Urban Service Area Intensity Rate) 
(2)  Residential, single-family in rural service area: 
1 ERU x (City-Wide Rate) 
(3)  Residential, duplex in urban service area: 
1 ERU per parcel x (City-Wide Rate + Urban Service Area Base Rate + Urban Service Area Intensity Rate), or 
½ ERU per unit x (City-Wide Rate + Urban Service Area Base Rate + Urban Service Area Intensity Rate) 
(4)  Residential, duplex in rural service area: 
1 ERU per parcel x (City-Wide Rate), or 
½ ERU per unit x (City-Wide Rate) 
(5)  Residential, multifamily in urban service area: 
[(Impervious Area of Parcel ÷ Impervious Area of 1 ERU) x (City-Wide Rate + Urban Service Area Base Rate)] + [(Impervious Area of Parcel ÷ Impervious Area of 1 ERU) x Intensity of Development Factor x Urban Service Area Intensity Rate] 
(6)  Residential, multifamily in rural service area: 
(Impervious Area of Parcel ÷ Impervious Area of 1 ERU) x (City-Wide Rate) 
(7)  Nonresidential in urban service area: 
[(Impervious Area of Parcel ÷ Impervious Area of 1 ERU) x (City-Wide Rate + Urban Service Area Base Rate)] + [(Impervious Area of Parcel ÷ Impervious Area of 1 ERU) x Intensity of Development Factor x Urban Service Area Intensity Rate] 
(8)  Nonresidential in rural service area: 
(Impervious Area of Parcel ÷ Impervious Area of 1 ERU) x (City-Wide Rate) 
(9)  Undeveloped parcels shall not be charged. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(6))  
Sec. 40-930. - Billing method. 
The charges established hereunder will be billed quarterly on the utility bill to customers in the urban service area. The charges established hereunder will be billed annually on the utility bill to customers in the rural service area. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(7)(A), (B))  
Sec. 40-931. - Penalties for nonpayment; collection of unpaid bills. 
A late payment charge of one percent per month compounded monthly will be added to bills not paid within 21 days after issuance or by due date, whichever is later. All unpaid bills for stormwater service which are due and outstanding as unpaid bills for stormwater service which are due and outstanding as of October 15 shall be collected by the city treasurer in the manner provided by Wis. Stats. § 66.0809(3). The additional penalty provided by Wis. Stats. § 66.0809(3) shall apply to any delinquent amount due. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(7)(C))  
Sec. 40-932. - Credits. 
(a)  Credits to a stormwater utility bill may be considered for multifamily and nonresidential customers who own and properly maintain on-site stormwater management systems that control the quantity of stormwater runoff and/or control the quality of runoff utilizing a design that has been approved by the director. 
(b)  A credit may be considered for single-family and duplex customers who utilize on-site stormwater management systems that control stormwater runoff quantity and/or quality utilizing a design that has been approved by the director. 
(c)  The board shall approve and the director shall keep on file a set of written criteria for issuing credits. These criteria will include eligible best management practices and their corresponding credit amounts. Criteria may be amended or updated from time to time, as seen fit by the director. 
(d)  The customer shall be responsible for submitting any requests for credit in writing to the director. The customer shall provide all supporting documentation, surveys, and engineering reports as may be necessary to document the justification for the request for credit. 
(e)  A credit may be granted in full, in part, or denied at the discretion of the director based on the supporting materials included with the credit application. The amount of any credit issued to a customer shall be proportional to the amount the on-site stormwater management system reduces the customer's impact on the public stormwater system. 
(f)  The city grants stormwater utility credits to the ratepayer of record - the person who pays the stormwater bill for the property. If approved, the credit will be deducted from the city stormwater bill for the utility account provided. 
(g)  The city may revoke the credit, require payment of previous credits, and impose civil penalties if any of the following conditions occur: 
(1)  The application for credit or accompanying documentation is inaccurate or falsified; 
(2)  The private stormwater management system is unsafe or illegal; 
(3)  The property does not comply with city building, plumbing or stormwater requirements; or 
(4)  The city is denied an opportunity to conduct a limited site inspection of the stormwater systems. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(8); Ord. No. 2014-O-06, § 3, 3-25-2014)  
Sec. 40-933. - Utility charge changes. 
Any future changes in the service areas, customer classifications, intensity of development factors, billing unit calculations, rates, or credits shall be made by resolution or ordinance of the city council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(9)(F))  
Secs. 40-93440-954. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - APPEAL AND REVIEW 
 
Sec. 40-955. - Adjustment to measured impervious and parcel areas. 
Property owners may submit to the director site and building surveys or other documentation which more accurately describes the impervious area or total area of a parcel. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(9)(A))  
Sec. 40-956. - Appeals to the director. 
Whenever the customer advises the director that all or part of any billing, including determination of impervious area, as rendered is in dispute, the director shall investigate the dispute promptly and completely, advise the customer of the results of the investigation, attempt to resolve the dispute, and provide the opportunity for the customer to enter into a deferred payment agreement when applicable in order to settle the dispute. 
(1)  The director may request the customer to provide survey, measurements, or other supporting material as may be necessary for completion of the review of the request in a timely manner. 
(2)  Within 30 days of the appeal, written notice of the decision of the director shall be sent to the appellant. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(9)(B))  
Sec. 40-957. - Appeals to the board of public works. 
Any person who objects to any action or decision of the director or his/her designee shall first appeal to the board for reconsideration. 
(1)  A written notice of appeal shall be filed with the city clerk within 30 days of the date of the action or decision appealed from. 
(2)  The notice of appeal shall state the action or decision of the director or his/her designee being appealed. 
(3)  The secretary of the board shall schedule the appeal for a formal hearing by the board at a meeting, open to the public, within 30 days of the filing of the notice of appeal. The secretary shall send notice of the time scheduled for the consideration of the appeal to the appellant at least ten days prior to the hearing. 
(4)  Within ten days of filing a written notice of appeal, the customer shall pay 50 percent of the bill in dispute or post a bond for that amount on or before the hearing date. Failure to pay the amount or post the bond will constitute a waiver of the right to a hearing. In no way does this relieve the customer from the obligation of paying charges which are not disputed. 
(5)  Within 30 days of the appeal hearing, the board, by majority vote, shall affirm, modify, or reverse the action or decision. Notice of the final decision of the board shall be sent to the appellant. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(9)(C))  
Sec. 40-958. - Appeals to the city council. 
Any person who objects to any final decision of the board after appeal to the board may appeal to the city council. 
(1)  A written notice of appeal shall be filed with the city clerk within 30 days of the date when notice of the final decision of the board is mailed to the customer. 
(2)  The notice of appeal shall state the action of the board appealed from, shall specify the reasons stated by the board for taking such action, and shall specify why the appellant believes said action was inappropriate. 
(3)  The city clerk shall file the notice of appeal with the common council and shall schedule the appeal for consideration by the common council at a meeting open to the public, within 45 days of the filing of the notice of appeal. The clerk shall send notice of the time scheduled for the consideration of the appeal to the appellant and the secretary of the board. 
(4)  Within 30 days of the appeal hearing, the city council, by majority vote, shall affirm, modify, or reverse the action of the board or shall refer the matter back to the board for further consideration. Notice of the decision of the common council shall be sent to the appellant and the board. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(9)(D))  
Sec. 40-959. - Granting of refund or adjustment. 
If a decision or determination of the director or board is reversed or modified the board shall grant a refund or adjustment to the aggrieved party, prorated and retroactive to the billing date on which an application for fee adjustment was filed with the secretary of the board. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 35.04(9)(E))  
Chapter 41 - SOLID WASTE AND RECYCLING[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Municipal authority to regulate offense industries, Wis. Stats. § 66.0415, littering, Wis. Stats. § 287.81; storage of junked vehicles, Wis. Stats. § 175.25; municipal authority for removal of rubbish, Wis. Stats. § 66.0405; water and sewage, Wis. Stats. § 281.01 et seq.; transportation and disposal of animal carcasses, Wis. Stats. § 95.72; prohibitions on land disposal and incineration, Wis. Stats. § 287.07; disposal of batteries, Wis. Stats. §§ 287.07, 287.185; solid waste facilities, Wis. Stats. § 289.01 et seq.; hazardous waste management, Wis. Stats. § 291.001 et seq.; open burning, Wis. Stats. § 289.51. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 41-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Approved construction and demolition reuse/recycling facility means a facility approved pursuant to guidelines set forth by the city whose practices cause the recycling or reuse of construction and demolition debris. 
Brush means any woody material over one-quarter inch but less than six inches in diameter from a tree, bush or plant, including, but not limited to, tree branches, small trees, prunings, and trimmings. 
Clean wood means wood that has not been rendered non-recyclable by the application or attachment of liquids or solids such as paint, stains, varnish and excessive metals as determined by approved recycling facility. 
Construction means the assembly of materials to form a new building 
Construction and demolition debris means materials resulting from the construction, remodeling, repair and demolition of utilities, structures, buildings, and roads, including but not limited to the following: bricks, concrete, and other masonry materials; soils; rocks; wood, including painted, treated, and coated wood and wood products; wall coverings; plaster; drywall; aluminum and vinyl siding; plumbing fixtures; non-asbestos insulation; roofing shingles and other roof coverings; reclaimed asphalt pavement; glass; plastics; electrical wiring, and piping or metals incidental to any of those materials, blocks, broken concrete, plaster, wire and wood lath, timbers and wood building products and other similar non-putrescible materials. This term does not include materials that are contaminated by lead, asbestos, or other hazardous materials in such a way as to render recycling illegal or impossible, or materials which the city engineer, from time to time, may indicate are no longer able to be readily reused/recycled in an economically viable manner. 
Contractor means any person, other than the property owner, who is responsible for the construction, demolition, or remodeling of a building, or any part thereof, and where such work requires the issuance of a building, plumbing, electrical, HVAC or demolition permit under the Fitchburg Municipal Code of Ordinances. Demolition means the demolition or dismantling of a building, but does not include the systematic dismantling of part of a building for alteration, maintenance, remodeling or repair. 
Electronic device means a device that requires electric current or electromagnetic fields to function and that contains a circuit board. 
Hauler means the person specifically authorized by the common council to collect refuse and recyclables, and dispose of the same. 
Household sharp medical waste means sharps and any type of product capable of puncturing or lacerating the skin that is designed or used to treat, diagnose, or prevent a disease or medical condition, including, but not limited to, scalpels and hypodermic needles. 
Major appliance means a residential or commercial air conditioner, boiler, clothes dryer, clothes washer, dehumidifier, dishwasher, humidifier, freezer, furnace, microwave oven, oven, pressure tank, refrigerator, stove or water heater. 
Materials recovery facility means a facility that is used for the storage, processing, and recovery of recyclables. 
Multiple-family dwelling means a building containing five or more residential units, including those which are occupied seasonally. 
Noncontaminated recyclable plastic bag shall mean any bag made of plastic film that does not remain soiled by organic or non-organic materials and is able to be recycled in the Dane County area. Plastic film types subject to this provision include Society of the Plastics Industry (SPI) code #2 - high density polyethylene (HDPE) and SPI code #4 - low density polyethylene (LDPE). 
Nonresidential facilities and properties. 
(1)  The term "nonresidential facilities and properties" means commercial, retail, industrial, institutional and governmental facilities and properties. 
(2)  The term "nonresidential facilities and properties" does not include multiple-family dwellings. 
Person includes any individual, corporation, limited liability company, partnership, association, local governmental unit, as defined in Wis. Stats. § 66.0131(1)(a), state agency or authority or federal agency. 
Recyclables means aluminum containers; corrugated paper or other containerboard; foam polystyrene packaging; glass containers; magazines; newspaper; office paper; rigid plastic containers, including those made of PETE, HDPE, PVC, LDPE, PP, PS and other resins or multiple resins; steel containers; waste tires; and bi-metal containers as described further below: 
(1)  Aluminum container means a container made of aluminum. 
(2)  Bi-metal container means a container for carbonated or malt beverages that is made primarily of a combination of steel and aluminum. 
(3)  Containerboard means corrugated paperboard used in the manufacture of shipping containers and related products. 
(4)  Magazines means magazines and other materials printed on similar paper. 
(5)  Mixed paper means miscellaneous household paper, including junk mail, school paper, brown paper bags, magazines, gift, shoe, and cereal boxes, and similar material. 
(6)  Newspaper means a newspaper and other materials printed on newsprint. 
(7)  Office paper. 
a.  The term "office paper" means high-grade printing and writing papers from offices in nonresidential facilities and properties. Printed white ledger and computer printout are examples of office paper generally accepted as high grade. 
b.  The term "office paper" does not include industrial process waste. 
(8)  Plastics means any of the following plastic products and containers labeled with recycling arrows and the Society of the Plastics Industry (SPI) code No. 1 through No. 7 described as follows: 
a.  SPI code No. 1 is PETE, polyethylene terephthalate. 
b.  SPI code No. 2 is HDPE, high-density polyethylene. 
c.  SPI code No. 3 is PVC, polyvinyl chloride. 
d.  SPI code No. 4 is LDPE, low-density polyethylene. 
e.  SPI code No. 5 is PP, polypropylene. 
f.  SPI code No. 6 is PS, polystyrene or EPS, expanded polystyrene; commonly called "block polystyrene" 
g.  SPI code No. 7 is other resins or multiple resins. 
Recycle means any process by which materials are diverted from final disposal as solid waste at a permitted landfill and instead are collected, separated and/or processed into raw materials for new, reused or reconstituted products, or for the recovery of materials for energy production processes. 
Refuse means any solid waste not included in the list under the term "recyclables" that is allowed to be disposed of in a sanitary landfill. 
Remodeling means any improvement or alteration made to buildings that do not involve the complete demolition and reconstruction of the building. 
Reuse means: 
(1)  The on-site use of reprocessed construction and demolition debris including bricks, concrete, other masonry materials, soil and rock used as fill, if such on-site use is authorized in writing by the city engineer; 
(2)  The off-site redistribution of a material which would otherwise be disposed of, for use in the same or similar manner; or 
(3)  The use of non-toxic wood as an alternative fuel source. 
Sanitary landfill means a facility that is designed and constructed to receive refuse. 
Sharps means medical equipment or clinical laboratory articles that may cause punctures or cuts. Sharps include, but are not limited to, contaminated, unused and disinfected items listed in Wis. Admin. Code § NR 526.05(1). 
Sharps container means a leakproof, rigid, puncture-resistant container that is taped closed or tightly lidded to prevent the loss of the sharps waste. 
Solid waste means any refuse, recyclables, or other salvageable materials that are removed from a property when deemed no longer needed. 
Waste oil means used motor oil, transmission fluid or other lubricating oil. 
Waste tire means a tire that is no longer suitable for its original purpose because of wear, damage or defect. 
Yard waste means leaves, grass clippings, yard and garden debris. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(10); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012; Ord. No. 2013-O-03, 3-26-2013)  
Secs. 41-241-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - REFUSE COLLECTION 
 
Sec. 41-21. - Schedule. 
(a)  The department of public works and the hauler shall establish the time of collection of refuse and recyclables, and the clerk shall publish the collection schedule at any time when the collection schedule is changed. 
(b)  All persons having refuse and recyclables shall place the same in containers or watertight bags as herein required at the required collection point not sooner than 24 hours prior to the regularly scheduled collection time and no person shall permit refuse or recyclables or containers thereof to accumulate or remain at the curbline longer than 12 hours thereafter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(18)(a); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-22. - Placing refuse and recyclables for collection. 
(a)  Except as otherwise specifically directed or authorized by the director of public works under section 41-21, containers for refuse and recyclables from all residential premises shall be placed at the curbline adjacent to the street designated in the published collection schedule. Containers of refuse and recyclables from all commercial, industrial, school or church premises shall be placed to the rear of the premises in a suitable enclosure. 
(b)  The director of public works may direct or authorize the placing of containers for refuse and recyclables in a manner different than that provided herein in order to facilitate a more reasonable mode of collection from particular premises. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(18)(b); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-23. - Preparation of refuse and recyclables for collection. 
All refuse and recyclables set out for collection shall be placed in the approved city refuse or recycling carts or watertight bags. No container or bag placed for collection shall exceed 32 gallons in capacity or 50 pounds in net weight, except for such containers as provided by the hauler. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(18)(c); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-24. - Household sharp medical waste disposal. 
Household sharp medical waste shall be disposed of in accordance with the requirements of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 526 and shall not be deposited in any other place or manner in the city than as provided in this section: 
(1)  Acceptable means of disposing of household sharp medical waste under this article include disposal in a sharps container or a heavy plastic container and delivery of the sealed container to a sharps collection station or other person authorized under Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 526 to accept such waste. 
(2)  Containers for household sharp medical waste or loose household sharp medical waste shall not be mixed with refuse or recyclables. 
(3)  The hauler shall refuse to pick up any refuse or recyclables containing household sharp medical waste. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(19); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-25. - Placement for collection. 
(a)  No person shall place any refuse or recyclables on any street, alley, sidewalk or other public or private property unless the same shall be placed in appropriate containers or bags for city collection at the times and in the manner as herein provided. 
(b)  No person shall place for collection any refuse or recyclables at the curbline or alley adjacent to any premises not owned or occupied by such person without permission. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(20); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-26. - Ownership of recyclable materials. 
(a)  All residential recyclable material collected and deposited, as provided in this section, shall be the property of the city. 
(b)  Recyclable materials collected privately for businesses and apartments are the property of those entities. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, except the hauler or licensed waste haulers collecting recyclable materials privately for businesses and apartments, to collect or remove any recyclable materials that have been placed at the curb or in a container adjacent to a home or nonresidential building for the purposes of collection for recycling. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(21); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-27. - Items not to be placed for pick up. 
No person shall dump, deposit or place at the curbline adjacent to any street or public alley for collection by the city or for any other purpose any of the following: 
(1)  Stone, concrete, rubber, earth or sod. 
(2)  Lead-acid batteries. 
(3)  Waste tires. 
(4)  Containers over 32 gallons or over 50 pounds, except containers provided by the hauler or licensed waste haulers collecting refuse or recyclables privately for businesses and apartments. 
(5)  Tree trunks or stumps. 
(6)  Garbage or rubbish in such a manner as will permit strewing by animals or vandals prior to collection. 
(7)  Hazardous and toxic wastes. 
(8)  Chemicals, paint or flammable liquids. 
(9)  Explosives. 
(10)  Construction debris. 
(11)  Carcasses. 
(12)  Infectious waste, sharps or medical waste, as defined in Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 500 and household sharp medical waste. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(22); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-28. - Permit required for deposit of waste from outside city. 
It shall be unlawful to deposit refuse or recyclables from outside the city within the city unless authorized by permit from the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(23); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-29. - Right of city to inspect. 
For the purpose of ascertaining compliance with the provisions of this article, the director of public works or his/her designee may inspect recyclable materials separated for recycling, postconsumer waste intended for disposal, recycling collection sites and facilities, collection vehicles, collection areas of multiple-family dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties, and any records relating to recycling activities, which shall be kept confidential when necessary to protect proprietary information. No person may refuse to allow access to the director of public works or his/her designee who requests access for purposes of inspection, and who presents appropriate credentials. No person may obstruct, hamper, or interfere with such an inspection. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(24); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-30. - Violations, citations and penalties. 
Any person who violates a provision of this article may be issued a citation by the director of public works or his/her designee to collect forfeitures. The issuance of a citation shall not preclude proceeding under any other ordinance or law relating to the same or any other matter. Proceeding under any other ordinance or law relating to the same or any other matter shall not preclude the issuance of a citation under this section. Penalties for violation of this article shall be as provided in section 1-21. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(24)(b); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Secs. 41-3141-48. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - RECYCLING STANDARDS AND PROCEDURE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 41-49. - Findings. 
(a)  The common council of the city hereby finds and determines that: 
(1)  There is an increasing necessity to conserve natural resources, and to reduce the need for landfill space for the citizens of the city; 
(2)  Newspapers, glass, motor oil, aluminum and tin cans, white goods, plastics, mixed paper, office paper, containerboard, brush, and yard waste comprise a substantial portion of residential and business solid waste material; 
(3)  In an age of shortage, conservation of recyclable materials is an important public concern; 
(4)  Newspapers, glass, aluminum and tin cans, oil, white goods, plastic, mixed paper, office paper, containerboard, yard material, waste tires and lead-acid batteries are items which can be separated from other solid waste materials and recycled without imposing an undue burden upon residents and businesses of the city; and 
(5)  Residents, taxpayers and businesses of the city benefit from the reduction of the volume of solid waste materials collected by the city and transported and deposited in available, authorized landfill sites. 
(b)  The common council further finds and ordains that: 
(1)  Improper disposal of household sharp medical waste, such as hypodermic needles, poses a significant health risk to workers in the waste disposal industry; 
(2)  Safe disposal of household sharp medical waste is possible through inexpensive, easily obtained means, without posing an undue burden on users of household sharp medical waste; and 
(3)  Removal of household sharp medical waste from the city's waste stream is beneficial to residents of the city as well as the city's waste hauler and users of the county landfill. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(1); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-50. - Purposes. 
The purposes of this article are to: 
(1)  Promote recycling, composting, and resource recovery through the administration of an effective recycling and waste reduction program, as provided in Wis. Stats. § 287.11 and Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 544; 
(2)  Promote safe disposal of household sharp medical waste consistent with the requirements of Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 526; and 
(3)  Promote sound and safe solid waste collection and disposal practices within the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(2); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-51. - Authority. 
This article is adopted as authorized under Wis. Stats. § 287.09 and under the city's municipal authority under Wis. Stats. ch. 66 and elsewhere to regulate solid waste within the city. All references to state statutes and administrative regulations in this article shall refer to such statutes and regulations as they may be hereafter amended and renumbered. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(3); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-52. - Interpretation. 
(a)  In their interpretation and application, the provisions of this article shall be held to be the minimum requirements and shall not be deemed a limitation or repeal of any other power granted by state law. 
(b)  Where any terms or requirements of this article may be inconsistent or conflicting, the more restrictive requirements or interpretation shall apply. 
(c)  Where a provision of this article is required by state statute or by a standard in Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 526 or 544 and where the article provision is unclear, the provision shall be interpreted in light of the state statute and the Wis. Admin. Code ch. NR 526 or 544 standards, in effect on the date of the adoption of the ordinance from which this article is derived, or in effect on the date of the most recent text amendment to the ordinance from which this article is derived. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(5); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-53. - Applicability. 
The requirements of this article apply to all persons within the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(7); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-54. - Administration. 
The provisions of this article shall be administered by the director of public works or his/her designee. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(8); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Secs. 41-5541-81. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PREPARATION AND COLLECTION 
 
Sec. 41-82. - Separation of recyclables. 
Occupants of single-family and two-unit to four-unit residences, multiple-family dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties shall separate the following materials from postconsumer waste: 
(1)  Lead-acid batteries; 
(2)  Major appliances; 
(3)  Electronic devices; 
(4)  Waste oil and oil filters; 
(5)  Yard waste; 
(6)  Brush; 
(7)  Waste tires; 
(8)  Noncontaminated recyclable plastic bags; 
(9)  Aluminum containers; 
(10)  Bi-metal containers; 
(11)  Corrugated paper or other containerboard; 
(12)  Foam polystyrene packaging; 
(13)  Glass containers; 
(14)  Magazines; 
(15)  Newspaper; 
(16)  Office paper; 
(17)  Mixed paper; 
(18)  Plastic containers; and 
(19)  Steel containers. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(11); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012; Ord. No. 2013-O-03, 3-26-2013)  
Sec. 41-83. - Care of separated recyclables. 
To the greatest extent practicable, the recyclable materials separated in accordance with section 41-82 shall be substantially clean and kept free of contaminants such as food or product residue, oil or grease, or other nonrecyclable materials, including, but not limited to, household hazardous waste, medical waste and agricultural chemical containers. Recyclables shall be stored in a manner which protects them from wind, rain and other inclement weather conditions until such time as the materials are set at the curb for collection. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(12); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-84. - Management of lead acid batteries, major appliances, waste oil, yard waste, brush, tires, and noncontaminated recyclable plastic bags. 
Occupants of single-family and two- to four-unit residences, multiple-family dwellings and non-residential facilities and properties shall manage lead acid batteries, major appliances, waste oil, yard waste, brush, tires, and noncontaminated recyclable plastic bags as follows: 
(1)  Lead-acid batteries shall be recycled at private businesses where purchased or at private recycling centers. 
(2)  Major appliances shall be recycled at private businesses where purchased or at private recycling centers. The hauler shall also provide collection service for major appliances for a separate charge which shall be paid by the party disposing of said appliance. 
(3)  Electronic devices shall be recycled at private businesses where purchased or at private recycling centers. The hauler shall also provide collection service for electronic devices for a separate charge which shall be paid by the party disposing of said electronic device. 
(4)  Waste oil and oil filters shall be recycled at private businesses where purchased, at private or public recycling centers, or through the county. 
(5)  Yard waste shall be composted or land applied through local public or private recycling centers. Residents are encouraged to compost yard waste on site. 
(6)  Brush shall be recycled through local public or private recycling collection methods. Residents are encouraged to chip brush on site and use the chips as mulch. 
(7)  Waste tires shall be recycled at private businesses where purchased or at private recycling centers. The hauler shall also provide collection service for waste tires for a separate charge which shall be paid by the party disposing of waste tires. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(13); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012; Ord. No. 2013-O-03, 3-26-2013)  
Sec. 41-85. - Preparation and collection of recyclables. 
Except as otherwise directed by the director of public works, occupants of single-family and two-unit to four-unit residences shall do the following for the preparation and collection of the separated materials specified in section 41-82: 
(1)  Aluminum, bi-metal, glass, plastic, and steel containers shall be rinsed free of any substantial product residue, and placed loosely in the approved city recycling containers or taken to an approved local recycling drop-off site. 
(2)  Corrugated paper or other containerboard shall be placed within the approved city recycling cart or taken to an approved local recycling drop-off site. Corrugated paper and other containerboard shall be kept free from contamination by oil, grease, and food. 
(3)  Foam polystyrene packaging shall be taken to an approved local recycling drop-off site. 
(4)  Mixed paper shall be placed within the approved city recycling cart or taken to an approved local recycling drop-off site. 
(5)  Newspaper shall be placed within the approved city recycling cart or taken to an approved local recycling drop-off site. Newspaper shall not be tied. 
(6)  Office paper shall be placed within the approved city recycling cart or taken to an approved local recycling drop-off site. 
(7)  Noncontaminated recyclable plastic bags shall be separated and recycled in accordance with the rules, procedures and schedules specified by the public works director, or such items may be disposed of in any other lawful manner, including through merchant-provided drop off locations. No person shall mix or permit the mixing of noncontaminated recyclable plastic bags with refuse or other recyclables. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(14); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012; Ord. No. 2013-O-03, 3-26-2013)  
Sec. 41-86. - Responsibilities of owners or designated agents of multiple-family dwellings. 
(a)  Owners or designated agents of multiple-family dwellings shall do all of the following to recycle the materials specified in section 41-82: 
(1)  Provide adequate, separate containers for the recyclable materials. 
(2)  Notify tenants in writing at the time of renting or leasing the dwelling and at least semiannually thereafter about the established recycling program, including: 
a.  Reasons to reduce and recycle solid waste; 
b.  Which materials are collected; 
c.  How to prepare the materials in order to meet the processing requirements; 
d.  Collection methods or sites; 
e.  Locations and hours of operation; and 
f.  A contact person or company, including a name, address and telephone number. 
(3)  Provide for collection of the materials separated from the solid waste by the tenants and the delivery of these materials to a recycling facility. 
(4)  Recyclables shall not be placed in containers with solid waste. 
(b)  Provide space for recycling for public buildings. 
(1)  Any new residential building with five units or more in the city must make space considerations and accommodations for recycling within the building in each apartment, on every floor or in a central area within the building, and on the grounds accessible to collection vehicles. The space required by this section is that space which is sufficient to allow for items mandated for recycling in section 41-82. 
(2)  A person in the city owning or occupying a new building or a building that is remodeled or expanded by 50 percent or more in floor area, shall provide a designated area for the separation, temporary storage and collection of refuse and recyclables either within or adjacent to the building. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(15); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-87. - Responsibilities of owners or designated agents of nonresidential facilities and properties. 
(a)  Owners or designated agents of nonresidential facilities and properties shall do all of the following to recycle the materials specified in section 41-82: 
(1)  Provide adequate, separate containers for the recyclable materials. 
(2)  Notify in writing, at least semiannually, all users, tenants and occupants of the properties about the established recycling program. 
(3)  Provide for the collection of the materials separated from the solid waste by the users, tenants and occupants and the delivery of the materials to a recycling facility. 
(4)  Notify users, tenants and occupants of: 
a.  Reasons to reduce and recycle solid waste; 
b.  Which materials are collected; 
c.  How to prepare the materials in order to meet the processing requirements; 
d.  Collection methods or sites; 
e.  Locations and hours of operation; and 
f.  A contact person or company, including a name, address and telephone number. 
(5)  Recyclables shall not be placed in containers with refuse. 
(6)  Provide space for recycling for public buildings. 
(b)  A person in the city owning or occupying a new building or a building that is remodeled or expanded by 50 percent or more in floor area, shall provide a designated area for the separation, temporary storage and collection of refuse and recyclables either within or adjacent to the building. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(16); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-88. - Prohibitions on disposal of recyclable materials separated for recycling. 
No person may dispose of in a solid waste disposal facility any of the materials specified in section 41-82 which have been separated for recycling, except waste tires may be burned for recovery of energy in a solid waste treatment facility. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.06(17); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-89. - Right of city to inspect. 
For the purpose of ascertaining compliance with the provisions of this article, the director of public works or his/her designee may inspect recyclable materials separated for recycling, postconsumer waste intended for disposal, recycling collection sites and facilities, collection vehicles, collection areas of multiple-family dwellings and nonresidential facilities and properties, and any records relating to recycling activities, which shall be kept confidential when necessary to protect proprietary information. No person may refuse to allow access to the director of public works or his/her designee who requests access for purposes of inspection, and who presents appropriate credentials. No person may obstruct, hamper, or interfere with such an inspection. 
(Ord. No. 2012-O-18, § 1, 12-11-2012)  
Sec. 41-90. - Violations, citations and penalties. 
Any person who violates a provision of this article may be issued a citation by the director of public works or his/her designee to collect forfeitures. The issuance of a citation shall not preclude proceeding under any other ordinance or law relating to the same or any other matter. Proceeding under any other ordinance or law relating to the same or any other matter shall not preclude the issuance of a citation under this section. Penalties for violation of this article shall be as provided in section 1-21. 
(Ord. No. 2012-O-18, § 1, 12-11-2012)  
Secs. 41-9141-108. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - UNLAWFUL WASTE DISPOSAL  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 41-10941-129. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - DUMPING 
 
Sec. 41-130. - Property owners not to permit dumping without city approval. 
No person owning, controlling or occupying real estate within the city shall permit or allow the dumping of garbage, ashes, rubbish, miscellaneous wastes, or other substances upon said real estate without first having been granted a permit therefore by the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(1)(a); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-131. - Illegal dumping prohibited. 
No person shall dump, dispose, deposit or store refuse or recyclables in the city outside of a licensed sanitary landfill facility on either private or public lands, except as provided in sections 41-82 and 70-88. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(1)(b); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-132. - Owner's consent required. 
No person shall dump or deposit any garbage, ashes, rubbish, miscellaneous wastes, manure or other substances upon private property unless the written consent of the owner or his/her authorized agent shall first be obtained and filed with the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(1)(c); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-133. - Disposal of construction related debris. 
No person shall dispose of rocks, trees, brush, stumps, waste building material or other debris from land development, building construction, street grading, installation of underground utilities, upon the surface of the land in the city unless approved by the owner and city building inspector or city engineer. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(1)(d); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-134. - Property owners not to permit disposal of construction related debris. 
No landowner shall permit the accumulation of rocks, trees, brush, stumps, waste building material or other debris from land development, building construction, street grading, installation of underground utilities, upon the surface of the land in the city for a period of more than 15 days, unless such accumulation is related to a construction activity approved for the site or area by the city building inspector or city engineer. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(1)(e); Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 1, 5-22-2012)  
Secs. 41-13541-150. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION REUSE/RECYCLING 
 
Sec. 41-151. - Applicability and reuse/recycling requirements for construction and demolition projects. 
(a)  Recycling and reuse requirement for certain multi-family dwellings and commercial buildings. 
(1)  All projects subject to this subsection shall be required to recycle or reuse construction or demolition debris produced on-site as part of construction, demolition or moving permit activities by meeting the following requirements: 
a.  The owner or contractor on a project that is issued a permit with an application date on or after the effective date of this section shall cause to be recycled or reused at least 70 percent of the construction and demolition debris produced on-site, as measured by weight or volume. 
(2)  The following types of projects are subject to this subsection: 
a.  The construction or demolition of a multi-family dwelling constructed using concrete and steel supports. 
b.  The construction or demolition of a commercial building where the total square footage of the space involved is over 1,000 square feet. 
c.  Any moving of building projects, which require a permit. 
(b)  Recycling and reusing requirements for certain multi-family dwellings, residential buildings and remodeling projects. 
(1)  The owner or contractor on a project subject to this subsection shall cause to be recycled or reused all of the following construction or demolition debris produced on-site as part of construction, demolition, or remodeling permit activities: 
a.  Wood that has not been rendered no recyclable by the application or attachment of paint, stains, varnish, or other liquids or solids; 
b.  Non-toxic metals; 
c.  Clean drywall scrap materials; 
d.  Corrugated cardboard; and 
e.  Shingles. 
(2)  The following types of projects are subject to this subsection: 
a.  The construction or demolition of multi-family dwellings using wood frame construction. 
b.  The construction or demolition of a single-family, two-family or three-family dwelling. 
c.  Except for roofing projects, the remodeling of a residential or commercial building where the total value of the project is $20,000.00 or greater. 
d.  Any roofing project that includes the tear off of the roofing materials shall reuse or recycle 100 percent of asphalt shingles and clean wood. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 2, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-152. - Construction and demolition reuse/recycling plan. 
(a)  Construction and demolition reuse/recycling plan. Each person who applies for a construction and demolition reuse/recycling permit shall submit a construction and demolition reuse/recycling plan to the city engineer or his/her designee. The construction and demolition reuse/recycling plan shall include an estimate of total construction or demolition debris that will be created on-site and describe how much will be reused/recycled (by weight or volume). No building permit shall be issued unless the applicant submits the construction and demolition reuse/recycling plan to the city engineer. 
(b)  Reserved. 
(c)  The city maintains the right to suspend requirements of section 41-151 if the market for recyclable materials changes and makes compliance unattainable, as determined by the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 2, 5-22-2012; Ord. No. 2019-O-19 , §§ 1, 2, 8-27-2019)  
Sec. 41-153. - Certification. 
(a)  Within 60 days of completion of a project, certification of compliance shall be made by the owner or contractor in the form and manner prescribed by the city engineer. Report shall include: 
(1)  A list of the construction and demolition debris materials that were reused or recycled; 
(2)  Information on where the construction and demolition debris were recycled or how reused; 
(3)  A statement from the owner or contractor that the documentation supporting compliance with this section exists and will be maintained for two years from submission of the report; 
(4)  A statement from the owner or contractor certifying that the information in the report is truthful and accurate. 
(b)  It shall be sufficient proof of compliance if the owner or contractor maintains records of the following for two years from submission of the report; and provides copies upon request: 
(1)  Weight tickets from the owner or contractor that show the amount of debris from the project taken to an approved recycling facility; and 
(2)  Weight tickets from the owner or contractor that show the amount of debris from the project taken to a landfill; or 
(3)  Proof of achievement of applicable green building certification credit resulting in the same limits for construction and demolition reuse/recycling of section 41-152 (reuse/recycling requirement): 
a.  LEED (Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design) for New Construction MR Credit 2; 
b.  LEED for Homes MR Credit 3.1 - 1.5 points; 
c.  GBH (Green Built Home); or 
d.  Other green building certification acceptable to the city engineer. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 2, 5-22-2012)  
Secs. 41-154, 41-155. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 2019-O-19 , §§ 3, 4, adopted August 27, 2019, repealed §§ 41-154 and 41-155. Former §§ 41-154 and 41-155 pertained to refunds and use of construction and demolition reuse/recycling deposits and derived from Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 2, adopted May 22, 2012.  
Sec. 41-156. - Violations. 
Each violation to the provisions of this article shall be subject to the general penalty set forth in subsection 1-21(b). Each day in violation of the provisions of this article shall be considered a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 2, 5-22-2012)  
Sec. 41-157. - Effective date. 
Chapter 41 as recreated by Ord. No. 2013-O-03 shall take effect on the day after publication of Ord. No. 2013-O-03. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-16, § 2, 5-22-2012; Ord. No. 2013-O-03, 3-26-2013)  
Chapter 42 - EMERGENCY MANAGEMENT AND SERVICES 
(RESERVED)  
Chapter 44 - FIRE PREVENTION AND PROTECTION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) ---

Stats. § 167.10; regulation of hazardous substances, Wis. Stats. § 167.11; negligent handling of burning material, Wis. Stats. § 941.10; unsafe burning of buildings, Wis. Stats. § 941.11; interfering with firefighting, Wis. Stats. § 941.12; false fire alarms, Wis. Stats. § 941.13; town fire wardens, Wis. Stats. § 26.13; authority of local fire chief and inspector regarding multifamily dwellings, Wis. Stats. § 101.976; mutual aid agreements, Wis. Stats. § 175.46; firefighter pay, Wis. ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 44-144-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - FIRE DEPARTMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 44-19. - Established; personnel. 
The city fire department consists of a fire chief, deputy chief-fire prevention and such number of firefighters as shall from time to time be provided for by the common council and appointed by the fire chief with the approval of the board of police and fire commissioners. The department is organized under Wis. Stats. § 62.13, operates pursuant to the laws of the state and ordinances of the city, under the direct supervision of the fire chief, who is responsible for the program of fire defense and prevention for the citizens and property within the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.01)  
Sec. 44-20. - Fire chief. 
(a)  Head of department. The fire department shall be under the direction of the fire chief, subject to the lawful written orders of the mayor and city council. 
(b)  Appointment and removal. The chief of the fire department shall be appointed by the city board of police and fire commissioners for an indefinite term, subject to suspension or removal by the board for cause under Wis. Stats. § 62.13(5) and the rules and regulations of the board. The chief shall be selected on the basis of demonstrated qualifications in fire prevention, control and management. 
(c)  Duties and responsibilities. The chief shall have the following duties and responsibilities: 
(1)  To appoint, assign and promote individuals to firefighter and other subordinate positions within the department in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 62.13, the personnel policies of the city, the rules and regulations of the board and the policies and procedures of the department. Appointments of firefighters shall be made by promotion when this can be done to advantage, otherwise from the eligible list prepared by the board. Firefighter appointments are subject to approval by the board. 
(2)  To administer the city fire department under the supervision of the mayor and city council. It will be the responsibility of the mayor to ensure that the chief carries out proper planning, coordination and control within the fire department as well with other departments of the city in accordance with law and policies established by the city council. 
(3)  To administer and enforce all laws relating to fire prevention and control, including the provisions of this article. 
(4)  To develop organizational structure, policies, and procedures to achieve the goals of the department. 
(5)  To develop policies to provide for operation of the department at the highest levels of safety and health for all members. The prevention of accidents, injuries, and occupational illnesses shall be primary considerations at all times. This concern for safety and health applies to all members of the department and to any other persons who may be involved in department activities. 
(6)  To develop and administer the annual department budget in accordance with chapter 2, finance. 
(7)  To provide the mayor and common council with projections of needs and goals spanning five, ten, and 20 years. These reports should be adjusted as frequently as changing conditions dictate and shall include predicted annual budget requests for personnel, equipment and capital expenditures. 
(8)  To identify the need for, negotiate and draft mutual and/or automatic aid agreements with agencies of other communities. Such agreements shall be submitted to the mayor and common council for review, consideration and approval. 
(9)  To maintain liaison with other city departments on matters of importance to the goals of the fire department. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.03)  
Sec. 44-21. - Firefighters. 
(a)  Selection. Firefighters shall be selected by the chief with the approval of the board in accordance with subsection (c)(1) of this section. 
(b)  Compensation. Persons receiving permanent appointments as firefighters shall receive such compensation as from time to time established by the city council. Such compensation may be based upon participation in department activities including, fire response and training. Except for failure to participate, compensation rates shall not be reduced without previous recommendation of the board. 
(c)  Layoffs, dismissals and reemployment. 
(1)  When it becomes necessary, because of need for economy, lack of work or funds, or for other just causes, to reduce the number of subordinates, the emergency, special, temporary, parttime or provisional subordinates, if any, shall be dismissed first, and thereafter subordinates shall be dismissed in the order of the shortest length of service in the department. 
(2)  When it becomes necessary for reasons stated in subsection (c)(1) of this section to reduce the number of subordinates in the higher positions or offices, or to abolish any higher positions or offices in the department, the subordinates affected thereby shall be placed in a position or office in the department less responsible according to his/her efficiency and length of service in the department. 
(3)  The name of a subordinate dismissed for any cause set forth in this section shall be left on an eligible reemployment list for a period of two years after date of dismissal. If any vacancy occurs, or if the number of subordinates is increased, in the department, such vacancy or new positions shall be filled by persons on such list in inverse order of dismissal. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.04)  
Secs. 44-2244-45. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FIRE PREVENTION BUREAU 
 
Sec. 44-46. - Created; administration. 
(a)  Created. To assist in the performance of the responsibilities and duties placed on the fire chief, a bureau of fire prevention is hereby created within the city fire department. 
(b)  Administration. The fire prevention bureau shall operate under the supervision of the chief. The chief shall designate a member of the department as deputy chief-fire prevention. The deputy chief-fire prevention shall be responsible for direct administration and enforcement of the city fire prevention code. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.05(1), (2))  
Sec. 44-47. - Appointment of deputy chief-fire prevention, fire inspectors. 
The deputy chief-fire prevention shall be designated on the basis of the candidate's demonstrated qualifications in fire prevention, investigation and public fire safety education. The fire chief may also designate such number of inspectors as shall be authorized by the mayor and city council. Inspectors shall be selected on the basis of demonstrated qualifications in fire prevention investigation and public fire safety education. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.05(3))  
Sec. 44-48. - Duties. 
The members of the bureau of fire prevention shall have the following duties and powers: 
(1)  To enforce all laws and ordinances of the city relating to prevention of fires, storage, sale and use of combustible, flammable or explosive materials, installation and maintenance of automatic suppression fire alarm and other fire extinguishing equipment; and means and adequacy of exit in case of fire from factories, schools, hotels, roominghouses, multiple-family dwellings, hospitals, churches, halls, theaters, amphitheaters, and all other places in which numbers of persons work, live or congregate, from time to time for any purpose. 
(2)  To investigate the origin, cause and circumstances of every fire occurring within the city. 
(3)  To maintain fire cause and loss records. 
(4)  Such other duties as may be imposed by law or required by the chief or mayor. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.05(4))  
Sec. 44-49. - Fire records. 
The deputy chief-fire prevention shall keep a record of all fires within the city and all facts concerning the same. Such record shall be made monthly from reports completed under the provisions of this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.05(5))  
Sec. 44-50. - Annual report. 
The deputy chief-fire prevention shall make an annual report to the mayor of activities of the bureau of fire prevention and any recommended amendments to the city fire prevention code and shall submit this report to the chief for review and approval before filing with the mayor. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.05(6))  
Sec. 44-51. - Fire investigations administered. 
The fire prevention bureau shall investigate the origin, cause, and circumstances of every fire occurring in the city. Such investigation shall begin immediately upon the occurrence of a fire. The deputy chief-fire prevention shall take steps to obtain physical evidence, notify the proper law enforcement authorities and cooperate with other agencies as required. Every fire shall be reported in writing to the fire prevention bureau within two days of its occurrence. Such report shall be submitted as prescribed by the deputy chief-fire prevention, and shall contain a statement of all facts relating to the origin, cause, and circumstances of such fire, the extent of the damage and such other information as may be required. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.05(7))  
Sec. 44-52. - Permit inspections. 
The fire prevention bureau shall inspect and approve all locations and objects for any use or structure requiring a permit under article III of this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.05(8))  
Sec. 44-53. - Periodic fire inspections. 
The fire prevention bureau shall inspect all premises classified as public occupancies on a periodic basis to determine compliance with the laws and ordinances applicable to fire prevention. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.05(9))  
Sec. 44-54. - Corrective orders. 
Whenever any fire inspector finds any of the following conditions, the inspector shall order removal of the dangerous matter, obstruction or remedy of the condition: 
(1)  Combustible or explosive matter; 
(2)  Dangerous accumulations of rubbish or flammable material; 
(3)  Obstructed means of exit; 
(4)  Obstructions likely to interfere with operations of the department or egress of occupants in case of fire; 
a corrective order shall be served upon the owner and occupant of the premises by delivering a copy to the occupant personally or leaving it with any person of suitable age and discretion in charge of the premises or, in case no such person is found upon the premises by affixing a copy thereof in a conspicuous place on or near the entrance of said premises. The owner of the premises shall be served personally or by delivering a copy of the order to a person of suitable age and discretion at the owner's residence or place of business or, if such owner is absent from the city, by mailing a copy by certified mail to the owner's last known post office address. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.05(10))  
Sec. 44-55. - Appeals. 
Any person aggrieved by any of the following decisions of the fire chief or deputy chief-fire prevention may appeal to the zoning board of appeals within 30 days after the decision and shall be entitled to review in accordance with the rules of procedure for the board of appeals except those rules specifically related to zoning appeals: 
(1)  Rejection of an application for any required permit, certificate or approval; 
(2)  Revocation of any permit or certificate previously issued; 
(3)  Conditioning issuance of any required permit certificate or approval upon compliance with any requirements other than those established by this chapter or by any other applicable state, federal, county or city law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.05(11))  
Secs. 44-5644-83. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - AUTHORITY OF FIRE OFFICIALS 
 
Sec. 44-84. - Control at scene. 
The fire chief or department official conducting operations in connection with the extinguishment and control of any fire, explosion or other emergency shall have full authority to direct all operations of fire extinguishment or control and to take the necessary precautions to save life, protect property and prevent further injury or damage as provided in Wis. Stats. § 213.095. In the pursuit of such operations, including the investigation of the cause of such emergency, the chief or department official may control or prohibit the approach to the scene of such emergency by any person. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.06(1))  
Sec. 44-85. - Access barriers at scene of emergency. 
The chief or official in charge of an emergency scene shall have the authority to establish fire line barriers to control access in the vicinity of such emergency, and to secure any street, alley or fire lane. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.06(2))  
Sec. 44-86. - Obstruction of operations prohibited. 
No person shall obstruct the operations of the department in connection with extinguishing any fire or responding to other emergencies. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.07(1))  
Sec. 44-87. - Disobedience of fire officials. 
No person shall disobey any lawful command of the fire official in charge of the emergency, or any lawful order of a police officer assisting the fire department at any fire or other emergency. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.07(2))  
Sec. 44-88. - Crossing or removing fire line barriers. 
No unauthorized person shall cross a fire line barrier or remove, unlock, destroy or tamper with any barricade or sign which has been lawfully installed by the fire department or by its order or is under its control. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.07(3))  
Secs. 44-8944-119. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - PERMITS 
 
Sec. 44-120. - Required. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section all permits required under this chapter or the codes adopted herein shall be required under this Code and shall be obtained from the fire chief or his/her designee. 
(b)  Building plan check. The owner or applicant for a building permit for a multiple dwelling, commercial, manufacturing or public assembly unit shall pay a plan check to offset actual costs incurred by the fire department for inspection and review of plans and on-site inspection during the planning and construction period of the development or construction. 
(c)  Exceptions. The following permits shall not be required under this Code: 
(1)  Combustible dust-producing operations. 
(2)  Compressed and liquefied gases. 
(3)  Flammable and combustible liquids. 
(4)  Flammable finishing. 
(5)  Pyroxylin plastics. 
(6)  Welding cutting and other hot work. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.29(1))  
Sec. 44-121. - Fees. 
Fees as set forth in the annual budget fee schedule shall be paid to the city treasurer for the permits certificates, approvals and other functions performed under this Code with an application for permit approval, certificate and any required inspection. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.29(2))  
Secs. 44-12244-140. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - FIRE PROTECTION CHARGES 
 
Sec. 44-141. - Scope. 
Due to the continuing increase in the cost of providing adequate fire protection to the city, a fire protection fund is to be established to assist in the provision of this service. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.30(1))  
Sec. 44-142. - Impositions. 
The city shall impose a fee for service rendered by the fire department which imposes a financial burden above the level of service established by the common council in the following circumstances: 
(1)  Standby charges. The fire chief may charge a standby fee for costs incurred by the city that are necessitated by a need for special fire protection and prevention devices provided for special functions general public safety at emergency and nonemergency situations. The fee will be based on the schedule as adopted pursuant to section 44-143. 
(2)  User fee. The fire chief may charge a fee based on actual cost incurred by the city for any service performed by the fire department where the service requires a recall of additional fire personnel or the use of specialized equipment or resources to terminate an emergency. 
(3)  State and federal mandated duties. The fire chief may bill the offices or agencies of the state or the United States actual costs incurred for the performance of duties mandated by them. This charge will be based on the schedule as adopted pursuant to section 44-143. 
(4)  Fire cause determination fee. The fire chief may charge a fee for all costs incurred by the fire department for providing service as the result of actions that are determined to be a violation of the fire prevention code. This fee will be based on the schedule as adopted pursuant to section 44-143 and shall be payable by the person. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.30(2))  
Sec. 44-143. - Fee schedule. 
The fees as provided under section 44-142 shall be based upon actual costs of services rendered. The fire chief shall annually present to the common council for approval, a fee schedule based on the approved fire department budget. The fee schedule will encompass manpower, equipment, material and maintenance costs to ensure proper charges for services rendered. Said schedule shall be as set forth in the annual budget fee schedule. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.30(3))  
Sec. 44-144. - Charges binding on successors. 
The fees in section 44-142 shall be binding upon all persons rendered such services as well as their successors in interest, assigns, estates and heirs. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.30(4))  
Sec. 44-145. - Disposition of funds. 
All monies received under the provisions of this division shall be placed in an account set up for the express purpose of funding expenses necessary to furnish fire protection to the citizens of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.30(5))  
Sec. 44-146. - Fire facilities impact fee. 
(a)  Authority. 
(1)  This section is authorized under Wis. Stats. § 66.0617. 
(2)  The provisions of this section shall not be construed to limit the power of the city to adopt this section pursuant to any other source of local authority, nor to utilize any other methods or powers otherwise available for accomplishing the purposes set forth in subsection (c) of this section, either in substitution of or in conjunction with this section. 
(b)  Definitions. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this section, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this subsection, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Capital cost means the capital costs to construct, expand, upgrade or improve public facilities, including the cost of land, and including legal, engineering and design and permit costs to construct, expand, upgrade or improve public facilities, except that not more than ten percent of capital costs may consist of legal, engineering and design costs unless the city can demonstrate that its legal, engineering and design costs which relate directly to the public improvement for which the impact fees were imposed exceed ten percent of costs. The term "capital costs" does not include other non-capital costs to construct, expand, upgrade or improve public facilities, the costs of equipment to construct, expand, upgrade or improve public facilities or the costs for vehicles. 
Developer means a person that constructs or creates a land development. 
Impact fees means cash fees imposed upon a developer under this section. 
Land development means the construction or modification of improvements to real property that creates additional residential dwelling units within the city, or that results in nonresidential uses that create a need for new, expanded or improved fire protection facilities within the city. 
(c)  Purpose. The purpose of this section is to promote the public health, safety and general welfare of the community and to facilitate the adequate provision for fire protection by imposing impact fees upon those developing or redeveloping their property within the city, to pay for the necessary capital costs for the facilities needed. 
(d)  Imposition of fees. 
(1)  Impact fees are hereby imposed on all land development within the city. 
(2)  For all development, impact fees shall be due in full upon the issuance of a building permit. 
(3)  The effective date of a building permit is the date on which all impact fees imposed under this section are paid in full and unless all impact fees are paid in full upon issuance as required by Wis. Stats. § 66.0617(6)(g); said building permit shall expire 15 days after issuance. 
(e)  Payment and collection of fees; use of fund. 
(1)  Any developer creating or constructing land development within the city shall pay a fee to the city to provide for the capital costs of fire protection facilities that are necessary to accommodate land development. 
(2)  The fire facilities impact fee shall be established according to the following tables: 
Projected Five Year Rate Increase 
Fire Protection Impact Fee 
Year 	Single-Family Residential (per d.u.) 	Multifamily Residential (per d.u.) 	Studio and One-Bedroom Apartment 	Commercial/Industrial (per SF) 	Industrial/Business Park Use 
2009 (1) 	$500 	$500 	$500 	$0.100 	$0.050 
2010 	$524 	$493 	$462 	$0.126 	$0.069 
2011 	$549 	$487 	$424 	$0.151 	$0.087 
2012 	$573 	$480 	$387 	$0.177 	$0.106 
2013 	$597 	$473 	$349 	$0.203 	$0.124 
2014 (2) 	$622 	$466 	$311 	$0.228 	$0.143 
Notes: 
(1) Existing Fire Protection Impact Fee $500.00 per dwelling unit l; $500.00 per commercial unit or per 5,000 sq. ft. whichever is greater; $500.00 per manufacturing unit or 4,000 sq. ft. whichever is greater; and $500.00 per public assembly unit or 2,500 sq. ft. whichever is greater. 
(2) Calculated fire impact fee calculated in 2010. Taken from Tables 13 and 14. 
 
(3)  Such fees collected by the city shall be placed in a special fund which shall be separate from the general fund of the city, and the special fund and all interest earned thereon shall be used exclusively for the particular capital costs for which the fee was imposed. 
(4)  Impact fees imposed and collected by the city under this section shall be used within the time limits defined by Wis. Stats. § 66.0617(9) by the city to pay the capital costs of the public facilities for which they were imposed, or, in the alternative, refunded to the current owner of the real property with respect to which the impact fees were imposed along with any interest that has accumulated. Specifically, the time limits shall be as follows: 
a.  With regard to impact fees collected within seven years of the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived enacting the impact fees, ten years after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived enacting the impact fees. 
b.  With regard to impact fees collected more than seven years after the effective date of the ordinance from which this section is derived enacting the impact fees, 20 years after the date on which the fee was collected. 
(5)  Impact fees for redevelopment and building additions shall be calculated as follows: 
a.  Redeveloped properties shall be charged the total amount of the impact fee for the redeveloped use less the impact fee that would be imposed for its current (predevelopment) use. 
b.  Impact fees for building additions shall be calculated on the square footage in excess or in addition to the existing structure. 
(f)  Fee reduction. Any impact fee imposed under this section shall be reduced to compensate for capital costs otherwise imposed by the city, upon the land development subject to this section, for the same public facilities for which an impact fee has been imposed under this section, including, by way of special assessments, special charges, land dedications, or any ordinance adopted thereunder or any other items of value. Impact fees imposed under this section shall also be reduced to compensate for moneys received from the federal or state government specifically to provide or pay for the public facilities for which the impact fees under this section are imposed. 
(g)  Exemption from fees. The lawful new construction of a single-family dwelling structure upon a nondivisible parcel of land supporting or having supported a habitable single-family dwelling structure razed or to be razed within one year of the date of the issuance of a building permit for the new construction as part of the new construction project shall be exempt from the fees imposed under this section. Any new construction of a single-family dwelling structure upon a single parcel of land involving the demolition of a preexisting residential structure upon such single parcel of land, which project is similar to but not exactly as described above to be exempt, may be found to be exempt upon application to the city council and a finding by the city council that such project does not bear a rational relationship to the need for new, expanded or improved public facilities required to serve such development. Such application shall be made to the city council prior to the payment of any fees under this section. 
(h)  Administration and review. 
(1)  All fees collected and special accounts maintained under this section shall be subject to administration by the city treasurer. The city treasurer shall report annually to the city council with regard to all deposits, withdrawals and fund balances in these accounts. The purpose of the annual report is to provide the city council with information necessary to determine that all funds collected are spent within the time required for the purpose intended and that the amount of fees imposed continues to represent an equitable and reasonable apportionment of the cost of public improvements and requirements generated by land development. The revenue and expenditure totals for each impact fee must also be included in the city's annual budget, and a summary of the revenue and expenditure totals for each impact fee must also be made available in the city's annual budget summary required under Wis. Stats. § 65.90(3)(a). 
(2)  As part of the annual budget process, the impact fees imposed under this section shall be increased annually at a rate equal to the percentage change in the Engineering News Record Construction Cost Index 20-City Average for the previous 12 months, with the adjustment effective January 1 of each year. The city treasurer or his/her designee shall calculate the adjusted fees and maintain a copy of the calculation and the adjusted impact fees in the office of the city clerk. 
(i)  Appeal. Any developer upon whom an impact fee is imposed under this section shall have the right to contest the amount, collection or use of the impact fee to the city council, provided that the developer files a written notice of appeal in the city clerk's office within 15 days of the developer's filing of an application for a building permit upon which the impact fee is imposed.
