(12)  Noise levels emanating from the vending site shall be kept to a minimum, shall not be directed toward the street or sidewalk, and shall be reasonable so as not to disturb the peace and quiet of those in the vicinity, including but not limited to residents, merchants, and customers. No sound amplification shall be permitted. 
(13)  No vendor shall drive or permit another to drive a motor vehicle upon any sidewalk area for the purpose of depositing vending carts or other equipment thereon. This prohibition does not apply to permanent or temporarily established driveways. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-13, § 1, 5-24-2011)  
Sec. 67-6. - Penalties. 
Penalties for conviction of any offenses under this chapter shall be as provided in section 1-21. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-13, § 1, 5-24-2011)  
Sec. 67-7. - Procedure for revocation, suspension or nonrenewal of vending license general procedure. 
In addition to any other penalty provided under this chapter, an category or type of street vending license issued hereunder may be revoked, suspended or not renewed for a stated period of time or otherwise limited by the imposition of conditions or restrictions by the public safety and human services committee, after notice and hearing, for any of the following: any violation of this chapter, serious or repeated violations of restrictions on parking, stopping or standing; and violations of any other city general ordinance or state statute where the circumstances of the offense are substantially related to vending activities. Any party aggrieved by the decision of the public safety and human services committee may within ten days of the decision appeal in writing to the city clerk for review of the decision by the common council. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-13, § 1, 5-24-2011)  
TITLE VI OFFENSES AND NUISANCES  
Chapter 68 - TRAFFIC[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 68-1. - State statutes adopted. 
(a)  Wis. Stats. ch. 340 which defines words and phrases used in Wis. Stats. chs. 340 through 348, together with any existing or future amendments thereto, is adopted and incorporated herein by reference as though fully set forth in this chapter. 
(b)  Except as otherwise specifically provided in this chapter, each and every provision of Wis. Stats. chs. 341 through 348, for which the penalty for violation thereof is as provided in section 1-21, and the penalties imposed for violation, and procedures for prosecution set forth in those chapters, together with any existing or future amendments thereto, are adopted and incorporated herein by reference as though fully set forth in this chapter. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by any statutes incorporated herein by reference is required or prohibited by this chapter. 
(c)  The sections of state statutes set forth in this subsection are adopted and incorporated herein by reference. However, the prosecution for any violation of the following statutes under this chapter shall be as provided in Wis. Stats. chs. 340 through 348 and the penalty imposed for a violation thereof shall be limited to a forfeiture as provided in section 70-309: 
(1)  Wis. Stats. § 941.01(1), negligent operation of vehicle off highway. 
(2)  Wis. Stats. § 947.04, drinking in common carriers. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.01(1))  
Sec. 68-2. - State vehicle equipment standards adopted. 
(a)  Wis. Admin. Code ch. Trans. 305 regulating standards for vehicle equipment is hereby adopted by reference and made part of this chapter as if set forth in full. The penalty for violations of this section shall be as prescribed in Wis. Admin. Code § Trans. 305.04; therefore, the penalty provisions set forth in section 70-309 shall not apply to violations of this section. 
(b)  The bond deposit schedule amount for any violation of this section shall be as follows: 
(1)  Any violation of this section, which also constitutes a violation of Wis. Stats. ch. 347, shall have a bond deposit in the amount specified for the specific violation under Wis. Stats. ch. 347 as set forth by the revised uniform state traffic deposit schedule, as now enacted and as hereinafter amended by the state judicial conference. 
(2)  Any violation of this section, which does not constitute a violation of Wis. Stats. ch. 347, shall have a bond deposit in the amount specified for violations of Wis. Admin. Code ch. Trans. 305 as set forth by the revised uniform state traffic deposit schedule, as now enacted and as hereinafter amended by the state judicial conference. 
(c)  A copy of the provisions of the Wisconsin Administrative Code which has been adopted in this chapter by reference shall be kept on file at the office of the chief of police and shall be made available to the public for inspection and copying upon request. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, §§ 8.01(3), 14.01(10))  
Sec. 68-3. - State snowmobile statutes adopted. 
Each and every provision of Wis. Stats. ch. 350 relating to the operation and maintenance of snowmobiles, together with any existing or future amendments thereto, are adopted and incorporated into this Code by reference. Any act required to be performed or prohibited by the statutes incorporated herein by reference is required or prohibited by this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.01(2))  
Secs. 68-468-24. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - SIGNS, SIGNALS AND STREET DESIGNATIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 68-25. - Installation of signs and signals. 
The chief of police or a designated subordinate, is hereby authorized and directed to procure and erect and maintain appropriate standard traffic signs, signals and markings conforming to the rules of the state highway division giving such notice of the provisions of this article as required by state law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.06(1))  
Sec. 68-26. - Removal of unofficial signs and signals. 
The chief of police shall have the authority granted by Wis. Stats. § 349.09 and is hereby directed to remove or order the removal any sign, signal, marking or device placed, maintained, or displayed in violation of this chapter or Wis. Stats. § 346.41. Any charge imposed on a premises for removal of such an illegal sign, signal or device shall be reported to the common council at its next regular meeting for review and certification. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.06(2))  
Secs. 68-2768-55. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - OFFICIAL TRAFFIC MAP 
 
Sec. 68-56. - Established. 
The public works department is hereby directed to prepare an official traffic map for the city upon which shall be indicated no parking and restricted parking areas, required stops, arterial intersections, through highways, safety zones, turns and lanes, heavy traffic routes, yield signs, special speed limits, one-way highways, school crossings and all other restrictions or limitations adopted by ordinance, order or resolution of the common council under the authority of Wis. Stats. ch. 349, as from time to time amended or modified. When the laws of the state require the erection or use of official traffic control devices to enforce any such restrictions or limitations, the location and nature of such signs shall be indicated on the official traffic map hereby established. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.07(1))  
Sec. 68-57. - Violations prohibited. 
When official traffic control devices giving notice of the restrictions, prohibitions and limitations shown on the official traffic map are erected and maintained in accordance with the provisions of this section, a violation of the restriction, prohibition or limitation shown on the official traffic map shall be a violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.07(2))  
Sec. 68-58. - Maintenance; display. 
A copy of the official traffic map shall be maintained by the department of public works and displayed in the office of the police department and municipal court. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.07(3))  
Sec. 68-59. - Additions or deletions. 
The council may from time to time, in accordance with Wis. Stats. ch. 349, make additions to or deletions from the official traffic map and the director of public works shall keep such official traffic map current. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.07(4))  
Secs. 68-6068-76. - Reserved.

All vehicles proceeding:

(8)  Northerly on Tower Hill Drive shall stop before entering the intersection of said street with Barbara Drive.

(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.04(3))

Secs. 68-10568-134. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - TRAFFIC RULES AND REGULATIONS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 68-135. - Traffic and pedestrian safety. 
(a)  Purpose. Pedestrians are increasingly using highways in ways for which the roads were not designed. These uses include approaching vehicles when in use or staying upon medians for purposes other than crossing the highway. These activities create safety hazards for pedestrians and distract drivers, making automobile crashes more likely. This section is designed to decrease the safety hazards by restricting such activity. These safety concerns are most acute on the busiest streets within the city, identified as arterial and collector streets or highways, and some streets intersecting with those arterial streets. This section applies to those "covered highways" identified in subsection (g) herein. 
(b)  Definitions. As used in this section: 
(1)  Covered highway is defined in subsection (g) herein. 
(2)  In operation. A vehicle is "in operation" when it has an operator, as defined in Wis. Stat. § 340.01(41). 
(3)  Median. A "median" is a paved or unpaved area dividing a street or highway that separates lanes of traffic traveling in opposite directions, or in the case of left or right hand turn lanes, vehicles traveling in the same direction. 
(c)  No person, other than a person in or on a vehicle, shall be on a covered highway listed in subsection (g) and approach any vehicle in operation, except a vehicle that is legally parked at the curb or the shoulder. 
(d)  No person shall be upon a median of a covered highway listed in subsection (g) unless that person is in the process of crossing the highway in a safety zone or crosswalk. It is prima facie evidence of a violation of this section if a person stays on the median through two consecutive opportunities to cross the highway in a legal manner under this chapter and the state traffic laws adopted herein. This may include a change in the traffic control signal or lack of traffic, as applicable. After such two consecutive opportunities, such person shall not be considered to be "using the safety zone or crosswalk to cross the highway" for purposes of the exception in subsection (f)(2). 
(e)  No operator of a vehicle shall park, stop or leave standing a vehicle on a covered highway listed in subsection (g) where prohibited or suddenly decrease the speed of said vehicle or deviate from a traffic lane for the purpose of responding to persons violating subsection (c) or (d). 
(f)  Exceptions. This section does not apply to: 
(1)  Persons on the sidewalk; 
(2)  Persons using the safety zone or crosswalk to cross the highway; 
(3)  Persons engaged in law enforcement or rescue activities, including providing assistance to an injured or disabled vehicle or person; 
(4)  Persons entering a vehicle as an invited passenger where it is lawful to do so, including activity permitted under Wis. Stat. § 346.29(1) (taxis); 
(5)  Persons engaged in repair or maintenance activities on the highway under the direction or authority of the city or the state; or 
(6)  Streets or portions thereof that have been closed pursuant to a street use permit or other express authorization from the city. 
(g)  Covered highways. This section applies only to covered highways, which are those highways or portions of highways listed in subsection (1) and (2) below: 
(1)  The following highways are designated as arterial and collector streets, the streets and highways within the city that have the most traffic, and are covered highways under this section: 
Cheryl Dr 	Kapec Rd (between King James Way and McKee Rd) 	Rothmore Ln 
Crescent Rd 	King James Way 	S. Seminole Hwy 
CTH B 	Lacy Rd 	S. Syene Rd (between McCoy Rd and Irish Ln) 
CTH D/Fish Hatchery Rd 	Leopold Way 	Seminole Hwy 
CTH M 	Longford Terrace 	Sentinel Pass (between Crescent Rd and Seminole Hwy) 
CTH MM/Rimrock Rd 	McCoy Rd 	Syene Rd 
CTH PD/McKee Rd 	Nesbitt Rd 	USH 14 
E. Cheryl Pkwy 	Osmundsen Rd (between Verde View Rd and Lacy Rd) 	USH 18/151/Verona Rd 
Fitchrona Rd 	Pembroke Dr 	Verde View Rd 
Greenway Cross (between Fish Hatchery Rd and Index Rd) 	Post Rd 	Whalen Rd (between Fitchrona Rd and Fish Hatchery Rd) 
Haight Farm Rd 	Raymond Rd 	Williamsburg Way 
Irish Ln 	Richardson St 	
 
(2)  In addition to the arterial highways designated above, this section applies to any highway containing a median that intersects with any of the arterial highways, but only for the first 200 feet of the intersecting highway from the arterial highway, as measured along the center line of the intersecting highway from the point the intersecting highway touches the right of way of the arterial highway. 
(h)  Any person violating this section may be required to forfeit not less than $25.00 nor more than $300.00. 
(Ord. No. 2017-O-15, § 1, 6-27-2017)  
Secs. 68-13668-151. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - VEHICLE NOISE 
 
Sec. 68-152. - Compression brakes prohibited. 
No person shall use motor vehicle brakes which are in any way activated or operated by compression of the engine of any motor vehicle. It shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under this section that the compression brakes were applied in an emergency and were necessary to prevent immediate danger to life or property. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.04(7))  
Sec. 68-153. - Excessive radio and other vehicle noise prohibited; exceptions. 
(a)  Except as provided under subsection (b) of this section or as provided in Wis. Stats. § 347.38(1), which is adopted in this chapter, no person may: 
(1)  Operate, park, stop or leave stand a motor vehicle while using a radio or other electric sound amplification device emitting sound from the vehicle, which includes, but is not limited to, a horn, that is clearly audible under normal conditions from a distance of 50 or more feet, unless the electric sound amplification device is being used to request assistance or warn against an unsafe condition. 
(2)  Operate a motor vehicle so as to cause unreasonable and excessive noise levels whether by excessive acceleration or braking causing the tires to squeal, by excessive horn blowing, by excessive racing of the motor, by having a modified or inadequately maintained exhaust or braking system or by any other means. 
(b)  This section does not apply to any of the following: 
(1)  The operator of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the law or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm. 
(2)  The operator of a vehicle of a public utility. 
(3)  The operator of a vehicle that is being used for advertising purposes. 
(4)  The operator of a vehicle that is being used in a community event or celebration, procession or assemblage. 
(5)  The activation of a theft alarm signal device. 
(6)  The operator of a motorcycle being operated outside of a business or residence district. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.04(8))  
Secs. 68-15468-164. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SCHOOL ZONES AND BUSES 
 
Sec. 68-165. - School crossing guards. 
Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 349.215, those adult persons hired by the department of police to act as school crossing guards shall have the authority to stop traffic and to keep it stopped as long as necessary at school crossings for the protection of persons who are crossing a street in the vicinity of a school. The school crossing guards shall wear insignia or uniforms which designate them as school crossing guards and shall be equipped with signals or signs to direct traffic to stop at school crossings. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.04(5))  
Sec. 68-166. - School bus warning lights in residence and business zones. 
Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 349.21, whenever a duly licensed school bus is equipped with flashing red warning lights, such lights shall be used by a bus operator within a residence or business district in the city when pupils or other authorized passengers are to be loaded or unloaded at a location at which there is no traffic signals and such persons must cross the street or highway before being loaded or after being loaded. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.04(6))  
Secs. 68-16768-177. - Reserved.

DIVISION 5. - HEAVY VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 68-201. - Weight restrictions. 
Except for motor buses, and except when necessary for the purpose of obtaining orders; delivering and moving supplies or other necessary commodities to or from any place of business or residence fronting any such streets, and except when necessary for the purpose of leaving or returning to the terminal or place of garaging of any such vehicle, it shall be unlawful for any person to operate any motor vehicle having a gross weight of more than 8,000 pounds on the following designated streets: 
(1)  Seminole Highway from McKee Road north to the city limits. 
When it is necessary for the operator of such a vehicle to travel upon a street which is designated with this restriction, such operator shall leave and re-enter at the point closest to their immediate destination. 
(Ord. No. 2012-O-11, § 4, 9-11-2012)  
Secs. 68-20268-206. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - PARKING  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 68-207. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Large vehicle means as any automobile, truck, trailer, truck power unit, bus, recreational vehicle and/or combination of vehicles: 
(1)  Having a gross vehicle weight in excess of 8,000 pounds and exceeding 16 feet in length (including accessories, racks or other physical extensions); or 
(2)  Exceeding eight feet in height measured from the roadway to the highest point of the vehicle, excluding only antennas. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(9)(a)(1))  
Sec. 68-208. - Vehicle abandonment prohibited; removal. 
(a)  Whenever any vehicle has been left unattended on any public highway, public property or private property without the permission of the property owner, for more than 48 hours the vehicle is deemed abandoned within the meaning of Wis. Stats. § 342.40, adopted in this chapter, and constitutes a public nuisance. 
(b)  In addition to the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 342.40, adopted in this chapter, relating to abandoned vehicle removal, whenever any traffic officer finds a vehicle standing upon a highway in violation of a prohibition, limitation or restriction on stopping, standing or parking, he/she is authorized to move such vehicle to a place of safekeeping by towing at the owner's expense or to require the operator in charge thereof to move such vehicle to a position where such stopping, standing, or parking is not prohibited. Such removal shall not relieve the owner or operator of such vehicle from any penalty incurred because of such violation. 
(c)  Whenever any vehicle has been abandoned as defined in subsection (a), or has been taken into custody pursuant to Wis. Stat. § 968.19 and is no longer required for evidence or use in further investigation, certified mail notice shall be sent to the owner and lienholders of record to permit reclamation of the vehicle after payment of accrued charges of towing and impoundment, if any. Such notice shall set forth the year, make, model, and serial number of the vehicle, the place where the vehicle is held, and shall inform the owner and any lienholders of their right to reclaim the vehicle. The notice shall state that the failure of the owner or lienholders to exercise their rights to reclaim the vehicle within 30 days is a waiver of all right, title, and interest in the vehicle and consent to the sale, donation, or junking of the vehicle. Each retained vehicle not reclaimed by its owner or lienholder within 30 days after certified mail notice has been sent may be sold, donated to a nonprofit organization, or, if the police chief and finance director determine that the cost of storage and title transfer would exceed the value of the vehicle, the vehicle may be junked with the approval of the city administrator. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(4), (5); Ord. No. 2017-O-02, § 1, 2-14-2017)  
Sec. 68-209. - Temporary parking regulations. 
(a)  When necessary for the cleaning, clearing, or repairing of any street, or for other emergency or special conditions including experimental traffic and parking regulations, the chief of police, or a designated subordinate, is authorized to make temporary regulations of traffic and parking upon the streets as conditions require. Notice shall be given of the regulations by the posting of reasonably conspicuous signs, within a reasonable time before such regulations are to become effective. 
(b)  The experimental temporary regulations, to test new or experimental traffic and parking regulations, shall be allowed for a period of 90 days except that such experiments may be continued for an additional 90-day period unless the common council, by resolution, determines otherwise. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(3); Ord. No. 2010-O-17, § 1, 10-26-2010)  
Sec. 68-210. - Snow and ice emergency regulations. 
(a)  When it becomes necessary for the effective movement of vehicles and to remove snow or ice from streets which because of the accumulation of snow or ice thereon causes such a hindrance to traffic as constitutes an emergency unless the snow or ice is promptly removed, the chief of police or a designated subordinate, after consultation with the superintendent of streets or a designated subordinate, shall by appropriate public media announcement declare the beginning of an emergency and the application of emergency snow parking regulations. The regulations shall remain in force and effect until lifted by the chief of police or a designated subordinate. 
(b)  For the purposes of this section, the accumulation of snow and ice on any street or area is sufficient for the declaration of an emergency when any accumulation hinders the safe movement of traffic or impedes the safe and expeditious travel of emergency and public transportation vehicles. 
(c)  Emergency snow parking regulations shall mean there will be parking permitted only on the even-numbered side of any street or any street in any specified aldermanic district or any street in any specified geographical area from 7:00 p.m. to 7:00 a.m. and there shall be parking permitted only on the odd-numbered side of any street or any street or streets in any specified aldermanic district or any street in any specified geographical area from 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. 
(d)  All parking regulations under this section shall remain in full effect except that enforcement of alternate side parking shall be suspended during the pendency of the emergency regulations on those streets in the areas affected. In addition, there shall be no parking on either side of any street or court of a width of 20 feet or less between face of curb and face of curb or of a roadway width of 20 feet or less. Vehicles in violation will be ticketed and towed. 
(e)  Signs shall be erected at or reasonably near the corporate limits of the city giving notice that snow emergency parking regulations are in effect in the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(3m))  
Sec. 68-211. - Parking on street limited to 24 hours. 
When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall stop or leave standing any vehicle upon any street for a period exceeding 24 hours. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(1))  
Sec. 68-212. - Winter parking restrictions. 
(a)  Between November 15 and March 15, no person may park, stop or leave standing any vehicle between the hours of 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m. on the even-numbered side of the street on odd-numbered calendar days, and on the odd-numbered side of the street on even-numbered calendar days except streets which prohibit parking at all times on one side of the street. 
(b)  Official traffic signs shall be placed or erected at or reasonably near the corporate limits of the city on all state and county trunk highways and connecting highways informing motorists that calendar night parking regulations are in effect in the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(2))  
Sec. 68-213. - School area parking restrictions. 
No person may park a vehicle on the following streets from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m. or from 2:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. on days when the schools of the Verona Area School District are in session: 
(1)  On the westside of Osmundsen Road from Lacy Road to Cordley Street. 
(2)  On the westside of Richardson Street from Lacy Road to Tudor Drive. 
(3)  On the southside of Norwich Street from Tudor Drive to Osmundsen Road. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(6))  
Sec. 68-214. - Parking of all vehicles restricted during certain time periods in specific areas. 
No person may park a vehicle on any of the following streets at the time indicated: 
(1)  On the westside of Richardson Street between Pennwall Street and Lacy Road from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m. on days when the schools of the Verona Area School District are in session. 
(2)  On the eastside of Richardson Street between Pennwall Street and Lacy Road from 2:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. on days when the schools of the Verona Area School District are in session. 
(3)  On the northside of Norwich Street between Tudor Drive and Osmundsen Road from 7:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m. on days when the schools of the Verona Area School District are in session. 
(4)  On the southside of Norwich Street between Tudor Drive and Osmundsen Road from 2:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. on days when the schools of the Verona Area School District are in session. 
(5)  On the southside of King James Way from 200 feet west of Chesapeake Drive to 100 feet west of Chesapeake Dr. from 6:00 a.m. to 10:00 a.m. and 2:30 p.m. to 6:30 p.m. 
(6)  On the southside of Post Road from a point 120 feet east of Leopold Way to a point 70 feet west of Traceway Drive between 7:00 a.m. and 8:30 a.m. and between 2:00 p.m. and 3:30 p.m. on days when the schools of Madison Metropolitan School District are in session. 
(7)  On the southside of Post Road from Leopold Way east 120 feet between 7:30 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. on days when the schools of Madison Metropolitan School District are in session. 
(8)  On the south side of Post Road from 370 feet east of Leopold Way to 525 feet east of Leopold Way between 7:30 a.m. and 4:30 p.m. on days when the schools of Madison Metropolitan School District are in session. 
(9)  On the north and south side of East Cheryl Parkway from 180 feet east of Research Park Drive to 460 feet east of Research Park Drive on Thursdays from 2:00 pm to 7:00 pm. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(7), (10); Ord. No. 2010-O-17, § 2, 10-26-2010; Ord. No. 2017-O-10, § 2, 4-25-2017)  
Sec. 68-215. - Parking prohibited during certain periods; handicapped loading zone. 
(a)  When signs are erected giving notice thereof, no person shall park any vehicle within a handicapped loading zone, at the indicated times, unless they are directly engaged in loading or unloading a handicapped person. Vehicles may park in the handicapped loading zone for up to 15 minutes for the purpose of loading or unloading a handicapped passenger. 
(b)  The board of public works may authorize, by resolution or otherwise, the issuance of permits for handicapped loading zones upon recommendation of the chief of police or director of public works. 
(Ord. No. 2010-O-7, § 1(8.05(7a)), 5-11-2010)  
Sec. 68-216. - Large vehicle parking restricted. 
No person shall park or leave standing any large vehicle upon any street between 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. or for more than two hours between 7:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., unless otherwise lawfully parked and engaged in continuous loading and unloading or directly engaged in activities for which such vehicles are necessary, including without limitation, loading and unloading goods, digging, hauling and trimming. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(9)(a)(2))  
Sec. 68-217. - Motor homes, mobile homes and certain trailer parking restricted; parking permits. 
(a)  No person shall, without a permit, park or store any motor home, mobile home, manufactured homes, camper trailer or any trailer having two or less axles, on any street in excess of 24 hours. 
(b)  The board of public works may authorize, by resolution or otherwise, the issuance of complimentary parking permits to motor vehicle owners or operators visiting the city for the purpose of a convention, conference, tournament or other function determined to be primarily for a public charitable religious philanthropic, educational or other nonprofitable purpose. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(9)(b))  
Secs. 68-21868-230. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - PROHIBITED PARKING 
 
Sec. 68-231. - Specific streets. 
No person shall at any time park a vehicle: 
(1)  On the southside of McKee Road (CTH PD) from Verona Road to Seminole Highway. 
(2)  On both sides of Chalet Gardens Court from the west end of the cul-de-sac to a point 100 feet east therefrom. 
(3)  On the southside of Big Bow Road from Big Bow Court to Tawhee Drive. 
(4)  On the eastside of Seminole Highway from Sentinel Pass north to the city limits. 
(5)  On both sides of the Verona Frontage Road. 
(6)  On the westside of Carling Drive for the entire length. 
(7)  On the westside of Red Arrow Trail from the city limit southerly to Thurston Lane.

Sec. 68-232. - Public right-of-way and public property. 
No person shall park any vehicle for sale within any public right-of-way or property controlled by the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(11))  
Sec. 68-233. - Traffic calming devices. 
No person shall at any time park at or along any traffic calming devices (excluding speed humps) throughout the city, including a minimum distance of 30 feet in either direction of the device, as determined necessary by city engineer. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(12))  
Sec. 68-234. - Fire hydrants. 
No person shall, at any time, park any vehicle at or along a fire hydrant including a minimum distance of ten feet in either direction of the hydrant. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(13))  
Sec. 68-235. - Bus stops. 
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle other than a bus in any bus stop when such stop has been officially designated and appropriately signed, except that the driver of a passenger vehicle may temporarily park therein for the purpose and while actually engaged in loading or unloading passengers when such stopping does not interfere with any bus about to enter such stop, and while such vehicle is attended by a licensed operator. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.05(14))  
Secs. 68-23668-252. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - PERSONAL TRANSPORTATION DEVICES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Secs. 68-25368-282. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - BICYCLES 
 
Sec. 68-283. - Registration and licenseRequired. 
Every owner of a bicycle within the city shall, within ten days of acquisition of said bicycle, properly register and tag said bicycle, except as provided in Wis. Stats. § 349.18 (19911992), as may be amended. No person shall operate a bicycle in the city unless said bicycle has been properly registered and tagged in the city or has a valid current registration in another municipality. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.075(1))  
Sec. 68-284. - SameFees. 
A registration and fee schedule for bicycles shall be set forth in the city fee schedule. The fee schedule shall be kept on file in the police department's and city clerk's office and shall be made available for reference and public inspection during normal business hours. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.075(2))  
Sec. 68-285. - Issuance of license. 
(a)  Licenses shall be issued to owners by the city police department upon payment of the required fee and presentation of the following required registration information. The registration information shall include: 
(1)  A license number; 
(2)  The owner's name and address; and 
(3)  A complete description of the bicycle including: 
a.  Make; 
b.  Model; 
c.  Color; 
d.  Serial number; and 
e.  Any additional descriptive information. 
(b)  The license shall be a tag or sticker of durable material bearing the license number and the name of the city in which it is issued. Bicycle licenses are nontransferable and nonexpiring. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.075(3))  
Sec. 68-286. - Attachment of license to bicycle. 
The owner or operator shall securely attach the license to the bicycle frame so that it is plainly visible. Any bicycle without the proper license properly attached to the bicycle shall be presumed to be unregistered and unlicensed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.075(4))  
Sec. 68-287. - Abandoned bicycles. 
(a)  Violation. 
(1)  No person may leave unattended any bicycle on any public street, highway, building, place or park upon any public or private property, for such time and under such circumstances as to cause the bicycle to reasonably appear to be abandoned. 
(2)  Any bicycle left on any public street, highway, public place, or park, and not affixed with a lock to a post, pole, or bicycle rack, or otherwise secured by a lock, is deemed to be abandoned. 
(b)  Notice of abandonmentLocked bicycle. Any bicycle that is affixed with a lock to a post, pole, or bicycle rack, or otherwise secured with a lock, in violation of subsection (a)(1) may have a notice affixed to it which informs the owner of the bicycle, that the bicycle appears to be abandoned. Only a police officer, civilian service employee, or other police department designee shall have authority to affix such notices upon bicycles. The notice shall indicate: 
(1)  The date and time the notice was affixed; 
(2)  A phone number for the owner to call to inform the agency which affixed the notice, that the bicycle is not abandoned; 
(3)  The date and time after which the bicycle may be removed under subsection (c). 
A bicycle shall be deemed as "not abandoned" if the owner of the bicycle, within 48 hours of the affixing of a notice of abandonment, notifies the agency affixing that notice, that the bicycle is not abandoned. 
(c)  Removal. If a bicycle is deemed to be abandoned under subsection (a)(2) or remains in violation of subsection (a)(1) more than 48 hours after the notice of abandonment has been affixed in compliance with subsection (b), that bicycle may be removed by any police officer, civilian service employee, or other police department designee, and immediately thereafter delivered to the police property storage room. However, before any designated person removes a bicycle they shall first determine whether their agency has designated the bicycle as "not abandoned." A bicycle designated "not abandoned" may not be removed. A bicycle removed under this section shall remain in the custody of the police department until it is retrieved by the owner or otherwise disposed of according to subsection (d). 
(d)  Disposal of abandoned bicycles. 
(1)  Upon removal, an abandoned bicycle shall be held a minimum of 30 days by the police department unless earlier claimed by the owner. The police department shall make a reasonable effort to identify and notify the owner of the bicycle. 
(2)  For purposes of disposal, a bicycle that has remained unclaimed for a period of 30 days becomes the property of the city. Bicycles that are not claimed within 30 days may be disposed of in any of the following ways: public auction, sale of the bicycle through the Internet, donation to non-profit entities, or disposal as waste. Bicycles shall only be donated to non-profit entities or disposed as waste where the police chief and finance director determine that the cost of storage and transportation exceeds the value of the bicycle, and city administrator grants approval to such disposal. In case of donation, preference shall be given to local non-profit entities. 
(Ord. No. 2018-O-30, § 1, 9-25-2018)  
Secs. 68-28868-305. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - NEIGHBORHOOD ELECTRIC VEHICLES 
 
Sec. 68-306. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this division, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Connecting highway has the same meaning as in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(9). 
Neighborhood electric vehicle has the same meaning as in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(36r). 
State trunk highway has the same meaning as in Wis. Stats. § 340.01(60). 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.076(1))  
Sec. 68-307. - Penalties. 
(a)  Each violation of this division shall result in the issuance of a citation and the payment to the city of a penalty by the violator in an amount not less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00. 
(b)  Each violation of a state or local traffic code not contained within this division shall subject the operator of the neighborhood electric vehicle to the citations and penalties set forth for such violations in the applicable state statutes and Code provisions. Such violations are cumulative to and not in lieu of those set forth in this division. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.076(4))  
Sec. 68-308. - Use permitted on city streets. 
(a)  The use of a neighborhood electric vehicle on a public street within the city is prohibited except as explicitly specified in this division. 
(b)  The use of a neighborhood electric vehicle that has been registered with the state department of transportation is hereby authorized on roadways under the jurisdiction of the city with a speed limit no greater than 35 miles per hour with the following provisions: 
(1)  A neighborhood electric vehicle may be used upon connecting highways within the city, but only upon those sections where the speed limit is no greater than 35 miles per hour. 
(2)  A neighborhood electric vehicle may cross state trunk highways within the city, but only at public intersections where the speed limit upon the state trunk highway at that particular intersection is no greater than 35 miles per hour. 
(3)  Subsections (b)(1) and (2) of this section are subject to the approval of the state department of transportation as outlined in Wis. Stats. § 349.26(3). 
(4)  A neighborhood electric vehicle may be used upon county trunk highways in which jurisdiction is shared by the city and the county, but only upon those sections where the speed limit is no greater than 35 miles per hour. 
(5)  A neighborhood electric vehicle may cross a county trunk highway with posted speeds in excess of 35 miles per hour only at intersections with traffic control signals. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.076(2)(A), (B))  
Sec. 68-309. - City engineer authorized to designate additional restricted areas; location map. 
(a)  The city engineer may, at his/her discretion, restrict out certain collector and arterial roadways, which have a 35 miles per hour or lower speed limit, where the use of neighborhood electric vehicles would pose a public safety issue. Such restrictions shall be subject to the approval of the board of public works. 
(b)  A list of all such locations on which a neighborhood electric vehicle may be operated shall be compiled, kept and updated in written form by the city engineer or his/her designee. The list shall be kept on file for inspection during normal business hours in the police department, city clerk's department and public works department. 
(c)  The city engineer or his/her designee shall produce a map showing all such locations on which a neighborhood electric vehicle may be operated. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.076(2)(C), (D))  
Sec. 68-310. - Operation. 
The operation of a neighborhood electric vehicle as permitted in this division shall comply in all respects with this chapter and other applicable provisions of this Code, as applicable to the operation of motor vehicles. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.076(3))  
Secs. 68-31168-338. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PENALTIES AND ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 68-339. - PenaltiesCosts, assessments and surcharges to be included. 
The penalty for violation of any provision of this chapter shall be a penalty as provided in section 1-21 together with any costs of prosecution, penalty assessments, and surcharges authorized or imposed by the state statutes adopted by reference in this chapter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.08)  
Sec. 68-340. - SameFor adopted state offenses. 
Except as provided in section 68-341 for nonmoving traffic offenses, penalties for violation of any provision of Wis. Stats. chs. 341 through 348 adopted by reference in this chapter shall conform to penalties for violation of the comparable state offense, including any variations or increases for second offenses. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.08(1))  
Sec. 68-341. - SameFor nonmoving and other violations. 
Penalties for nonmoving violations and all other violations of this chapter not specifically addressed in this article shall be as provided in section 1-21.  
Sec. 68-342. - Enforcement in accordance with state law. 
This chapter shall be enforced in accordance with the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 66.0114 and 345.20 through 345.53 and Wis. Stats. chs. 299 and 800. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.09)  
Sec. 68-343. - Stipulation of guilt or no contest. 
(a)  Stipulations of guilt or no contest may be made by persons arrested for violations of this chapter in accordance with Wis. Stats. §§ 345.27 or 66.0114, whenever the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 345.27 are inapplicable to such violations. 
(b)  The uniform traffic citation promulgated under Wis. Stats. § 345.11 shall be used for all moving traffic violations under this article. Stipulations may be accepted by the police department. 
(c)  Citations for all nonmoving traffic violations under this article shall permit a direct mail payment of the applicable penalty to the police department in lieu of a court appearance. The issuing officer shall specify on the citation the amount of the applicable penalty provided in this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.09(1))  
Sec. 68-344. - Deposits. 
Any person stipulating guilt or no contest must make the deposit required under Wis. Stats. § 345.26 or, if the deposit is not established under such statute, shall deposit a forfeiture penalty as provided in the schedule established by the chief of police and approved by the common council. Deposits may be brought or mailed to the office of the police department as directed by the arresting officer. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.09(2))  
Sec. 68-345. - Officer to furnish receipt; alleged violator to sign citation and complaint. 
Every officer accepting a forfeiture, made as a deposit under section 68-344, shall furnish a receipt therefor as provided in Wis. Stats. § 345.26(3)(b). Every officer accepting a stipulation under the provision of this article shall comply with the provisions of Wis. Stats. §§ 343.27, 345.26(1)(a) and 345.27(2) and shall require the alleged violator to sign a traffic citation and complaint promulgated under Wis. Stats. § 345.11. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.09(3))  
Sec. 68-346. - Forfeitures in treasury; officer to post bond, qualify. 
Any officer accepting deposits of forfeiture under this article shall deliver them to the city treasurer within 20 days after receipt. Any officer authorized to accept deposits under Wis. Stats. § 345.26 or this chapter shall qualify by taking the oath prescribed by Wis. Stats. § 19.01 and filing an official bond in the sum of $1,000.00, as described by Wis. Stats. § 19.01. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 8.09(4))
