Sec. 70-2. - Intent defined. 
(a)  When the term "intent" is an element of an offense in this chapter, such intent is indicated by the term "intentionally," the phrase "with intent to," the phrase "with intent that," or some form of the verbs "know" or "believe." 
(b)  The term "know" requires that the actor believes that the specified fact exists. 
(c)  The term "intentionally" means that the actor either has a purpose to do the thing or cause the result specified or believes that his/her act, if successful, will cause the result. 
(d)  The term "with intent to" or "with intent" means that the actor either has a purpose to do the thing or cause the result specified or believes that his/her act, if successful, will cause that result. 
(e)  The term "intent" does not require proof of knowledge of the existence or constitutionality of the provision under which he/she is prosecuted or the scope of meaning of the terms used in that section. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.12(3)) 
State Law reference Criminal intent, Wis. Stats. § 939.23.  
Secs. 70-370-20. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - OFFENSES AGAINST PEACE AND QUIET 
 
Sec. 70-21. - Disorderly conduct. 
No person shall: 
(1)  In a public or private place, engage in violent, abusive, indecent, profane, boisterous, unreasonably loud, or otherwise disorderly conduct under circumstances in which such conduct tends to cause or provoke a disturbance; or 
(2)  With intent to annoy another, make a telephone call, whether or not conversation ensues. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(1)) 
State Law reference Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 947.01.  
Sec. 70-22. - Indecent conduct or language. 
No person shall use any indecent, vile, profane or obscene language or conduct himself/herself in an indecent, lewd, lascivious or obscene manner. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(2)) 
State Law reference Lewd and lascivious behavior, Wis. Stats. § 944.20.  
Sec. 70-23. - Loitering. 
No person shall loiter. 
(1)  Loitering defined. The term "loitering" means that a person loiters if he/she stands idly, moves slowly about, lingers, or remains in an area for no obvious reason in a manner or under circumstances that warrant alarm for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. Among the circumstances which may be considered in determining whether such an alarm is warranted is the fact that the actor takes flight upon the appearance of a peace officer, refuses to identify himself/herself or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself/herself or any object. 
(2)  Opportunity to dispel alarm. Unless flight by the actor or other circumstances make it impracticable, a peace officer shall, prior to any arrest for any offense under this subsection, afford the actor an opportunity to dispel any alarm which would otherwise be warranted, by requesting him/her to identify himself/herself and explain his/her presence and conduct. 
(3)  Exception. No person shall be convicted of an offense under this section if the peace officer did not comply with the provisions of subsection (2) of this section, or if it appears at trial that the explanation given by the actor was true and, if believed by the peace officer at the time, would have dispelled the alarm. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(3)) 
State Law reference Standing or loitering in roadway or highway prohibited, Wis. Stats. § 346.29; vagrancy, Wis. Stats. § 947.02; presence of minors restricted on premises licensed for sale of alcoholic beverages, Wis. Stats. § 125.07; vagrancy, Wis. Stats. § 947.02.  
Sec. 70-24. - Obstructing public buildings. 
No person shall obstruct in any manner the entrance or any stairway or hallway in any public place, business or building. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(4)) 
State Law reference Unlawful assembly, Wis. Stats. § 947.06.  
Sec. 70-25. - Picketing or mass demonstrations. 
No person shall, either singly or in concert with others, engage in picketing or mass demonstration in such a manner as to obstruct or unreasonably interfere with free ingress to or egress from any public premises, or so as to obstruct or unreasonably interfere with the free use of the public streets, sidewalks, or other public ways. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(6)) 
State Law reference Unlawful assembly, Wis. Stats. § 947.06.  
Sec. 70-26. - Intoxicants on the property of another. 
No person shall possess or consume any amount of an alcoholic beverage, whether in an open or closed container, on the property of another without the permission of the owner or a lawful tenant of the property. 
(Ord. No. 2013-O-11, § 1, 6-11-2013)  
Secs. 70-2770-38. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC HEALTH AND SAFETY[2] 
Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference Crimes against public health and safety generally, Wis. Stats. § 941.01 et seq.; crimes against public peace, order, and other interests, Wis. Stats. § 947.01 et seq. 
 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 70-39. - Discharging firearms. 
No person, except a sheriff, constable, police officer, or other deputy, shall fire or discharge any pistol, firearm, rifle, spring or airgun within the city or have any pistol, firearm, rifle, spring or airgun in his/her possession or under his/her control unless it is unloaded and knocked down or enclosed within a carrying case or other suitable container, except as follows: 
(1)  Firearms may be discharged at skeet or trap shooting courses or at dog training or field trials, but in such cases permission must first be obtained in writing from the common council and the owner of the land. 
(2)  Firearms may be discharged by a person at his/her home or in his/her premises in the defense of his/her life or of his/her property. 
(3)  Firearms may be discharged for hunting purposes during lawful hunting seasons and within the provisions and rules of the state department of natural resources and with written permission of the landowner. 
(4)  Firearms may be discharged with cause by a private detective or private security person while going in accordance with the rules promulgated by the state department of regulation and licensing; provided, however, that any private detective or private security person, who has his/her principal place of business located in the city, must first obtain written authorization to discharge firearms from the city chief of police after providing documentation to the city chief of police pertaining to policies, procedures, qualifications and training. 
(5)  Firearms may be discharged with cause by armored car carriers licensed by the state department of regulation and licensing, while actually employed in the shipment, transportation or delivery of any money, bullion, bonds or any other thing of value within the city. Such individuals must be completely attired in the uniform of their employer; provided, however, that any armored car carrier, who has his/her principal place of business located in the city, must first obtain written authorization to discharge firearms from the city chief of police after providing documentation to the city chief of police pertaining to policies, procedures, qualifications and training. 
(6)  Firearms may be discharged with cause by a correctional officer while in conformance with the officer's duties. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.02(1)) 
State Law reference Endangering safety by use of dangerous weapon, Wis. Stats. § 941.20; carrying concealed weapon, Wis. Stats. § 941.23; carrying handgun where alcohol beverages may be sold and consumed, Wis. Stats. § 941.237; local regulation of firearms, Wis. Stats. § 66.0409; use of firearms near parks, Wis. Stats. § 167.30; safe use and transportation of firearms and bows, Wis. Stats. § 167.31.  
Sec. 70-40. - Blocking fire hydrants. 
No person shall park any motor vehicle within ten feet of any fire hydrant or otherwise interfere with the accessibility of any fire hydrant by piling, dumping or placing any other obstructive material or object within ten feet of a fire hydrant without first obtaining written permission from the fire chief. Every day during which such interference continues constitutes a separate offense. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.02(4)) 
State Law reference Interfering with firefighting, Wis. Stats. § 941.12.  
Secs. 70-4170-56. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - FIRES AND BLASTING 
 
Sec. 70-57. - Fires and trash burning regulated. 
(a)  No person shall kindle any grass fire within the city without first securing a written permit from the fire chief. 
(b)  No person shall kindle or cause to be kindled any fire in or upon a street, alley, public lake, park, or any other public or private ground within the city within 100 feet of any building or within any fire lane unless the same shall be confined within a wire refuse burner, basket, or metal enclosure with a cover attached to prevent the escape of sparks and burning material, or unless in the care of some responsible person until extinguished. 
(c)  No person shall handle burning material in a negligent manner. Burning material is handled in a negligent manner if, under the circumstances, the person knows or should know that he/she creates a risk of harm to another or damage to another's property. 
(d)  Compliance with DNR regulations. Nothing in this division and no permit issued by the city shall be construed to allow any burning which is prohibited by valid regulations of the state department of natural resources. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.02(5)) 
State Law reference Solid waste open burning standards, Wis. Stats. § 289.51.  
Sec. 70-58. - Prohibited. 
Except as provided in this division, no person within the city shall set any fire or blast on any land, burn in a dump or engage in open burning within any residential subdivision or commercial district or within 100 feet of the boundary of a residential subdivision or commercial district. As used in this section, the term "residential subdivision" means a subdivision, multifamily development or a planned development district located in the urban service area and created under chapter 15. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.12(1))  
Sec. 70-59. - ExceptionCertain fires. 
The setting of fires shall be allowed in any of the following situations provided applicable state regulations are followed: 
(1)  Where a fire is set for the sole purpose of warming persons or cooking food. 
(2)  Where rubbish is burned in a barrel, trash can or other closed burner and a heavy wire screen or cover is used to prevent material or embers from blowing out. 
(3)  Where a written permit has been obtained from the city fire department. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.12(2))  
Sec. 70-60. - SameCertain blasting. 
Blasting is allowed if all applicable state regulations are followed and if a written permit has been obtained from the city fire department. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.12(3))  
Sec. 70-61. - Careless burning. 
No person shall through negligence allow a fire for the open burning of brush, trash or other permitted combustibles to escape or handle burning material in a highly negligent manner. Burning material is handled in a highly negligent manner if, under the circumstances, the person should realize that manner of handling creates an unreasonable risk and high probability of death or great bodily harm to another or serious damage to another's property. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.12(4))  
Sec. 70-62. - Compliance with state regulations required. 
Nothing in this division shall be construed to allow any burning which is prohibited by regulations of the state department of natural resources. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.12(5))  
Sec. 70-63. - Open excavations. 
No person shall leave open, cause to be left open, or permit to be left open, any cistern, well or other dangerous excavation on any lot, part of a lot, or parcel of land in the city unless the same is securely guarded. Every day during which such excavation continues to be open constitutes a separate offense. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.02(6))  
Sec. 70-64. - Obstructing or interfering with traffic. 
No person shall place an obstacle in or upon a highway, intentionally damage a highway, remove or tamper with a sign or signal used for the guidance of vehicles or pedestrians, give a false traffic signal, or otherwise interfere with the orderly flow of traffic upon any highway, public way, thoroughfare or bridge, including any roadways commonly used for vehicular traffic, whether public or private, within the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.02(7)) 
State Law reference Stopping prohibited in certain specified places, Wis. Stats. § 346.52.  
Sec. 70-65. - Moving buildings regulated. 
No person shall: 
(1)  Move any building along or upon the public streets and highways in the city without first having received a permit from the building inspector. 
(2)  Violate any of the conditions to be complied with or designated routes as set forth in such permit. 
(3)  Allow any such building to remain overnight upon any street or highway within the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.02(8))  
Sec. 70-66. - Throwing missiles. 
No person shall throw any stone, or other missile at or in the vicinity of any person, automobile, or other property within the city; provided that this subsection shall not apply if the person at whom the missile is directed or the owner of the property consents thereto. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.02(9)) 
State Law reference Throwing missile, circular or pamphlet in or on any vehicle prohibited, Wis. Stats. § 346.94.  
Secs. 70-6770-90. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - LITTERING 
 
Sec. 70-91. - Prohibited. 
No person shall throw or deposit any glass, can, plastic or metal container, paper, refuse, waste, filth or other litter upon the streets, alleys, highways, public parks, or other public or private property within the city other than in proper receptacles intended therefor. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(2))  
Sec. 70-92. - Placing refuse and recyclables for pickup regulated. 
No person shall place refuse or recycling carts, cans, bags, or other containers along any street, alley, highway, or other roadway within the city and not in the front yard or side yard setback; provided that this section shall not apply to the placement of such receptacles within 24 hours of a regularly scheduled time for refuse or recyclables removal. Every day during which such containers are permitted to remain shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(3))  
Sec. 70-93. - Storing junk. 
No person shall store junk or discarded property, including automobiles, automobile parts, trucks, tractors, refrigerators, furnaces, washing machines, stoves, machinery or machinery parts, wood, bricks, cement blocks, or other unsightly debris, except in an enclosure which houses such property from public view or upon permit issued by the common council. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(4))  
Sec. 70-94. - Storing automobiles in public view. 
No person which owns, controls, or occupies any real estate within the city shall permit disassembled, inoperable, unlicensed or junked vehicles to be stored or allowed to remain open to view, upon public or private property within the city, for a period in excess of five days, unless it is in connection with an automobile sales or repair business operated within a properly zoned area. Each day during which the provisions of this section are violated shall constitute a separate offense. For purposes of this section, racing cars and equipment shall be deemed unlicensed vehicles. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(5))  
Sec. 70-95. - Property must be free from debris. 
All exterior property areas shall be properly maintained in a clean and sanitary condition, free from debris, rubbish, garbage, refuse, recyclables, physical hazards, rodent harborage and infestation, and animal feces. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(6))  
Sec. 70-96. - Enforcement. 
For the purpose of enforcing compliance with the provisions of this division, the zoning administrator, building inspector, director of public works or their designees may either issue citations to the property owner immediately or send notice to the property owner or tenant giving them a deadline to comply with the provisions of this division. If the property owner or tenant does not comply within the deadline specified, the city may coordinate the necessary cleanup and invoice the property owner or tenant for the cost of cleanup including administrative costs. If the invoices are not paid when due, the city may place the costs for the associated cleanup and administrative actions as a special charge on the property tax roll for the respective property, pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 74.01(4). The amount of the charges shall be as specified in the city fee schedule. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.05(7))  
Secs. 70-9770-120. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - OFFENSES AGAINST PUBLIC MORALITY 
 
Sec. 70-121. - Prostitution and solicitation of prostitution. 
(a)  No person shall, for anything of value, intentionally have or offer to have non-marital sexual intercourse or commit or offer to commit an act of sexual perversion with another person. 
(b)  No person shall intentionally give or offer to give anything of value to another in return for a person engaging in an act of nonmarital sexual intercourse or an act of sexual perversion. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.03(1), (2)) 
State Law reference Prostitution, Wis. Stats. § 944.30.  
Sec. 70-122. - Possession of marijuana. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this subsection, the following definitions shall apply: 
Marijuana means all parts of the plant Cannabis Sativa L. , whether growing or not; the seeds thereof; the resin extracted from any part of the plant; and every compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of the plant, its seeds or resin. The term "marijuana" does not include the mature stalks of the plant, fiber produced from the stalks, oil or cake made from the seeds of the plant, any other compound, manufacture, salt, derivative, mixture or preparation of the mature stalks (except the resin extracted therefrom), fiber, oil or cake or the sterilized seed of the plant which is incapable of germination. 
Practitioner means a physician, dentist, veterinarian, podiatrist, scientific investigator or other person licensed, registered or otherwise permitted to distribute, dispense, conduct research with respect to or administer a controlled substance in the course of professional practice or research in the city and a pharmacy, hospital or other institution licensed, registered or otherwise permitted to distribute, dispense, conduct research with respect to or administer a controlled substance in the course of professional practice or research in the city. 
(b)  No person shall possess and/or use marijuana unless the marijuana was obtained directly from, or pursuant to, a valid prescription or order of a practitioner while acting in the course of his/her professional practice, or except as otherwise authorized by state statutes. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.03(3)) 
State Law reference Authority of municipality to prohibit possession of 25 grams or less of marijuana, Wis. Stats. § 66.0107.  
Secs. 70-12370-142. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - OFFENSES AGAINST PROPERTY 
 
Sec. 70-143. - Graffiti or injury to property of another. 
(a)  Definitions. As used in this section, the following definitions shall apply. 
Graffiti means any writing, printing, marks, signs, symbols, figures, designs, inscriptions or other drawings which are scratched, scrawled, painted, drawn or otherwise placed on any surface of a building, wall, fence, sidewalk, curb or other structure on public or private property which have the effect of defacing the property. 
Intentionally means that the actor either has a purpose to do the thing or cause the result specified, or is aware that his/her conduct is practically certain to cause that result. In addition, the actor must have knowledge of those facts which are necessary to make his/her conduct unlawful and which are set forth after the word intentionally. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally cause damage to any physical property of another without the person's consent. 
(c)  If more than one item of property is damaged under a single intent and design, the damage to all of the property may be prosecuted as a single offense. 
(d)  In any case of unlawful damage involving more than one act of unlawful damage, but prosecuted as a single offense, it is sufficient to allege generally that unlawful damage to property was committed between certain dates. At the trial, evidence may be given of such unlawful damage that was committed on or between the dates alleged. 
(e)  It shall be unlawful for any person to intentionally place graffiti on any surface located on public or private property. 
(f)  This section does not prohibit any person from using water soluble chalk to mark words or figures, otherwise lawful, upon city pavement and sidewalks. 
(g)  Any person who shall violate this section shall pay the costs of repairing the property to its original state. 
(h)  See section 70-309 for penalties for any person violating any provision of this chapter where a penalty has not already been provided. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.04(1)) 
State Law reference Graffiti, Wis. Stats. § 943.017.  
Sec. 70-144. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 2012-O-12, § 2, adopted August 28, 2012, amended the Code by repealing former § 70-144. Former § 70-144 pertained to trespass on private property, and derived from the Compiled Ordinances of 2009, § 14.04(2).  
Sec. 70-145. - Backing or driving over curbs without blocking. 
No person shall back or drive any truck or other motorized machinery or equipment over 10,000 pounds gross weight over any curb in the city without blocking the curb. Blocking shall consist of wooden blocks a minimum of four inches high by four inches wide by two feet long, plus tire or tread width (four inches by four inches by two feet plus tire or tread width). Blocking shall be placed under each wheel or tread. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.04(5)) 
State Law reference Damage to property, Wis. Stats. § 943.01.  
Sec. 70-146. - Driving motor vehicles on public lands. 
No person shall drive, operate or park any unauthorized motorized vehicle in or on any portion of public land including, but not limited to, parks, median strips parkways, school grounds or open space easements, unless designated as a park drive, roadway, parking area or temporary parking area within such public land. The term "motorized vehicle" means any self-propelled device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.04(6)) 
State Law reference Damage to property, Wis. Stats. § 943.01.  
Sec. 70-147. - Fraud on hotel or restaurant keeper. 
No person shall: 
(1)  Having obtained any food, lodging or other service or accommodation at any hotel, motel, boardinghouse or lodginghouse, or restaurant, intentionally abscond without paying for it. 
(2)  While a guest at any hotel, motel, boardinghouse or lodginghouse, or restaurant, intentionally defraud the keeper thereof in any transaction arising out of such relationship as a guest. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.04(3)) 
State Law reference Fraud on hotel or restaurant keeper, recreational attraction, taxicab operator or gas station, Wis. Stats. § 943.21.  
Sec. 70-148. - Fraud on taxicab or bus driver. 
No person who has obtained any transportation or other service from any taxicab or bus driver shall intentionally abscond without paying for such transportation or other service. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.02(10)) 
State Law reference Fraud on hotel or restaurant keeper, recreational attraction, taxicab operator or gas station, Wis. Stats. § 943.21.  
Sec. 70-149. - Fraud on fuel distributor. 
No person having obtained fuel, oil, products, or service from any distributor of fuel shall intentionally leave the premises of such distributor without paying for it absent the consent of the distributor. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.04(7)) 
State Law reference Fraud on hotel or restaurant keeper, recreational attraction, taxicab operator or gas station, Wis. Stats. § 943.21.  
Sec. 70-150. - Worthless checks. 
No person shall issue any check or other draft which will not be honored upon presentment because the drawer does not have an account with the drawee or because the drawer does not have sufficient funds in the account or sufficient credit with the drawee. This section shall not apply to a postdated check issued with the consent of the payee provided that the check is honored if presented on or after the date it bears. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.04(8)) 
State Law reference Issuance of worthless check, Wis. Stats. § 943.24.  
Sec. 70-151. - Shoplifting. 
No person shall intentionally alter the indicia of price or value of merchandise or take or carry away, transfer, conceal or retain possession of merchandise held for resale by a merchant without the merchant's consent. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.04(4)) 
State Law reference Retail theft, Wis. Stats. § 943.50.  
Sec. 70-152. - Firearms in public buildings. 
(a)  Pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 943.13(1m)(c)4., no person shall enter or remain in any part of a building owned, occupied or controlled by the state or local governmental unit if the state or local governmental unit has notified the person not to enter or remain in the building while carrying a firearm or a specific type of firearm. 
(b)  The city administrator shall cause signs to be erected at all entrances to all buildings owned, occupied or under the control of the city providing notice that no person is to enter or remain in any such building while carrying a firearm or other weapons. Such signs shall be five inches by seven inches or larger. 
(c)  Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to apply to prohibit a peace officer or armed forces or military personnel armed in the line of duty or any person duly authorized by the chief of police to possess a firearm in any public building. Notwithstanding Wis. Stats. § 939.22(22), for purposes of this paragraph, peace officer does not include a commission warden who is not a State certified commission warden. 
(d)  Nothing in this subsection shall be construed to authorize the carrying of any firearm or dangerous weapon contrary to Wis. Stats. §§ 941.23 or 941.235. 
(Ord. No. 2011-O-19, § 1, 10-25-2011)  
Secs. 70-15370-170. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - OFFENSES AGAINST ADMINISTRATION OF JUSTICE  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 70-171. - Obstructing justice; giving false information. 
No person shall knowingly give false information to any officer of any court with the intent to influence said officer in the performance of his/her functions. The term "officer of any court" includes the judge, clerk, reporter, bailiff and city attorney. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.08(1)) 
State Law reference Similar provision, Wis. Stats. § 946.65.  
Sec. 70-172. - False swearing. 
No person, while under oath or affirmation, shall make or subscribe a false statement which he/she does not believe is true. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.08(2)) 
State Law reference Perjury, Wis. Stats. § 946.31; false swearing, Wis. Stats. § 946.32.  
Sec. 70-173. - Interference with witnesses. 
No person shall: 
(1)  With intent to induce another to refrain from giving evidence or testifying in any matter before any court, board, or agency, transfer to him/her or on his/her behalf, any property or pecuniary advantage; 
(2)  Accept any property or any pecuniary advantage, knowing that such property or pecuniary advantage was transferred to him/her or on his/her behalf, with the intent to induce him/her to refrain from giving evidence or testifying before any court, board or agency. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.08(3)) 
State Law reference Solicitation, Wis. Stats. § 939.30; bribery of witnesses, Wis. Stats. § 946.61; communicating with jurors, Wis. Stats. § 946.64;  
Secs. 70-17470-199. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - INTERFERENCE WITH LAW ENFORCEMENT 
 
Sec. 70-200. - Resisting or obstructing officer. 
(a)  For purposes of this section: 
Obstructs includes, without limitation, knowingly giving false information to an officer with the intent to mislead him/her in the performance of his/her duty including the service of any civil process. 
Officer means a police officer, firefighter, animal control officer, building inspector, and includes any other public officer or public employee having the authority, by virtue of his/her office or employment, to issue citations for the violation of city ordinances. 
(b)  No person shall resist, obstruct or in any way interfere with a city officer while such officer is doing any act in his/her official capacity and with lawful authority. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.07(1)) 
State Law reference Wis. Stats. § 946.41.  
Sec. 70-201. - False fire or police reports. 
No person shall intentionally falsely report, in any manner, directly or indirectly, to any police officer, city officer, or officer or member of the city fire department, that a crime or a violation of this Code has been or is being committed or that there is any fire in the city or in any territory protected by said fire department. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.07(2)) 
State Law reference Bomb scares, Wis. Stats. § 947.015; false fire alarms, Wis. Stats. § 941.13.  
Sec. 70-202. - Impersonating police officers. 
No person shall impersonate a police officer with the intent to mislead others into believing that he/she is actually a police officer. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.07(3)) 
State Law reference Impersonating peace officers, Wis. Stats. § 946.70.  
Sec. 70-203. - Falsely assuming to act as public officer or employee. 
No person shall: 
(1)  Assume to act in an official capacity or to perform an official function, knowing that he/she is not the public officer or public employee he/she assumes to be; or 
(2)  Exercise any function of a public office knowing that he/she is not qualified so to act or his/her right to act has ceased. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.07(4)) 
State Law reference Falsely assuming to act as a public officer or employee or a utility employee, Wis. Stats. § 946.69.  
Secs. 70-20470-229. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VII. - OFFENSES RELATED TO MINORS  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 70-230. - Unlawful sheltering. 
No person unless licensed under the state statutes or without having first obtained the permission of the parents or legal guardian of any minor or without first notifying the city police department of the presence of a minor on the premises owned or operated by or under the control of such person, shall: 
(1)  By any means conceal or shelter, or assist in concealing or sheltering any minor under the age of 18 years while the minor is under the legal custody of the minor's parent or legal guardian and while the minor is on report with any law enforcement agency as a missing person or runaway or a wanted person. 
(2)  Supply false information to or obstruct any police officer in the performance of his/her duty to locate or to take into custody any minor under the age of 18 years. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(9)) 
State Law reference Interference with custody by parents or others, Wis. Stats. § 948.31.  
Secs. 70-23170-253. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - TRUANCY[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
State Law reference Municipal ordinances regarding truancy and school dropouts, Wis. Stats. § 118.163; emergency powers of local governments, Wis. Stats. § 166.23. 
 
Sec. 70-254. - Definitions. 
As used in this division, the following definitions shall apply: 
Habitual truant means a pupil who is absent from school without an acceptable excuse under Wis. Stats. §§ 118.15 and 118.16(4) for part or all of five or more days on which school is held during a school semester. 
Pupil means a child who is at least six years of age and less than 18 years of age, who is required to attend school regularly under the provisions of Wis. Stats. § 118.15. 
Truant means a pupil who is absent from school without an acceptable excuse under Wis. Stats. §§ 118.15 and 118.16(4) for part or all of any day on which school is held during a school semester. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.95(1)) 
State Law reference Similar definitions, Wis. Stats. § 118.163.  
Sec. 70-255. - Prohibited. 
No pupil subject to the state school attendance laws shall be a truant as defined in section 70-254. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.95(2))  
Sec. 70-256. - Penalty. 
(a)  A pupil found by a court of competent jurisdiction to have violated section 70-255 shall be subject to one or more of the following dispositional orders pursuant to Wis. Stats. §§ 48.345 and 118.163: 
(1)  An order for the person to attend school. 
(2)  A forfeiture in the amount provided in section 70-309. 
(b)  The dispositional orders in subsections (a)(1) and (2) of this section are in addition to and do not limit the court's authority under Wis. Stats. ch. 800. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.95(3))  
Sec. 70-257. - Habitual truancyProhibited. 
No pupil subject to the state school attendance laws shall be an habitual truant as defined in section 70-254. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.95(4))  
Sec. 70-258. - SamePenalty. 
(a)  A pupil found by a court of competent jurisdiction to have violated the provisions of section 70-257 shall be subject to one or more of the following dispositional orders pursuant to Wis. Stats. §§ 48.345 and 118.163: 
(1)  Suspension of the person's operating privilege for not less than 30 days or more than one year. The court shall immediately take possession of any suspended license and forward it to the department of transportation together with a notice stating the reason for and the duration of the suspension. 
(2)  An order for the person to participate in counseling or a supervised work program or other community service work as described in Wis. Stats. § 938.34(5g). The costs of any such counseling, supervised work program or other community service work may be assessed against the person, the parents or guardian of the person, or both. Any county department of human services or social services, community agency, public agency or nonprofit charitable organization administering a supervised work program or other community service work to which a person is assigned pursuant to an order under this paragraph acting in good faith has immunity from any civil liability in excess of $25,000.00 for any act or omission by or impacting on that person. 
(3)  An order for the person to remain at home except during hours in which the person is attending religious worship or a school program, including travel time required to get to and from the school program or place of worship. The order may permit a person to leave his/her home if the person is accompanied by a parent or guardian. 
(4)  An order for the person to attend an educational program as described in Wis. Stats. § 938.34(7d). 
(5)  An order for the department of workforce development to revoke, under Wis. Stats. § 103.72, a permit under Wis. Stats. § 103.70 authorizing the employment of the person. 
(6)  An order for the person to be placed in a teen court program as described in Wis. Stats. § 938.342(1g), (f). 
(7)  An order for the person to attend school. 
(8)  All or part of the forfeiture plus costs may be assessed against the person, the parents or guardian of the person, or both. 
(9)  Any other reasonable conditions consistent with this section, including a curfew, restrictions as to going to or remaining on specified premises and restrictions on associating with other children or adults. 
(10)  An order placing the person under formal or informal supervision, as described in Wis. Stats. § 938.34(2), for up to one year. 
(11)  An order for the person's parent, guardian or legal custodian to participate in counseling at the parent's, guardian's or legal custodian's own expense or to attend school with the person, or both. 
(b)  The dispositional orders contained in subsections (a)(1) through (11) of this section are in addition to and do not limit the court's authority under Wis. Stats. ch. 800. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.95(5))  
Secs. 70-25970-279. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - CURFEW 
 
Sec. 70-280. - For persons at least 12 years of age but under the age of 17 years. 
It shall be unlawful for any person at least age 12 years but under the age of 17 years to be upon the streets or alleys or other public places in the city during the following times: 
(1)  From 11:00 p.m. on any Sunday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday or Thursday until 4:00 a.m. of the following day; 
(2)  From 12:00 midnight until 5:00 a.m. on Friday or Saturday, unless accompanied by his/her parent, legal guardian, or an adult with permission of a parent or legal guardian, except when: 
a.  There is an emergency involving serious bodily injury; 
b.  Involved in interstate travel; 
c.  Attending or traveling to or from church, school, a civic event, or work; or 
d.  Otherwise exercising First Amendment rights, protected by the United States Constitution, including free exercise of religion, freedom of speech, and the right of assembly; 
(3)  It shall be unlawful for a parent or legal guardian, or an adult with the permission of a parent or legal guardian, to permit any person under his/her control to be in violation of this division; and 
(4)  A citation may only be issued, and an arrest may only be made, under this section if the issuing or arresting officer asks the minor's age, inquires into the minor's reasons for being upon the streets, alleys or other public place during curfew hours and the issuing or arresting officer reasonably believes this section has been violated and no exception applies. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.09(1); Ord. No. 2004-O-49, §§ 1, 2, 12-14-2004)  
Secs. 70-28170-308. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VIII. - PENALTIES[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
State Law reference Citations for violations of certain ordinances, Wis. Stats. § 66.0113; bond or cash disposition under municipal ordinances, Wis. Stats. § 66.0111.
