Chapter 72 - LANDLORD AND TENANT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Landlord and tenant generally, Wis. Stats. § 704.01 et seq.; untenantability, Wis. Stats. § 704.07; municipal rent control prohibited, Wis. Stats. § 66.1015. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Sec. 72-1. - Definitions. 
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
Affected applicant. In rent abatement categories where the percentage of rent abatement is expressed as a certain percentage or a certain dollar amount "per affected applicant," the abatement applies only to those dwelling units/lodging rooms affected by the violation and only if a tenant therein has applied for rent abatement. 
Affected dwelling unit or lodging room means a dwelling unit or lodging room in which a rent impairing violation exists or a dwelling unit or lodging room in a residential building where a common area violation exists. 
Applicant encompasses the total number of eligible tenants residing in a dwelling unit or lodging room where an eligible tenant has applied for rent abatement and not an individual eligible tenant within the unit or room. 
Authorized agent means a person empowered by landlords, tenants, or tenant unions to represent them. The agent need not be a member of the authorizing group. 
Common area violation means a condition constituting a rent impairing violation which exists in any part of a residential building or lot not contained within a dwelling unit or lodging room. 
Earnest money deposit means the total of any payments or deposits, however denominated or described, given by a prospective tenant to a landlord in return for the option of entering into a rental agreement in the future, or for having a rental application considered by the landlord. 
Eligible tenant means any current or former tenant of a landlord of residential premises where the landlord fails to comply with an order of the building department to correct a rent impairing violation by the original due date in the orders unless that date is found unreasonable by the rent abatement committee, provided that the tenant has lived in an affected dwelling unit for some portion of the time period from the date of the initial inspection by the building inspector to the close of the 15-day period during which a request for abatement hearing may be filed. 
Form provision means a written rule, regulation, or rental or contract provision that has not been specifically and separately negotiated and agreed to by the tenant in writing. Any provision appearing as part of a preprinted form is rebuttably presumed to be a form provision. 
Grievance means any dispute between tenant and landlord over rents or other conditions of tenancy. 
Guest means any person present on the leased premises, with the consent of the current tenant, who is not listed in the lease. 
Landlord means a person or authorized agent, who has the right to exclusive possession of the premises and who, for consideration under a rental agreement, agrees to relinquish that right to another temporarily, retaining a right of reversion in the premises upon the termination of such agreement. 
Only facility means the only appliance of its kind in the dwelling unit or lodging room. 
Owner means one or more persons, jointly or severally vested with all or part of the beneficial ownership and right to present use and enjoyment of the premises. The term "owner" includes a mortgagee in possession. 
Per fixture means per affected appliance regardless of how many separate rent impairing violations may affect that appliance. 
Provider agency means any governmental agency or private social services agency which by contract provides rental assistance on behalf of low-income tenants where such assistance payments are paid directly to the landlord. 
Rent impairing violation means a condition in a dwelling unit, lodging room or other area of a residential building or lot which constitutes or, if not promptly corrected, will constitute a fire hazard or a threat to the health or safety of occupants thereof. Such conditions include, but are not limited to, those which involve deficiencies in security, heating, electricity and/or plumbing. 
Rental agreement means a written or oral agreement embodying and fixing the terms and conditions for the transfer of possession and the use and occupancy of premises whether or not for a definite period of time. 
Residential property means any premises which is used for any residential purpose under the terms of a rental agreement. 
Security deposit means the total of all payments given by a tenant to the landlord as rent in excess of one month's prepaid rent unless the tenant voluntarily prepays the rent. 
Successor tenant means any individual who becomes a tenant in a dwelling unit or lodging room where a prior tenant was authorized or is in the process of being authorized to abate rent pursuant to article III of this chapter and where, at the time the tenancy of the successor tenant commences, there exists an uncorrected rent impairing violation which was determined or is in the process of being determined by a hearing examiner to be abatable. Anyone who succeeds a successor tenant is also a successor tenant, provided that at the time his/her tenancy commences there exists an uncorrected rent impairing violation for which abatement was authorized. 
Tenant means a person, excluding any authorized agent of landlord, entitled to exclusive possession and occupancy of either a mobile home or a dwelling unit and the right to the use of the appropriate appurtenances as provided in a rental agreement, and any other person 18 years of age or over who shares such a unit with the knowledge and consent of the landlord. The term "tenant" applies to persons holding over after termination of tenancy until removed by sheriff's execution of a judicial writ of restitution issued under Wis. Stats. § 799.44. The term "tenant" also applies to person entitled to the return of a security deposit or an accounting for the security deposit. 
Voluntary prepaid rent means rent paid at the tenant's option in advance of the date required by the rental agreement. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.02) 
State Law reference Similar definitions, Wis. Stats. § 704.01.  
Sec. 72-2. - Statement of purpose. 
The city has a significant tenant population and the promotion of equitable landlord-tenant relations is in the interest of citizens of the city. It shall be the policy of the city to encourage equitable landlord-tenant relations and resolution of differences between landlords and tenants. To accomplish these goals, this landlord and tenant code is adopted to establish rights and obligations of landlords and tenants. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.01)  
Sec. 72-3. - Retaliation prohibited: penalty. 
No person shall willfully and maliciously use or attempt to use this Code to harass a landlord or tenant. Harass shall include, but not be limited to, eviction or threats of eviction, inconsistent rent payment increases, failure to perform promised repairs or other harassment. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.14)  
Sec. 72-4. - Tenants rights not waivable. 
Tenant rights established under this chapter shall not be waivable by contract or otherwise.  
Sec. 72-5. - Penalties. 
Penalties for violation of this chapter, unless otherwise specifically provided herein, shall be as provided in section 1-21.  
Secs. 72-672-28. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - RIGHTS AND RESPONSIBILITIES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 72-29. - Tenants rights to privacy and exclusive possession. 
No person within the city shall commit or permit any of the following acts: 
(1)  Removing or altering, without the consent of the tenants therein and the landlord, except as is necessary to preserve or protect the premises in the event of damage or destruction in the tenant's absence locks furnished with the premises or locks affixed to the premises at any time during the tenancy. 
(2)  Removing doors or windows unless for a temporary repair without the consent of the tenant therein and the landlord, except as is reasonably necessary to preserve or protect the premises. 
(3)  Confiscating personal property belonging to tenants or the landlord, in lieu of rent or any other alleged claim. 
(4)  Entering on a tenant's leased property without at least 24 hours' notice unless the tenant approves a shorter period of notice, except when the landlord reasonably believes that entry is necessary to preserve or protect the premises from damage or destruction which is not intentionally caused by the landlord. 
(5)  Unreasonably denying a landlord entry to a dwelling unit if notice has been properly given in accordance with subsection (4) of this section. 
(6)  No landlord may enter a dwelling unit during tenancy without first announcing his/her presence to persons who may be present in the dwelling unit, and identifying himself or herself upon request. 
(7)  A landlord may regulate guests, but may not prohibit a tenant from having all guests. Guest regulations, if any, shall be included in the rental agreement. Guest regulations shall not permit the violation of zoning regulations, including capacity standards, provided in chapter 22. Nothing in these ordinances shall prohibit a landlord from commencing an eviction action against a tenant for permitting person to reside in the tenant's rental unit in violation of this Code or state law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.05)  
Sec. 72-30. - Prohibited rental agreement provisions. 
No rental agreement may: 
(1)  Authorize the eviction or expulsion of a tenant from the premises, other than by judicial eviction procedures as provided under Wis. Stats. ch. 799. 
(2)  Provide for the acceleration of rent payments in the event of tenant default or breach of obligations under the rental agreement or otherwise purport or waive the landlord's obligation to mitigate damages as provided under Wis. Stats. § 704.29. 
(3)  Require payment, by the tenant, of attorney's fees or costs incurred by the landlord in any legal action or dispute arising under the rental agreement. This does not prevent the recovery of costs or attorney's fees pursuant to a court order under Wis. Stats. ch. 799 or 814. 
(4)  Authorize the landlord or any agent of the landlord to confess judgment against the tenant in any action arising under the rental agreement. 
(5)  Relieve, or purport to relieve, the landlord from liability for property damage or personal injury caused by negligent acts or omissions of the landlord. This does not affect ordinary maintenance obligations assumed by the tenant under a rental agreement, in accordance with this article and Wis. Stats. § 704.07. 
(6)  Impose, or purport to impose liability on a tenant for: 
a.  Personal injury arising from causes clearly beyond the tenant's control. 
b.  Property damage caused by natural disasters, or by persons other than the tenant or the tenant's guests or invitees. This does not affect ordinary maintenance obligations assumed by a tenant under a rental agreement, in accordance with this article and Wis. Stats. § 704.07. 
(7)  Provide, by means of a form provision, for the waiver of any statutory or other legal obligation on the part of the landlord to deliver the premises in a fit or habitable condition, or maintain the premises during tenancy except in the event a written agreement is made in which the tenant is contracted to do planned repairs or rehabilitations which are to be completed by a given date. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.10)  
Secs. 72-3172-48. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - EARNEST MONEY DEPOSITS 
 
Sec. 72-49. - Refund or credit. 
If a rental application is rejected by the landlord, the entire amount of any earnest money deposit shall be immediately refunded to the prospective tenant. If a rental agreement is entered into, the entire amount of any earnest money deposit shall be applied toward the payment of rent or a security deposit, or returned to the tenant. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.09(1))  
Sec. 72-50. - Limitations on withholding. 
(a)  No portion of an earnest money deposit may be permanently withheld by a landlord in excess of actual costs and damages incurred because of the failure of a prospective tenant to enter into a rental agreement. Deposits may not be permanently withheld as compensation for lost rents unless the landlord has made reasonable efforts to mitigate the rental loss in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 704.29. 
(b)  Upon request by any person giving an earnest money deposit, the landlord shall provide that person with a written statement accounting for all amounts permanently withheld from the deposit. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.09(2))  
Secs. 72-5172-73. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - SECURITY DEPOSITS 
 
Sec. 72-74. - Purposes. 
The landlord may require as a condition of a rental agreement a security deposit for the purposes provided in this division and for no other purpose. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(1))  
Sec. 72-75. - Limited exemption. 
The amount of the security deposit shall not exceed one month's rent. Landlords who charge an amount less than or equal to 50 percent of one month's rent as a security deposit shall be exempt from the provisions of this division that require the payment of a rent credit. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(2))  
Sec. 72-76. - Rent credit. 
The landlord shall provide a rent credit equivalent to the yearly annual interest rate as published by the public service commission for interest rates on consumer deposits. No rent credit shall be payable, however, for any month or months that rent was paid after the date agreed upon in the rental agreement. The landlord has the burden of proving that the rent was not timely paid for any month for which he/she asserts that no rent credit should be given. Rent credit shall be paid at least annually or within calendar 21 days after termination of the tenancy, whichever occurs sooner. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(3))  
Sec. 72-77. - Receipt. 
Immediately upon accepting any earnest money or security deposit, the landlord shall provide the tenant or prospective tenant with a written receipt for the deposit, stating the nature of the deposit and its amount. A receipt is not required where payment is made by check, money order or bank draft bearing a notation describing the purpose for which it was given, unless requested by the tenant. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(4))  
Sec. 72-78. - Tenant responsibility. 
The tenant shall place the dwelling unit in as overall clean condition as when the tenancy commenced, excepting ordinary wear and tear. Except in cases which there is an agreement to the contrary, charges against the security deposit can only be made if full disclosure was made by the landlord prior to commencement of the lease. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(5))  
Sec. 72-79. - Repairs or cleaning during tenancy. 
If a landlord makes repairs or does cleaning after the beginning of a tenancy, or contracts with tenants or others to do such work, the tenant shall return the premises to the landlord in as good and clean a condition as it was in after such work was done, excepting ordinary wear and tear. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(6))  
Sec. 72-80. - Written check-in and check-out procedure. 
(a)  The landlord and tenant shall use a written check-in and check-out procedure. Upon acceptance of the deposit, the landlord shall inform the tenant that the tenant may inspect the dwelling unit and notify the landlord of any damages or defects which existed before the beginning of the tenancy. The tenancy shall be deemed to start on the first day of the least term or any other date agreed to in writing by both parties. 
(b)  The landlord shall be responsible for the distribution of the blank check-in form and shall retain documented evidence of this. The tenant shall be responsible for the return of the check-in form within seven calendar days after the receipt of the form. 
(c)  The landlord shall furnish the tenant with a written itemized description of any physical damages or defects for which deductions from the previous tenant's security deposit were made. The description shall be furnished to the new tenant before a security deposit is accepted, or at the same time the previous tenant is notified of security deposit deductions. If damages or defects have been repaired by the landlord, this may be noted in connection with the damage description. Disclosure of the previous tenant's identity, or the amounts withheld from the previous tenant's security deposit is not required. 
(d)  All check-out forms shall be comparable to the check-in forms. All check-out forms shall provide an obvious place for the tenant's forwarding address. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(7))  
Sec. 72-81. - Effect of failure to provide or complete form. 
Failure by the landlord to offer either the check-in or check-out forms shall forfeit the landlord's right to withhold any amount from a security deposit for alleged cleaning costs or damages. Failure by the tenant to return the completed check-in form within seven calendar days after beginning of tenancy shall forfeit the tenant's right to claim any preexisting damages. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(8))  
Sec. 72-82. - Return of security deposit. 
Every landlord who accepts a security deposit shall, within 21 calendar days of surrender of the premises to the landlord, return, in person or by mail, to the tenant at the tenant's last known address if a forwarding address is not provided to the landlord, either the full security deposit or a written, itemized statement showing the specific reason for the withholding of the deposit or any portion of the deposit, applicable receipts and estimates including the necessary hours and the wage rate for the work done or to be done. The landlord shall not be held responsible for the inability of the post office to complete delivery of a first class letter. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(9))  
Sec. 72-83. - Forfeiture of deposit. 
If the landlord fails to provide a written statement within the prescribed period in accordance with section 72-82 or fails to comply with the rent credit provisions of section 72-76, the landlord forfeits all rights to any portion of the deposit. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(10))  
Sec. 72-84. - Recovery of damages by tenant. 
If the landlord fails to provide the written statement required under section 72-82 or fails to comply with the rent credit provisions of section 72-76, the tenant may recover damages in an amount up to twice the amount wrongly withheld plus reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(11))  
Sec. 72-85. - Recovery of damages by landlord. 
If the deposit held by the landlord does not cover all the damages done, and/or other amounts owed, by a tenant, and the tenant does not pay to the landlord the amount not covered within 21 calendar days of the landlord's notice, the landlord may recover damages up to twice the money due plus reasonable attorney's fees. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(12))  
Sec. 72-86. - Landlord at termination responsible. 
The holder of the landlord's interest in the premises at the time of the termination of the tenancy is bound by this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(13))  
Sec. 72-87. - No effect on recovery under other laws. 
This section does not preclude the landlord or tenant from recovering other damages to which the landlord or tenant is entitled by other laws. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(14))  
Sec. 72-88. - Reasons for withholding security deposit restricted. 
(a)  Except for reasons clearly agreed in writing at the time the rental agreement is entered into, other than in a form provision, security deposits may be withheld only for tenant damage, waste or neglect of the premises, or the nonpayment of: 
(1)  Rent for which the tenant is legally responsible, subject to Wis. Stats. § 704.29. 
(2)  Actual amounts owed by the tenant for utility service to the extent that the landlord becomes liable for the tenant's nonpayment. 
(3)  Mobile home parking permit fees assessed against the tenant by the city under Wis. Stats. § 66.0435 to the extent that the landlord becomes liable for the tenant's nonpayment. 
(b)  Nothing in this subsection shall be construed as authorizing any withholding for normal wear and tear or other damages or losses for which the tenant is not otherwise responsible under applicable law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(15))  
Sec. 72-89. - False claims against security deposit prohibited. 
No person may intentionally misrepresent or falsify any claim against a security deposit, including the cost of repairs, or withhold or claim the right to any portion of a security deposit pursuant to an intentionally falsified claim. Any person who intentionally misrepresents or falsifies any claim against a security deposit, including the cost of repairs, or withhold or claim the right to any portion of a security deposit, may be subject to paying the money due, together with damages in the amount of up to twice the amount owed and reasonable attorney fees. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.06(16))  
Secs. 72-9072-106. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - INFORMATION DISCLOSURES 
 
Sec. 72-107. - Disclosure of manager and owner. 
(a)  The landlord or any person authorized to enter into a rental agreement on the landlord's behalf shall disclose to the tenant in writing, at or before the execution of a rental agreement whether oral or written, the name and address of: 
(1)  The person authorized to collect or receive rent and manage and maintain the premises, and who can readily be contacted by the tenant; and 
(2)  An owner of the premises or a person authorized to act for and on behalf of the owner for the purpose of service of process and for the purpose of receiving and receipting for notices and demands. The address disclosed shall be an address within the state at which service of process can be made in person. 
(b)  This section does not apply to an owner-occupied structure containing no more than four dwelling units. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.07(1))  
Sec. 72-108. - Code violations and conditions affecting habitability. 
Before entering into a rental agreement or accepting any earnest money or security deposit from the prospective tenant, the landlord or any person authorized to enter into a rental agreement with a prospective tenant shall disclose the following information to the prospective tenant: 
(1)  Rental agreements and rules and regulations established by the landlord, if in writing, shall be furnished to prospective tenants for their inspection before a rental agreement is entered into, and before any earnest money or security deposit is accepted from the prospective tenant. Copies shall be given to the tenant at the time of agreement. 
(2)  The following conditions affecting habitability, the existence of which the landlord knows or reasonable inspection, whether or not notice has been received from code enforcement authorities: 
a.  The dwelling unit lacks hot and cold running water, plumbing or sewage disposal facilities in good operating condition. 
b.  Heating facilities serving the dwelling unit are not in safe operating condition, and are not available to maintain a temperature in the dwelling unit of at least 67 degrees Fahrenheit (19 degrees Celsius) for a 24-hour period during all seasons of the year in which the dwelling unit may be occupied. In circumstances where the tenant is responsible for heating of a dwelling unit, the tenant shall not permit the temperature in the dwelling unit to drop below 55 degrees during any 24-hour period. 
c.  The dwelling unit is not served by electricity, or the electrical wiring, outlets, fixtures or other components of the electrical system are not in safe operating condition. 
d.  Any structural or other conditions in the dwelling unit or premises which constitute a substantial hazard to the health or safety of the tenant, or create an unreasonable risk of personal injury as a result of any reasonably foreseeable use of the premises other than negligent use or abuse of the premises by the tenant. 
(3)  The fact, if true, that charges for water, heat or electricity are not included in the rent and, if individual dwelling units and common areas are not separately metered, and if the charges are not included in the rent, the landlord shall disclose the basis on which charges for utility services will be allocated among individual dwelling units. 
(4)  A copy of any notice of outstanding violation of chapter 37, article III (property maintenance), chapter 22 (zoning), or chapter 35 (buildings and building regulations)as from time to time amended, of which the said landlord or person has actual notice and which affects the subject rental building regardless of the location of the violations or defects therein. Any tenant required to vacate leased premises because of a violation of any of the sections of this Code herein specified is relieved of any further obligation under the lease, if he/she has not received written notification. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.07(2))  
Sec. 72-109. - Notice of change in ownership. 
The information required to be furnished by this section shall be kept current by notification and disclosure of change in ownership within ten calendar days of any such change. This section extends to and is enforceable against any successor landlord, owner or manager. The term "owner," as used in this section, means one or more persons, jointly or severally, in whom is vested: 
(1)  All or part of the legal title to property fee title holders; or 
(2)  All or part of the beneficial ownership and a right to present use and enjoyment of the premises (land contract vendee or mortgagee in possession); and 
(3)  Who may, for consideration under a rental agreement, agree to relinquish rights to exclusive possession to another lessee temporarily, retaining a right of reversion in the premises upon termination of such lease agreement. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.07(3))  
Sec. 72-110. - Agent to receive process, perform obligations. 
Any person authorized to enter into a rental agreement on the landlord's behalf and who fails to comply with sections 72-108 and 72-109, becomes an agent of each person who is a landlord for the purpose of: 
(1)  Service of process and receiving and receipting for notices and demands; and 
(2)  Performing the obligations of the landlord under this section and under the rental agreement and expending or making available for such purpose all rent collected from the premises. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.07(5))  
Sec. 72-111. - Disclosure of automatic renewal clause. 
A provision in a lease of residential property that the lease shall be automatically renewed or extended for a specified period unless the tenant or either party gives notice to the contrary prior to the end of the lease is not enforceable against the tenant unless the lessor, at least 15 calendar days but not more than 30 days prior to the time specified for the giving of such notice to him/her, gives to the tenant written notice in the same manner as specified in Wis. Stats. § 704.21 calling the attention of the tenant to the existence of the provision in the lease for automatic renewal or extension. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.07(7))  
Secs. 72-11272-135. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - PROMISES TO REPAIR 
 
Sec. 72-136. - Date of completion. 
Every promise or representation made by a landlord to a tenant or prospective tenant to the effect that the dwelling unit or any other portion of the premises, including furnishings or facilities, will be cleaned, repaired or otherwise improved by the landlord shall specify the date or time period on or within which the cleaning, repairs or improvements are to be completed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.08(1))  
Sec. 72-137. - Initial promises to be in writing. 
All promises made before the initial rental agreement shall be in writing with a copy furnished to the tenant. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.08(2))  
Sec. 72-138. - Performance; unavoidable delays. 
No landlord shall fail to complete the promised cleaning, repairs or improvements on the date or within the time period represented under section 72-136, unless the delay is for reason of labor stoppage, unavailability of supplies or materials, unavoidable casualties, or other causes beyond the landlord's control. The landlord shall give timely notice to the tenant of reasons beyond the landlord's control for any delay in performance, and stating when the cleaning, repairs or improvements will be completed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.08(3))  
Sec. 72-139. - Private right to recovery. 
Nothing in the provision of this article shall be construed so as to deprive any tenant or prospective tenant from maintaining and prosecuting a private action against a landlord for damages caused by said landlord's failure to comply with any provision of this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.08(4))  
Secs. 72-14072-161. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - REPAIRS AND UNTENANTABILITY 
 
Sec. 72-162. - Applicability. 
This section applies to any tenancy if there is no contrary provision in writing signed by both parties. Nothing in this section is intended to affect rights and duties arising under other provisions of the state statutes. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.12(1))  
Sec. 72-163. - Duty of landlord. 
(a)  Unless the repair was made necessary by the negligence or improper use of the premises by the tenant or the tenant's guests or invitees, the landlord is under a duty to: 
(1)  Keep in reasonable state of repair portions of the premises over which he/she maintains control; 
(2)  Keep in a reasonable state of repair equipment under his/her control necessary to supply services which he/she has expressly or impliedly agreed to furnish the tenant, such as heat, water, elevator or air conditioning; 
(3)  Make necessary structural repairs; 
(4)  Except as provided in section 72-164(b) repair or replace plumbing, electrical wiring, machinery or equipment furnished with the premises and no longer in reasonable working condition. 
(b)  If the premises are part of a building, other parts of which are occupied by one or more other tenants, negligence or improper use by one tenant does not relieve the landlord from his/her duty as to the other tenants to make repairs as provided in subsection (a) of this section. 
(c)  If the premises are damaged by fire, water or other casualty, not the result of the negligence or intentional act of the landlord, this subsection is inapplicable and either section 72-164 or 72-165, governs. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.12(2))  
Sec. 72-164. - Duty of tenant. 
(a)  If the premises are damaged by the negligence or improper use of the premises by the tenant, the tenant must repair the damages and restore the appearance of the premises by redecorating. However, the landlord may elect to undertake the repair or redecoration, and in such case the tenant must reimburse the landlord for the reasonable cost thereof or challenge the costs in writing; the cost to the landlord is presumed reasonable unless proved otherwise by the tenant. 
(b)  The tenant is also under a duty to keep plumbing, electrical wiring, machinery and equipment furnished with the premises in reasonable working order if repair can be made at cost which is minor in relation to the rent. 
(c)  The tenant is under a duty to provide written notice of maintenance problems to the landlord. 
(d)  The tenant shall comply with all obligations upon tenant by applicable minimum standards of building and housing codes. 
(e)  The tenant shall upon termination of the tenancy, place the dwelling unit in as clean condition, excepting normal wear and tear, as when the tenancy commenced. 
(f)  The tenant and/or landlord shall recycle or otherwise dispose of all ashes, rubbish, garbage and other waste from his/her dwelling unit in a safe and clean manner that complies with all local ordinances. 
(g)  The tenant shall use in a reasonable manner all electrical, plumbing, sanitary, heating, ventilating, air conditioning and other facilities and appliances, including elevators, in the premises. Reasonable manner includes complying with all applicable codes, ordinances, rules and regulations. 
(h)  The tenant shall not deliberately or negligently destroy, deface, damage, impair or remove any part of the premises or knowingly permit any guest to do so. 
(i)  The tenant shall conduct himself/herself and require other persons on the premises with his/her consent to conduct themselves in a manner that will not disturb his/her neighbor's peaceful enjoyment of the premises. 
(j)  If a tenant by his/her actions causes a code violation resulting in the issuance of a citation for building or zoning or fire code violations, the tenant shall be responsible for the cost of the citation and correcting the violation. 
(k)  The landlord shall conduct himself/herself and require persons on the premises with the consent of the landlord to conduct themselves in a manner that will not disturb the tenants' peaceful enjoyment thereof. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.12(3))  
Sec. 72-165. - Untenantability because of damage of fire, water or other casualty, or hazard to health. 
(a)  If the premises becomes untenantable because of damage by fire, water or other casualty or because of any condition hazardous to health, the tenant may remove from the premises unless the landlord proceeds promptly to repair or rebuild or eliminate the health hazard; or the tenant may remove if the inconvenience to the tenant by reason of the nature and period of repair, rebuilding or elimination would impose undue hardship on him/her. 
(b)  If the tenant justifiably moves out under this subsection, the tenant is not liable for rent after the premises become untenantable or the date the tenant removes from the premises, whichever is later, and the landlord must repay any rent paid in advance apportioned to the period after the premises become untenantable or the date the tenant removes from the premises, whichever is later. 
(c)  This subsection is inapplicable if the damage or condition is caused by negligence or improper use by the tenant or the tenant's guests or invitees. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.12(4))  
Secs. 72-16672-183. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 7. - PROHIBITED PRACTICES 
 
Sec. 72-184. - Advertising or rental of condemned premises. 
No landlord may rent or advertise for rent any premises which have been placarded and condemned for human habitation, or on which a notice of intent to placard or condemn, or an order to raze, or to rehabilitate or raze, or any similar order has been received under state or local laws or ordinances, until and unless all repairs required to bring the property into compliance with the laws or ordinances have been completed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.11(1))  
Sec. 72-185. - Automatic lease renewal without notice. 
No landlord shall enforce, or attempt to enforce, an automatic renewal or extension provision in any lease unless, as provided under Wis. Stats. § 704.15, the tenant was given separate written notice in accordance with Wis. Stats. § 704.21 of the pending automatic renewal or extension at least 15 days, but not more than 30 days prior to the time specified for giving of notice to the landlord. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.11(2))  
Sec. 72-186. - Confiscation of personal property. 
No landlord shall seize or hold a tenant's personal property, or otherwise prevent the tenant from having access to or removing the tenant's personal property, except as authorized under Wis. Stats. §§ 704.05(5) and 779.43, or a lien agreement entered into in writing other than in a form provision. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.11(3))  
Sec. 72-187. - Retaliatory eviction. 
No landlord shall terminate a tenancy or give notice preventing the automatic renewal of a lease, or constructively evict a tenant by means of the termination or substantial reduction of heat, water or electricity to the dwelling unit, in retaliation against a tenant because the tenant has: 
(1)  Reported a violation of this chapter or a building or housing code to any governmental authority, or filed suit alleging such violation; 
(2)  Joined or attempted to organize a tenant's union or association; or 
(3)  Asserted, or attempted to assert any right specifically accorded to tenants under state or local law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.11(4))  
Sec. 72-188. - Failure to deliver possession. 
No landlord shall fail to deliver possession of the dwelling unit to the tenant at the time agreed upon in the rental agreement, except where the landlord is unable to deliver possession because of circumstances beyond the landlord's control, nor shall a tenant fail to deliver possession of the dwelling unit to the landlord at the time agreed upon in the rental agreement. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.11(5))  
Sec. 72-189. - Rent absconding. 
No tenant of residential property which the tenant is entitled to occupy shall intentionally abscond without paying all current and past rent due unless the tenant has provided the landlord with a security deposit equal to or exceeding the amount owed for rent and damage to property or pays all current and past rent due within five days after vacating the rental premises or within said five days provides the landlord in writing a complete and accurate forwarding address. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.11(6))  
Secs. 72-19072-216. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - RENT ABATEMENT  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 72-217. - Statement of intent. 
The common council hereby finds that in order to ensure the proper repair and maintenance of residential buildings within the city, to prevent the deterioration and neglect of such structures to the protection of the health and safety of the people of the city and to further enforcement of and compliance with the building and property maintenance codes of the city, it is necessary, in the case of uncorrected rent impairing violations, that tenants residing in the city be authorized to abate an appropriate portion of their rental payments under the provisions of this section. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(1))  
Sec. 72-218. - Other remedies of tenant. 
The right of a tenant to abate a portion of the rent as provided in this article shall not preclude or affect in any way the tenant's right to abate under Wis. Stats. ch. 704; nor shall it preclude or affect in any way the tenant's or landlord's right to any of the remedies provided by the laws of the state and this Code pertaining to the relationship of landlord and tenant. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(b))  
Sec. 72-219. - Other remedies of city. 
It is the intent of this section that any use of abatement will not prohibit the building inspection department from prosecuting violations of this Code relating to said property. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(8))  
Sec. 72-220. - Eviction or retaliation prohibited. 
(a)  No person or tenant who complains to the building inspection department of violations of chapters 22, 35, 37 or this chapter or complies with this section shall be evicted for nonpayment of rent or because said person or tenant has elected to act under said section, so long as rent is being abated in accordance with the provisions of this article or Wis. Stats. ch. 704. 
(b)  In addition, no tenant shall be evicted for nonpayment of rent where the tenant continues to abate rent pursuant to a lawful order of a hearing examiner pending judicial review of the order after a stay of the hearing examiner's decision has been ordered by the reviewing court, if written notice of the request for judicial review was not given to the tenant in accordance with section 72-373. 
(c)  Furthermore, no tenant who has been authorized to abate a portion of his/her rental payment shall be evicted for failure to pay rent as a result of underpayment of rent due to a computation error, so long as the tenant remedies the underpayment within five days after notice thereof by the landlord. 
(d)  No person or tenant shall be evicted or retaliated against for complaining of violations of chapters 22, 35, 37 or this chapter or for complying with this section, and it shall be presumed that any attempt to terminate the tenancy of such tenant or to evict such tenant or to raise such tenant's rental payments or to otherwise harass or retaliate against such tenant during the period from the first complaint to the building inspection department to six months after the certification by the building inspection department of the city that all violations have been corrected is done in retaliation for the tenant's complaint to the building inspection department of a violation of chapters 22, 35, 37 or this chapter or for his/her compliance with this section. Said attempt is hereby declared null and void and subject to a forfeiture for each such attempt. It is further provided that in order to overcome such presumption, the landlord must show by a preponderance of the evidence that such acts by him/her were based upon good cause. 
(e)  The term "good cause," as used in this section, means that the landlord must show a good reason for his/her action, other than one related to or caused by the operation of this chapter, including but not limited to normal uniform rental increases due to utility increases or other increased costs to landlord, or for other bonafide, nondiscriminatory business reason. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(7))  
Sec. 72-221. - PenaltiesUnlawful acquisition of rent abatement. 
Any person who accepts, as a result of misrepresentation, harassment or coercion, rental payments for premises subject to abatement under this article may be subject to a forfeiture whether said rental payments are tendered by or on behalf of the tenant occupying the premises at the time abatement is authorized or by, or on behalf of, any subsequent or other tenant who occupies the premises during the existence of such abatement authorization. Each such payment accepted shall constitute a separate violation.  
Sec. 72-222. - SameUse of this article to harass landlord. 
Any tenant who willfully and maliciously uses or attempts to use this article to harass a landlord shall be fined. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(9))  
Sec. 72-223. - SameAll other violations. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this section shall upon conviction be subject to a forfeiture unless a different penalty is specifically provided, with each separate day of violation to be considered a separate offense. 
(b)  Any person who shall fail or neglect to comply with any lawful order of the rent abatement hearing examiner issued pursuant to the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a violation of this section, and every day or fraction thereof on which such person shall fail or neglect to comply with such order, shall be deemed a separate offense. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(10))  
Secs. 72-22472-254. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - OVERSIGHT COMMITTEE 
 
Sec. 72-255. - Composition. 
The city has established a committee of the city called the rent abatement oversight committee. The rent abatement oversight committee consists of the three members of the public safety committee who shall be appointed by the president of the common council and subject to confirmation by the common council. The city clerk or his/her designee shall serve, without voting privileges, as secretary to the committee and shall keep a detailed record of all proceedings. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.03(1))  
Sec. 72-256. - Duties. 
The rent abatement oversight committee shall have the following powers and duties: 
(1)  To adopt such rules and regulations, subject to approval by the common council, as may be necessary to carry out the purpose and provisions of the rent abatement process in this article. 
(2)  To recommend to the common council additions to, deletions from, and changes in the schedule of rent impairing violations in section 72-345 as well as other provisions in this chapter. 
(3)  To approve forms for the use of tenants, landlords, the building inspection department and rent abatement hearing examiners to facilitate the rent abatement process in this article. 
(4)  To institute procedures for the selection of rent abatement hearing examiners, for the setting of a time and place for rent abatement hearings and for the giving of notice thereof to interested landlords and tenants within ten days of the filing of a request for a hearing concerning authorization for rent abatement with the building inspection department. 
(5)  To establish criteria and procedures for waiving the filing fee in cases of economic hardship. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.03(2))  
Sec. 72-257. - Staff. 
The building inspection department shall provide staff support for the rent abatement hearing examiners and shall receive and retain all documents, reports and records relating thereto. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.03(3))  
Sec. 72-258. - Designation of rent impairing violations. 
The common council shall adopt a list of violations of the provisions of chapters 22, 35, 37 and this chapter to be classified as "rent impairing," as the term is defined in section 72-1. Said list shall contain a brief description of the condition constituting the violation, the section of the ordinances violated and the percentage range of possible rent abatement. The rent abatement committee may at any time recommend a change in the number of violations, their descriptions or the percentage of possible rent abatement for a particular violation but no such change shall be made except in the manner set forth above. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(c))  
Secs. 72-25972-279. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 3. - NOTICES AND DISCLOSURES 
 
Sec. 72-280. - Notice to tenant of code violations and right to abate rent. 
The landlord or any person authorized to enter into a rental agreement shall exhibit to the prospective tenant, prior to the time a rental agreement is entered into, the following: 
(1)  A copy of any official notice of outstanding violation of this Code that the landlord or person has actual notice and which affects the subject rental building regardless of the location of the violations or defects therein and a copy of any hearing examiner decision and order which affects the subject rental unit or any common areas of the subject rental building. The failure by a landlord to comply with the provisions of this subsection regarding written notice of a successor tenant's right to abate rent shall not be subject to the penalties set forth in section 1-21. 
(2)  In addition, prior to the time a rental agreement is entered into, the landlord shall advise the prospective tenant in writing of a successor tenant's right to abate rent pursuant to the order aforementioned until authorization to abate ceases as provided in section 72-346. In cases where the rent abatement request is pending at the time the rental agreement is entered into, the landlord shall provide the successor tenant written notification of a successor tenant's rights when the case has been decided and shall exhibit a copy of the decision and order to the successor tenant upon receipt thereof. 
(3)  At the time occupancy commences the landlord shall exhibit to the tenant (formerly, a prospective tenant) a copy of all additional official notices referred to in subsection (1) of this section and a copy of all decisions and orders referred to in subsection (2) of this section, if any have been issued since the signing of the rental agreement. Similarly, at the time of occupancy the landlord shall provide the required written notice of a successor tenant's rights with respect to all such additional official notices and decisions. 
(4)  The written notice of successor tenant's rights shall specifically state in underlined or otherwise emphasized print the following: 
"If you wish to become a successor tenant and to abate rent in accordance with chapter 72 of the Fitchburg Code of Ordinances you must provide your landlord and the building inspection department of the city with written notice of that intent within fifteen calendar (15) days of receiving written notification from your landlord of your right as a successor tenant to abate rent. Failure to provide your landlord with timely written notice forfeits your right to be a "successor tenant" and to abate rent as a successor tenant under chapter 72 of the Fitchburg Code of Ordinances." 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(6))  
Sec. 72-281. - Weekly publication and service of notice of uncorrected rent-impairing violations. 
(a)  A list of addresses of rental properties with uncorrected rent-impairing violations shall be published each week in the official city paper within ten calendar days of the reinspection which reveals noncompliance. Such notice shall indicate that the tenants may be eligible for rent abatement and shall state that any such tenant must request authorization to abate rent within 30 calendar days of publication of the notice of eligibility by the building inspection department of the city. 
(b)  A copy of the notice shall also be sent by first class mail, addressed to the occupant at each rental unit with uncorrected rent impairing violations, on or before the date of publication of the notice. Together with the copy of the notice, there shall be mailed a cover letter including, but not limited to, the following information: Notice of eligibility to apply for rent abatement, the owner of your apartment has not followed an order from the city building inspection department to correct housing code violations. Because the owner has not complied, you may be able to get a portion of your rent back pursuant to this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(2))  
Secs. 72-28272-310. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 4. - ELIGIBILITY 
 
Sec. 72-311. - Uncorrected rent impairment. 
(a)  Notwithstanding any other provision of law or any agreement, whether oral or written, tenants and provider agencies shall be eligible to abate a portion of the total rental payments, in accordance with this section and pursuant to the order of a rent abatement hearing examiner or by written agreement of the parties, if the landlord of the residential premises fails to comply with an order of the building inspection department to correct by the original due date, unless such due date is found to be unreasonable upon appeal to the rent abatement committee, a violation which is rent impairing, as that term is defined in section 72-1. 
(b)  Any such order of the building inspection department shall specifically state that uncorrected violations may be eligible for abatement in addition to any other penalties provided by law. A tenant's eligibility to abate rent shall apply only to the eligible tenant or successor tenant upon whose rented premises the uncorrected rent impairing violation exists or to any eligible tenant or successor tenant in a building with an uncorrected rent impairing violation in a common area. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(a))  
Sec. 72-312. - Provider agent; joint payment to provider agency and tenant. 
(a)  A provider agency's ability to abate rent shall apply only to provider agencies which pay or have paid a portion of an eligible tenant's rent while an uncorrected rent impairing violation exists on the premises or common area of the eligible tenant's building. 
(b)  Where an award is made and rent has been paid by both a tenant and a provider agency, the tenant's portion of the award shall be up to but not greater than the amount of rent the tenant has paid. Where the award amount is less than or equal to the amount of rent the tenant paid, the tenant shall receive all of the award. 
(c)  No rent may be abated pursuant to this article until abatement is ordered by the rent abatement hearing examiner or authorized by written agreement between the parties. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(a))  
Sec. 72-313. - Successor tenant. 
(a)  A successor tenant is entitled to abate rent pursuant to the order of a rent abatement hearing examiner issued in accordance with this chapter, provided that at the time the tenancy commences there exists an uncorrected rent impairing violation which was determined or is in the process of being determined by the hearing examiner to be abatable. 
(b)  In order to be deemed a successor tenant under this article an otherwise eligible individual must advise the landlord in writing with a copy to the building inspection department of his/her intent no later than 15 calendar days after receipt of written notification by the landlord which conforms to the requirements of section 72-280 regardless of whether said written notification is given within the times prescribed therein. If said written notification is given at or prior to the time the rental agreement is entered into, the successor tenant's notice of intent must be given no later than 15 calendar days after the commencement of the successor tenancy. 
(c)  Failure to provide the landlord with a timely written notice of intent to become a successor tenant forfeits a tenant's right to proceed to abate rent as a successor tenant under this chapter, except where the landlord has failed to provide the written notification of the tenant's right to abate rent pursuant to subsection (b) of this section. In cases where the landlord fails to provide written notice as required, an otherwise eligible tenant may assert the rights of a successor tenant at any time during the tenancy or in any action relating to or arising out of the tenancy. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(4))  
Secs. 72-31472-344. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 5. - AMOUNT AND DURATION OF ABATEMENT 
 
Sec. 72-345. - Schedule of rent impairing violations. 
A tenant authorized to abate rent shall do so in accordance with the following schedule with the precise amount to be set by the rent abatement hearing examiner after notice and hearing pursuant to sections 72-366 through 72-369. The maximum total abatement authorized pursuant to this article shall not exceed 95 percent of the periodic rental payment, except where the premises have been vacated pursuant to an order of the director of the building inspection department or pursuant to any other tenant right to remove from residential rental premises secured under state law.
