Sec. 72-346. - Duration of abatement. 
(a)  Authorization to abate a portion of the rent pursuant to this article for failure of a landlord to correct a rent impairing violation ceases upon certification by the building inspection department that said violation has been satisfactorily corrected, except that a tenant, a provider agency or successor tenant shall not be required to reimburse any appropriately abated portion of the rent to a landlord where correction of the rent impairing violation was made after payment of the balance of the rental payment had been tendered to the landlord. Where more than one rent impairing violation has been authorized for rent abatement and partial correction has been certified, authorization to abate continues for the uncorrected rent impairing violations, until such time as their satisfactory correction has been verified. 
(b)  If abatement is authorized, the landlord must promptly repay any rent previously paid by the tenant, provider agency or successor tenant and apportioned to rent impairing violations from the date of the original inspection by the building inspection department at which said violations were discovered. 
(c)  If the landlord fails to promptly reimburse the tenant, provider agency or successor tenant as required in subsection (b) of this section, the tenant, provider agency or successor tenant may enforce the order requiring reimbursement as follows: 
(1)  The tenant, provider agency or successor tenant may deduct the amount previously paid and subsequently determined to be apportioned to rent impairing violations from future rental payments. 
(2)  If the total of future rental payments payable for the balance of the tenancy is less than the reimbursement required in subsection (b) of this section or if the tenant or successor tenant no longer resides at the premises in question, the tenant, provider agency or successor tenant shall recover from the landlord double the amount not reimbursed in accordance with the order of the hearing examiner plus costs of collection including reasonable attorney fees. 
(d)  The failure of a landlord to promptly reimburse the tenant, provider agency or successor tenant as required in subsection (b) of this section and the failure of either a landlord, a tenant or a provider agency after a decision by the reviewing court on judicial review, to return monies wrongfully not reimbursed or wrongfully abated shall be deemed a violation of this article and shall be punishable pursuant to section 72-223. 
(e)  Rent abatement awarded in a decision and order of a rent abatement hearing examiner shall accrue during the period when either a tenant or a successor tenant is entitled to the exclusive possession and occupancy of an affected dwelling unit. Under no circumstances shall there be recovery by both a tenant and a successor tenant for the same period of time. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(5))  
Secs. 72-34772-365. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 6. - PROCEDURE 
 
Sec. 72-366. - Application for authorization for rent abatement; request for hearing; fees. 
(a)  An eligible tenant who may be entitled to abate a portion of his/her rental payment under this article shall have 30 calendar days from publication of the notice of possible eligibility by the building inspection department of the city to file a request for a hearing on authorization for rent abatement. The request shall be in writing on a form approved by the rent abatement oversight committee, shall state with specificity the name and address of the landlord and the alleged rent impairing violation and shall be filed with the building inspection department. 
(b)  The application shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount provided in the city fee schedule made payable to the city treasurer, which fee shall be recovered from the landlord if abatement is ordered. If the applicant qualifies for waiver of the filing fees, however, the application shall be accompanied by an affidavit of economic hardship signed by the applicant. 
(c)  Within ten calendar days of the filing of the request, the building inspection department staff shall select a hearing examiner from the rent abatement hearing examiner panel, set a time and place for the hearing and give the landlord and the tenant written notice thereof. The hearing shall be held as soon as possible, but not prior to the end of the 30-calendar-day filing period. 
(d)  Notice of the hearing including a statement of the time, place and nature of the hearing shall be mailed to the landlord and tenant at least ten calendar days prior to the hearing. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(e)(1))  
Sec. 72-367. - Hearing examiner authority. 
(a)  The rent abatement hearing examiner shall have the authority to conduct hearings on requests for authorization for rent abatement and to determine the exact amount of rent, if any, which may be abated pursuant to this article. 
(b)  The rent abatement hearing examiner shall have the authority to administer oaths and to issue subpoenas pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 885.01 at the request of the parties and shall be responsible for the fair, orderly and impartial conduct of the rent abatement hearing and the preservation of the exhibits and the record therein. 
(c)  In any matter set for hearing the rent abatement hearing examiner may hold a conference between the parties to attempt to clarify or simplify the issues. In addition, prior to the hearing, upon request of the parties the hearing examiner may function as a mediator to encourage voluntary settlement. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(e)(2))  
Sec. 72-368. - Conduct of hearing. 
(a)  The rent abatement hearing examiner shall conduct the hearing on the request for authorization for rent abatement, shall administer oaths to all witnesses and may issue subpoenas upon request of the parties. The landlord and the tenant may be represented by counsel or other representatives, may call and examine witnesses and cross examine witnesses of the other party. 
(b)  All proceedings and testimony shall be recorded on tape. If a review is sought of the hearing examiner's decision, a written transcript shall be prepared at a cost to the requesting parties determined by the hourly staff rate plus a reasonable fee for copies. For all purposes, a copy of the tape recordings shall be supplied to anyone requesting the same at the requester's expense. If either party requests a stenographic recording and transcription, the building inspection department shall make the necessary arrangements, but the expense shall be borne by the requesting party. 
(c)  In the hearing, the tenant shall have the burden of proving to a reasonable certainty by the greater weight of the credible evidence, (i.e., by the preponderance of the evidence,) that the landlord failed to correct rent impairing violations by the due date in an order of the building inspection department. 
(d)  It is the landlord's burden to show by the preponderance of the evidence that any rent impairing violations were negligently or willfully caused by the tenant or the tenant's guests or that the tenant's refusal to allow entry prevented the landlord from making the corrections in a timely manner. Thereafter, the tenant has the burden to show that any such refusal was reasonable under the circumstances. 
(e)  Either party may present additional evidence on the nature, extent and seriousness of violations, the length of time conditions existed and the extent to which the tenant was deprived of the full use of the rented premises, to assist in determining the percent of abatement which should be allowed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(e)(3))  
Sec. 72-369. - Decision. 
(a)  In favor of tenant. 
(1)  If, on the evidence at the hearing, the rent abatement hearing examiner finds that the landlord failed to comply with an order of the building inspection department to correct by the original due date a rent impairing violation as that term is defined in section 72-1, the hearing examiner shall order that rent be abated retroactive to the date of the initial inspection in order to effectuate the purpose of this article and to provide fair and equitable compensation to the tenant for the diminished value of the rented premises due to the landlord's continued violation of the city's building/housing codes. 
(2)  Any such abatement shall be established in accordance with the schedule of rent impairing violations in section 72-345. In setting the exact percentage of abatement the hearing examiner shall consider the nature, extent and seriousness of the particular conditions, the total number of rent impairing violations at issue, the length of time the conditions existed and the extent to which the conditions deprive the tenant of full use of the rented premises. 
(3)  If the hearing examiner finds that the landlord's failure to comply with the order of the building inspection department by the due date was caused by factors wholly outside the landlord's control and if the hearing examiner further finds that the landlord has taken affirmative steps to minimize the impact of the uncorrected rent-impairing conditions on the tenant, any sums reasonably expended by the landlord in that regard should be considered in setting the percentage of abatement and may operate to reduce the final abatement percentage below the minimum percentage listed for the items in the schedule of rent impairing violations in section 72-345. 
(4)  The hearing examiner shall not authorize rent abatement for any conditions found to be caused either negligently or willfully by the tenant or his/her guests, nor shall abatement be ordered for any period of time after the tenant has unreasonably refused entry to the landlord for the purpose of correcting the conditions giving rise to the violations. 
(b)  In favor of landlord. 
(1)  If, after hearing, the hearing examiner finds that the landlord did not fail to comply with an order of the building inspection department to correct a rent impairing violation by the due date or that the rent impairing violations were caused by the tenant or the tenant's guests or that the tenant unreasonably refused entry for the purpose of correcting a rent impairing violation, the hearing examiner shall enter an order denying the request for authorization to abate rent for any items negligently or willfully caused by the tenant or guests of the tenant or for any items which remained uncorrected due to the tenant's unreasonable refusal to allow entry for repair purposes. 
(2)  Where the landlord has received a list of code violations requiring correction within 72 hours or less, a refusal by the tenant to allow entry after reasonable notice of less than 24 hours may be deemed an unreasonable refusal solely for the purpose of determining whether rent abatement shall be awarded for the violation which was the subject of the official notice. 
(c)  Time for service of written findings; effect of failure to comply. The decision and order of the hearing examiner shall contain written findings and shall be mailed to the parties within seven calendar days of completion of the hearing or as soon thereafter as possible. The failure to issue and mail a decision within seven calendar days shall neither deprive the hearing examiner of jurisdiction to render a final decision in the matter nor affect the validity thereof. 
(d)  Persons upon whom decision is binding. Except as provided in section 72-313 relating to the rights of successor tenants, the holder of the landlord's interest in the premises at the time the decision and order of the hearing examiner is issued and the holder of the landlord's interest during the period of time that the right to continuing abatement remains in effect are bound by the order and by the applicable provisions of this chapter relating to rent abatement. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(e)(4))  
Sec. 72-370. - Petition for reconsideration. 
(a)  Within ten calendar days after service by mail of the decision of the hearing examiner, either party may file with the building inspection department a written petition for reconsideration specifying in detail the grounds for the relief sought. In addition, a hearing examiner may, on his/her own motion, reconsider the decision or order a hearing on reconsideration. Reconsideration will be granted only on the basis of: 
(1)  A material error of fact or law or an error in the calculation of an award amount; or 
(2)  Where the landlord's or tenant's failure to appear at the hearing was due solely to extraordinary, justifiable and unforeseeable circumstances beyond his/her control, which circumstances prevented attendance at the hearing. Petitions for reconsideration based on a tenant's or landlord's failure to appear must contain a sworn, notarized statement describing factually and in detail those extraordinary circumstances which caused the petitioner's non-appearance. In addition, said petition must be received by the building inspection department by 4:30 p.m. on the first business day following the hearing date or be deemed untimely. 
(b)  Copies of the petition shall be served by first class mail by the petitioner on all parties, who may file replies within seven calendar days after service by mail of the petition. 
(c)  Within 21 calendar days of the filing of the petition, the hearing examiner shall enter an order denying reconsideration or an order granting reconsideration disposing of the petition without a hearing or shall order a rehearing, which shall be held within 20 calendar days. The failure to issue a decision within the specified time period shall not deprive the hearing examiner of jurisdiction to render a decision on reconsideration or affect the validity thereof. If no order is entered within 21 calendar days of the filing of the petition, the petition shall be deemed denied. 
(d)  Upon rehearing, if any, proceedings shall conform as nearly as may be to sections 72-366 through 72-369, relating to an original hearing. 
(e)  The filing of a petition for rehearing shall not suspend or delay the effective date of the original decision and order, and the order shall take effect on the date fixed by the hearing examiner and shall continue in effect unless the petition is granted or until the order is superseded, modified, or set aside as provided by law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(f))  
Sec. 72-371. - Request for modification. 
If, subsequent to a decision by a hearing examiner ordering rent abatement, substantial further deterioration or substantial improvement occurs in any rent impairing conditions which were the subject of the original order, the applicant, landlord or any successor tenant may request modification of the rent abatement amount. Only one such request for modification may be made by each eligible individual, which request shall follow the procedures in sections 72-366 through 72-369, relating to the original application. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(g))  
Sec. 72-372. - Enforcement. 
Whenever, in the judgment of the rent abatement oversight committee, the judicial enforcement of this article is necessary, the committee shall in writing request the city attorney to enforce this article in the name of the city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(h))  
Sec. 72-373. - Appeal. 
(a)  All orders of the rent abatement hearing examiner shall be final administrative determinations and shall be subject to review in court as by law may be provided. Any party to the proceeding may seek review thereof within 30 calendar days of service by mail of the final determination of the hearing examiner. In addition, written notice of any request for judicial review shall be given by the party seeking review to all parties who appeared at the proceeding before the hearing examiner, with said notice to be sent by first class mail to each party's last known address. 
(b)  The institution of the proceeding for judicial review shall not stay the decision and order of the hearing examiner; however, the reviewing court may order a stay upon such terms as it deems proper. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 28.04(3)(i))  
Chapter 74 - NUISANCES[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference Jurisdiction over nuisances, Wis. Stats. § 823.01; collection of expenses for abatement of nuisances, Wis. Stats. § 823.06. 
 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 
 
Secs. 74-174-18. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE II. - PUBLIC NUISANCES 
 
Sec. 74-19. - Prohibited; defined. 
No person shall erect, contrive, continue, cause, maintain or permit to exist any public nuisance within the city. For purposes of this article, the term "public nuisance" is defined as a thing, act, occupation condition or use of property which shall continue for such a length of time as to: 
(1)  Substantially annoy, injure or endanger the comfort, health, repose or safety of the public; 
(2)  In any way render the public insecure in life or in the use of property; 
(3)  Greatly offend the public morals or decency; or 
(4)  Unlawfully and substantially interfere with, obstruct or tend to obstruct or render dangerous for passage any street, alley, highway, navigable body of water, or other public way or the use of public property. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.13(1))  
Sec. 74-20. - Affecting health. 
The following acts, omissions, places, conditions and things are hereby specifically declared to be public health nuisances, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other health nuisances coming within the definition of section 74-19: 
(1)  All decayed, harmfully adulterated or unwholesome food or drink provided or offered for sale to the public. 
(2)  Carcasses or excrement of animals, birds, or fowl which are not buried or otherwise disposed of in a sanitary manner within 24 hours. 
(3)  Accumulations of decayed animal or vegetable matter, trash, rubbish, rotting lumber, bedding, packing material, scrap metal, or any material whatsoever in which insects, rats, or other vermin may breed. 
(4)  All stagnant water in which mosquitoes, flies, or other insects can multiply. 
(5)  Privy vaults and garbage cans which are not flytight. 
(6)  All noxious weeds and other rank growth of vegetation. 
(7)  All animals running at large. 
(8)  The escape of smoke, soot, cinders, noxious acids, fumes, gases, dust, fly ash, industrial dust, or other atmospheric pollutants within the city limits or within one mile therefrom in such quantities as to endanger the health of persons or to threaten or cause substantial injury to property in the city. 
(9)  Set any fire or blast on any land, burn in a dump or engage in open burning in, or within 100 feet of the boundary of, any residential subdivision, or commercial, or mixed use district. 
(10)  Any use of property, substances, or things within the city emitting or causing any toxic, foul, offensive, noisome, nauseous, noxious or disagreeable odors, gases, dust, effluvia, or stenches extremely repulsive to the physical senses of ordinary persons which annoy, discomfort, injure, or inconvenience the health of any appreciable number of persons within the city. 
(11)  All abandoned wells not securely covered or secured from public use. 
(12)  Any use of property which shall cause any nauseous or unwholesome liquid or substance to flow into or upon any street, gutter, alley, sidewalk, or public place within the city or the pollution of any public well or cistern, stream, lake, canal, or other body of water by sewage, creamery, or industrial wastes or other substances. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.13(2)) 
State Law reference Adulterated food defined, Wis. Stats. § 97.02; sale of adulterated food prohibited, Wis. Stats. § 97.10; lodging and food protection, Wis. Stats. § 254.61 et seq.; municipal authority to prohibit emission of smoke, Wis. Stats. § 254.57; disposition of animal carcasses, Wis. Stats. § 95.50; municipal authority to regulate disposition of animal carcasses, Wis. Stats. § 254.58; municipal authority to abate human health hazards, Wis. Stats. § 254.59.  
Sec. 74-21. - Offending morals and decency. 
The following acts, omissions, places conditions and things are hereby specifically declared to be public nuisances offending public morals and decency, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances offending public morals and decency coming within the definition of section 74-19. 
(1)  All disorderly houses, gambling houses, and building or structures kept or resorted to for the purpose of prostitution, promiscuous sexual intercourse or gambling. 
(2)  All gambling devices and slot machines. 
(3)  All places where intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverages are sold, possessed, stored, brewed, bottled, manufactured, or rectified without a permit or license as provided for by the laws of the state and/or this Code. 
(4)  Any place or premises within the city where city ordinances or state laws relating to public health, safety, peace, morals, or welfare are openly, continuously, repeatedly, and intentionally violated. 
(5)  Any place or premises resorted to for the purpose of drinking intoxicating liquor or fermented malt beverages in violation of the laws of the state or city. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.13(3)) 
State Law reference Gambling, Wis. Stats. § 945.01 et seq.; gambling place as public nuisance, Wis. Stats. § 823.20; keeping a place of prostitution, Wis. Stats. § 944.34; bawdyhouses as nuisance, Wis. Stats. § 823.09; disorderly house, Wis. Stats. § 823.10; drug or criminal gang house as public nuisance, Wis. Stats. § 823.113.  
Sec. 74-22. - Affecting peace and safety. 
The following acts, omissions, places, conditions, and things are hereby declared to be public nuisances affecting peace and safety, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances affecting peace or safety coming within the provisions of section 74-19: 
(1)  All signs and billboards, awnings, or other similar structures over or near streets, sidewalks, public grounds or places frequented by the public, so situated or constructed as to endanger the public safety. 
(2)  All buildings erected, repaired, or altered within the fire limits of the city in violation of the provisions of this Code, relating to materials and manner of construction of buildings and structures within said district. 
(3)  All unauthorized signs, signals, markings, or devices placed or maintained upon or in view of any public highway or railway crossing, which purport to be or may be mistaken as an official traffic control device, railroad sign or signal or which because of its color, location, brilliance, or manner of operation interferes with the effectiveness of any such device, sign, or signal. 
(4)  All trees, hedges, billboards, vehicles, or other obstructions which prevent persons driving vehicles on public streets, alleys, or highways from obtaining a clear view of traffic when approaching an uncontrolled intersection or pedestrian crosswalk. 
(5)  All limbs of trees which project over and less than seven feet above the surface of a public sidewalk or street or less than 12 feet above any other public place. 
(6)  All use or display of fireworks except as provided by the laws of the state and this Code. 
(7)  All buildings or structures so old, dilapidated, or out of repair as to be dangerous, unsafe, unsanitary, or otherwise unfit for human use. 
(8)  All wires over streets, alleys, or public grounds which are strung less than 15 feet above the surface thereof. 
(9)  All loud, discordant, and unnecessary noises or vibrations of any kind. 
(10)  The keeping or harboring of any animal or fowl, which habitually disturbs the peace and quiet of any person in the vicinity of the place where such animal is kept. 
(11)  All obstructions of streets, alleys, sidewalks, or crosswalks and all excavations in or under the same, except as permitted by this Code of which, although made in accordance with such ordinances, are kept or maintained for an unreasonable or illegal length of time after the purpose thereof has been accomplished. 
(12)  All open and unguarded pits, wells, excavations, or unused basements freely accessible from any public street, alley, or sidewalk. 
(13)  All abandoned refrigerators, or iceboxes from which the doors and other covers have not been removed. 
(14)  Any unauthorized or unlawful use of property abutting on a public street, alley, or sidewalk or of a public street, alley, or sidewalk which causes large crowds of people to gather obstructing traffic and free use of the streets or sidewalks. 
(15)  Repeated or continuous violations of this Code or laws of the state relating to the storage of flammable liquids. 
(16)  All snow and ice not removed or sprinkled with, salt, sand or other suitable substance as provided in this subsection, and snow and ice moved from private property into or across the public right-of-way. 
(17)  Graffiti is prohibited. Graffiti shall be removed by the property owner or by the city at the property owner's expense. The term "graffiti," as used in this subsection, means any unauthorized drawing, figure, inscription, or painting appearing on sidewalks, streets, walls or other places in public view. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.13(4)) 
State Law reference Dilapidated building as public nuisance, Wis. Stats. § 823.21; vegetation obstructing view of outdoor advertising signs, Wis. Stats. § 84.305; regulation of outdoor advertising, Wis. Stats. § 84.30; restrictions on placement of highway signs, Wis. Stats. § 86.19; regulation of trees on and adjacent to highways, Wis. Stats. § 86.03; utility lines on highways, Wis. Stats. § 86.16; display of unauthorized traffic signs and signals prohibited, Wis. Stats. § 346.41; regulation of fireworks, Wis. Stats. § 167.10; abandonment of refrigerators and iceboxes, Wis. Stats. § 167.25; sidewalk obstructions prohibited, Wis. Stats. § 66.0907(1); graffiti, Wis. Stats. § 943.017.  
Sec. 74-23. - Offending public welfare generally. 
The following acts, omissions, places, conditions, and things are hereby specifically declared to be public nuisances offending the public welfare, but such enumeration shall not be construed to exclude other nuisances offending the public welfare coming within the definition of section 74-19. 
(1)  Except where otherwise expressly authorized by law, storage of junk or discarded property including automobiles, automobile parts, trucks, tractors, refrigerators, furnaces, washing machines, stoves, machinery or machinery parts, wood, bricks, cement blocks, or other unsightly debris which tend to depreciate property values in the immediate vicinity. 
(2)  As used in this section, the term "junked or discarded automobiles" includes any unlicensed or inoperable vehicle or any vehicle that may not otherwise be lawfully operated upon any public highway. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.13(5)) 
State Law reference Abandonment of vehicles prohibited, municipal authority for regulation of abandoned vehicles and recovery of costs thereof, Wis. Stats. § 342.40.  
Sec. 74-24. - Accumulation of stagnant water in urban service area. 
All premises in the urban service area shall be graded and maintained so as to prevent the accumulation of stagnant water thereon, or within any structure located thereon. Stagnant water shall be determined as an accumulation of rainwater that has not dispersed within seven days of the last recorded rainfall with the exception of: 
(1)  Stormwater retention or detention facilities approved by the city engineer; 
(2)  Areas clearly intended for water storage or drainage; or 
(3)  Decorative landscape features such as ornamental ponds, wetlands or other bodies of water shown on the city's officially adopted wetlands map. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.02(11))  
Secs. 74-2574-51. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE III. - CHRONIC NUISANCE PREMISES  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 74-52. - Purpose. 
The common council finds that from time to time certain premises in the city require a disproportionate amount of city resources to be devoted to addressing various problems and incidents that occur thereon. Often this disproportionate devotion of city resources is due to property owners' own actions or the failure of property owners to accept and exercise sufficient responsibility for and over the actions of occupants, guests, agents, or employees that reside upon or frequent the premises. Such premises, as further described in section 74-53, are deemed chronic nuisance premises and are public nuisances. This article is enacted to encourage property owners to recognize their responsibility to ensure that activities occurring on their property conform to the law and do not unduly burden the city's resources and to provide a mechanism for the city to take action against property owners who fail to ensure premises they own do not require a disproportionate devotion of resources to such premises. This article is not intended to discourage crime victims or any person in legitimate need of police services from requesting them. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(1))  
Sec. 74-53. - Determination. 
(a)  Any premises to which a department responds to complaints of any nuisance activity, three or more separate times within any 30-day period is deemed to have received and required more than the general, acceptable level of city services, and places an undue burden upon the taxpayers of the city. For purposes of this section, the term "nuisance activity" means any offenses under any offense defined in this Code as a nuisance or their statutory or their statutory counterparts, or any offense under state law for which a penalty of forfeiture, fine, or imprisonment is provided. An offense shall not be considered a nuisance activity if it is committed by a person having no association with the premises by acquaintance with, relation to or expressed or implied invitation from the owner, occupant, operator, or agent of the premises. 
(b)  Whenever any such premises exists, the appropriate department head shall determine from the facts of each incident and considering the purpose of this subsection as set forth in section 74-52, whether the premises is a chronic nuisance premises. A chronic nuisance premises is a public nuisance. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(2))  
Sec. 74-54. - Notice. 
Whenever the department head finds a premises constitutes a chronic nuisance premises under section 74-53, the department head shall provide written notice of his/her determination to the owner of the premises as identified by the records of the city assessor. Such notice shall be delivered by registered mail, return receipt requested or by personal service. If the owner cannot be located, the notice shall be published as a Class 2 notice under Wis. Stats. ch. 985. The notice shall contain the following additional information: 
(1)  The street address and unit number, if applicable, otherwise the parcel number or legal description sufficient to identify the premises. 
(2)  A brief statement, including a description of the relevant activities, supporting the determination that the premises is a chronic nuisance premises. 
(3)  A statement that the owner shall, within ten days of receipt of the notice, or last day of publication if published, respond to the appropriate department head requesting a hearing before the common council or proposing in writing a course of action that will be taken to abate the nuisance activities. 
(4)  A statement that the owner shall immediately notify the appropriate department head of any change in address to ensure receipt of future notices. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(3))  
Sec. 74-55. - Owner abatement. 
If the owner responds to the notice in section 74-54 within ten days of receipt of the notice or last day of publication if published with a nuisance abatement proposal, the department head may accept, reject, or work with the owner to modify the proposal in his/her discretion. If the department head rejects the abatement proposal, determines that an agreement on an appropriate abatement proposal cannot be reached or determines that the owner abatement is for any reason unsuccessful, the matter shall be referred to the common council for hearing. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(4))  
Sec. 74-56. - Hearing. 
If a hearing is requested by the owner or if the department head determines that a satisfactory abatement plan cannot be agreed upon or if the department head determines that abatement actions taken by the owner are unsuccessful, a hearing shall be held before the common council. The owner shall receive ten days' written notice of the hearing sent by first class mail or, if the owner cannot be located, by publication of a Class 2 notice under Wis. Stats. ch. 985. The common council shall hear any and all evidence it deems relevant and shall affirm or reverse the determination of the department head. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(5))  
Sec. 74-57. - Penalties and remedies. 
If the department head's determination is affirmed, the common council may order the owner to pay the actual cost of city services to respond to any nuisance activities occurring after the three responses that led to the determination that the premises was a chronic nuisance premises. Such costs shall be presented to the common council and may include costs incurred prior to the common council's determination. The common council may order costs of all such calls to the chronic nuisance premises be paid until the public nuisance is abated under section 74-58. Such costs, plus a reasonable administrative charge, shall be billed to the owner by invoice sent by regular mail and if not paid within 30 days of the date on the invoice shall be charged to the property as a special charge pursuant to Wis. Stats. §66.0627. The common council may authorize any other penalty or remedy authorized by law. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(6))  
Sec. 74-58. - When nuisance deemed abated. 
The public nuisance created by a chronic nuisance premises shall be deemed abated when no city resources have responded to the premises to address nuisance activities occurs for a period of six consecutive months. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(7))  
Secs. 74-5974-89. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - JUNK AND DEBRIS 
 
Sec. 74-90. - Open storage prohibited. 
No person shall store junk or discarded property, including automobiles, automobile parts, trucks, tractors, refrigerators, furnaces, washing machines, stoves, machinery, machinery parts, wood, bricks, cement blocks or unsightly debris, except in an enclosure which houses such property from public view or upon permit issued by the city council. The items listed in this section shall be deemed a hazard to life and property and shall be removed to a licensed landfill site. Each day during which the provisions of this section are violated shall constitute a separate offense. The owner of the property will be held responsible for any forfeitures or expenses incurred. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.11(1))  
Sec. 74-91. - Storage of inoperable vehicles in public view prohibited. 
(a)  No person that owns, controls or occupies any real estate within the city shall permit disassembled, inoperable, unlicensed or junked vehicles to be stored or allowed to remain open to view upon public or private property within the city for a period in excess of five days, except in connection with an automobile sales or repair business operated within a properly zoned area. Each day during which the provisions of this section are violated shall constitute a separate offense. For purposes of this section, racing cars and equipment shall be deemed unlicensed vehicles. 
(b)  Inoperable vehicles stored in violation of this section shall be deemed a hazard to life and property and shall be removed to a properly zoned auto salvage area. The owner of the property on which the vehicle is stored shall be responsible for the cost of removal of the vehicle. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 3.11(2))  
Sec. 74-92. - Additional limitations on outdoor storage in residential areas. 
On lots with a residential zoning classification outdoor storage shall be further limited as follows: 
(1)  Inoperative, and/or unlicensed vehicles are allowed only in fully enclosed buildings. 
(2)  Recreational vehicles and equipment customarily used off the parcel that are stored on the premises on a regular basis. 
If the size of the item is in excess of 16 feet in length, five feet in height and six feet in width, the object must be in rear yard or side yard and must be two feet or more from side and rear lot lines. 
If the item is under the size limits above, one such item may be located anywhere on the property. 
On lots occupied by single or two family structures, there can be not more than one such object stored per unit without having to be covered or screened. Additional items that are to be stored must be screened so that the appearance of the item from other properties will be softened. The adequacy of screening shall be a determination of the Building Inspector and the extent and character of general landscaping and the size of the lot shall be taken into consideration. 
(3)  Heavy trucks. Heavy equipment of vocational nature. Trucks larger than one ton or similar equipment having a gross capacity in excess of four tons may not be regularly parked on a residential parcel, other than in a garage. 
(Ord. No. 2016-O-21, § 1, 6-12-2016)  
Secs. 74-9374-110. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE IV. - NOISE REGULATION  
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 
 
Sec. 74-111. - Noises disturbing the public prohibited. 
(a)  Making noise tending to unreasonably disturb person in the vicinity prohibited. No person shall make or assist in making any noise tending to unreasonably disturb the comfort, quiet or repose of persons in the vicinity thereof. This provision shall not apply if the making and continuing of the noise cannot be prevented and is necessary for the protection or preservation of property or of the health, safety, life or limb of some person. 
(b)  Loud operation of mechanical or electrical devices prohibited. No person occupying or having charge of any building or premises, or any part thereof, shall cause or allow any loud, excessive or unusual noise in the operation or use of any radio, phonograph, tape recorder, loudspeaker or other mechanical or electrical device, instrument or machine, which noise shall unreasonably disturb the comfort, quiet or repose of persons therein or in the vicinity. 
(c)  Noise between certain hours prohibited. Except when necessary to protect the public health, safety or welfare, no person shall cause or allow any noise between the hours of 12:00 midnight and 7:00 a.m. or between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 12:00 midnight on any day as a result of excavating, grading, building, constructing, or otherwise erecting any building. 
(d)  Order by officer. Any person violating this section shall upon the request of a law enforcement officer immediately cease any activities causing a violation of this section. Failure to cease such activities immediately upon the request of a law enforcement officer shall constitute an additional and separate violation. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(5))  
Secs. 74-11274-120. - Reserved.  
DIVISION 2. - OUTDOOR USE OF SOUND AMPLIFYING DEVICES 
 
Sec. 74-121. - Findings of fact. 
The common council finds that excess noise and excessive vibration can degrade the environment of the city to a degree which is harmful and detrimental to the public health, safety and welfare of its inhabitants and interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life, property and recreation therein and causes nuisances. The council further finds that no one has any right to interfere with comfortable enjoyment of life, property and recreation within the city by creating excess noise or excess vibration by the use of sound amplification devices which may unreasonably interfere with normal pursuits of life and recreation or the health and welfare of the city's inhabitants. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(8)(a))  
Sec. 74-122. - Permit required. 
(a)  No person within the city shall operate or permit operation, outside of a reasonably soundproof enclosure, any loudspeaker, public address system, or similar sound amplifying device without first obtaining a permit from the public safety and human services committee as provided in this section. 
(b)  The following uses are exempted from the permit required under subsection (a): 
(1)  Cases of clear emergency. 
(2)  Businesses which are on a fixed site and have drive-through services, auction services, and other similar businesses that use loudspeakers to service customers. 
(3)  A private event on a private property, provided that the use of sound amplifying device is not in violation of Sec. 74-111 and commences on or after 11:00 a.m. and ceases on or before 11:00 p.m. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(8)(b); Ord. No. 2016-O-26, § 1, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 74-123. - Application. 
An application for an outdoor sound amplification permit shall be filed with the city clerk on forms provided by the clerk as approved by the public safety and human services committee and shall include at least the following information: 
(1)  The name and address of the applicant. 
(2)  The dates and times for which the applicant is applying and the type of equipment to be used. 
(3)  The premises or area of the city where the sound amplifying equipment will be used and the anticipated affected area. 
(4)  A sworn statement of the applicant that all information provided in the application is true and correct. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(8)(c); Ord. No. 2016-O-26, § 1, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 74-124. - Time of filing. 
Each application for an outdoor sound amplification permit shall be filed with the city clerk at least 30 days prior to the date on which the permit is proposed to be used and at least 15 days prior to granting of the permit. If an application is not filed in a timely manner, but time allows for the clerk to perform the necessary public notice requirements, the clerk will use his/her discretion in accepting the permit for processing. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(8)(d); Ord. No. 2016-O-26, § 1, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 74-125. - Public notice. 
The city clerk shall publish each application for a permit on the City website prior to its issuance. The publication shall include the name and address of the applicant, a description, by street address and area, of the location of the premises where the sound amplification equipment is to be used, and the proposed date and time of such use. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(8)(e); Ord. No. 2016-O-26, § 1, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 74-126. - Fee. 
The nonrefundable fee for an outdoor sound amplification permit shall be as set forth in the city fee schedule and shall be paid at the time of filing the application for the permit. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(8)(f); Ord. No. 2016-O-26, § 1, 11-22-2016)  
Secs. 74-127, 74-128. - Reserved. 
Editor's note Ord. No. 2016-O-26, § 1, adopted November 22, 2016, amended the Code by repealing former §§ 74-127 and 74-128. Former § 74-127 pertained to public hearing notice, and derived from the Comp. Ords. of 2009, § 14.01(8)(g). Former § 74-128 pertained to investigation, and derived from the Comp. Ords. of 2009, § 14.01(8)(h).  
Sec. 74-129. - Granting of permit. 
(a)  No permit may be granted until and unless the public safety and human services committee by a majority vote has authorized granting of the same. 
(b)  If the committee decides not to issue a permit it shall notify the applicant of its decision in writing and state the reasons therefore. 
(c)  Permits shall be numbered in the order in which they are granted and shall contain the date of issuance, the amount of fee paid and the name of the permittee. No permit shall be valid at times or dates other than as stated on the face thereof, nor for longer than six months. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(8)(i); Ord. No. 2016-O-26, § 1, 11-22-2016)  
Sec. 74-130. - Appeals. 
Any applicant aggrieved by the committee's denial of a permit may appeal the denial to the common council by filing a written appeal setting forth the reasons why the denial of the permit is unreasonable, arbitrary or contrary to law within ten days after the committee's action to deny the permit. The city clerk shall refer the appeal to the next regular council meeting to be held no sooner than four days after the appeal is filed. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(8)(j))  
Sec. 74-131. - Abatement orders. 
In lieu of or in addition to issuing a citation or complaint, any law enforcement officer may issue an order requiring the immediate abatement of any source of sound in violation of this article. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.01(8)(l))  
Secs. 74-13274-142. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE V. - ABATEMENT 
 
Sec. 74-143. - Inspection of premises. 
Whenever a complaint is made to any city official or employee that a public nuisance exists within the city, said complaint shall be directed to the appropriate department head who shall in his/her reasonable discretion inspect or cause to be inspected the premises complained of and shall make a written report of his/her findings to the city administrator. Whenever practicable, the inspecting officer shall cause photographs to be made of the premises. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(8))  
Sec. 74-144. - Summary abatement; notice to owner. 
If the inspecting officer shall determine that a public nuisance exists within the city, the department head may serve notice personally or by certified mail on the persons causing, permitting, or maintaining such nuisance or and upon the owner or occupant of the premises where such nuisance is caused, permitted, or maintained and to post a copy of said notice on the premises. Such notice shall direct the person causing, permitting, or maintaining such nuisance or the owner or occupant of the premises to abate or remove such nuisance within a specified, reasonable period of time after consideration or all relevant circumstances and shall state that unless the same is done will cause the nuisance to be abated and will charge the cost thereof to the owner, occupant, or person causing, permitting, or maintaining the nuisance, as the case may be and that said costs may be collected as a special charge pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0627. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(9)(a))  
Sec. 74-145. - By city. 
If the nuisance is not abated within the time provided or if the owner, occupant, or person causing the nuisance cannot be found, the department head shall cause the abatement or removal of such public nuisance. Wherever possible, costs or abatement shall be billed to the owner, occupant, or person causing the nuisance. If said costs are not paid within 30 days of billing such costs, or if the owner, occupant or person causing the nuisance cannot be found, said costs may be collected pursuant to Wis. Stats. § 66.0627. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(9)(b))  
Sec. 74-146. - Other methods not excluded. 
Nothing in this article shall be construed as prohibiting the abatement of public nuisances by the city or its officials in accordance with the laws of the state including, but not limited to, an action under Wis. Stats. ch. 823. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(9)(c))  
Sec. 74-147. - Cost. 
In addition to any other penalty imposed by this chapter for the erection, contrivance, continuance, or maintenance of a public nuisance, the cost of abating a public nuisance by the city shall be collected as a debt from the owner, occupant, or person causing, permitting, or maintaining the nuisance, and if notice to abate the nuisance has been given to the owner, such cost shall be assessed against the real estate as a special charge. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(10))  
Secs. 74-14874-177. - Reserved.  
ARTICLE VI. - PENALTIES 
 
Sec. 74-178. - What constitutes a separate offense. 
Each violation and each day a violation continues or occurs shall constitute a separate offense. Nothing in this Code shall preclude the city from maintaining any appropriate action to prevent or remove a violation of any provision contained in this Code. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(11)(d))  
Sec. 74-179. - Execution against defendant's property. 
Whenever any person fails to pay any forfeiture and costs of prosecution upon the order of the court for violation of any ordinance of the city, the court may, in lieu of ordering imprisonment of the defendant, or after the defendant has been released from custody, issue an execution against the property of the defendant for said forfeiture and costs. 
(Comp. Ords. 2009, § 14.14(11)(e))
